Literature review
The role of fetal movement counting 
and ‘kick charts’ to reduce stillbirths 
in pregnancies ≥28 weeks’ gestation
D
espite advances in maternity care 
internationally, stillbirths remain a 
significant global issue (Frøen et al, 
2011) with approximately 2.6 million 
cases reported in 2015 (Lawn et al, 
2016).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
In Ireland, stillbirth is defined as a baby born 
without signs of life beyond 23+6 weeks’ gestation or 
with a birthweight ≥500g (Health Service Executive 
Shauna Callaghan 
Registered midwife, University College Dublin
shauna.callaghan@ucdconnect.ie
(HSE), 2011; Manning et al, 2015).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This accounted 
for approximately 1/250 births in 2015, representing a 
stillbirth rate of 4.0/1000 births (HSE, 2017).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Reports 
demonstrate that stillbirths frequently occur in low-risk 
pregnancies (Warland et al, 2015), and an estimated 30% 
occur after 37 weeks’ gestation (Gilchrist, 2015), while 
approximately 50% of all stillbirths are unexplained 
(Draper et al, 2015).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
The significance of this issue must 
therefore be addressed.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Stillbirth prevention has emerged 
as a leading research priority internationally (Goldenberg 
et al, 2011; Frøen et al, 2016).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Research demonstrates that stillbirths are frequently 
preceded by changes in fetal movement patterns, 
generally presenting as periods of reduced or absent 
movement (Flenady et al, 2011; Warland et al, 2015).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
However, recent studies suggest that periods of excessive 
fetal movement are also a risk factor for late stillbirth 
(Stacey et al, 2011; Linde et al, 2015; Warland et al, 2015; 
Heazell et al, 2018).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Fetal activity in utero is a commonly 
referenced indicator of fetal wellbeing (Heazell and Frøen, 
2008; Saastad et al, 2011a), and is generally first perceived 
between 18-20 weeks’ gestation (Rådestad, 2010).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Practice guidelines define fetal movement as any distinct 
roll, kick or flutter (Royal College of Obstetricians 
and Gynaecologists (RCOG), 2011), which develop 
into patterns of stronger gross movements as gestation 
advances (Tveit et al, 2009).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
These movements may occur 
between 4-100 times per hour (Mangesi et al, 2015), 
with natural periods of absent movements during fetal 
‘sleep-cycles’ of up to 40 minutes (Gilchrist, 2015).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
These 
patterns provide an indirect indication of the integrity of 
fetal musculoskeletal and central nervous systems (Berbey 
et al, 2001).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
A perceived decrease in these movements 
can occur as a result of maternal factors, including 
smoking, obesity, sedatives, position, activity and anxiety; 
or fetal factors, including sleep-cycles, oligohydramnios, 
polyhydramnios, or an anterior placenta (Unterscheider 
et al, 2010; Mangesi et al, 2015).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
However, research 
also demonstrates that decreased movements may be 
indicative of fetal compromise associated with adverse 
outcomes including fetal growth restriction, hypoxia, 
preterm birth and stillbirth (Gilchrist, 2015).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Maternally 
Abstract
Background Stillbirths represent a significant global issue, with 
2.6 million cases reported in 2015.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Stillbirths are often unexplained 
and preceded by changes in fetal movement patterns.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Fetal 
movement counting methods may be used to monitor maternally 
perceived fetal movement to identify pregnancies at increased risk.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Aims This article reports on an in-depth, evidence-based practice 
review conducted to investigate the relationship between fetal 
movement counting and stillbirth rates.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Methods A comprehensive search of online databases was 
undertaken to identify relevant literature using keywords.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
The results 
were then appraised.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Findings Although a lack of conclusive evidence exists to support 
or refute the routine implementation of fetal movement counting to 
reduce stillbirth, indirect evidence suggests that increased maternal 
and professional awareness of fetal movement may assist in reducing 
stillbirth rates.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Conclusions Further research is required to develop an appropriate 
definition of reduced fetal movement, and to determine the potential 
implications of fetal movement counting as a diagnostic screening 
tool to reduce stillbirths.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

perceived reduced fetal movements (RFM) reportedly 
occurs in 5-15% of all pregnancies—frequently leading 
to unscheduled hospital consultations (Kamalifard et al, 
2013)—and precedes approximately 50% of stillbirths 
(Efkarpidis et al, 2004; Linde et al, 2015).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
There is no accepted definition for RFM (Gilchrist, 
2015).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Difficulties arise throughout the literature and 
clinical practice regarding consensus for an appropriate 
definition of RFM and a lack of evidence-based advice 
for pregnant women concerning recognition of abnormal 
movement (Heazell and Frøen, 2008).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Fetal movement counting and ‘kick charts’
Fetal movement counting (FMC) using ‘kick-charts’ to 
systematically quantify and monitor maternal perceptions 
of fetal activity over a defined period of time (Saastad 
et al, 2012) evolved between 1960-1970 (Frøen, 2004) 
and since then, its role in identifying pregnancies at 
increased risk of stillbirth has been explored repeatedly 
(Mangesi et al, 2015; Winje et al, 2016).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
FMC is one of 
the oldest and most commonly used methods to monitor 
fetal wellbeing (Bhutta et al, 2011) as it is simple, cost-
effective, non-invasive and easily accessible (Kamalifard et 
al, 2013).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
A variety of formal FMC methods and ‘alarm 
limits’ for RFM have been published (Rayburn, 1995; 
Frøen et al, 2008), ranging from complete cessation of 
fetal movements for 1 day (Harper et al, 1981; Leader 
et al, 1981), to fewer than 10 movements in 12 hours, 
known as the ‘Cardiff method’ (Pearson and Weaver, 
1976).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Alternative measures also include fewer than 10 
movements in 2 hours (Moore and Piacquadio, 1989), 
or fewer than two to three per hour during defined 
daily periods (Sadovsky and Polishuk, 1977; Neldham, 
1980).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
The proposed rationale for ‘kick-charts’ is to 
identify fetal compromise through maternal detection 
of RFM (Winje et al, 2015).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Timely reporting to health 
professionals should initiate further diagnostic screening, 
including cardiotocography (CTG) monitoring and 
ultrasonography (Velazquez and Rayburn, 2002; Haws 
et al, 2009) to prevent perinatal morbidity and mortality 
(Saastad et al, 2011b).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
However, this method has been criticised for 
failing to acknowledge the importance of individual 
temporal patterns (Winje et al, 2012), as well as the 
issue of inconsistent and conflicting definitions of RFM 
(Pakenham et al, 2013).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
There is also concern that the 
implementation of FMC may cause maternal anxiety, 
leading to increased hospital consultations and obstetric 
interventions (Saastad et al, 2010; Delaram and Shams, 
2016) As a result, in Ireland, and internationally, there 
is inconsistency in the use and perceived importance of 
FMC methods as an intervention to reduce fetal loss 
(Smith et al, 2014)—a problem that should therefore 
be addressed.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Due to the perceived association between fetal 
movements and stillbirth, this article proposes to conduct 
an in-depth literature review from the following question: 
‘What role has fetal movement counting interventions 
and “kick charts” to play in developing maternal 
awareness of fetal movement patterns to reduce stillbirths 
in pregnancies ≥28 weeks’ gestation?’.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This question was 
constructed using a population, intervention, outcome, 
comparison (PICO) framework to include pregnant 
women experiencing singleton pregnancies ≥28 weeks’ 
gestation as the intended population (P) and FMC as 
the specific intervention (I).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
The primary outcome (O) 
was stillbirth rates and control/comparison (C) related 
to standard care or no FMC.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This is an intervention/
effectiveness question.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Therefore, the most applicable 
evidence required includes systematic reviews, 
randomised controlled trials (RCTs) and cohort studies.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Method
A comprehensive search of online databases, including 
CINAHL, Medline, PubMed and Embase, was 
undertaken to identify relevant published literature.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Supplementary searches using Google Scholar identified 
relevant grey literature.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Keywords included ‘fetal/
foetal movement counting/monitoring’, ‘kick-charts’, 
‘stillbirths’ and ‘perinatal mortality/deaths’, used 
singularly and combined using ‘and/or’ as Boolean 
operators.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Filters applied included English language, 
peer reviewed, scholarly/academic journals, RCTs and 
systematic reviews.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Publication dates were not restricted 
due to insufficient evidence.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
One PubMed database 
search for systematic reviews using keywords ‘fetal 
movement’ yielded 17 results, from which a relevant 
systematic review was obtained.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Further material that 
met the inclusion criteria of pregnancies ≥28 weeks using 
FMC and stillbirth outcomes was sourced by searching 
the reference list in this review.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Literature review 
Introduction of evidence
From the systematic review conducted by Winje et al 
(2016) on FMC interventions to enhance maternal 
awareness of RFM, two RCTs (Neldam, 1980; Grant et 
al, 1989), one controlled non-randomised study (Lobb 
et al, 1985) and three cohort-analytic studies (Westgate 
and Jamieson, 1986; Moore and Piacquadio, 1989; Tveit 
et al, 2009) were also selected for appraisal in this review 
due to their correspondence with the proposed topic and 
the applicability of their research design in answering 
this intervention question based on published evidence 
hierarchies (Polit and Beck, 2014) (Figure 1).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
All included studies aimed to examine the perceived 
association between fetal movement and perinatal deaths, 
either through specific focus on formal FMC (Neldam,

introduction of uniform information and guidelines

source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
All studies 
included pregnant women in the third trimester as sample 
populations; however, methods of FMC and ‘alarm limits’ 
varied, as did comparisons between universal FMC and 
selective FMC, no FMC or standard care.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
A deductive 
paradigm and positivism approach was common across 
all studies which qualified them as suitable for inclusion 
is this review (Table 1).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Research designs
Winje et al (2016) involved 23 publications, including 
three RCTs (a total of 72 888 pregnant women) 
and five non-randomised studies (a total of 115 435 
pregnant women), which focused on the effect of FMC 
interventions on perinatal death (Table 2).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Both RCTs 
and non-RCTs were included as the potential for 
contamination in RCTs associated with public health 
interventions such as FMC may influence the validity of 
reported results.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Among these studies, Grant et al (1989) published 
a large multicentre 1:1 paired cluster allocation RCT 
across five countries, involving 68 654 women between 
28-32 weeks’ gestation.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This study aimed to assess the 
effect of FMC on late antepartum fetal death in singleton 
pregnancies against a control group in which FMC was 
not routinely discussed.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This strategy was also used in 
an older RCT (Neldam, 1980), involving 2250 women 
randomly allocated to commence FMC from 28 weeks’ 
gestation or receive standard antenatal care.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Lobb et al 
(1985) conducted a non-randomised study during which 
women attending Unit A (n=6597) were instructed 
regarding FMC while Unit B (n=13 705) were provided 
standard care that did not routinely use ‘kick-charts’, 
except for in selected high-risk cases and only with 
other measures of fetal wellbeing such as ultrasound and 
cardiotocography.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Both Westgate and Jamieson (1986) 
and Moore and Piacquadio (1989) used a cohort-
analytic design involving pre-intervention control and 
intervention study periods, during which the stillbirth 
rate for each period was assessed and compared.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This 
design was also applied in Tveit et al (2009); however, 
the intervention consisted of routine information on 
fetal movement and guidelines for RFM management, 
and the subsequent impact on stillbirth rates.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This study 
involved 14 hospitals across Norway, including 19 407 
baseline and 46 143 intervention cohort participants.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
FMC method and RFM ‘alarm limits’ varied 
between studies, which presented difficulties comparing 
methods and outcomes.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
In the study by Neldam (1980), 
participants were instructed to count fetal movement 
three times daily from 32 weeks’ gestation, with RFM 
described as fewer than three movements per hour.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Both 
Lobb et al (1985) and Westgate and Jamieson (1986) 
used the Cardiff ‘count-to-10’ method, as demonstrated 
in previous studies (Pearson and Weaver, 1976), whereby 
RFM was defined as the absence of fetal movement 
for 12 hours, or fewer than 10 fetal movements in 12 
hours over 2 consecutive days.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This method was also 
incorporated in Grant et al (1989), although modified 
to give sufficiently high specificity by defining RFM 
as no fetal movements in 1 day or fewer than 10 in 
10 hours on 2 successive days.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
However, one cohort 
defined RFM as fewer than 10 movements perceived 
in 1 day.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Significantly, Moore and Piacquadio (1989) 
undertook a pilot study (n=100) to identify and validate 
the parameters for maternally perceived fetal movements 
over 30 consecutive days, concluding the mean time to 
perceive ten fetal movements was 20.9 ± 18.1 (mean 
± standard deviation (SD)) and 99.5% reported ten 
fetal movements within 90 minutes.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This led to further 
modification of the ‘count-to-10’ method whereby RFM 
was defined as fewer than 10 movements in 2-hour 
periods, which was also incorporated in Tveit et al (2009).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

Results 
Perinatal mortality and stillbirth rates associated 
with FMC introduction
The key outcome measured in each study, and the 
primary focus of this review, was perinatal mortality 
and stillbirth rates associated with FMC introduction.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Significant variation in FMC method, RFM definition 
and obstetric risk status of participants led to significant 
heterogeneity between studies and, subsequently, pooling 
the results in Winje et al’s (2016) systematic review was 
not feasible.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Evidence both supporting and rejecting 
routine implementation of FMC was demonstrated.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
A 
reduction in stillbirths of between 24-75% was reported; 
however, the supportive evidence of improved outcomes 
is indirect from non-randomised studies, with no strong 
evidence of benefit or harm apparent (Winje et al, 2016).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
In Neldam’s (1980) RCT, eight stillbirths were 
recorded in the control group not instructed on fetal 
movements, while no stillbirths were recorded in the 
intervention group randomised to initiate FMC (95% CI; 
P<0.01).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

75% were deemed to be of high obstetric risk—from 
6.3/1000 births to 4.3/1000 births during the study 
period (P<0.01).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Westgate and Jamieson (1986) also 
reported a reduction in population stillbirth rates from 
10.83 to 8.21/1000 births (P<0.05) following the 
introduction of FMC.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Before the intervention period, 
there were 88 stillbirths (n=8127), of which 55% 
were deemed unexplained.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
During the intervention 
(n=8163) 67 stillbirths were reported, 40% of which 
were unexplained, resulting in a reported relative risk 
of stillbirth of 0.76 (95% CI; 0.55–1.04).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

However, the large multicentre RCT conducted 
by Grant et al (1989) failed to demonstrate the same 
supportive findings regarding the effect of FMC on

while 100 stillbirths occurred in the control group

text:
Approximately 10% of stillbirths (n=11) in the

was reported at 60%, with 50% of women responding

study by Lobb et al (1985) demonstrated a statistically

P=0.47).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

triggers and inappropriate management resulted in fetal

However, as in Grant et al (1989), an overall

text:
Appraisal of evidence
The evidence represented in this review was appraised 
for inclusion; however, as demonstrated in Winje et al 
(2016), a formal meta-analysis of the data was not feasible, 
due to significant variations in methodology, design and 
RFM definitions.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Winje et al (2016), as a systematic 
review, was the highest level of evidence obtained and 
was deemed suitable, as a clear search strategy, specific 
inclusion and exclusion criteria, and quality assessment 
measures conducted independently by two authors were 
included.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Data were clearly provided for risk of selection, 
performance, attrition, detection and reporting bias in 
RCTs, and for bias, confounding and directness in non-
randomised studies using evidence-based checklists (Wells 
et al, 2013).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text: Low effect magnitude/size was reported.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Inconsistency of results may be related to variations in 
study type, FMC method and gestation.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Precision was 
deemed insufficient in some studies, and significance 
levels for stillbirth outcomes ranged from P<0.01–0.63.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This review was limited by the lack of high-quality 
studies and the proportion of studies conducted over 
20 years previously that included insufficient data to 
accurately evaluate methodological standards.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Both Neldam (1980) and Grant et al (1989) 
demonstrated reliability and external validity through 
randomisation, large sample sizes and detailed methods 
undertaken during their respective RCTs, as well as 
low risk of detection bias as outcome assessments were 
blinded.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
However, reliability is uncertain, as both studies 
included modified measurement tools for FMC, and 
clinical errors reported in the management of RFM 
once identified by FMC may have affected the results.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
The effect sizes between intervention groups were low 
and internal validity may be affected by contamination 
through discussion of FMC in both groups and selected 
FMC in 8.9% of control groups of unknown risk status 
(Grant et al, 1989), as well as lack of blinding of controlled 
participants aware of FMC indicating performance bias.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
The use of in-hospital paired clusters in Grant et al (1989) 
may have increased awareness and vigilance towards 
fetal movement in the overall population, resulting in 
contamination of the study and consistency in findings 
is possibly affected by different alarm limits used for one 
cohort.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Although RCTs are considered high-standard 
evidence in relation to intervention-based questions, 
the inability to blind participants and professionals to 
FMC, as well as the high risk of contamination through 
increased awareness throughout the population, suggests 
that RCTs may not be appropriate to accurately detect 
the effect of FMC on stillbirth rates.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Consideration 
should also be given to potential ethical issues associated 
with conducting RCTs on fetal movements, as the 
nature of the intervention and link to fetal wellbeing 
raises questions about the suitability of RCTs in this area.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
The strength of the remaining evidence included is 
impacted by the non-randomised designs.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Three studies 
were historically controlled as participating sample 
groups were organised by time difference before and after 
the interventions (Westgate and Jamieson, 1986; Moore 
and Piacquadio, 1989; Tveit et al, 2009), while Lobb et 
al (1985) generated their sample population through 
separate locations.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Risk of selection bias was present in 
this study, as exclusion criteria differed between groups.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Directness of the evidence was demonstrated in Lobb 
et al (1985), Moore and Piacquadio, (1989), and Tveit 
et al (2009), based on the relevance of their population,

However, 
Westgate and Jamieson (1986) exhibited methodological 
weaknesses with high risk of bias and uncertainty 
regarding the timing of retrospective outcome assessments 
which were not reported.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
χ² tests were used for statistical 
analysis in three of the studies (Lobb et al, 1985; Moore 
and Piacquadio, 1989; Tveit et al, 2009).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
There was also 
a substantial risk of confounding bias identified in Lobb 
et al (1985) and Westgate and Jamieson (1986) as limited 
evidence was provided for the suitable control of known 
or unknown confounding variables.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Both Moore and 
Piacquadio (1989) and Tveit et al (2009) demonstrated 
consideration for confounding variables and assessed 
comparability between control and intervention groups 
based on these.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Tveit et al (2009) undertook multivariate 
analysis, adjusting outcomes for potential confounders 
including maternal age, body mass index, parity, ethnicity 
and smoking.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
A correction was published in 2010 for 
this study; however, the results did not affect the focus 
of this review (Tveit et al, 2010).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Although the evidence 
presented in these studies indicated support for FMC, 
caution in the acceptance of these results must be 
exercised, due to the potential for unknown confounding 
and the methodological weaknesses of non-randomised 
studies when compared to RCTs.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Implications for practice
The evidence for FMC and its role in antepartum 
care as a screening tool for fetal compromise through 
recognition of RFM is inconsistent and inconclusive, 
as demonstrated in this review, and has led to variation 
in practice internationally (Pakenham et al, 2013).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
As a 
result, maternal monitoring of fetal movement in Ireland 
and worldwide is predominantly an unstructured self-
assessment interpreted by women individually with 
varying guidance from professionals (Saastad et al, 2011a).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
The concept of FMC is endorsed in Canada for high-
risk patients from 28 weeks’ gestation (The Society of 
Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada (SOGC), 
2007), while guidelines in the UK, USA, and Norway 
do not recommend FMC and argue that education on 
fetal moevment is significant to identify RFM (National 
Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE), 2008; 
RCOG, 2011; Saastad et al, 2011a; American Academy of 
Pediatrics (AAP) and American College of Obstetricians 
and Gynecologists (ACOG), 2012).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
However, commonly 
reported practice for RFM concerns involves 
implementation of the ‘count-to-10’ FMC method 
demonstrated in Moore and Piacquadio (1989) (RCOG, 
2011; Winje et al, 2011; AAP and ACOG, 2012).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
That 
said, these numerical recommendations fail to highlight 
the importance of unique and individual movement 
patterns and maternal experiences (Akselsson et al, 
2017).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
A study exploring 19 women’s experience of fetal 
activity in the third trimester found that descriptions of 
movement patterns varied widely and were incomparable 
between participants (Bradford and Maude, 2018).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Future 
guidelines must therefore take into account the wide 
variety in individual fetal movements to focus on the 
unique pattern of each fetus and avoid applying universal 
numerical recommendations for fetal activity.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Concerns regarding potentially laborious FMC 
methods, compliance, maternal anxiety and increased 
hospital attendance for RFM have been raised 
repeatedly throughout the literature (Christensen et 
al, 2003; Saastad et al, 2012).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
In order for FMC to be 
universally acceptable, minimal disruption to daily 
routines is needed to encourage maternal compliance 
and promote prolonged use (Pakenham et al, 2013).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This is demonstrated in the high compliance rates of 
67-90% reported in studies using the modified ‘count-
to-10’ method requiring a maximum of 2 hours (Moore 
and Piacquadio, 1989; Freda et al, 1993; Christensen 
et al, 2003; Gómez et al, 2007).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Recent literature also 
highlights the emergence of ‘mindfetalness’ as a daily 
self-assessment tool of fetal movements, where mothers 
are encouraged to focus on identifying their baby’s 
movement pattern for 15 minutes daily from 28 weeks’ 
(Akselsson et al, 2017), a concept that may warrant further 
exploration as a method to monitor and understand 
individual fetal movement patterns.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Effective FMC or 
self-assessment of fetal movements requires ongoing 
support from health professionals and should be discussed 
routinely throughout antepartum care (Velazquez and 
Rayburn, 2002).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
However, arguments persist regarding 
the potential for increased maternal anxiety, cost and 
iatrogenic complications as RFM is a common reason for 
unscheduled hospital consultations (Delaram and Shams, 
2016; Winje et al, 2016).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Moore and Piacquadio (1989) 
reported an increase of 13% in antepartum investigations 
for RFM (χ²=89, P<0.00001).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This association was 
refuted in recent literature, however, which stated that 
routine fetal movement information and FMC did not 
increase RFM consultation rates compared with standard 
care (Tveit et al, 2009; Saastad et al, 2010; Delaram and 
Shams, 2016).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

and FMC has been studied repeatedly using validated 
tools to measure anxiety, including the Spielberger State-
Trait Anxiety Inventory (Cronbach’s alpha (α)=0.86) and 
the Cambridge Worry Scale (α=0.82), which reported 
reduced maternal anxiety levels associated with FMC

(Liston et al, 1994; Saastad et al, 2012; Delaram and

source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Therefore, the association between FMC 
and increased maternal concern, as well as resource use, 
is not supported by the evidence (Saastad et al, 2012; 
Delaram and Shams, 2016).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
As seen through the stillbirths reported due to clinical 
error in both Grant et al (1989) and Lobb et al (1985), 
appropriate and timely management of reported RFM 
is essential (Haws et al, 2009; RCOG, 2011).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
However, 
as many of the studies included in this review were 
conducted more than 20 years ago, consideration should 
be given to modern advances in maternity care, as well 
as changes in society and health complexities in the 21st 
century, which may influence the ability to apply these 
results to the current climate.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
That said, clinical practice 
regarding the management of RFM varies across Ireland 
and worldwide, and, therefore, there is a need for national 
and international guidelines to ensure safe and effective 
antenatal care for women perceiving RFM has been 
identified (Unterscheider et al, 2010; Draper et al, 2015).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
As with FMC, evidence concerning the appropriate 
management and identification of RFM is inconsistent 
and inconclusive (Tveit et al, 2009; Unterscheider 
et al, 2010).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Education regarding the significance of 
fetal movement is of vital importance and should be 
prioritised (McArdle et al, 2015); however, insufficient 
evidence on RFM definitions may impact maternal 
compliance with inconsistent advice (Draper et al, 
2015).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
In addition, with the ever-increasing popularity 
of message boards and social media, pregnant women 
have easy access to information that may be of variable 
quality and lack an evidence-based foundation (Warland 
and Glover, 2017).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Similarly, the increasing popularity 
of hand-held fetal Doppler devices indicates the need 
for a safe reliable tool to assist maternal monitoring of 
fetal wellbeing, as they are openly available to purchase 
online.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
These devices are not recommended for maternal 
use as an audible fetal heart is not reliably indicative of 
fetal wellbeing and may be present despite periods of 
RFM suggestive of fetal compromise (NICE, 2008; 
Gilchrist, 2015), which therefore give false reassurance 
to mothers.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
This represents a new challenge for maternity 
care providers in monitoring the use of these devices 
and providing information regarding the potential risks 
associated with their use.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Further research is urgently 
needed to develop a suitable definition of RFM, and 
to devise consistent evidence-based clinical guidelines 
on the management of RFM to limit clinical error and 
false reassurances in order to allow the potential benefits 
of FMC discussed in this review to be explored further.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Conclusion
This review demonstrates a lack of conclusive evidence to 
support or refute the introduction of FMC into clinical 
practice as a measure to reduce stillbirth rates in singleton 
pregnancies ≥28 weeks’ gestation.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
However, indirect 
evidence appears to suggest that increased vigilance 
and awareness of fetal movements by midwives, doctors 
and women may help reduce the risk of stillbirth, as all 
studies included in this review reported a reduced overall 
mortality rate for the studied population following FMC 
interventions.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
There is strong evidence to support the 
importance of RFM as an indicator of fetal compromise; 
however, significant inconsistencies in the definition of 
RFM and appropriate management must be addressed 
in order to potentially influence stillbirth rates (Winje 
et al, 2011).
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Further research is warranted to identify an 
appropriate and applicable definition of RFM, developed 
using a sample representative of the complete obstetric 
population, in order to develop guidelines on the 
diagnosis and management of RFM to reduce perinatal 
mortality and improve antepartum care.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
In addition, 
further robust studies in obstetric settings are required 
to identify the acceptability, feasibility and potential 
implications of formal FMC as a diagnostic screening 
tool to identify fetal compromise and decrease stillbirth 
rates within Ireland and internationally.
source: Callaghan2018Theroleoffetalmovementcountingandkickchartstoreducestillbirths.pdf

text:
Key points
●
●There is a lack of conclusive evidence to support or refute the introduction of 
fetal movement counting (FMC) charts into clinical practice as a measure to 
reduce stillbirth rates in singleton pregnancies ≥28 weeks’ gestation
●
●There is, however, strong evidence to support the importance of reduced fetal 
movement (RFM) as an indicator of fetal compromise
●
●Further research is warranted to identify an appropriate and applicable 
definition of RFM
●

Nutrition before pregnancy
Good eating habits before pregnancy are important.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
The health of a woman affects her 
ability to get pregnant, as well as the health of the unborn baby.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A woman who wants to have a baby should be in good health and have a healthy body 
weight.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
The risk of pregnancy complications is higher for women who are too thin or too 
heavy.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
High levels of folate are needed during pregnancy, especially in the early stages, for a 
healthy baby.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Lack of sufﬁcient folate early in pregnancy can lead to severe birth defects 
in the baby.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
It is recommended that all women who could become pregnant eat at least 
5 servings a day of vegetables and fruits rich in folate, especially leafy green vegetables, 
bean, peas and other legumes, and liver.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Women who are not able to meet their need 
for folate through their diet during this time are advised to eat foods fortiﬁed with folic 
acid or take folic acid supplements, in addition to eating folate-rich foods.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A doctor or 
health professional should always be consulted for advice about vitamin and mineral 
supplements before or during pregnancy.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Nutrition during pregnancy
All pregnant women need to eat a good, balanced diet and gain 
additional weight to support a healthy pregnancy and childbirth.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A 
diet that provides the increased energy (calories) and nutrients  
needed during pregnancy is necessary for the health of both  
mother and baby.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
During pregnancy, the mother’s own stores of nutrients may  
be reduced, putting her at increased risk of illness.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A baby  
deprived of adequate nutrition before birth is likely to have poor 
development in childhood and health problems throughout life.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
FACT
SHEET
Pregnant women need to eat enough to supply the extra energy, protein, vitamins and 
minerals needed by the growing foetus (baby).
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
However, it is not necessary to “eat for two” 
during pregnancy.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A woman entering pregnancy with a healthy weight generally needs to 
eat about 280 extra calories a day.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: Protein is especially important to create new tissues, blood, cells and bones.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: Iron requirements are particularly high and supplements are often needed.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Iodine during pregnancy helps prevent serious birth defects, such as brain damage and 
mental retardation.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: Folate is needed to prevent severe birth defects during the ﬁrst few weeks of pregnancy.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: Other nutrients that are important are zinc, vitamins A and C.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Daily meals
A pregnant woman should have the following foods every day:
P 4 glasses of milk or milk products
P 3 portions of meat, ﬁsh, eggs, beans
P 4 portions of fruit and vegetables
P 6 portions of bread and cereals
P Lots of liquid .
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Women should avoid drinking alcohol and should have regular medical checks 
throughout their pregnancy.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Nutrition during breastfeeding
Breastfeeding requires additional nutrients and energy, as the mother needs to replace 
the nutrients and energy that are passed on to the baby through the milk.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
If the mother 
does not satisfy the needs of her baby, the baby will draw on, and reduce, the mother’s 
own stores of nutrients.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
This puts the mother at risk of illness and can affect the baby’s 
development.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
The nutrients that are important for a good supply of breastmilk are the same as those 
that are important for a healthy pregnancy.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
These include protein, zinc, calcium, vitamins 
A and C, iron and folate.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Additional servings of milk and high protein snacks between 
meals or an additional small meal every day are good ways to meet the additional needs 
of breastfeeding.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A breastfeeding woman needs a varied and nutritious diet with staple 
foods, vegetables, legumes, meat and ﬁsh, and plenty of fruits.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
She should also drink 
plenty of water, milk and other ﬂuids.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
It may take two to three years after stopping breastfeeding for all of the mother’s 
nutritional stores to be replaced, therefore good spacing between pregnancies is 
recommended for the health of the mother and her future babies.
source: nutriton.pdf

FACT
SHEET Breastfeeding babies
(0-6 months)
Colostrum (ﬁrst milk) is important for newborn babies
The newborn baby should be breastfed as soon as possible after birth (within 30 
minutes) because:
P The ﬁrst milk that comes right after birth for 2-3 days, called colostrum, helps 
protect newborns from infections and disease and is rich in Vitamin A.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
P It encourages the baby to suck, which stimulates the ﬂow and production of 
breastmilk.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: P Breastfeeding right after birth is also good for the mother.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
It helps the uterus to 
shrink and to stop bleeding after birth.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Breastmilk is ideal for babies 
P Babies should be given only breastmilk from birth to 6 months of age.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A baby’s 
stomach is too small and weak to digest solid foods in the ﬁrst 6 months.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Giving 
the baby other foods, liquids or water too early can introduce bacteria and 
increase the risk of infections and illness.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
P Babies who are breastfed exclusively for the ﬁrst six months and who continue 
partial breastfeeding for up to two years have lower rates of illness and death.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
P If the baby is fed often, or the milk is expressed for feeding, this meets the 
baby’s needs and will help make sure that the mother  
has a good supply of milk.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
P Expressed breastmilk can be stored in  
a clean container in the fridge or  
in a sufﬁciently cool place for 24 hours.
source: nutriton.pdf

Introducing ﬁrst foods
As the baby grows older, breastmilk is still very important but it is not enough on its 
own to meet the nutritional needs of older babies.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Babies and young children 6-24 
months old have very high energy and nutrient needs for their body size and are 
often at risk of being malnourished.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Breastfeeding should continue even until the age 
of 2, if possible, while the baby starts to eat other foods.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
P At about 6 months, the baby should be introduced gradually to other foods that 
supplement breastmilk.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Feeding of solid foods should start with one small meal a 
day and increase to 2 or 3 meals a day by the age of 7 months.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Different foods are 
usually introduced one at a time to give the baby a chance to get used to eating 
and digesting that food.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
P By the age of one year, if a child is breastfed, it should have 3 meals a day, and 
nutritious snacks in between meals.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
If the child is not breastfed, it should be fed 5 
meals a day.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
P By the age of one year most children can eat ﬁnely mashed family meals and 
snacks.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: Meals should be increased to 5 a day.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
If the child is not breastfed, give two 
extra small meals.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Healthy ﬁrst foods
P Starchy foods alone are not the best ﬁrst foods for babies because they do not 
provide enough protein, calories and other nutrients to meet the needs of the 
rapidly growing baby.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Foods from all food groups – meats, dairy, fruits, vegetables, 
breads, grains, cereals – should be included in the baby’s diet.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Starchy staple foods 
that are part of the local diet can be enriched to make good ﬁrst foods by adding 
small amounts of shredded, chopped or 
pounded foods from other food groups 
and a small amount of oil.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
P Babies’ ﬁrst foods require special 
preparation to make sure they are clean, 
soft and easy to eat and digest.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
They 
should be mashed and diluted to prevent 
 
Feeding young children frequently 
with appropriate foods, in addition to breastmilk, will help ensure that they get 
the energy and nutrients they need to grow normally and stay healthy.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Foods should be 
prepared without added salt, as babies cannot yet process it.

text:
P Some examples of good ﬁrst foods are:
 - Porridge or cereal with milk, fruit juice, a little oil, fat or butter, ﬁnely chopped 
nuts or sugar
 - Mashed yellow and green vegetables and yellow fruits (spinach, potatoes, 
yams, carrots, papayas, pumpkin, cooked breadfruit, maize, bananas, mangoes, 
guavas)
 - Mashed vegetables with a little soup, sauce or gravy from meat dishes
 - Soft, ﬁnely chopped or shredded meat, chicken, egg yolk, ﬁsh or liver
 - Very ﬁnely chopped or mashed  nuts, legumes or seeds (groundnuts, chickpeas, 
sunﬂower seeds) 
How to encourage small children to eat
Children eat more when their parents, family and others around them actively 
encourage them to eat.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Here are some suggestions:
P Sit with children and talk to them about how good the food is.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
P Feed young children with the rest of the family but give them their own plates and 
spoons to make sure they eat their share.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
P If the child wants to hold food, give it to him and tell him not to worry about messy 
eating.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: Make sure all of it gets into the child’s mouth.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: P Mix foods together if the child picks out only favourite foods.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: P Do not hurry children.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: They may eat a bit, play a bit, and then eat again.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: P Feed young children frequently, as soon as they are hungry.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Do not wait for them 
to start crying for food.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: P Do not feed when children are tired or sleepy.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:

text:
FACT
SHEET Nutrition of
school-age children 
What can happen if school-age children do not eat well?
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Schoolchildren who are hungry or have poor diets usually grow more slowly than 
well-nourished children.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
They often have too little energy to play, study or learn 
properly.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: They may become ill more frequently.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
They are likely to have difﬁculty 
concentrating at school and may not do as well as well-fed children.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
As a result, 
their educational achievements may be poor and they may leave school early before 
ﬁnishing.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
The combination of poor education and poor health can seriously affect 
their ability to lead full, active, productive lives.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: What is a healthy diet for school-age children?
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Both girls and boys of this age grow at approximately the same rate and need the 
same amount of food.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A healthy diet for children ﬁve years and older should provide 
every day sufﬁcient quantity and variety of foods to meet their needs for proper 
growth and development.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Parents, teachers and other caregivers should make sure 
that children have plenty of foods rich in energy, protein, vitamin A, calcium, 
iron, iodine.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A healthy diet for children this age should have:
P plenty of ﬁbre-rich starchy foods (such as rice, maize, 
cassava, bread, noodles and yams)
P plenty of different coloured vegetables (especially dark 
leafy greens and orange-coloured vegetables)
P plenty of different fruits (fresh or dried)
P beans, peas and small amounts of meat and 
ﬁsh
P some dairy products (milk, yoghurt, 
cheese) and eggs
P a little fat (added to other dishes)
P plenty of clean, fresh drinking water.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
School-age children are growing rapidly 
and have particularly high energy and nutrient needs.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A varied and balanced diet 
is important for protecting their health and for promoting their physical and mental 
development.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A good diet and good eating habits can help children improve their 
concentration and educational performance in school and can reduce some health risks 
such as vitamin A deﬁciency, anaemia and other micronutrient deﬁciencies.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A good diet in 
childhood may also help to minimize illness and chronic disease later in life.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
FACT
SHEET
Nutrition for school-age children (cont.)
How many meals should schoolchildren have?
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Children this age need to have, every day, three meals, plus nutritious snacks in 
between meals.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Breakfast is always important, but especially so if a child has to walk a long way to 
school and does not eat much at midday.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Schoolchildren should start every day with 
a nutritious meal before going to school.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
An example of a good breakfast would be a starchy food, such as bread, porridge, 
cereals, cassava, sweet potato, with milk, yoghurt, peanut butter, cooked beans, fruit 
or fresh fruit juice.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: Mid-morning snacks keep up the child’s energy for play and study.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Some examples 
of good snacks, especially when more than one food is eaten, are: fresh or dried 
fruits; cheese; nuts or seeds; eggs (easy to carry if hard boiled), bean cakes; rice 
cakes; bread with cheese, groundnut paste/peanut butter or other spreads; boiled or 
roasted maize cobs; boiled or fried cassava, plantain, yam, sweet potatoes and other 
potatoes; dried meats or small ﬁsh.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Lunch (midday meal) should contain a variety of foods and should provide sufﬁcient 
energy.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
If meals are provided by the school, they should be as nutrient-rich as 
possible.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
If school meals are not provided, children will need to take food from home 
to eat at school.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Mid-afternoon snacks are important if the midday meal is not sufﬁcient or if the child 
has to walk a long distance back home.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Dinner (evening meal) may be the biggest meal of the day for many children, so it 
should be a good, varied meal.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
It is very important to include many different foods in 
children’s meals in order to meet all of their nutritional needs.
source: nutriton.pdf

HIV/AIDS and nutrition
Poor nutrition can be a serious danger for people living with HIV/AIDS.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Even 
at the early stages of HIV infection when very few symptoms appear, HIV 
makes demands on the body’s nutritional status.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
And during the course of the 
HIV infection, the risk of malnutrition in the form of undernutrition and lack of 
micronutrients increases signiﬁcantly.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
The HIV virus attacks and damages the body’s immune system, which increases 
the risk of other infections.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
These infections can lower food intake because they 
reduce appetite and interfere with the body’s ability to digest and absorb food.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: As a result, the person becomes malnourished, loses weight and is weakened.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Eating well helps to maintain and improve the performance of the immune 
system - the body’s protection against infection – and therefore helps a person to 
stay healthy.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
One of the possible signs of the onset of clinical AIDS is a weight loss of about 6-7 
kg for an average adult.

A person who is infected with HIV/AIDS and is not showing signs of illness does 
not need a speciﬁc “HIV diet”.

text:

every effort to adopt healthy and balanced eating habits in order to meet their 
increased protein and energy needs and maintain their nutritional status.

text: Once people with HIV/AIDS become ill, they have special needs.

text:
As the body 
works harder to ﬁght against infections, energy and nutrient needs increase.
source: nutriton.pdf

text: Further infection and fever also increase the body’s demand for food.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
Once 
people are infected with HIV they have to eat more to meet their extra energy 
and nutrient needs.
source: nutriton.pdf

text:
A healthy and balanced diet should be one of the goals of counselling and care 
for people at all stages of HIV infection.

4
Having a baby is one of the most exciting things that 
can happen to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But you might be feeling nervous  
as well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it’s your ﬁrst baby, it’s hard to know what  
to expect.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your mum, colleagues, friends and relations might all  
be giving you advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
And then there is all the information  
on the internet as well as in magazines and books.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At times 
it can feel overwhelming and it’s hard to know who is  
right when people say different things.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This book brings together everything you need to know 
to have a healthy and happy pregnancy, and to make sure 
you get the care that is right for you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The guidance about 
pregnancy and babies does change.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
So it’s important to get  
up-to-date, trusted advice  
so that you can make  
the right decisions  
and choices.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have any  
questions or concerns  
– no matter how trivial  
they may seem – talk to 
your midwife or doctor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They are there to  
support you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

BEFORE YOU  
GET PREGNANT
• Think about the lifestyle factors 
that might affect your ability to 
get pregnant and have a healthy 
pregnancy (see Chapter 3).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
applies to men too.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are more 
likely to get pregnant if you are 
both in good health.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
– If you smoke, get advice 
about stopping.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can  
talk to your doctor, visit  
www.nhs.uk/smokefree or  
call the free NHS smoking 
helpline on 0800 022 4 332.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: – Eat a balanced diet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: – Maintain a healthy weight.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
– You should avoid drinking 
alcohol if you are pregnant or 
trying to conceive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you do 
choose to drink, then protect 
your baby by drinking no more 
than one to two units of alcohol 
once or twice a week and don’t 
get drunk (see page 32).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you or your partner take 
any medication, talk to your 
doctor about whether it will  
affect your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Take 400 micrograms of folic 
acid a day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should continue  
to take this until you are 12  
weeks pregnant (see page 27).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you have a health condition,
for example mental health 
problems, diabetes or a  
family history of any  
inherited diseases,  
talk to your GP  
or a specialist  
before you try  
to get pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Talk to your 
GP or a  
healthcare 
professional 
if you have 
any concerns 
or need 
support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
0–8 WEEKS
• You can take a pregnancy 
test from the ﬁrst day that 
you miss your period (see 
Finding out that you are 
pregnant on page 16).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• As soon as you know you 
are pregnant, get in touch 
with a midwife or your GP 
to organise your antenatal 
care (see Finding out that 
you are pregnant on page 
16 and Antenatal care on 
page 40).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Begin to think 
about where you want 
your baby to be born (see 
Choosing where to have 
your baby on page 70).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Some pregnant women 
start to feel sick or tired or 
have other minor physical 
problems for a few weeks 
(see Common minor 
problems on page 58).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Take 10 micrograms of 
vitamin D per day, which 
is in Healthy Start vitamin 
supplements or other 
supplements recommended 
by your midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
should continue to take 
vitamin D throughout your 
pregnancy and while you 
are breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
8–12 WEEKS 
• You will usually attend your 
ﬁrst appointment by 10 
weeks and your booking 
appointment by 12 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• At the booking appointment, 
your weight, height and 
body mass index will be 
measured.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be 
asked about your health 
and family history as well as 
about your baby’s father’s 
family history.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is to 
ﬁnd out if you are at risk of 
certain inherited conditions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your hand-held notes and 
plan of care will be completed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your midwife will discuss 
various tests you will 
be offered during your 
pregnancy, one of which 
is an ultrasound scan to 
check for abnormalities 
in your baby (see page 
48).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be offered 
information about what to 
expect during pregnancy 
and how to have a healthy 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask if you are 
unsure about anything.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You can ask your midwife 
about your rights at work 
and the beneﬁts available 
(see Rights and beneﬁts 
on page 156).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You will usually be offered 
an ultrasound scan between 
eight and 14 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
will check the baby’s 
measurements and give 
an accurate due date.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The scan can also detect 
abnormalities and check  
if you are carrying more 
than one baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your partner 
can come along to the 
scan (see Antenatal care 
on page 40).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you get Income Support, 
income-based Jobseeker’s 
Allowance or income-
related Employment and 
Support Allowance or 
are on a low income and 
receive Child Tax Credit, you 
should complete a Healthy 
Start application form (see 
page 28).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is to claim 
vouchers to spend on milk, 
fruit and vegetables.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Healthy 
Start vitamin supplements 
(containing vitamin D) are 
free without prescription for 
any pregnant woman, new 
mother or child who gets 
Healthy Start vouchers  
(see Rights and beneﬁts 
on page 156).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Make a dental appointment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
NHS dental care is free 
during pregnancy and for  
a year after the birth of  
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Just 12 weeks after 
conception, your baby is 
fully formed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It has all its 
organs, muscles, limbs and 
bones, and its sex organs 
are well developed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your baby is already moving 
about but you cannot feel 
the movements yet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
>

text:
12–16 WEEKS
• Find out about antenatal 
education (see Antenatal 
care on page 40).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Start to think about how 
you want to feed your baby 
(see Feeding your baby 
on page 102).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Make sure you are wearing 
a supportive bra.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your 
breasts will probably 
increase in size during 
pregnancy so you need to 
make sure you are wearing 
the right sized bra.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you have been feeling sick 
and tired, you will probably 
start to feel better around 
this time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• At 14 weeks, your baby‘s 
heartbeat is strong and  
can be heard using an 
ultrasound detector.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your pregnancy may just 
be beginning to show.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This varies a lot from 
woman to woman.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Vas deferens  The two tubes called the vas deferens

becomes hard and erect.

the scrotum, which hangs outside the body.

below body temperature.

be produced.

text:
When it is warm, the scrotum hangs down 
away from the body to keep the testes cool.

the scrotum draws up closer to the body for warmth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Pelvis  The pelvis is the bony structure that the 
baby will pass through when it is born.

Womb or uterus  The uterus is about the size 
and shape of a small, upside down pear.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is made  
of muscle and increases in size as the baby grows.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
3
Fallopian tubes  The fallopian tubes lead from 
the ovaries to the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eggs are released from  
the ovaries into the fallopian tubes each month.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This is where fertilisation takes place.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

size of a walnut.

text: They produce the eggs or ova.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

5
Cervix  The cervix is the neck of the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is 
normally almost closed, with just a small opening 
through which blood passes during monthly  
periods.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During labour, the cervix will dilate to  
let the baby move from the uterus into the vagina.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

6

which is a tube about 8cm (3 inches) long.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

It leads 
from the cervix down to the vulva, where it opens 
between the legs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The vagina is very elastic, so it  
can easily stretch around a man’s penis during sex  
or around a baby during labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Fertilisation
During sex, sperm are ejaculated from 
a man’s penis into a woman’s vagina.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In one ejaculation there may be more 
than 300 million sperm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most of the 
sperm leak out of the vagina but 
some begin to swim up through the 
cervix.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When a woman is ovulating, 
the mucus in the cervix is thinner 
than usual to let sperm pass through 
more easily.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sperm swim into the 
uterus and into the fallopian tubes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fertilisation takes place if a sperm 
joins with an egg and fertilises it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
3
Attached embryo 
Implantation
During the week after fertilisation, 
the fertilised egg (which is now an 
embryo) moves slowly down the 
fallopian tube and into the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It is already growing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The embryo 
attaches itself ﬁrmly to the specially 
thickened uterus lining.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is called 
implantation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Hormones released 
by the embryonic tissue prevent the 
uterus lining from being shed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
is why women miss their periods 
when they are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
HORMONES 
Both men and women have 
hormones, which are chemicals that 
circulate in the bloodstream.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They 
carry messages to different parts 
of the body and result in certain 
changes taking place.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Female 
hormones, which include oestrogen 
and progesterone, control many of 
the events of a woman’s monthly 
cycle, such as the release of eggs 
from her ovaries and the thickening 
of her uterus lining.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During pregnancy, your hormone 
levels change.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As soon as you 
have conceived, the amount of 
oestrogen and progesterone in your 
blood increases.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This causes the 
uterus lining to build up, the blood 
supply to your uterus and breasts 
to increase and the muscles of your 
uterus to relax to make room for  
the growing baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The increase in hormone levels 
can affect how you feel.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may 
have mood swings, feel tearful or 
be easily irritated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For a while you 
may feel that you cannot control 
your emotions, but these symptoms 
should ease after the ﬁrst three 
months of your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Every normal human cell contains 
46 chromosomes, except for male 
sperm and female eggs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These 
contain 23 chromosomes each.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When a sperm fertilises an egg, the 
23 chromosomes from the father 
pair with the 23 from the mother, 
making 46 in all.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Chromosomes are tiny, thread-like 
structures which each carry about 
2,000 genes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Genes determine 
a baby’s inherited 
characteristics, such as 
hair and eye colour, 
blood group, height 
and build.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A fertilised 
egg contains one sex 
chromosome from 
its mother and one 
from its father.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The 
sex chromosome from 
the mother’s egg is always the same 
and is known as the X chromosome.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But the sex chromosome from  
the father’s sperm can be an X or  
a Y chromosome.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the egg is fertilised by a sperm 
containing an X chromosome,  
the baby will be a girl (XX).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the 
sperm contains a Y chromosome, 
the baby will be a boy (XY).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Sperm is about 1/25th of a millimetre long and has a head, neck and tail.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The tail moves from side to side so that the sperm can swim up the vagina 
into the uterus and fallopian tubes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
One egg or ovum (occasionally two or more) is released from the  
woman’s ovaries every month.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It moves down into the fallopian tube  
where it may be fertilised by a man’s sperm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

You are most likely to get pregnant

source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

after it is released.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:

pregnant, the egg must be fertilised

a woman’s body.

TWINS, TRIPLETS 
OR MORE
Identical twins occur when one 
fertilised egg splits into two; each 
baby will have the same genes  
– and therefore they will be the  
same sex and look very alike.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Non-identical twins are more 
common.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They are the result of  
two eggs being fertilised by two 
sperm at the same time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The babies 
may be of the same sex or different 
sexes, and will probably look no 
more alike than any other brothers 
and sisters.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A third of all twins  
will be identical and two-thirds  
non-identical.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Twins happen in about 1 in every  
65 pregnancies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A couple is more 
likely to have twins if there are  
twins in the woman’s family.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Triplets occur naturally in 1 in 
10,000 pregnancies and quads 
are even rarer.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Nowadays, the use 
of drugs in the treatment of 
infertility has made multiple 
births more common.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf
