Are you carrying 
twins?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You might suspect that you 
are carrying more than 
one baby if:
• you are very sick in 
early pregnancy
• you seem bigger than you should 
be for your ‘dates’
• twins run in your family, or 
• you have had fertility treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is usually possible to ﬁnd out 
through your dating ultrasound 
scan, which happens between eight 
and 14 weeks (see page 48).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should be told at this point 
whether the babies share a placenta 
(are identical) or if they have two 
separate placentas, in which case 
they can be either identical or 
non-identical.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this cannot be 
determined, you should be offered 
a further scan.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A third of identical 
twins have two separate placentas.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This happens when the fertilised 
egg splits in the ﬁrst 3–4 days after 
conception and before it implants  
in the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
What is different about 
being pregnant with 
twins or more?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All multiple pregnancies have  
a higher risk of complications  
– particularly premature birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your babies share a placenta 
(identical twins) it is recommended 
that you are scanned every two 
weeks from 16 weeks onwards, 
and every four weeks if your babies 
have separate placentas.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may 
be advised to have a caesarean 
section.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should discuss this 
with your doctor, but it is your 
choice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is possible to breastfeed 
twins and triplets and there is more 
information about how you can do 
this in Chapter 9.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may ﬁnd that 
a combination of breast and formula 
feeding is best for you – particularly 
if you have triplets or more.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
THE SIGNS OF 
PREGNANCY
For women who have a regular 
monthly cycle, the earliest and  
most reliable sign of pregnancy  
is a missed period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes 
women who are pregnant have a 
very light period, losing only a little 
blood.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Other signs of pregnancy  
are as follows:
• Feeling sick – you may feel sick, 
or even be sick.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is commonly 
known as ‘morning sickness’ but 
it can happen at any time of the 
day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are being sick all the 
time and cannot keep anything 
down, contact your GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Changes in your breasts – your 
breasts may become larger and 
feel tender, like they might do 
before your period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may also 
tingle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The veins may show up 
more and the nipples may darken 
and stand out.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Needing to pass urine more 
often – you may ﬁnd that you 
have to get up in the night.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• An increased vaginal discharge 
without any soreness or irritation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•�Having a strange taste in your 
mouth – many women describe  
it as metallic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•�‘Going off’ certain things, for 
example tea, coffee, tobacco 
smoke or fatty food.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
PREGNANCY TESTS
Pregnancy tests can be carried 
out on a sample of urine from the 
ﬁrst day of a missed period, which 
means that, if you are pregnant, 
you are about two weeks after 
conception.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some very sensitive 
tests can be used even before you 
miss a period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can collect urine at any time 
of the day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Use a clean, soap-free, 
well-rinsed container to collect it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can get pregnancy tests free 
of charge from your GP or family 
planning clinic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pregnancy tests are 
also available at NHS walk-in centres.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many pharmacists and most 
pregnancy advisory services also  
offer tests, usually for a small 
fee.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can buy do-it-yourself 
pregnancy testing kits from 
pharmacists.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can give you  
a quick result and you can do  
the test in private.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There are a  
range of tests that are available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How they work varies, so check  
the instructions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Results of the test
A positive test result is almost 
certainly correct.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A negative result is 
less reliable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you still think you are 
pregnant, wait a week and try again 
or go and see a midwife or GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
smoke or fatty foo
You might ﬁnd it helpful to 
contact support groups like 
Tamba (Twins and Multiple 
Births Association) and the 
Multiple Births Foundation 
(see pages 188 and 183) before 
your babies are born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See your midwife or doctor as soon as possible if you are 
currently being treated for a long-term disease such 
as diabetes or epilepsy, or you have serious mental 
health problems.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
FINDING OUT 
THAT YOU ARE 
PREGNANT
When you ﬁnd out that you are 
pregnant, you may feel happy and 
excited or even shocked, confused 
and upset.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Everybody is different 
and you should not worry if you are 
not feeling as happy as you might 
have expected.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Even if you have 
been trying to get pregnant, your 
feelings may take you by surprise.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some of these feelings may be 
caused by changes in your  
hormone levels, which can  
make you feel more emotional.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Even if you feel anxious and 
uncertain now, your feelings may 
change.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your midwife, GP 
or family planning clinic, who will 
try to help you to adjust or will give 
you advice if you don’t want to 
continue with your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Men may also have mixed feelings 
when they ﬁnd out that their 
partner is pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may  
ﬁnd it hard to talk about these 
feelings because they don’t want  
to upset their partner.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Both partners 
should encourage each other to 
talk about their feelings and any 
worries or concerns that they have 
at this stage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However you are feeling, you 
should contact an NHS professional 
(see Chapter 4) so that you can start 
to receive antenatal care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is the 
care that you will receive leading up 
to the birth of your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Telling people
You may want to tell your family 
and friends immediately or wait 
a while until you have sorted out 
how you feel.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many women wait 
until they have had their ﬁrst scan 
before they tell people that they  
are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Members of your family/extended 
family may have mixed feelings or 
react in unexpected ways to your 
news.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may wish to discuss this 
with your midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ACCESSING 
ANTENATAL CARE
When you ﬁnd out that you  
are pregnant, it’s important to  
contact an NHS professional  
as soon as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can book an appointment 
directly with a midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your GP 
surgery will be able to put you  
in touch with your nearest  
midwife service.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have special health needs, 
your midwife, GP or other doctors 
may take shared responsibility for 
your maternity care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your ﬁrst or second meeting 
with your midwife is the booking 
appointment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will last for up to 
two hours and could take place at  
a hospital, in a clinic or a Children’s 
Centre, in a GP surgery or at home.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife will ask you many 
questions about your health, the 
health of your family and your 
preferences in order to develop your 
own plan of care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife 
will order a number of blood tests 
and scans, which will be done 
throughout your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The 
results of these tests may affect your 
choices later in pregnancy, so it’s 
important not to miss them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your 
midwife will also ask about any other 
help or social care support you may 
have or need – for example support 
from social workers or family liaison 
ofﬁcers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more information about 
the booking appointment, see  
pages 42 and 44–45.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
HELP FOR  
YOUNG MUMS
If you are a young mum, there are 
a wide range of services to support 
you when you are pregnant and 
after you have had your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your 
midwife or health visitor will be able 
to give you details of local services.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are on your own
If you are pregnant and on your 
own, it is even more important that 
there are people with whom you 
can share your feelings and who 
can offer you support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sorting out 
problems, whether personal or 
medical, is often difﬁcult when you 
are by yourself, and it is better to 
ﬁnd someone to talk to rather than 
let things get you down.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more 
information on coping on your own, 
see page 79.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Carrying on with  
your education
Becoming a mother certainly does 
not have to mean the end of  
your education.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are still  
of compulsory school age, your  
school should not exclude you  
on grounds of pregnancy or health  
and safety issues connected with 
your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, they may 
talk to you about making alternative 
arrangements for your education.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be allowed up to 18 
calendar weeks off school before 
and after the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After your return to education, you 
can get help with childcare costs 
through the Care to Learn scheme.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Care to Learn also provides support 
with childcare costs for teenage 
parents above the compulsory 
schooling age who want to study.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also be eligible for the 
Education Maintenance Allowance 
(EMA), which is available for young 
people between 16 and 18.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: EMA provides up to £30 a week.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more information about  
EMA and Care to Learn, phone 
0800 121 8989 or visit http://
moneytolearn.direct.gov.uk
Help and support
The following national 
organisations can also give  
you help and advice:
Sexwise helpline
If you think you may be pregnant, 
you can get conﬁdential advice 
from the Sexwise helpline on  
0800 282930 or get further 
information from  
www.ruthinking.co.uk  
Brook centres
If you are under 25, you can visit a 
Brook centre for free, conﬁdential 
advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To ﬁnd your nearest centre, 
go to www.brook.org.uk or call 
the national Ask Brook helpline on 
0808 802 1234.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Connexions
Teenagers in England can get help 
and advice from the Connexions 
service.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You have the offer of 
support from a personal adviser to 
help deal with a variety of issues so 
that you can make the best choices 
for your future.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can ﬁnd 
Connexions advisers in a variety of 
places, including schools, colleges 
and one-stop shops and through 
youth and community projects.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For conﬁdential personal advice, 
practical help or details of your 
local Connexions service, phone 
Connexions Direct, on 080 800 
13219, text 07766 4 13219 or go 
to www.connexions-direct.com
The young woman’s  
guide to pregnancy
The young woman’s guide to 
pregnancy is written speciﬁcally 
for women under the age of 20 
and includes the real pregnancy 
experiences of young mums.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is produced by Tommy’s and is 
available free to teenagers from 
the Tommy’s website at  
www.tommys.org/publications 
For information on sex and 
contraception, see page 122.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Somewhere  
to live
Many young mothers 
want to carry on living 
with their own family until they 
are ready to move on.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are 
unable to live with your family, 
your local authority may be 
able to help you with housing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some local authorities provide 
specialised accommodation 
where young mothers can live 
independently while getting 
support and advice from trained 
workers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more information 
about housing, contact your  
local authority.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

This chapter describes how your baby develops from the day you conceive until  
you give birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
MEASURING YOUR PREGNANCY
Doctors and midwives in the UK 
measure the duration of pregnancy 
from the ﬁrst day of your last 
menstrual period, not from the 
day you conceive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
So when you 
are ‘four weeks pregnant’, it is 
actually about two weeks after 
you conceived.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pregnancy normally 
lasts for 37–42 weeks from the 
ﬁrst day of your last period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: The average is 40 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are not sure about the date 
of your last period, then your early 
scan (see page 48) will give a  
good indication of when your  
baby will be due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the very early weeks, the 
developing baby is called an 
embryo.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
From about eight weeks, 
it is called a fetus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WEEK 3
This is three weeks from the ﬁrst 
day of your last period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The  
fertilised egg moves slowly along 
your fallopian tube towards your 
uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It begins as one single cell, 
which divides again and again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
By the time the fertilised egg 
reaches your uterus, it has become 
a mass of over 100 cells, called an 
embryo.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once in 
your uterus, the embryo attaches 
itself into your uterus lining.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This is called implantation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WEEKS 4–5
Week 4
The actual size of the embryo  
is about 5mm
The embryo now settles into your 
uterus lining.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The outer cells reach 
out like roots to link with your 
blood supply.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The inner cells form 
two – and then later three – layers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Each of these layers will grow to be 
different parts of your baby’s body.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
One layer becomes their brain and 
nervous system, skin, eyes and ears.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Another layer becomes their lungs, 
stomach and gut.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The third layer 
becomes their heart, blood, muscles 
and bones.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The ﬁfth week is when you will 
miss your period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At this time, most 
women are only just beginning to 
think they may be pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Already your baby’s nervous system 
is starting to develop.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A groove 
forms in the top layer of cells.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The 
cells fold up and round to make a 
hollow tube called the neural tube.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will become your baby’s brain 
and spinal cord, so the tube has a 
‘head end’ and a ‘tail end’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Defects 
in this tube are the cause of spina 
biﬁda (see page 49).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The heart is  
also forming and your baby already 
has some blood vessels.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A string of 
these blood vessels connects your 
baby to you – this will become the 
umbilical cord.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WEEKS 6–7
There is now a large bulge where 
your baby’s heart is and a bump 
for the head because the brain is 
developing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The heart begins to 
beat and can be seen beating on an 
ultrasound scan.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Dimples on the side 
of the head will become the ears 
and there are thickenings where the 
eyes will be.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
On the body, bumps are 
forming that will become muscles 
and bones.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
And small swellings 
(called ‘limb buds’) show where the 
arms and legs are growing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At seven 
weeks, the embryo has grown to 
about 10mm long from head to 
bottom.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This measurement is called 
the ‘crown–rump length’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Week 6 
The actual size from head  
to bottom is about 8mm
Week 7 
The actual size from head  
to bottom is about 10mm

WEEKS 8–9
Your baby’s face is slowly forming.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The eyes are more obvious and 
have some colour in them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The 
fetus has a mouth with a tongue.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There are the beginnings of hands 
and feet, with ridges where the 
ﬁngers and toes will be.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The major 
internal organs – the heart, brain, 
lungs, kidneys, liver and gut – are all 
developing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At nine weeks, the baby 
has grown to about 22mm long 
from head to bottom.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Week 9 
The actual size from head  
to bottom is about 22mm
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:

The umbilical cord 
The umbilical cord is a baby’s lifeline.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is the link between you  
and your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Blood circulates through the cord, carrying oxygen 
and food to the baby and carrying waste away again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The placenta 
The placenta is attached to the lining of the uterus and separates 
your baby’s circulation from your circulation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the placenta, oxygen 
and food from your bloodstream pass into your baby’s bloodstream 
and are carried to your baby along the umbilical cord.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Antibodies 
that give resistance to infection pass to your baby in the same way.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Alcohol, nicotine and other drugs can also pass to your baby this way.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The amniotic sac
Inside the uterus, the baby ﬂoats in a bag of ﬂuid called the amniotic 
sac.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Before or during labour the sac, or ‘membranes’, break and the 
ﬂuid drains out.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This is known as the ‘waters breaking’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WEEKS 10–14
Just 12 weeks after conception, the 
fetus is fully formed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby has 
all of their organs, muscles, limbs 
and bones, and their sex organs are 
developed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
From now on your baby 
will grow and mature.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby 
is already moving about, but you 
will not be able to feel movements 
yet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
By about 14 weeks, your baby’s 
heartbeat is strong and can be 
heard by an ultrasound scanner.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The heartbeat is very fast – about 
twice as fast as a normal adult’s 
heartbeat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At 14 weeks, the baby 
is about 85mm long from head to 
bottom.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your pregnancy may start 
to show, but this varies a lot from 
woman to woman.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Week 14 
The actual size from head  
to bottom is about 85mm
20
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WEEKS 15–22
Your baby is growing faster than 
at any other time in their life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Their body grows bigger so that 
their head and body are more in 
proportion, and they don’t look 
so ‘top heavy’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The face becomes 
much more deﬁned and the 
hair, eyebrows and eyelashes are 
beginning to grow.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Their eyelids stay 
closed over their eyes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby 
already has their own individual 
ﬁngerprints, as the lines on the skin 
of their ﬁngers are now formed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Their ﬁngernails and toenails are 
growing and their hands can grip.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At about 22 weeks, your baby 
becomes covered in a very ﬁne,  
soft hair called lanugo.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
We don’t 
know what this hair is for, but it  
is thought that it may keep the  
baby at the right temperature.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The lanugo disappears before  
birth or soon after.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Between 16 and 22 weeks, you 
will usually feel your baby move for 
the ﬁrst time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this is your second 
baby, you may feel it earlier – at 
about 16–18 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At ﬁrst, you 
feel a ﬂuttering or bubbling, or a 
very slight shifting movement.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
can feel a bit like indigestion.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Later, 
you will be able to tell that it is the 
baby’s movements and you may 
even see the baby kicking about.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes you will see a bump  
that is clearly a hand or a foot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Week 22 
The actual size from head  
to bottom is about 27cm
2
HOW YOUR BABY DEVELOPS
21
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WEEKS 23–30
Your baby is now moving about 
vigorously, and responds to touch 
and sound.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A very loud noise close 
by may make them jump and kick.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They are also swallowing small 
amounts of the amniotic ﬂuid in 
which they are ﬂoating, and are 
passing tiny amounts of urine back 
into the ﬂuid.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes your baby 
may get hiccups, and you can feel 
the jerk of each hiccup.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby 
may also begin to follow a pattern 
for waking and sleeping.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Very often 
this is a different pattern from  
yours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
So when you go to bed at 
night, your baby may wake up and 
start kicking.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby’s heartbeat can be heard 
through a stethoscope.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Later, 
your partner may be able to hear 
the heartbeat by putting their ear 
to your abdomen, but it can be 
difﬁcult to ﬁnd the right place.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby is now covered in a 
white, greasy substance called 
vernix.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is thought that this may 
be to protect its skin as it ﬂoats in 
the amniotic ﬂuid.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The vernix mostly 
disappears before the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
From 24 weeks, your baby has a 
chance of survival if it is born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most 
babies born before this time cannot 
live because their lungs and other 
vital organs are not developed well 
enough.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The care that can now 
be given in neonatal units means 
that more and more babies born 
this early do survive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies born 
at around this time have increased 
risks of disability.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Week 30 
The actual size from head to bottom  
is about 33cm
22
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
23
At around 26 weeks your baby’s eyelids open for the  
ﬁrst time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies’ eyes are almost always blue or dark blue, 
although some babies do have brown eyes at birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is not until some weeks after they are born that your  
baby’s eyes will become the colour that they will stay.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: The head-to-bottom length at 30 weeks is about 33cm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WEEKS 31– 40
Your baby continues to grow.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Their skin, which was quite 
wrinkled before, becomes smoother, and both the vernix  
and the lanugo begin to disappear.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
By about 32 weeks, the baby is usually lying with  
its head pointing downwards, ready for birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The baby’s head can ‘engage’, or move down  
into the pelvis, before birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes the  
head doesn’t engage until labour has started.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

with your

Helpful tips
Regularly talking, reading 
and singing to your bump 
while you are pregnant will 
help you to bond with your 
baby before birth.

A healthy diet and lifestyle can help you to keep well during pregnancy and give your 
baby the best possible start in life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This chapter explains some of the things you can  
do to stay healthy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A healthy diet is very important if 
you are pregnant or trying to get 
pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eating healthily during 
pregnancy will help your baby to 
develop and grow and will help to 
keep you ﬁt and well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You don’t need 
to go on a special diet, but make 
sure that you eat a variety of different 
foods every day in order to get the 
right balance of nutrients that you 
and your baby need.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should also 
avoid certain foods – see ‘Foods to 
avoid’ on page 26.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will probably ﬁnd that you are 
more hungry than normal, but you 
don’t need to ‘eat for two’ – even if 
you are expecting twins or triplets.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Have breakfast every day – this will 
help you to avoid snacking on foods 
that are high in fat and sugar.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
may have to change the amounts of 
different foods that you eat, rather 
than cutting out all your favourites.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More information
Visit www.eatwell.gov.uk 
for useful information on what 
you should eat when you are 
pregnant or trying for a baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The leaﬂets Eating while you 
are pregnant and Thinking 
of having a baby?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
are also 
available in several languages.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Both leaﬂets are available 
online at www.food.gov.uk  
or can be ordered on  
0845 606 0667.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

and

delicious

The ‘eatwell plate’ below shows how

text:
3
YOUR HEALTH IN PREGNANCY
25
Bread, rice, potatoes,  
pasta and other  
starchy foods
Carbohydrates are 
satisfying without 
containing too many 
calories, and are an 
important source of 
vitamins and ﬁbre.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They include bread, 
potatoes, breakfast 
cereals, pasta, rice,  
oats, noodles, maize, 
millet, yams, cornmeal 
and sweet potatoes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These foods should  
be the main part 
of every meal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eat 
wholegrain varieties  
when you can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Foods and drinks  
that are high in  
fat and/or sugar
This food group includes all 
spreading fats, oils, salad 
dressings, cream, chocolate, 
crisps, biscuits, pastries, ice 
cream, cake, puddings and  
ﬁzzy drinks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should only  
eat a small amount of these 
foods.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sugar contains calories 
without providing any other 
nutrients that the body needs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Having sugary foods and drinks 
too often can cause tooth decay, 
especially if you have them 
between meals.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If we eat more 
than we need, this can lead to 
weight gain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eating more fatty 
foods is likely to make you put 
on weight.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Having too much 
saturated fat can increase the 
amount of cholesterol in the 
blood, which increases the 
chance of developing heart 
disease.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to cut down on 
food that is high in saturated 
fat and have foods rich in 
unsaturated fat instead.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fruit and vegetables
As well as vitamins and  
minerals, fruit and vegetables 
provide ﬁbre, which 
helps digestion and 
prevents constipation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eat at least ﬁve 
portions of fresh, 
frozen, canned, 
dried or juiced fruit 
and vegetables 
each day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Always 
wash them 
carefully.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To get 
the most out 
of vegetables, 
eat them raw 
or lightly cooked.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more 
information and portion sizes, 
visit www.5aday.nhs.uk 
Meat, ﬁsh, eggs, 
beans and other  
non-dairy sources  
of protein
Protein includes meat (except 
liver), ﬁsh, poultry, eggs, 
beans, pulses and nuts (for 
information on peanuts see 
page 112).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These foods are all 
good sources of nutrients.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eat moderate amounts each 
day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Choose lean meat, 
remove the skin from poultry 
and cook using only a little  
fat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure eggs, poultry, 
pork, burgers and sausages 
are cooked all the way through.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Check that there is no pink 
meat and that juices have no 
pink or red in them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to eat 
two portions of ﬁsh a week, 
one of which should be oily 
ﬁsh.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There are some ﬁsh that 
you should avoid – see ‘Foods 
to avoid’ on page 26 for more 
information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Milk and dairy foods
Dairy foods like milk, cheese, 
yoghurt and fromage frais 
are important because they 
contain calcium and other 
nutrients that your baby 
needs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eat two or three 
portions a day, using low-fat 
varieties whenever you can  
– for example, semi-skimmed  
or skimmed milk, low-fat 
yoghurt and half-fat hard 
cheese.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, there are 
some cheeses that you  
should avoid – see ‘Foods  
to avoid’ on page 26 for more 
information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
FOODS TO AVOID
There are some foods that you 
should not eat when you are 
pregnant because they may  
make you ill or harm your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should avoid:
• Some types of cheese.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t 
eat mould-ripened soft cheese, 
like Brie, Camembert and others 
with a similar rind.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should 
also avoid soft blue-veined cheese, 
like Danish blue.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These are made 
with mould and they can contain 
listeria, a type of bacteria that can 
harm your unborn baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Although 
listeriosis is a very rare infection, 
it is important to take special 
precautions during pregnancy 
because even the mild form of 
the illness in the mother can lead 
to miscarriage, stillbirth or severe 
illness in a newborn baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can 
eat hard cheeses such as cheddar 
and parmesan, and processed 
cheeses made from pasteurised 
milk such as cottage cheese, 
mozzarella and cheese spreads.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Avoid all types of pâté, 
including vegetable pâtés, as  
they can contain listeria.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Raw or partially cooked eggs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure that eggs are thoroughly  
cooked until the whites and yolks 
are solid.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This prevents the risk 
of salmonella food poisoning.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Avoid foods that contain raw and 
undercooked eggs, such as home-
made mayonnaise.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Raw or undercooked meat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cook all meat and poultry 
thoroughly so that there is no 
trace of pink or blood.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Take 
particular care with sausages and  
minced meat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is ﬁne to eat steaks 
and other whole cuts of beef and 
lamb rare, as long as the outside 
has been properly cooked or sealed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t eat liver, or 
liver products like liver pâté or liver 
sausage, as they may contain a lot 
of vitamin A.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Too much vitamin A 
can harm your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Supplements containing 
vitamin A.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t take high-
dose multivitamin supplements, 
ﬁsh liver oil supplements or any 
supplements containing vitamin A.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t eat 
shark, marlin and swordﬁsh, and 
limit the amount of tuna you eat 
to no more than two tuna steaks 
a week (about 140g cooked or 
170g raw each) or four medium-
sized cans of tuna a week (about 
140g when drained).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These types 
of ﬁsh contain high levels of 
mercury, which can damage  
your baby’s developing nervous 
system.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t eat more than two 
portions of oily ﬁsh per week.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Oily ﬁsh includes fresh tuna 
(but not canned tuna), salmon, 
mackerel, sardines and trout.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eat cooked rather 
than raw shellﬁsh as they can 
contain harmful bacteria and viruses 
that can cause food poisoning.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you would like to 
eat peanuts or foods containing 
peanuts (such as peanut butter) 
during pregnancy, you can choose 
to do so as part of a healthy 
balanced diet, unless you are 
allergic to them or your health 
professional advises you not to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may have heard that some 
women have, in the past, chosen 
not to eat peanuts when they 
were pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is because the 
government previously advised 
women that they may wish to 
avoid eating peanuts during 
pregnancy if there was a history  
of allergy in their child’s immediate 
family (such as asthma, eczema, 
hayfever, food allergy or other 
types of allergy).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But this advice 
has now been changed because 
the latest research has shown that 
there is no clear evidence to say 
if eating or not eating peanuts 
during pregnancy affects the 
chances of your baby developing 
a peanut allergy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Unpasteurised milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Drink only 
pasteurised or UHT milk which 
has been pasteurised.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If only raw 
or green-top milk is available, boil 
it ﬁrst.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t drink unpasteurised 
goats’ or sheep’s milk or eat 
certain food that is made out of 
them, e.g.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
PREPARING FOOD
26
• Wash fruit, vegetables and salads 
to remove all traces of soil, which 
may contain toxoplasma.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can 
cause toxoplasmosis, which can 
harm your baby (see page 37).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Heat ready-meals until they are 
piping hot all the way through.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is especially important for 
meals containing poultry.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Keep leftovers covered in the 
fridge and use within two days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Wash all surfaces and utensils, 
and your hands, after preparing 
raw meat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will help to avoid 
infection with toxoplasma.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your weight 
Most women gain between 
10kg and 12.5kg (22–28lb) while 
pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Weight gain varies 
a great deal and depends on 
your weight before pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Much of the extra weight is due 
to the baby growing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Putting 
on too much weight can affect 
your health and increase your 
blood pressure.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Equally, it is 
important that you do not 
diet, but eat healthily.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try and 
stay active by keeping up your 
normal daily activity or exercise.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are concerned, talk to 
your midwife or GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may 
give you advice if you weigh 
more than 100kg (about 15½ 
stone) or less than 50kg (about 
8 stone).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
VITAMINS  
AND MINERALS
Eating a healthy, varied diet will  
help you to get all the vitamins  
and minerals you need while you 
are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There are some 
vitamins and minerals that are 
especially important:
•  Folic acid.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Folic acid is important 
for pregnancy as it can reduce 
the risk of neural tube defects 
such as spina biﬁda.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are 
thinking about getting pregnant, 
you should take a 400 microgram 
folic acid tablet every day until 
you are 12 weeks pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If 
you did not take folic acid before 
you conceived, you should start 
as soon as you ﬁnd out that you 
are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should also eat 
foods that contain folic acid, such 
as green leafy vegetables, fortiﬁed 
breakfast cereals and brown rice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some breakfast cereals, breads 
and margarines have folic acid 
added to them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you already 
have a baby with spina biﬁda, 
or if you have coeliac disease or 
diabetes or take anti-epileptic 
medicines, ask your GP or midwife 
for more advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will need to 
take a bigger dose of folic acid.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You need vitamin D
to keep your bones healthy and 
to provide your baby with enough 
vitamin D for the ﬁrst few months 
of their life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vitamin D regulates 
the amount of calcium and 
phosphate in the body, and these 
are needed to help keep bones 
and teeth healthy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Deﬁciency of 
vitamin D can cause children’s 
bones to soften and can lead 
to rickets.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should take a 
supplement of 10 micrograms of 
vitamin D every day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Only a few 
foods contain vitamin D, including 
oily ﬁsh like sardines, fortiﬁed 
margarines, some breakfast 
cereals and taramasalata.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The best source of vitamin D is 
summer sunlight.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The amount of 
time you need in the sun to make 
enough vitamin D is different 
for every person and depends 
on things like skin type, time of 
day and time of the year.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But 
you don’t need to sunbathe: the 
amount of sun you need to make 
enough vitamin D is less than the 
amount that causes tanning or 
burning.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have dark skin or 
always cover your skin, you may 
be at particular risk of vitamin D 
deﬁciency.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your midwife 
or doctor if you are worried 
about this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
(See also ‘Vitamin 
supplements’ on page 28.)
•  Iron.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are short of iron, 
you will probably get very 
tired and you can become 
anaemic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Lean meat, green, leafy 
vegetables, dried fruit and nuts 
(see page 26 about avoiding 
peanuts) all contain iron.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many 
breakfast cereals have iron 
added.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the iron level in your 
blood becomes low, your GP or 
midwife will advise you to take 
iron supplements.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These are 
available as tablets or a liquid.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You need vitamin C 
as it may help you to absorb iron.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Citrus fruits, tomatoes, broccoli, 
peppers, blackcurrants, potatoes 
and some pure fruit juices are 
good sources of vitamin C.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your iron levels are low, it may 
help to drink orange juice with 
an iron-rich meal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Calcium is vital for 
making your baby’s bones and 
teeth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Dairy products and ﬁsh 
with edible bones like sardines 
are rich in calcium.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breakfast 
cereals, dried fruit such as ﬁgs 
and apricots, bread, almonds, 
tofu (a vegetable protein made 
from soya beans) and green 
leafy vegetables like watercress, 
broccoli and curly kale are other 
good sources of calcium.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

For more 
information 
about folic 
acid, read

mark on the right

Vitamin supplements 
It is best to get vitamins and 
minerals from the food you eat, 
but when you are pregnant 
you will need to take some 
supplements as well:
• 10 micrograms of vitamin D 
throughout your pregnancy 
and if you breastfeed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• 400 micrograms of folic acid 
– ideally this should be taken 
from before you get pregnant 
until you are 12 weeks 
pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are vegetarian or vegan, 
you may need to take a vitamin 
B12 supplement as well as other 
supplements.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your doctor 
or midwife about this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have a special or restricted 
diet, you may need additional 
supplements.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your doctor 
or midwife about this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Do not take vitamin A 
supplements, or any supplements 
containing vitamin A, as too 
much could harm your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can get supplements from 
pharmacies and supermarkets or 
your GP may be able to prescribe 
them for you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you want to get 
your folic acid or vitamin D from 
a multivitamin tablet, make sure 
that the tablet does not contain 
vitamin A (or retinol).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Ask your GP or pharmacist  
for advice if you are unsure  
(see ‘Healthy Start’ on this page).

Your primary care trust and

supplement to women who

Healthy snacks
You may ﬁnd that you get hungry 
between meals.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Avoid snacks that 
are high in fat and/or sugar.

text:
Instead you could try the following: 
•  Fresh fruit.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Sandwiches or pitta bread ﬁlled 
with grated cheese, lean ham, 
mashed tuna, salmon or sardines 
and salad.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Low-fat yoghurt or fromage frais.

sticks.

•  Ready-to-eat apricots, ﬁgs or 
prunes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

•  Unsweetened breakfast cereals 
or porridge and milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

fruit juices.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Baked beans on toast or 
a baked potato.

text:
Caffeine 
High levels of caffeine can result in babies 
having a low birth weight, which can increase 
the risk of health problems in later life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Too much can also cause miscarriage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Caffeine is naturally found in lots 
of foods, such as coffee, tea and 
chocolate, and is added to some soft drinks 
and energy drinks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can also be found in certain cold and ﬂu 
remedies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your midwife, pharmacist or another health 
professional before taking these remedies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You don’t need to cut caffeine out completely, but you  
should limit how much you have to no more than 200mg a 
day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try decaffeinated tea and coffee, fruit juice or water and 
limit the amount of ‘energy’ drinks, which may be high in 
caffeine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t worry if you occasionally have more than this, 
because the risks are quite small.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Caffeine content in food and drink
• 1 mug of instant coffee: 100mg
• 1 mug of ﬁlter coffee: 140mg
• 1 mug of tea: 75mg 
• 1 can of cola: 40mg
• 1 can of ‘energy’ drink: up to 80mg
• 1 x 50g bar of plain chocolate: up to 50mg
• 1 x 50g bar of milk chocolate: up to 25mg
So if you eat...
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• one bar of plain chocolate and one mug of ﬁlter coffee
• two mugs of tea and one can of cola, or
• one mug of instant coffee and one can of energy drink 
you have reached almost 200mg of caffeine.

text:
SMOKING
Every cigarette you smoke harms your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cigarettes restrict the essential 
oxygen supply to your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
So their tiny heart has to beat harder every time 
you smoke.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Cigarettes contain over 4,000 chemicals.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Protecting your baby 
from tobacco smoke is one of the best things you can do to give your child 
a healthy start in life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It’s never too late to stop.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you stop smoking now
Stopping smoking will beneﬁt both you and your baby immediately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Carbon monoxide and chemicals will clear from the body and oxygen  
levels will return to normal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
Getting help with 
stopping smoking
The Smokefree Pregnancy 
Support DVD will show you all 
the free NHS support available 
to help you to stop and stay 
stopped.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To order your free 
DVD, call the NHS Pregnancy 
Smoking Helpline on  
0800 169 9 169, or visit  
www.nhs.uk/smokefree
The NHS Pregnancy 
Smoking Helpline on
0800 169 9 169 
is open from 12pm to 9pm 
every day and offers free 
help, support and advice  
on stopping smoking  
when you are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also sign up to receive 
ongoing advice and support  
at a time that suits you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also ask your 
midwife, health visitor, 
practice nurse or pharmacist 
for advice and for the  
details of your local NHS  
Stop Smoking Service.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They offer one-to-one or 
group sessions with trained 
stop smoking advisers and 
may even have a pregnancy 
stop smoking specialist.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can offer advice  
about dealing with stress, 
weight gain and nicotine 
replacement therapy to help 
you manage your cravings.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Stopping smoking action plan
1 Think
Think about: 
• what you and your baby will gain if you stop smoking (see above)
• how much smoking costs you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • What else could you spend your money on?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How can you treat 
yourself or your baby with the money you save?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • What is keeping you smoking?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: List your top ﬁve reasons for going smokefree; e.g.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
protecting your 
health or the health of your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you stop smoking:
• You will have less morning 
sickness and fewer complications  
in pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You are more likely to have 
a healthier pregnancy and a 
healthier baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • You will reduce the risk of stillbirth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • You will cope better with the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your baby will cope better with 
any birth complications.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your baby is less likely to be born 
too early and have to face the 
additional breathing, feeding  
and health problems which  
often go with being premature 
(see Chapter 14).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your baby is less likely to be born 
underweight and have a problem 
keeping warm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies of mothers 
who smoke are, on average, 200g 
(about 8oz) lighter than other 
babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These babies may have 
problems during and after labour 
and are more prone to infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You will reduce the risk of cot 
death (see page 129 for more 
information about how to  
reduce the risk of cot death).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It will also be better for your baby 
later in life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Children whose  
parents smoke are more likely to 
suffer from illnesses which need 
hospital treatment (such as asthma).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: The sooner you stop, the better.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But stopping even in the last few 
weeks of pregnancy will beneﬁt  
you and your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
2 Get help
Take advantage of the free NHS support that is available to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are four times more  
likely to quit successfully with NHS support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See the ‘Help and support’ box on the left for  
more information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Ask your friends and family to help and support you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
3 Prepare
If you understand why you smoke and what triggers your smoking, you will be able to prepare  
yourself so that you can cope when you quit.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can help to:
• give up with somebody else, so that you can support each other
• change the habits you associate with smoking, and
• plan how you will deal with difﬁcult situations without the use of cigarettes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Choose a day to stop.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Will the ﬁrst few days be easier during a working week or over a weekend?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: When you are busy or relaxed?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Whatever you choose, stop completely on that day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Review your plan and get rid of all of your cigarettes the day before your day for stopping.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
My chosen day for stopping smoking is:
4 Stop smoking
Lots of people start smoking again because they feel they cannot cope with the withdrawal 
symptoms.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The ﬁrst few days may not be much fun but the symptoms are a sign that your body  
is starting to recover.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Take one day at a time and reward yourself for success.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Go through your list of reasons for going smokefree to remind yourself why you have given up.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have had a scan, use your scan images to keep you going through the times when  
you are ﬁnding it tough.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Secondhand smoke
If your partner or anyone else who 
lives with you smokes, it can affect 
you and your baby both before  
and after birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also ﬁnd  
it more difﬁcult to quit.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Secondhand smoke can cause low 
birth weight and cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Infants 
of parents who smoke are more 
likely to be admitted to hospital for 
bronchitis and pneumonia during 
the ﬁrst year of life, and more than 
17,000 children under the age of 
ﬁve are admitted to hospital every 
year because of the effects of 
secondhand smoke.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ALCOHOL
When you drink, alcohol reaches 
your baby through the placenta.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Too much exposure to alcohol 
can seriously affect your baby’s 
development.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Because of this risk, pregnant 
women or women trying to conceive 
should avoid drinking alcohol.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
do choose to drink, then protect 
your baby by not drinking more 
than 1 to 2 units of alcohol once or 
twice a week, and don’t get drunk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Additional advice from the National 
Institute for Health and Clinical 
Excellence (NICE) advises women 
to avoid alcohol in the ﬁrst three 
months in particular, because of the 
increased risk of miscarriage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When you drink, alcohol passes from 
your blood, through the placenta, to 
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A baby’s liver is one of the 
last organs to develop fully and does 
not mature until the latter half of 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby cannot process 
alcohol as well as you can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Drinking is not just dangerous for 
the baby in the ﬁrst three months: 
alcohol can affect your baby 
throughout pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
And if you 
drink heavily during pregnancy, a 
particular group of problems could 
develop that are known as Fetal 
Alcohol Syndrome (FAS).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Children 
with this syndrome have:
•  restricted growth
•  facial abnormalities
• learning and behavioural 
disorders.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Drinking more than 1 to 2 units 
once or twice a week, as well as 
binge drinking, may be associated 
with lesser forms of FAS.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The risk is 
likely to be greater the more  
you drink.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are drinking with friends:
•  ﬁnd a non-alcoholic drink that 
you enjoy
• sip any alcohol you do drink slowly 
to make it last
•  don’t let people pressure you into 
drinking, and
•  avoid getting drunk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
What is a  
unit of alcohol?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
One UK unit is 10ml, or 8g,  
of pure alcohol.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A unit is:
1/2 pint of beer, lager 
or cider  
at 3.5% ABV
or
a single measure (25ml) 
of spirit (whisky, gin, 
bacardi, vodka, etc.)  
at 40% ABV
or
32
1/2 standard (175ml) 
glass of wine  
at 11.5% ABV
To ﬁnd out more about units, visit the Know Your Limits website  
at www.nhs.uk/units
Help and support
Getting help with 
drinking
If you have difﬁculty cutting 
down what you drink, talk to 
your doctor, midwife, pharmacist 
or other healthcare professional.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Conﬁdential help and support is 
available from local counselling 
services (look in the telephone 
directory or contact Drinkline  
on 0800 917 8282).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should talk to your midwife 
if you have any concerns you 
have about your drinking around 
the time of conception and early 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can get more 
advice from www.nhs.uk/units

text:
PILLS, MEDICINES 
AND OTHER DRUGS 
Some medicines, including some 
common painkillers, can harm your 
baby’s health but some are safe, for 
example medication to treat long-
term conditions such as asthma, 
thyroid disease, diabetes and epilepsy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To be on the safe side, you should:
•  always check with your doctor, 
midwife or pharmacist before 
taking any medicine
•  make sure that your doctor, 
dentist or other health professional 
knows you are pregnant before  
 
they prescribe you anything or 
give you treatment
•  talk to your doctor if you take 
regular medication – ideally before 
you start trying for a baby or 
as soon as you ﬁnd out you are 
pregnant, and
•  use as few over the counter 
medicines as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Medicines and treatments that are 
usually safe include paracetamol, 
most antibiotics, dental treatments 
(including local anaesthetics), some 
immunisations (including tetanus 
and ﬂu injections) and nicotine 
replacement therapy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But you 
should always check with your GP, 
pharmacist or midwife ﬁrst.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ILLEGAL DRUGS 
Illegal drugs like cannabis, ecstasy, 
cocaine and heroin can harm your 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you use any of these drugs, 
it is important to talk to your doctor 
or midwife so that they can provide 
you with advice and support to 
help you stop.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can also refer 
you for additional support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
dependent drug users initially need 
drug treatment to stabilise or come 
off drugs to keep the baby safe.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more information, contact 
Narcotics Anonymous (see page 
183) or talk to FRANK, the drugs 
information line, on 0800 77 66 00.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Herbal and homeopathic  
remedies and 
aromatherapy 
Not all ‘natural’ remedies are 
safe in pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Contact the 
Institute for Complementary  
and Natural Medicine to make 
sure that your practitioner  
is qualiﬁed (see page 183).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tell your practitioner that you are 
pregnant, and tell your midwife 
or doctor and pharmacist which 
remedies you are using.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
X-RAYS
X-rays should be avoided in 
pregnancy if possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure that 
your dentist knows you are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
KEEPING ACTIVE
The more active and ﬁt you are 
during pregnancy, the easier it will 
be for you to adapt to your changing 
shape and weight gain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It will also 
help you to cope with labour and to 
get back into shape after the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Keep up your normal daily physical 
activity or exercise (sport, dancing 
or just walking to the shops 
and back) for as long as you 
feel comfortable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t exhaust 
yourself, and remember that you 
may need to slow down as your 
pregnancy progresses or if your 
doctor advises you to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As a general 
rule, you should be able to hold  
a conversation as you exercise.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you become breathless as 
you talk, then you are probably 
exercising too strenuously.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you were inactive before you were 
pregnant, don’t suddenly take up 
strenuous exercise.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you start an 
aerobic exercise programme, begin 
with no more than 15 minutes’ 
continuous exercise, three times per 
week.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Increase this gradually to a 
maximum of 30-minute sessions, 
four times a week.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Inform the 
instructor that you are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Exercise tips
•  Exercise doesn’t have to be 
strenuous to be beneﬁcial.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Make sure that you warm up 
and cool down.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Try to keep active on a daily basis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Half an hour of walking each day  
can be enough.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you cannot 
manage that, any amount is 
better than nothing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Avoid any strenuous exercise 
in hot weather.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Drink plenty of water and 
other ﬂuids.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If you go to exercise classes, 
make sure that your teacher is 
properly qualiﬁed and knows that 
you are pregnant and how far 
your pregnancy has progressed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  You might like to try swimming, 
because the water will support 
your increased weight.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some local 
swimming pools provide aquanatal 
classes with qualiﬁed instructors.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Exercises to avoid
• Lying ﬂat on your back – particularly 
after 16 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The ‘bump’ presses 
on the big blood vessels and can 
make you feel faint.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Contact sports where there 
is a risk of being hit, such as 
kickboxing, judo or squash.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Horse riding, downhill skiing, ice 
hockey, gymnastics and cycling, 
because there is a risk of falling.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Scuba diving, because the 
baby has no protection against 
decompression sickness and  
gas embolism.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Exercising at heights over 
2,500 metres until you have 
acclimatised.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is because  
you and your baby are at risk  
of acute mountain sickness 
(decrease in oxygen).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Exercises for a ﬁtter 
pregnancy 
Try to ﬁt these exercises into your 
daily routine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They will strengthen 
your muscles so that you can carry 
extra weight, make your joints 
stronger, improve your circulation, 
ease backache and generally 
make you feel well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Stomach-strengthening 
exercises 
These strengthen your stomach 
(abdominal) muscles and ease 
backache, which can be a 
problem in pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As your 
baby gets bigger you may 
ﬁnd that the hollow in your 
lower back becomes more 
pronounced, which can lead  
to backache.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Start in a box position (on all 
fours), with your knees under 
your hips, your hands under 
your shoulders, your ﬁngers 
facing forward and your 
stomach muscles lifted so that 
your back is straight.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Pull in your stomach muscles 
and raise your back up 
towards the ceiling, curling 
your trunk and allowing your 
head to relax gently forward.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Don’t let your elbows lock.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Hold for a few seconds then 
slowly return to the box position.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Take care not to hollow your 
back – it should always return  
to a straight or neutral position.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Do this slowly and rhythmically 
10 times, making your muscles 
work hard and moving your back 
carefully.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Only move your back  
as far as you can comfortably.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pelvic tilt exercises
Stand with your shoulders and 
bottom against a wall.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Keep your 
knees soft.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pull your belly button 
towards your spine, so that your 
back ﬂattens against the wall.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Hold for four seconds and release.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Repeat up to 10 times.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pelvic ﬂoor exercises
Pelvic ﬂoor exercises help to 
strengthen the muscles of the  
pelvic ﬂoor, which are placed  
under great strain in pregnancy  
and childbirth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The pelvic ﬂoor consists of layers 
of muscles which stretch like a 
supportive hammock from the 
pubic bone (in front) to the 
base of the backbone.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During 
pregnancy you may ﬁnd that 
you leak urine when you cough 
or strain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is known as 
stress incontinence of urine 
and it can continue after 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
By performing 
pelvic ﬂoor exercises, you 
strengthen the pelvic 
ﬂoor muscles and this 
helps to reduce or 
avoid this problem 
after pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It 
is important to do 
them even if you 
are young and 
not suffering 
from stress 
incontinence  
now.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Close up your back passage 
as if trying to prevent a bowel 
movement.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  At the same time, draw in your 
vagina as if you are gripping  
a tampon, and your urethra  
as if to stop the ﬂow of urine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  First do this exercise quickly – 
tightening and releasing the 
muscles straight away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Then do it slowly, holding the 
contractions for as long as you 
can before you relax.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Try to do three sets of eight 
squeezes every day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To help you 
remember, you could do them 
once at each meal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As well as these exercises, you  
will also need to practise tightening 
up the pelvic ﬂoor before and 
during coughing and sneezing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your midwife or doctor  
about these exercises.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your local maternity  
unit should run  
classes where 
a specialist 
physiotherapist 
attends.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can 
instruct you 
in groups or 
individually.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Feel free to 
ask them 
for advice 
and help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Foot exercises
Foot exercises can be done sitting 
or standing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They improve blood 
circulation, reduce swelling in the 
ankles and prevent cramp in the  
calf muscles.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Bend and stretch your foot 
vigorously up and down 30 times.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Rotate your foot eight times 
one way and eight times the  
other way.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Repeat with the other foot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To protect your back
•  Sit up straight with your bottom 
against the back of your chair.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tuck a small cushion behind your 
waist if you wish.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  When you pick something up, 
bend your knees, not your back.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Try to stand tall.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
INFECTIONS
Rubella
If you catch rubella (or German 
measles) in the ﬁrst four months 
of pregnancy it can seriously affect 
your baby’s sight and hearing and 
cause brain and heart defects.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All 
children are now offered a vaccine 
against rubella through the MMR 
immunisation at 13 months and a 
second immunisation before they 
start school.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are not immune and you  
do come into contact with rubella,  
tell your doctor at once.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Blood  
tests will show whether you have 
been infected.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sexually transmitted 
infections
Sexually transmitted infections 
(STIs) are on the increase.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The most 
common is chlamydia.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Up to 70% 
of women and 50% of men who 
have an STI show no symptoms, so 
you may not know if you have one.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, many STIs can affect your 
baby’s health during pregnancy and 
after birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have any reason 
to believe that you or your partner 
has an STI, you should go for a 
check-up as soon as you can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
can ask your GP or midwife, or go 
to a genitourinary medicine (GUM) 
or sexual health clinic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be 
guaranteed strict conﬁdentiality.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
can ﬁnd your nearest GUM clinic or 
sexual health clinic in your phone  
book listed under the name  
of your primary care trust or at  
www.nhsdirect.nhs.uk or you can 
call the Sexual Health Helpline free 
on 0800 567 123.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are under 25, you can 
visit a Brook centre to get free, 
conﬁdential advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To ﬁnd your 
nearest centre, visit www.brook.org.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
uk or call the Ask Brook national 
helpline on 0808 802 1234.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can contact the National 
Chlamydia Screening Programme 
for a free, conﬁdential test.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Visit  
www.chlamydiascreening.nhs.uk 
HIV and AIDS
You will be offered a conﬁdential 
HIV test as part of your routine 
antenatal care (see page 47).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your doctor or midwife will discuss, 
the test with you, and counselling 
will be available if the result is 
positive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also go to a GUM 
clinic for an HIV test and advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Current evidence suggests that 
an HIV positive mother in good 
health and without symptoms 
of the infection is unlikely to be 
adversely affected by pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
HIV positive mothers can pass 
on the virus through breastmilk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, it is possible to reduce the 
risk of transmitting HIV to your baby 
during pregnancy and after birth 
(see box on page 47).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are HIV positive, talk to your 
doctor about your own health and 
the options open to you, or contact 
the organisations listed on page 185 
for advice and counselling.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

For more information, read 
the information on screening 
tests in Chapter 4 or go to

text:
Hepatitis B
Hepatitis B is a virus that infects the 
liver.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many people with hepatitis B, 
will have no signs of illness, but 
they might infect others.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
have hepatitis B, or are infected 
during pregnancy, you can pass 
the infection to your baby at birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be offered a blood test for 
hepatitis B as part of your antenatal 
care (see page 47).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies who 
are at risk should be immunised 
at birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is 90–95% effective 
in preventing them from getting 
hepatitis B and developing long-
term infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The ﬁrst dose is given 
within 24 hours of birth and two 
more doses are given at one and 
two months, with a booster dose 
at 12 months.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A few babies may 
also need an injection of hepatitis 
B immunoglobulin soon after birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby will be tested for  
hepatitis B infection at 12 months.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Any babies who have become 
infected should be referred for 
specialist assessment and follow-up.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Hepatitis C
Hepatitis C is a virus that infects the 
liver.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many people with hepatitis C  
may have no symptoms and be 
unaware that they are infected.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If 
you have hepatitis C, you might pass 
the infection to your baby, although 
the risk is much lower than with 
hepatitis B or HIV.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This cannot be 
prevented at present.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby can 
be tested for hepatitis C.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If they are 
infected, they can be referred for 
specialist assessment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Herpes 
Genital herpes infection can be 
caught through genital contact with 
an infected person or from oral sex 
with someone who has oral herpes 
(cold sores) and can be dangerous 
for a newborn baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Initial infection 
causes very painful blisters or 
ulcers on the genitals.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Less severe 
attacks usually occur for some years 
afterwards.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you or your partner 
are infected, use condoms or avoid 
sex during an attack.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Avoid oral 
sex if either of you have cold sores 
or active genital herpes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tell your 
doctor or midwife if either you  
or your partner have recurring 
herpes or develop the symptoms 
described above.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your ﬁrst 
infection occurs in pregnancy, there 
is treatment available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your ﬁrst 
infection occurs towards the end  
of your pregnancy or during 
labour, a caesarean section may  
be recommended to reduce the  
risk of transmission to your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Chickenpox 
Around 95% of women are 
immune to chickenpox.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
have not had it and you come 
into contact with someone who 
has it, speak to your GP, midwife 
or obstetrician at once.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A blood 
test will establish whether you are 
immune.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Chickenpox infection in 
pregnancy can be dangerous for 
both mother and baby, so seek 
advice as soon as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Toxoplasmosis
This infection can damage 
your baby if you catch it during 
pregnancy, so take precautions  
(see page 38).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most women  
have already had the infection 
before pregnancy and will be 
immune.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you feel you may 
have been at risk, talk to your GP, 
midwife or obstetrician.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you do 
catch toxoplasmosis while you are 
pregnant, you can get treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Parvovirus B19 
(slapped cheek disease)
Parvovirus B19 infection is  
common in children and causes  
a characteristic red rash on the 
face, so it is often called ‘slapped 
cheek disease’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
60% of women are immune to 
this infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, parvovirus 
B19 is very infectious and can be 
harmful to your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you come 
into contact with someone who 
is infected you should talk to your 
doctor, who can check whether 
you are immune through a blood 
test.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In most cases, the baby is not 
affected when a pregnant woman 
is infected with parvovirus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can get infected  
with HIV, hepatitis B,  
or hepatitis C if you: 
• have sex with someone who 
is infected without using a 
condom
• use injectable drugs and share 
equipment with an infected 
person.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may have already been 
infected with hepatitis B if 
you were born or spent your 
childhood outside the UK in 
a country where hepatitis B 
is common.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
(You may have 
acquired the infection at birth.)
You may have been 
infected with hepatitis 
C if you:
• received a blood transfusion 
in the UK prior to September 
1991, or blood products prior  
to 1986
• received medical or dental 
treatment in countries  
where hepatitis C is common 
and the infection is not 
controlled properly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf
