text:
Group B streptococcus
Group B streptococcus (GBS) is a 
bacterium carried by up to 30% of 
people which causes no harm or 
symptoms.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In women it is found in 
the intestine and vagina and causes 
no problem in most pregnancies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In a very small number it infects  
the baby, usually just before or during 
labour, leading to serious illness.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have already had a baby 
who had group B streptococcal 
infection, you should be offered 
antibiotics during labour to reduce 
the chances of your new baby 
getting the infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have 
had a group B streptococcal urinary 
tract infection with GBS (cystitis) 
during the pregnancy, you should 
also be offered antibiotics in  
labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Group B streptococcal 
infection of the baby is more likely 
if your labour is premature, your 
waters break early, you have a  
fever during labour or you currently 
carry GBS.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or doctor 
will assess whether you need  
antibiotics during labour to protect 
your baby from being infected.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is possible to be tested for GBS late 
in pregnancy if you have concerns.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Talk to your doctor or midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Infections transmitted 
by animals
Cats
Cats’ faeces can contain 
an organism which causes 
toxoplasmosis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Avoid emptying cat 
litter trays while you are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If 
no one else can do it, use disposable 
rubber gloves.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Trays should be 
cleaned daily and ﬁlled with boiling 
water for ﬁve minutes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Avoid close contact with sick cats 
and wear gloves when gardening 
– even if you don’t have a cat – in 
case the soil is contaminated with 
faeces.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Wash your hands and gloves 
after gardening.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you do come 
into contact with cat faeces, make 
sure that you wash your hands 
thoroughly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Follow the general 
hygiene rules under ‘Preparing food’ 
(page 26).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sheep
Lambs and sheep can be a source 
of an organism called Chlamydia 
psittaci, which is known to cause 
miscarriage in ewes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They also 
carry toxoplasma.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Avoid lambing or 
milking ewes and all contact with 
newborn lambs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you experience 
ﬂu-like symptoms after coming into 
contact with sheep, tell your doctor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pigs
Research is going on to see if pigs 
can be a source of hepatitis E 
infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This infection is dangerous 
in pregnant women, so avoid 
contact with pigs and pig faeces.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is no risk of hepatitis E from 
eating cooked pork products.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
INHERITED 
CONDITIONS
Some diseases or conditions are 
inherited from one or both parents.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These include cystic ﬁbrosis, 
haemophilia, muscular dystrophy, 
sickle cell disorders and thalassaemia.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you, your baby’s father or any 
of your relatives has an inherited 
condition or if you already have a 
baby with a disability, talk to your 
doctor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be able to have tests 
early in pregnancy to check whether 
your baby is at risk or affected (see 
page 49).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your GP or midwife 
to refer you to a genetic counsellor 
(a specialist in inherited diseases) for 
advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ideally, you should do this 
before you get pregnant or in the 
early weeks of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WORK HAZARDS
If you work with chemicals, lead 
or X-rays, or in a job with a lot of 
lifting, you may be risking your 
health and the health of your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have any worries about this, 
you should talk to your doctor, 
midwife, occupational health  
nurse, union representative or 
personnel department.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it is a known and recognised risk, 
it may be illegal for you to continue, 
and your employer must offer you 
suitable alternative work on the same 
terms and conditions as your original 
job.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If no safe alternative is available, 
your employer should suspend you 
on full pay (give you paid leave) for  
as long as necessary to avoid the risk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your employer fails to pay you 
during your suspension, you can 
bring a claim in an employment 
tribunal (within three months).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will not affect your maternity pay 
and leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: See also pages 168–169.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Coping at work
You might get extremely tired – 
particularly in the ﬁrst few and last 
few weeks of your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to 
use your lunch break to eat and rest, 
not to do the shopping.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If travelling 
in rush hour is exhausting, ask your 
employer if you can work slightly 
different hours for a while.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t rush home and start another 
job cleaning and cooking.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
have a partner, ask them to take 
over.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are on your own, keep 
housework to a minimum, and  
go to bed early if you can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your rights to antenatal care,  
leave and beneﬁts are set  
out in Chapter 17.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
FLYING AND 
TRAVEL 
Flying is not harmful for you or  
your baby, but some airlines will  
not let you ﬂy towards the end of 
your pregnancy, and you should 
check conditions with them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Long distance travel (longer than 
ﬁve hours) carries a small risk of 
thrombosis (blood clots) in pregnant 
women.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you ﬂy, drink plenty of 
water to stay hydrated and do the 
recommended calf exercises.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can buy a pair of support 
stockings in the pharmacy over  
the counter, which will reduce  
leg swelling.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Before you travel, think about your 
destination.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Could you get medical 
help if you needed it?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Are any 
immunisations needed which might  
be harmful to the pregnancy?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are travelling to Europe,  
make sure that you have a  
European Health Insurance  
Card (formerly known as E111), 
which entitles you to free treatment 
while abroad.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can get this from:
• a post ofﬁce
• by calling 0845 606 2030, or
• from www.ehic.org
Safety on the move 
Road accidents are among the 
most common causes of injury 
in pregnant women.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To protect 
yourself and your baby, always  
wear your seatbelt with the  
diagonal strap across your body 
between your breasts and with  
the lap belt over your upper  
thighs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The straps should lie 
above and below your  
bump, not over it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Computer screens
The most recent research 
shows no evidence of a risk 
from visual display units on 
computer terminals and  
word processors.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

You will be offered a series of appointments with a midwife, 
or sometimes with a doctor (an obstetrician).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They will check that you and 
your baby are well, give you useful information about being pregnant and 
what to expect as well as answering any questions you may have.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As soon as you know you are pregnant, you should get in touch with a 
midwife or your GP to organise your antenatal care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s best to see them 
as early as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Let your midwife know if you have a disability that 
means you have special requirements for your antenatal appointments 
or labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you don’t speak English, let your midwife know and 
arrangements will be made for an interpreter.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is important to tell your 
midwife or doctor if:
• there were any complications 
or infections in a previous 
pregnancy or delivery, such as 
pre-eclampsia or premature birth 
• you are being treated for a 
chronic disease such as diabetes 
or high blood pressure
• you or anyone in your family 
has previously had a baby with 
an abnormality, for example 
spina biﬁ da
• there is a family history of an 
inherited disease, for example 
sickle cell or cystic ﬁ brosis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are working, you have the right to paid time off 
for your antenatal care (see page 170).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ANTENATAL 
APPOINTMENTS
If you are expecting your ﬁ rst 
child, you are likely to have up to 
10 appointments.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have had 
a baby before, you should have 
around seven appointments.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In certain circumstances, for 
example if you have or develop 
a medical condition, you may 
have more appointments.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your appointments may take 
place at your home, in a Children’s 
Centre, in your GP’s surgery or in 
hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be asked to 
go to hospital for your scans.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your antenatal appointments 
should take place in a setting 
where you feel able to discuss 
sensitive problems that may affect 
you (such as domestic violence, 
sexual abuse, mental illness or 
recreational drug use).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Early in your pregnancy your 
midwife or doctor should give 
you information about how many 
appointments you are likely to 
have and when they will happen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should have a chance to discuss 
the schedule with them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The table 
on pages 42–43 gives a brief guide 
to what usually happens at each 
antenatal appointment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you cannot keep an antenatal 
appointment, please let the clinic 
or midwife know and make 
another appointment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
What should happen 
at the appointments
The aim is to check on you and 
your baby’s progress and to 
provide clear information and 
explanations about your care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At each appointment you should 
have the chance to ask questions 
and discuss any concerns or issues 
with your midwife or doctor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Each appointment should have 
a speciﬁ c purpose.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will need 
longer appointments early in 
pregnancy to allow plenty of time 
for your midwife or doctor to 
assess you, discuss your care and 
give you information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Wherever 
possible, the appointments 
should include any routine tests.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Information 
An important part of antenatal 
care is getting information that 
will help you to make informed 
choices about your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or doctor should 
give you information in writing 
or some other form that you 
can easily use and understand.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or doctor should 
provide you with information 
in an appropriate format if you:
• have a physical, learning or 
sensory disability
• do not speak or read English.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may have lots of things 
you want to ask the midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s a good idea to write your 
questions down, so you 
don’t forget.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
EARLY ANTENATAL 
APPOINTMENTS
In early pregnancy (up until 20–24 
weeks), your antenatal appointments 
will take longer than those in mid- 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is because your 
midwife or doctor will need time to 
assess you and your baby, discuss 
your care and give you information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At each appointment you should 
have the chance to ask questions 
and discuss any concerns or issues.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your ﬁrst appointment 
with your midwife  
or GP
As soon as you think you are 
pregnant, you should make an 
appointment to see your midwife 
or GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The earlier you do 
this, the better.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At this 
appointment you will 
be given information 
about: 
•  folic acid 
and vitamin D 
supplements
•  nutrition and diet
• food hygiene
•  lifestyle factors that 
may affect your health or the 
health of your baby, such as 
smoking, recreational drug use 
and alcohol consumption
• antenatal screening tests 
(see page 49 for more about  
these tests).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your booking 
appointment 
Most women have their ‘booking 
appointment’ between the 8th and 
12th week of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can 
take a couple of hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will see 
a midwife and sometimes a doctor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should also be offered an 
ultrasound scan.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should be given information 
about:
• how the baby develops during 
pregnancy
• nutrition and diet
• exercise and pelvic ﬂoor exercises
• antenatal screening tests
• your antenatal care
• breastfeeding, including 
workshops
• antenatal education
• maternity beneﬁts
• planning your labour
• your options for where 
to have your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Weight and height
You will be weighed at the booking 
appointment, but you probably will 
not be weighed regularly during 
your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your height will be 
measured along with your weight 
so that your midwife can calculate 
your BMI (body mass index).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most 
women put on between 10 and 
12.5kg (22–28lbs) in pregnancy, 
most of it after the 20th week.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Much of the extra weight is due to 
the baby growing, but your body 
will also be storing fat ready to 
make breastmilk after the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eating sensibly and taking regular 
exercise can help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See Chapter 3  
for what you should eat and for 
advice about exercise.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In some areas, height, weight 
and BMI are used to produce a 
personalised growth chart for your 
baby’s development.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, other 
areas will use an average growth 
chart instead.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are going to have your baby with  
midwifery care in a midwifery unit,  
in hospital or at home
You will probably see your own midwife for most of your antenatal  
care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be offered a visit at the hospital for an initial assessment 
and perhaps for an ultrasound scan or for special tests.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes  
your midwife may visit you at home.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are going to have your baby in hospital 
Antenatal care varies around the country.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In some areas, the booking 
appointment is at the hospital, then all or most of the remaining 
appointments are with a midwife or GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, if there are 
complications, all appointments will be at the hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In other areas,  
all care is given by a midwife or GP unless there are complications,  
which mean a referral to the hospital antenatal clinic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Questions at the  
booking appointment
You will be asked a lot of 
questions to build up a picture  
of you and your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is so that you are given 
the support you need and any 
risks are spotted early.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will 
probably want to ask a lot of 
questions yourself.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be asked about:
• the date of the ﬁrst day of your 
last period, to help work out 
when your baby is due
• your health
• any previous illnesses and 
operations 
• any previous pregnancies 
or miscarriages 
• your and your baby’s father’s 
origins.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is to ﬁnd out if 
your baby is at risk of certain 
inherited conditions, or if there 
are other factors, such as a 
history of twins 
• your work or your partner’s 
work and what kind of 
accommodation you live in,  
to see if there is anything 
about your circumstances that 
might affect your pregnancy
• how you are feeling and if you 
have been feeling depressed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At the end of your booking 
appointment, you should 
understand the plan of care for 
your pregnancy and have your 
hand-held notes to carry with  
you at all times.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your booking appointment  
is an opportunity to tell your 
midwife or doctor if you are  
in a vulnerable situation or  
if you need extra support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This could be because of 
domestic violence, sexual abuse  
or female genital mutilation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
4
ANTENATAL CARE
45
REGULAR CHECKS 
AT EVERY 
ANTENATAL 
APPOINTMENT
Your urine and blood pressure 
will be checked at every antenatal 
appointment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Urine
Your urine is checked for a number 
of things, including protein or 
‘albumin’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this is in your urine, 
it may mean that you have an 
infection that needs to be treated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may also be a sign of pre-
eclampsia (see ‘High blood pressure 
and pre-eclampsia’ on page 67).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Blood pressure
A rise in blood pressure later in 
pregnancy could be a sign of pre-
eclampsia (see page 67).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is very 
common for your blood pressure 
to be lower in the middle of your 
pregnancy than at other times.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is not a problem, but may  
make you feel light-headed if you 
get up quickly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your midwife 
if you are concerned.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
APPOINTMENTS 
IN LATER 
PREGNANCY 
From 20–24 weeks, your antenatal 
appointments will become more 
frequent.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your pregnancy is 
uncomplicated and you are well,  
you may not be seen as often.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your later appointments are usually 
quite short.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or  
doctor will:
• check your urine, blood pressure, 
and sometimes your weight 
• feel your uterus to check your 
baby’s position
• measure your uterus to check 
your baby’s growth
• listen to your baby’s heartbeat 
if you want them to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also ask questions or  
talk about anything that is  
worrying you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should be  
given information about: 
• your plan of birth
• how to prepare for labour 
and birth
• how to tell if you are in 
active labour
• induction of labour if your 
baby is late
• the ‘baby blues’ and postnatal 
depression
• feeding your baby
• screening tests for newborn 
babies
• looking after yourself and 
your new baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Checking your baby’s 
development and  
well-being
At each antenatal appointment 
from 24 weeks, your midwife or 
doctor should check your baby’s 
growth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To do this, they will 
measure the distance from the top 
of your uterus to your pubic bone.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The measurement will be recorded 
in your notes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the last weeks of pregnancy,  
you may also be asked to keep  
track of your baby’s movements.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby’s movements  
become less frequent, slow down 
or stop, contact your midwife or 
doctor immediately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be offered an ultrasound 
scan if your midwife or doctor  
has any concerns about your  
baby’s growth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
BLOOD TESTS
As part of your antenatal care, 
you will be offered a number of 
blood tests.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some are offered to all 
women and some are only offered 
if it is thought that you are at risk 
of a particular infection or inherited 
condition.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All of the tests are done 
to help make your pregnancy safer 
or to check that your baby is healthy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your midwife or doctor 
so that you understand why the 
blood tests are being offered and 
so that you can make an informed 
choice about whether or not you 
want them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or doctor 
should also give you information 
about the tests.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Below is an outline 
of all the tests that can be offered.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your blood group and 
rhesus factor
Your blood will be tested to check 
your blood group and to see 
whether you are rhesus negative or 
positive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women are rhesus 
negative.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is usually not a worry 
for a ﬁrst pregnancy but it may 
affect the next child.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
People who are rhesus positive have 
a substance known as D antigen on 
the surface of their red blood cells.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Rhesus negative people do not.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A woman who is rhesus negative  
can carry a baby who is rhesus 
positive if the baby’s father is 
rhesus positive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During pregnancy 
or birth, small amounts of the 
baby’s blood can enter the mother’s 
bloodstream.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can cause the 
mother to produce antibodies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
usually doesn’t affect the existing 
pregnancy, but the woman becomes 
‘sensitised’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This means that if she 
gets pregnant with another rhesus 
positive baby, the immune response 
will be quicker and much greater.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The antibodies produced by the 
46
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
mother can cross the placenta and 
attach to the D antigen on her 
baby’s red blood cells.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can be 
harmful to the baby as it may result 
in a condition called haemolytic 
disease of the newborn, which can 
lead to anaemia and jaundice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Prevention of  
rhesus disease 
Anti-D injections prevent  
rhesus negative women 
producing antibodies against 
the baby and reduce the risk 
of a rhesus negative woman 
becoming sensitised.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rhesus negative mothers  
who are not sensitised are 
offered anti-D injections at  
28 and 34 weeks as well as  
after the birth of their baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is quite safe for both the 
mother and her baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Anaemia
Anaemia makes you tired and  
less able to cope with  
any loss of blood when 
you give birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If tests 
show you are anaemic, 
you will probably be given 
iron and folic acid.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Immunity to rubella 
(German measles)
If you get rubella in early pregnancy, 
it can seriously damage your unborn 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or doctor will 
talk to you about what happens  
if your test results show low or  
no immunity.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be offered  
a rubella immunisation after  
your baby is born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more 
information about rubella, visit 
www.immunisation.nhs.uk
Syphilis
You will be tested for this sexually 
transmitted infection because if  
left untreated, it can lead to 
miscarriage and stillbirth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Hepatitis B
This is a virus that can cause serious 
liver disease.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have the virus 
or are infected during pregnancy, it 
may infect your baby (see page 37).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby will not usually be ill but 
has a high chance of developing 
long-term infection and serious 
liver disease later in life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby 
can start a course of immunisation 
at birth to help prevent infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have hepatitis B, you will be 
referred to a specialist.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Hepatitis C
This virus can cause serious liver 
disease and there is a small risk that it 
may be passed to your baby if you are 
infected.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This cannot be prevented at 
present.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tests for hepatitis C are not 
usually offered routinely as part of 
antenatal care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you think you may 
be at risk (see page 37), talk to your 
midwife or GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can arrange a 
test.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are infected, your baby 
can be tested within a few days of 
birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have hepatitis C, you  
will be referred to a specialist.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
HIV 
This is the virus that causes AIDS.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are infected you can pass 
the infection to your baby during 
pregnancy, at delivery, or after birth by 
breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As part of your routine 
antenatal care, you will be offered a 
conﬁdential test for HIV infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If 
you are HIV positive, both you and 
your baby can have treatment and 
care that reduce the risk of your baby 
becoming infected.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your test result is 
negative, the fact that you had the test 
as part of your antenatal care should 
not affect your ability to get insurance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are HIV positive
If you are HIV positive, your 
doctor will need to discuss 
the management of your 
pregnancy and delivery 
with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• There is a one in four chance 
of your baby being infected 
if you and your baby don’t 
have treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Treatment can signiﬁcantly 
reduce the risk of transmitting 
HIV from you to your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
20% of HIV-infected babies 
develop AIDS or die within 
the ﬁrst year of life, so it’s 
important to reduce the risk 
of transmission.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your labour will be managed 
to reduce the risk of infection 
to your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This may 
include an elective caesarean 
delivery (see page 98).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your baby will be tested for 
HIV at birth and at intervals 
for up to two years.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your 
baby is found to be infected 
with HIV, paediatricians 
will be able to anticipate 
certain illnesses that occur 
in infected babies, and treat 
them early.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All babies born 
to HIV positive mothers will 
appear to be HIV positive 
at birth, because they 
have antibodies from their 
mother’s infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the 
baby is not affected, the 
test will later become 
negative because the 
antibodies will disappear.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You will be advised not to 
breastfeed because HIV  
can be transmitted to your 
baby in this way.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
If you think that you are at risk of getting HIV or know you are  
HIV positive, talk to your midwife or doctor about HIV testing  
and counselling.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also get free conﬁdential advice from  
the National AIDS Helpline on 0800 567 123 or you can talk in 
conﬁdence to someone at Positively Women (see page 185).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sickle cell and 
thalassaemia disorders
Sickle cell and thalassaemia 
disorders are inherited blood 
conditions that mainly affect the 
way oxygen is carried around 
the body.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be offered a 
blood test early in pregnancy 
for thalassaemia and asked for 
information about your and 
your baby’s father’s family origin 
to decide if any other tests are 
required.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The information you give 
will help your midwife or doctor to 
offer the correct tests and will also 
help to give you the correct results 
of the test.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is very important 
that you tell the midwife, doctor  
or person doing the test if you 
think you or your baby’s father 
have an ancestor who came from 
outside northern Europe (for 
example, someone who is Italian, 
Maltese, Portuguese, Spanish, 
Indian, Chinese, African or  
African-Caribbean).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Healthy people can be carriers of 
sickle cell or thalassaemia without 
knowing it and can pass it on to 
their children.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s possible for you or 
your baby’s father to be carriers of 
these disorders without it affecting 
your baby at all.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Carriers cannot 
develop the disorders, but if both 
of you are carriers there is a risk 
that your baby could have a sickle 
cell or thalassaemia disorder.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your 
midwife or doctor will discuss 
the implications for your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For further information contact 
the Sickle Cell Society (www.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
sicklecellsociety.org) or the UK 
Thalassaemia Society (www.ukts.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: org) for more details.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cystic ﬁbrosis
Cystic ﬁbrosis is an inherited disease 
that affects vital organs in the body, 
especially the lungs and digestive 
system, by clogging them with thick 
sticky mucus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The sweat glands are 
usually also affected.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The disease 
is inherited and both parents must 
be carriers of the gene variation for 
their baby to be born with cystic 
ﬁbrosis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Testing is offered if there  
is a family history of cystic ﬁbrosis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tay-Sachs disease
Testing for Tay-Sachs disease should 
be offered if you or your partner 
is of Ashkenazi Jewish origin and 
if you consider yourself or your 
partner to be at risk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cervical cancer
Cervical smears detect early changes 
in the cervix (the neck of the uterus), 
which could later lead to cancer if 
left untreated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Routine smears are 
only offered to women over 25.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are due to have a cervical 
smear (if you have not had one 
in the last three years), you will 
probably be told to wait until  
three months after your baby is 
born unless you have a history  
of abnormal smears.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is  
based on guidance by the NHS 
cervical screening programme.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more information, go to  
www.cancerscreening.nhs.uk 
Herpes
If you, or your partner, have ever 
had genital herpes, or you get your 
ﬁrst attack of genital blisters 
or ulcers during 
your pregnancy, 
let your midwife 
or doctor know.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Herpes can be 
dangerous for 
your newborn 
baby and it may 
need treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ULTRASOUND 
SCANS
Most hospitals will offer women 
at least two ultrasound scans 
during their pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The ﬁrst 
is usually around eight to 14 
weeks and is sometimes called 
the dating scan because it can 
help to determine when the 
baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The second scan 
usually takes place between 18 
and 20 weeks and is called the 
anomaly scan because it checks 
for structural abnormalities.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ultrasound scans use sound 
waves to build up a picture  
of your baby in your uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They are completely painless, 
have no known serious side 
effects on mothers or their 
babies, and may be carried out 
for medical need at any stage  
of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you  
have any concerns  
about having a scan,  
talk it over with  
your midwife, GP  
or obstetrician.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: What do scans tell us?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Check your baby’s measurements.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This gives a better idea of when 
your baby was conceived and 
when it is likely to be born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can be useful if you are 
unsure about the date of your  
last period or if your menstrual 
cycle is long, short or irregular.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your due date may be adjusted 
depending on the ultrasound 
measurements.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Check whether you are carrying 
more than one baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Detect some abnormalities, 
particularly in your baby’s head 
or spine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Show the position of your 
baby and your placenta.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes a caesarean section  
is recommended – for example  
if your placenta is low lying in  
late pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Check that your baby is growing 
and developing as expected  
(this is particularly important  
if you are carrying twins  
or more).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At the scan
You may be asked to drink a lot of 
ﬂuid before you have the scan.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A full 
bladder pushes your uterus up and 
this gives a better picture.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You then 
lie on your back and some jelly is put 
on your abdomen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
An instrument 
is passed backwards and forwards 
over your skin and high-frequency 
sound is beamed through your 
abdomen to the uterus and pelvis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The sound is reﬂected back and 
creates a picture that is shown on  
a screen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be very exciting  
to see a picture of your own baby 
moving about inside you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask for the picture to be explained 
to you if you cannot make it out.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It should be possible for your 
partner to come with you and 
see the scan.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Although scans are 
medical procedures, many couples 
feel that they help to make the 
baby real for them both.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask if 
it’s possible to have a copy of the 
picture.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There may be a small 
charge for this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fetal movement
You will usually start feeling  
some movements between 16  
and 22 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Later in pregnancy 
your baby will develop its own 
pattern of movements – which  
you will soon get to know.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These movements will range 
from kicks and jerks to rolls and 
ripples and you should feel them 
every day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At each antenatal 
appointment, your midwife will 
talk to you about the pattern of 
movements.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A change, especially 
a reduction in movements, may 
be a warning sign that your 
baby needs further tests.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to 
become familiar with your baby’s 
typical daily pattern and contact 
your midwife or maternity unit 
immediately if you feel that the 
movements have changed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
TESTS TO DETECT 
ABNORMALITIES 
You will be offered screening 
tests that can detect structural 
abnormalities like spina biﬁda, which 
is a defect in the development of 
the spine, or some chromosomal 
disorders like Down’s syndrome, 
which is caused by an abnormal 
number of chromosomes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Different 
maternity services may use different 
tests, but all tests carried out in the 
NHS will meet national standards.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Discuss the tests and what they 
mean with your midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Screening tests can:
• reassure you that your baby 
has no detected structural 
abnormalities
• provide you with an opportunity 
to see your baby during the scan
• give you time to prepare for the 
arrival of a baby with special needs 
• allow you to consider the 
termination of an affected baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tests can also provide valuable 
information for your care during 
the pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, no test 
can guarantee that your baby will 
be born without an abnormality.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
No test is 100% accurate and some 
abnormalities may remain undetected.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Deciding whether to 
have tests
You may not want to have a 
screening test if you think that you 
would continue your pregnancy 
whatever the results.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you do have 
a screening test and it suggests an 
increased chance of a chromosomal 
abnormality, you will be offered 
diagnostic tests, which will give 
a more deﬁnite diagnosis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These 
diagnostic tests carry a small risk 
of miscarriage, so you may decide 
not to have them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Discussing the 
issues with your partner, midwife, 
doctor and friends may help you in 
deciding what is right for you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Haemophilia and 
muscular dystrophy
Some disorders, such as 
haemophilia and muscular 
dystrophy, are only found in boys 
(although girls may carry the 
disorder in their chromosomes 
and pass it on to their sons).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tell 
your midwife or doctor if these or 
other genetic disorders run in your 
family, as it may then be important 
to know your baby’s sex.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
TESTS FOR DOWN’S 
SYNDROME AND 
OTHER GENETIC 
DISORDERS
These tests are offered to all pregnant 
women.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There are different ways  
of carrying out screening.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Combined screening
Combined screening involves a 
blood test and an ultrasound scan.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All women should have dating and 
nuchal translucency scans between 
eight and 14 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These scans 
may be combined.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The blood test 
measures two pregnancy-associated 
blood chemicals.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At the scan, the 
radiographer measures the thickness 
of the nuchal translucency at the 
back of your baby’s neck.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
information is used to calculate your 
individual statistical chance of having 
a baby with Down’s syndrome.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This nuchal translucency scan can  
be used in multiple pregnancies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more information about 
screening for anomalies, visit www.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
fetalanomaly.screening.nhs.uk/
publicationsandleaﬂets
Serum screening
Serum screening is a blood test 
that screens for Down’s syndrome, 
usually at about 16 weeks into your 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It measures three or 
four pregnancy-associated blood 
chemicals to give your individual 
statistical chance of having a 
baby with Down’s syndrome.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Serum screening on its own is not 
recommended for twin and other 
multiple pregnancies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Screening results
Some maternity services give the 
result as ‘lower risk/screen negative’ 
or ‘higher risk/screen positive’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the screening test shows the risk  
of the baby having Down’s syndrome 
is lower than the recommended 
national cut-off, this is known as 
having a ‘low-risk’ result.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A low-risk 
result means that you are at a  
low-risk of having a baby with 
Down’s syndrome, but it does not 
mean there is no risk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the result shows the risk of the 
baby having Down’s syndrome is 
greater than the recommended 
national cut-off, this is known as an 
‘increased risk’ or ‘higher risk’ result.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
An increased risk means you will be 
offered diagnostic test but it does 
not mean that your baby deﬁnitely 
has the condition.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The diagnostic 
procedure you will be offered is 
either chorionic villus sampling (CVS) 
(see next page) or amniocentesis to 
give you a deﬁnite answer about 
Down’s syndrome.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or 
doctor will explain the result to you 
and help you decided whether you 
want to have further tests.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More information
50

source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
DIAGNOSTIC TESTS 
FOR DOWN’S 
SYNDROME AND 
OTHER GENETIC 
DISORDERS
These tests will give you a deﬁnite 
diagnosis of Down’s syndrome and 
sometimes other abnormalities.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or doctor will explain 
what is involved and you will usually 
be offered counselling.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Chorionic villus 
sampling (CVS)
CVS can be carried out at around 
11 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can give you an earlier 
diagnosis if you are at risk of having 
a child with an inherited disorder, 
such as cystic ﬁbrosis, sickle cell 
disorder, thalassaemia or muscular 
dystrophy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The test takes 10 to 20 minutes  
and may be a little uncomfortable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Using ultrasound as a guide, a 
ﬁne needle is passed through the 
abdomen into the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes a ﬁne tube is passed 
through the vagina and cervix 
into the uterus instead.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A tiny 
piece of the developing placenta, 
known as chorionic tissue, is taken.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The chromosomes in the cells of 
this tissue are examined.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As with 
amniocentesis, a rapid result can be 
obtained, but if all the chromosomes 
are going to be checked the results 
may take up to two weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The risks
CVS has a 1–2% risk of miscarriage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is slightly higher than 
amniocentesis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
IF A TEST DETECTS 
AN ABNORMALITY
It is always difﬁcult when you are 
told there is something wrong  
with your baby, especially if you  
are faced with a painful decision 
about the future of your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or doctor will make 
sure you see the appropriate health 
professionals to help you get all the 
information and support you need 
so you can make the choices that 
are right for you and your family.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Amniocentesis
Amniocentesis can be offered 
from 15 weeks of pregnancy if:
• you have a positive or higher 
risk Down’s syndrome screening 
result
• an ultrasound scan detects an 
abnormality that is associated  
with a genetic disorder
•�your past history or family 
history suggests that there may 
be a risk of your baby having 
a genetic or chromosomal 
disorder such as Down’s 
syndrome, sickle cell disorder  
or thalassaemia.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
What happens
Using ultrasound as a guide,  
a ﬁne needle is passed through 
the wall of the abdomen 
into the amniotic ﬂuid that 
surrounds your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Within 
the ﬂuid are cells that contain 
the same chromosomes as 
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A small sample of 
this ﬂuid is drawn off and sent 
to a laboratory for testing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most women feel only mild 
discomfort.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Usually, the ﬂuid will be tested 
for Down’s syndrome and other 
serious syndromes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The  
results should be available 
within three working days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If all the chromosomes have to 
be looked at, it can take up to 
three weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This test will reveal 
your baby’s sex, so tell your 
midwife or doctor whether, at 
this stage, you want to know  
if your baby is a boy or a girl.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The risks
Amniocentesis has a 0.5–1% 
risk of miscarriage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At most, 
one test in 100 will result in 
pregnancy loss.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When deciding 
whether or not to go ahead 
with this test, try to balance 
the risk of miscarriage against 
the value of the result to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
Antenatal Results and Choices (ARC) (see page 186) helps parents 
with all issues associated with antenatal testing and its implications.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can give you more information or put you in touch with parents 
who decided to continue with a pregnancy in which an abnormality 
had been detected or those who decided to have a termination.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Go to www.arc-uk.org for more information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: had been detected or those who decided to have a termination.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Go to www.arc-uk.org for more information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
MAKING THE MOST OF  
ANTENATAL CARE
Having regular antenatal care is important for your health 
and the health of your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most antenatal services are  
now provided in easily accessible community settings.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Waiting times in clinics can vary, and this can be particularly 
difﬁcult if you have young children with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to plan 
ahead to make your visits easier.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Here are some suggestions:
• In some clinics you can buy refreshments.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If not, take 
a snack with you if you are likely to get hungry.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Write a list of questions you want to ask 
and take it with you to remind you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure you get answers to your 
questions or the opportunity to 
discuss any worries.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If your partner is free, they may 
be able to go with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can  
help them feel more involved  
in the pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

While you are pregnant you should

Many mothers would like to be able 
to get to know the people who 
care for them during pregnancy and 
the birth of their baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The NHS is 
working to achieve this but you may 
still ﬁnd that you see a number of 
different carers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The professionals 
you see should introduce themselves 
and explain who they are, 
but if they forget, 
don’t hesitate to 
ask.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may help 
to make a note 
of who you 
have seen and 
what they have said 
in case you need to 
discuss any point 
later on.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The people you are most 
likely to meet are listed 
below
• A midwife is specially trained 
to care for mothers and babies 
throughout pregnancy and labour 
and after the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Midwives 
provide care for the majority of 
women at home or in hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Increasingly, midwives will be 
working both in hospitals and in 
the community, so that the same 
midwife can provide antenatal 
care and be present at the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should know the name of the 
midwife who is responsible for 
your care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A midwife will look after you 
during labour and, if everything is 
straightforward, will deliver your 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If any complications develop 
during your pregnancy or delivery, 
you will also see a doctor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
may also meet student midwives 
and student doctors.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After the 
birth, you and your baby will 
be cared for by midwives and 
maternity support workers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• An obstetrician is a 
doctor specialising in the care  
of women during pregnancy  
and labour and after the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or GP will refer 
you for an appointment with 
an obstetrician if they have 
a particular concern, such 
as previous complications in 
pregnancy or chronic illness.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

You can request to see an 
obstetrician if you have any 
particular concerns.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ANTENATAL 
EDUCATION
Antenatal education (sometimes 
called antenatal classes) can help 
to prepare you for your baby’s birth 
as well as for looking after and 
feeding your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can help you 
to keep yourself ﬁt and well during 
pregnancy and give you conﬁdence 
as well as information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can ﬁnd 
out about arrangements for labour 
and birth and the sorts of choices 
available to you (see page 74 for 
information about birth plans).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also meet some of the 
people who will look after you 
during labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be able to talk over any 
worries and discuss your plans,  
not just with professionals but  
with other women and their 
partners as well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Classes are also 
a really good way to make friends 
with other parents expecting babies 
at around the same time as you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These friendships often help you 
through the ﬁrst few months  
with a baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Classes are usually 
informal and fun.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Choosing an  
antenatal class
Think about what you hope to gain 
from antenatal classes so that you 
can ﬁnd the sort of class that suits 
you best.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You need to start making 
enquiries early in pregnancy so  
that you can be sure of getting  
a place in the class you choose.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: You can go to more than one class.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your midwife, health visitor or 
GP about what is available in your 
area, or contact the NCT (see next 
page).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Speak to your community 
midwife if you cannot go to classes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The midwife may have DVDs to  
lend you, or you may be able  
to hire or buy one.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The classes
During pregnancy, you may be able 
to go to some introductory classes 
on babycare.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most start about eight 
to 10 weeks before your baby is 
due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are expecting a multiple 
pregnancy, try to start your classes 
at around 24 weeks, because your 
babies are more likely to be born 
earlier.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Classes are normally held once a 
week, either during the day or in 
the evening, for about two hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some classes are for pregnant 
women only.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Others will welcome 
partners or friends, either to all 
the sessions or to some of them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In some areas there are classes for 
women whose ﬁrst language is not 
English, classes for single mothers 
and classes for teenagers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The 
kinds of topics covered in antenatal 
education are:
• health in pregnancy
• exercises to keep you ﬁt during 
pregnancy and help you in labour
• what happens during labour 
and birth
• coping with labour and 
information about different types 
of pain relief
• how to help yourself during 
labour and birth
and fun
relaxed
56
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• relaxation techniques
• how to give birth without any 
intervention, if that is what  
you want
• information on different kinds 
of birth and intervention
• caring for your baby, 
including feeding
• your health after the birth
• ‘refresher classes’ for those 
who have already had a baby
• emotions during pregnancy, birth 
and the early postnatal period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some classes will try to cover  
all of these topics.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Others will 
concentrate on certain aspects,  
such as exercises and relaxation  
or caring for your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The number of different antenatal 
classes available varies from  
place to place.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The NCT
The NCT (also known as  
the National Childbirth Trust) 
runs a range of classes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The groups tend to be smaller 
and may go into more depth, 
often allowing time for 
discussion and for practising 
physical skills.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For details of 
antenatal courses, along with 
information on local support 
groups, visit www.nct.org.uk

(sometimes called 
Sure Start Children’s

Children’s Centres also support 
families with children under the 
age of ﬁve.

They can provide:
• easy access to antenatal care
• health services
• parenting and family support
• drop-in sessions
• outreach services
• early education and childcare, 
and
• links to training and 
employment opportunities.

For more information on

CONDITIONS AND 
PROBLEMS 
IN PREGNANCY
58
Common minor problems 
58
More serious problems 
67
Your body goes through a lot of changes during pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes these changes 
can cause you discomfort or irritation, and you may be worried about what is happening 
to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is usually nothing to worry about, but you should mention anything that 
concerns you to your midwife or doctor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you think that something may be seriously 
wrong, trust your own judgement and get in touch with your midwife or doctor  
straight away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This chapter describes some of the minor and more serious health problems and gives 
advice on how to deal with them and when you should get help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These problems are 
listed in alphabetical order.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
COMMON MINOR 
PROBLEMS
Backache 
As your baby grows, the hollow 
in your lower back may become 
more pronounced, and this can 
also cause backache.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During 
pregnancy, your ligaments 
become softer and stretch  
to prepare you for 
labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can put a 
strain on the joints 
of your lower 
back and pelvis, 
which can cause 
backache.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to avoid backache
•  Avoid lifting heavy objects.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Bend your knees and keep your back 
straight when lifting or picking something 
up from the ﬂoor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Move your feet when turning round to 
avoid twisting your spine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Wear ﬂat shoes that allow your weight 
to be evenly distributed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Work at a surface that is high enough 
so that you don’t stoop.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Try to balance the weight between 
two bags when carrying shopping.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Sit with your back straight and 
well supported.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Make sure you get enough rest 
– particularly later in pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to ease backache
•  A ﬁrm mattress can help to 
prevent and relieve backache.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your mattress is too soft, put 
a piece of hardboard under it 
to make it ﬁrmer.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
If your backache is very painful, 
ask your doctor to refer you to an 
obstetric physiotherapist at your 
hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They will be able to give 
you some advice and may suggest 
some helpful exercises.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Constipation
You may become constipated very 
early in pregnancy because of the 
hormonal changes taking place in 
your body.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to avoid constipation
• Eat foods that are high in 
ﬁbre, like wholemeal breads, 
wholegrain cereals, fruit and 
vegetables, and pulses such as 
beans and lentils.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Exercise regularly to keep your 
muscles toned.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Drink plenty of water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Avoid iron supplements.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your 
doctor whether you can manage 
without them or change to a 
different type.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cramp
Cramp is a sudden, sharp pain, 
usually in your calf muscles or feet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is most common at night, but 
nobody really knows what causes it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to avoid cramp
Regular, gentle exercise in 
pregnancy, particularly ankle and 
leg movements, will improve your 
circulation and may help to  
prevent cramp occurring.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to ease cramp
It usually helps if you pull your  
toes hard up towards your ankle  
or rub the muscle hard.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Feeling faint
You may often feel faint when  
you are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is because  
of hormonal changes taking place  
in your body and happens if your 
brain is not getting enough blood 
and therefore enough oxygen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your oxygen level gets too low, 
you may actually faint.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are most 
likely to feel faint if you stand still 
for too long or get up too quickly 
from a chair or out of a hot bath.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can also happen when you are 
lying on your back.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to avoid feeling faint
•  Try to get up slowly after sitting 
or lying down.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If you feel faint when standing 
still, ﬁnd a seat quickly and the 
feeling should pass.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it doesn’t, 
lie down on your side.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If you feel faint while lying on 
your back, turn on your side.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is advisable not to lie ﬂat on 
your back at any time in later 
pregnancy or during labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Feeling hot 
During pregnancy you are likely  
to feel warmer than normal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This  
is due to hormonal changes and  
to an increase in the blood supply  
to your skin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are also likely to 
sweat more.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to avoid feeling hot
•  Wear loose clothing made of 
natural ﬁbres, as these are more 
absorbent and ‘breathe’ more 
than synthetic ﬁbres.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Keep your room cool.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
could use an electric fan to  
cool it down.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Wash frequently to help you 
to feel fresh.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

59
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Headaches
Some pregnant women ﬁnd they 
get a lot of headaches.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to ease headaches
•  Try and get more regular rest 
and relaxation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Paracetamol in the recommended 
dose is generally considered safe 
for pregnant women but there are 
some painkillers that you should 
avoid.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Speak to your pharmacist, 
nurse, midwife, health visitor or 
GP about how much paracetamol 
you can take and for how long.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
If you often have bad headaches, 
tell your midwife or doctor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Severe 
headaches can be a sign of high 
blood pressure (see page 67).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Incontinence 
Incontinence is a common  
problem.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can affect you during 
and after pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes pregnant women are 
unable to prevent a sudden spurt 
of urine or a small leak when they 
cough, sneeze or laugh, or when 
moving suddenly or just getting up 
from a sitting position.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This may be 
temporary, because the pelvic ﬂoor 
muscles relax slightly to prepare for 
the baby’s delivery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women have more severe 
incontinence and ﬁnd that they 
cannot help wetting themselves.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
In many cases incontinence is 
curable, so if you have got a 
problem talk to your midwife, 
doctor or health visitor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Indigestion and 
heartburn
Indigestion is partly caused by 
hormonal changes and in later 
pregnancy by your growing 
uterus pressing on your stomach.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Heartburn is more than just 
indigestion.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is a strong, burning 
pain in the chest caused by stomach 
acid passing from your stomach into 
the tube leading to your stomach.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is because the valve between 
your stomach and this tube relaxes 
during pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to avoid indigestion
•  Try eating smaller meals 
more often.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Sit up straight when you are 
eating, as this takes the pressure 
off your stomach.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Avoid the foods which affect 
you, e.g.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
fried or highly spiced 
food, but make sure you are still 
eating well (see pages 24–25 for 
information on healthy eating).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to avoid heartburn
•  Heartburn is often brought on by 
lying ﬂat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sleep well propped up 
with plenty of pillows.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Avoid eating and drinking for a 
few hours before you go to bed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Your midwife or GP may 
prescribe an antacid if the 
problem is persistent.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
You could also call the 
conﬁdential Continence 
Foundation helpline on 
0845 345 0165 (9.30am 
to 1pm Mon to Fri) or 
visit www.continence-
foundation.org.uk
60
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to ease heartburn
•  Drink a glass of milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Have one by 
your bed in case you wake with 
heartburn in the night.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Note that you should not take 
antacid tablets before checking 
with your midwife, doctor or 
pharmacist that they are safe for 
you to take.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Itching
Mild itching is common in pregnancy 
because of the increased blood 
supply to the skin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In late pregnancy 
the skin of the abdomen is stretched 
and this may also cause itchiness.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to avoid itching
• Wearing loose clothing may help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You may also want to avoid 
synthetic materials.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Leaking nipples
Leaking nipples are normal and 
usually nothing to worry about.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The leaking milk is colostrum, which 
is the ﬁrst milk your breasts make  
to feed your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
See your midwife or doctor if the 
milk becomes bloodstained.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Nausea and  
morning sickness
Nausea is very common in 
the early weeks of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women feel sick, and 
some are sick.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can happen 
at any time of day – or even  
all day long.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Hormonal changes in the  
ﬁrst three months are 
probably one cause.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Nausea 
usually disappears around  
the 12th to 14th weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be one of the most 
trying problems in early 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It comes at a time when you may be feeling tired and 
emotional, and when many people around you may not realise  
that you are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to avoid nausea and morning sickness
•  If you feel sick ﬁrst thing in the morning, give yourself time to get 
up slowly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If possible, eat something like dry toast or a plain biscuit 
before you get up.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Get plenty of rest and sleep whenever you can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Feeling tired can 
make the sickness worse.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Eat small amounts of food often rather than several large meals, 
but don’t stop eating.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Drink plenty of ﬂuids.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Ask those close to you for extra help and support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Distract yourself as much as you can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Often the nausea gets worse 
the more you think about it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Avoid foods and smells that make you feel worse.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It helps if 
someone else can cook.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If not, go for bland, non-greasy foods, 
such as baked potatoes, pasta and milk puddings, which are 
simple to prepare.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Wear comfortable clothes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tight waistbands can make you 
feel worse.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
If you are being sick all the time and cannot keep anything down, 
tell your midwife or doctor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some pregnant women experience 
severe nausea and vomiting.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This condition is known as  
hyperemesis gravidarum and needs 
specialist treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Nose bleeds
Nose bleeds are quite common 
in pregnancy because of 
hormonal changes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They don’t 
usually last long but can be quite 
heavy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As long as you don’t lose 
a lot of blood, there is nothing 
to worry about.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also 
ﬁnd that your nose gets more 
blocked up than usual.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to stop nose bleeds
•  Sit with your head forward.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Press the sides of your nose 
together between your thumb 
and foreﬁnger, just below the 
bony part, for 10 minutes and 
try not to swallow the blood.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Repeat for a further 10 
minutes if this is unsuccessful.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If the bleeding continues, 
seek medical advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Passing urine often
Needing to pass urine often may 
start in early pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes 
it continues right through 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In later pregnancy it’s  
the result of the baby’s head 
pressing on the bladder.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to reduce the need  
to pass urine
•  If you ﬁnd that you have to get up 
in the night try cutting out drinks 
in the late evening, but make sure 
you keep drinking plenty during 
the day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Later in pregnancy, some women 
ﬁnd it helps to rock backwards 
and forwards while they are on 
the toilet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This lessens the pressure 
of the uterus on the bladder so 
that you can empty it properly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Then you may not need to pass 
water again quite so soon.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
If you have any pain while passing 
water or you pass any blood, you 
may have a urine infection, which 
will need treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Drink plenty 
of water to dilute your urine and 
reduce pain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should contact 
your GP within 24 hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The growing baby will increase 
pressure on your bladder.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
ﬁnd this a problem, you can 
improve the situation by doing 
exercises to tone up your 
pelvic ﬂoor muscles 
(see page 35).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask a midwife or obstetric 
physiotherapist (see pages 54 and 
55) for advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pelvic joint pain 
If during or after your pregnancy 
you have pain in your pelvic joints 
when walking, climbing stairs or 
turning in bed, you could have 
pelvic girdle pain (PGP) or symphysis 
pubis dysfunction (SPD).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is  
a slight misalignment or stiffness of 
your pelvic joints, at either the back 
or front.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It affects up to one in four  
pregnant women to a lesser or 
greater extent.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women have 
minor discomfort, others may have 
much greater immobility.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
Getting diagnosed as early as 
possible can help to minimise 
the pain and avoid long-term 
discomfort.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Treatment usually 
involves gently pressing on or 
moving the affected joint so that  
it works normally again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask a member of your maternity 
team for a referral to a manual 
physiotherapist, osteopath or 
chiropractor who is experienced  
in treating pelvic joint problems.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They tend not to get better 
completely without treatment from 
an experienced practitioner.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Contact the Pelvic Partnership  
for support and information  
(see page 187).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Piles
Piles, also known as haemorrhoids, 
are swollen veins around your  
anus (back passage) which may  
itch, ache or feel sore.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can 
usually feel the lumpiness of the 
piles around your anus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Piles may 
also bleed a little and they can  
make going to the toilet 
uncomfortable or even painful.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They occur in pregnancy because 
certain hormones make your veins 
relax.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Piles usually resolve within 
weeks after birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to ease piles
•  Eat plenty of 
food that is 
high in ﬁbre, 
like wholemeal 
bread, fruit and 
vegetables, and 
drink plenty 
of water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
will prevent 
constipation, 
which can make 
piles worse.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Avoid standing 
for long periods.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Take regular exercise to improve 
your circulation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You may ﬁnd it helpful to use 
a cloth wrung out in ice water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Push any piles that stick out 
gently back inside using a 
lubricating jelly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Ask your midwife, doctor or 
pharmacist if they can suggest  
a suitable ointment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Skin and hair changes
Hormonal changes taking place 
in pregnancy will make your 
nipples and the area around 
them go darker.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your skin 
colour may also darken a little, 
either in patches or all over.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Birthmarks, moles and freckles 
may also darken.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women 
develop a dark line from their 
belly buttons down to the 
top of their pubic hair.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These 
changes will gradually fade 
after the baby has been born, 
although your nipples may 
remain a little darker.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you sunbathe while you are 
pregnant, you may ﬁnd that 
you tan more easily.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Protect 
your skin with a good, high-
factor sunscreen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t stay  
in the sun for very long.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Hair growth is also likely to 
increase in pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your 
hair may also be greasier.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After the baby is born, it may 
seem as if you are losing a lot 
of hair.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In fact, you are simply 
losing the extra hair that you 
grew during pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sleep
Late in pregnancy it can be very 
difﬁcult to get a good night’s  
sleep.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be uncomfortable 
lying down or, just when you get 
comfortable, you ﬁnd that you  
have to get up to go to the toilet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women have strange dreams 
or nightmares about the baby  
and about the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talking  
about them can help you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Stretch marks
These are pink or purplish lines 
which usually occur on your 
abdomen or sometimes on your 
upper thighs or breasts.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
women get them, some don’t.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It depends on your skin type.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Some people’s skin is more elastic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are more likely to get stretch 
marks if your weight gain is more 
than average.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is very doubtful 
whether oils or creams help to 
prevent stretch marks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After  
your baby is born, the marks  
should gradually pale and  
become less noticeable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Swollen ankles, feet 
and ﬁngers
Ankles, feet and ﬁngers often swell 
a little in pregnancy because your 
body is holding more water than 
usual.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Towards the end of the day, 
especially if the weather is hot or  
if you have been standing a lot,  
the extra water tends to gather in 
the lowest parts of your body.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It might be more comfortable to lie on one side with a pillow  
under your tummy and another between your knees.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
