Suggestions for swollen 
ankles, feet and ﬁngers
•  Avoid standing for long 
periods.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Wear comfortable shoes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Put your feet up as much as 
you can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to rest for an hour 
a day with your feet higher  
than your heart.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Do foot exercises (see page 35).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Teeth and gums
Bleeding gums are caused by a 
build-up of plaque (bacteria) on 
your teeth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During pregnancy, 
hormonal changes in your body can 
cause plaque to make your gums 
more inﬂamed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may become 
swollen and bleed more easily.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When your baby is born your gums 
should return to normal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to keep teeth and  
gums healthy
•  Clean your teeth and gums 
carefully.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your dentist to show 
you a good brushing method to 
remove all the plaque.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Avoid having sugary drinks and 
foods too often.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to eat them  
at mealtimes only.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Go to the dentist for a check-up.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
NHS dental treatment is free while 
you are pregnant and for a year 
after your baby’s birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Ask your dentist if any new or 
replacement ﬁllings should be 
delayed until after your baby  
is born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tiredness 
In the early months of pregnancy 
you may feel tired or even 
desperately exhausted.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The only 
answer is to try to rest as much  
as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make time to sit with 
your feet up during the day and 
accept any offers of help from 
colleagues and family.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Towards the end of pregnancy you 
may feel tired because of the extra 
weight you are carrying.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure 
that you get plenty of rest.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

65
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vaginal discharge
Almost all women have more 
vaginal discharge in pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It should be clear and white and 
should not smell unpleasant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If 
the discharge is coloured or smells 
strange, or if you feel itchy or sore, 
you may have a vaginal infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The most common infection is 
thrush, which your doctor can treat 
easily.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can help to prevent 
thrush by wearing loose cotton 
underwear.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
Tell your midwife or doctor if the 
discharge is coloured, smells strange, 
or if you feel itchy or sore.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tell your midwife or doctor if  
vaginal discharge, of any colour, 
increases a lot in later pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Varicose veins
Varicose veins are veins which have 
become swollen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The veins in the 
legs are most commonly affected.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also get varicose veins in 
the vulva (vaginal opening).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They 
usually get better after delivery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have varicose veins
•  Try to avoid standing for long 
periods of time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Try not to sit with your legs 
crossed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Try not to put on too much 
weight, as this increases the 
pressure.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Sit with your legs up as often as 
you can to ease the discomfort.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Try support tights, which may 
also help to support the muscles  
of your legs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Try sleeping with your legs higher 
than the rest of your body – use 
pillows under your ankles or put 
books under the foot of your bed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Do foot exercises (see page 35) 
and other antenatal exercises such 
as walking and swimming, which 
will help your circulation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
Contact Netmums, 
a unique local network 
and source of discussion  
– www.netmums.com
helps your 
exercise
circulation
66
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
MORE SERIOUS 
PROBLEMS
High blood pressure 
and pre-eclampsia
During pregnancy your blood 
pressure will be checked at 
every antenatal appointment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is because a rise in blood 
pressure can be the ﬁrst sign of a 
condition known as pre-eclampsia 
– also called pregnancy-induced 
hypertension (PIH) or pre-eclamptic 
toxaemia (PET).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can run in families 
and affects 10% of pregnancies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your urine is checked for protein  
at every visit, as this is a sign  
of pre-eclampsia.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The symptoms
Some of the symptoms  
of pre-eclampsia are:
• bad headaches
• problems with vision, such as 
blurred vision or lights ﬂashing 
before the eyes
• bad pain just below the ribs
• vomiting 
• sudden swelling of the 
face, hands or feet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, you can have severe  
pre-eclampsia without any 
symptoms at all.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Although most cases are mild and 
cause no trouble, it can be serious 
for both mother and baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can 
cause ﬁts in the mother (called 
eclampsia) and affects the baby’s 
growth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is life-threatening if left 
untreated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
That is why routine 
antenatal checks are so important.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pre-eclampsia usually happens 
towards the end of pregnancy, but 
it may happen earlier.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can also 
happen after the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is likely to 
be more severe if it starts earlier in 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Treatment may start with 
rest at home, but some women 
need admission to hospital and 
medicines that lower high blood 
pressure.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Occasionally, pre-eclampsia 
is a reason to deliver the baby early 
– this may be either by induction of 
labour or by caesarean section.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
If you get any of the symptoms 
described here, or have any reason 
to think that you have pre-eclampsia, 
contact your midwife, doctor or the 
hospital immediately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Placenta praevia 
Placenta praevia (or a low-lying 
placenta) is when the placenta is 
attached in the lower part of the 
uterus, near to or covering the cervix.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The position of your placenta is 
recorded at your 18 to 21-week 
ultrasound scan.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it is signiﬁcantly 
low you will be offered an extra 
ultrasound scan later in your 
pregnancy (usually at around  
32 weeks) to recheck its position.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For 9 out of 10 women the  
placenta has moved into the upper 
part of the uterus by this time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the placenta is still low in the 
uterus, there is a higher chance 
that you could bleed during your 
pregnancy or at the time of birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This bleeding can be very heavy 
and put you and your baby at 
risk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be advised to come 
into hospital at the end of your 
pregnancy so that emergency 
treatment can be given very quickly 
if you do bleed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the placenta is 
near or covering the cervix, the  
baby cannot get past it to be born 
vaginally and a caesarean section 
will be recommended.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
5
CONDITIONS AND PROBLEMS IN PREGNANCY
67
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Severe itching and 
obstetric cholestasis
Severe itching can be a sign 
of a condition called obstetric 
cholestasis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is a potentially 
dangerous liver disorder that seems 
to run in families, although it can 
occur even if there is no family 
history.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The main symptom is severe 
generalised itching without a rash, 
most commonly in the last four 
months of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Obstetric 
cholestasis can lead to premature 
birth, stillbirth or serious health 
problems for your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can 
also increase the risk of maternal 
haemorrhage after the delivery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
You should see your doctor if:
• the itching becomes severe – 
particularly if it affects your hands 
and feet 
• you develop jaundice (yellowing 
of the whites of the eyes and skin) 
• you get itching and a severe rash.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Slow-growing babies
Many of the tests in pregnancy 
check that your baby is growing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have previously had a 
very small baby, or if you smoke 
heavily, the midwives and doctors 
will already be monitoring your 
pregnancy closely.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Blood pressure 
checks may also pick up signs that 
there are complications.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If there is 
concern about your baby’s health, 
further tests might be carried out 
and your baby will be monitored 
more frequently.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
In the last weeks of pregnancy,  
you should keep track of your 
baby’s movements.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you notice 
your baby’s movements becoming 
less frequent or stopping, it may  
be a sign that your baby is unwell.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should contact your midwife  
or doctor immediately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If tests show that your baby is 
not growing well in the uterus, 
your midwife and doctor may 
recommend early delivery by 
induction of labour or caesarean 
section (see page 98).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Seek medical help
You should contact your 
GP if you have a sudden 
‘acute’ illness like diarrhoea, 
vomiting, abdominal pain 
or a high fever.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vaginal bleeding
Bleeding from the vagina at 
any time in pregnancy can be a 
dangerous sign.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some causes of 
vaginal bleeding are more serious 
than others, so it’s important to  
ﬁnd the cause straight away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Bleeding after sex 
The cells on the surface of the  
cervix often change in pregnancy 
and make it more likely to bleed  
– particularly after sex.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is 
called a cervical ectropion.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vaginal 
infections can also cause a small 
amount of vaginal bleeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ectopic pregnancy 
In early pregnancy, bleeding may  
be a sign of an ectopic pregnancy 
or a miscarriage (see page 151), 
although many women who bleed 
at this time go on to have normal 
and successful pregnancies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Bleeding in late pregnancy
The most common sort of  
bleeding in late pregnancy is the 
small amount of blood mixed  
with mucus that is known as a 
‘show’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is a sign that the cervix 
is changing and becoming ready  
for labour to start.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may happen  
a few days before contractions  
start or during labour itself.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
Always contact your 
midwife or doctor 
immediately if you have 
vaginal bleeding at any 
stage of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Deep vein thrombosis
Deep vein thrombosis is a 
serious condition where clots 
develop, often in the deep veins 
of the legs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be fatal if the 
clot travels from the legs to the 
lungs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The risk may increase if 
you are on a long-haul ﬂight 
(over ﬁve hours), where you sit 
still for a long time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
If you develop swollen and 
painful legs or have breathing 
difﬁculties, go to your GP 
or your nearest accident 
and emergency department 
immediately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More information
For more information see the  
Royal College of Obstetricians  
and Gynaecologists’ guideline 
Thromboprophylaxis during 
pregnancy, labour and after  
vaginal delivery at 
www.rcog.org.uk/womens-
health/clinical-guidance/
thromboprophylaxis-during-
pregnancy-labour-and-after-
vaginal-deliver
Vasa praevia
Vasa praevia is a rare condition 
(occurring in about 1 in 3,000 
to 1 in 6,000 births).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It occurs 
when the blood vessels of the 
umbilical cord run through the 
membranes covering the cervix.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Normally the blood vessels would 
be protected within the umbilical 
cord.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When the membranes 
rupture and the waters break, 
these vessels may be torn, causing 
vaginal bleeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The baby can 
lose a life-threatening amount of 
blood and die.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is very difﬁcult to 
diagnose but it may occasionally 
be spotted before birth by an 
ultrasound scan.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vasa praevia 
should be suspected if there is 
bleeding and the baby’s heart  
rate changes suddenly after  
rupture of the membranes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is linked with placenta  
praevia (see page 67).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

CONDITIONS AND PROBLEMS IN PREGNANCY

Problems in early 
pregnancy
Most women feel well in 
early pregnancy but it can be 
uncomfortable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women 
describe a pain low down in 
the abdomen similar to a period 
pain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This does not necessarily 
mean that something is wrong, 
but if the pain is more than 
discomfort or if there is any 
bleeding, your midwife or  
GP should refer you for a  
scan in the early pregnancy 
assessment unit.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This scan  
will show whether the 
pregnancy is growing in the 
uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes you need  
a second scan to check that  
all is well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

You can give birth at home, in a unit run by midwives or in a hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This chapter gives 
information about each of these options so that you can choose what is best for you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
SAFETY
Giving birth is generally very safe, 
wherever you choose to have your 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is not much evidence 
that compares how safe different 
places are.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, women  
who have their baby in a unit 
run by midwives or at home are 
less likely to need assistance, 
for example through the use of 
forceps or a ventouse.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you choose to have your baby  
at home or in a unit run by 
midwives, you should be given 
information about what would 
happen if you need to be 
transferred to hospital during 
labour and how long this  
would take.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should also be 
aware that if something goes 
seriously wrong during your labour 
(which is rare) it could be worse 
for you and your baby than if 
you were in hospital with access 
to specialised care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be 
advised to give birth in hospital 
if you have, or develop, certain 
medical conditions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
MAKING AN 
INFORMED  
DECISION
It is important that you and your 
partner make an informed choice 
about where you would like to  
give birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is your choice, and even after 
you have decided where 
you want to have your 
baby you can still 
change your mind.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife will 
discuss the options 
that are available 
to you locally, 
though you are 
free to choose 
any maternity 
services if  
you are  
prepared  
to travel.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As well as getting information 
from your midwife, you can get 
information from: 
• local maternity units
• Children’s Centres
• your GP surgery
• the NCT, which can put you 
in touch with local mothers  
(see page 57)
• Maternity Services 
Liaison Committees  
(www.csip.org.uk/~mslc)
• a supervisor of midwives
(see page 74).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also want to seek the 
views of your friends and family.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See also Chapter 4 on antenatal  
care and Chapter 8 on labour  
and birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
HOME BIRTHS
If you have a straightforward 
pregnancy and both you and the 
baby are well, you might choose 
to give birth at home.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In England, 
approximately 1 in 50 babies is  
born at home.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you give birth at home, you  
will be supported by a midwife, 
who will support you while you are 
in labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you need any help or 
your labour is not progressing as 
well as it should, your midwife will 
make arrangements for you to be 
transferred to hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The advantages of giving birth at 
home include the following:
• You can give birth in familiar 
surroundings where you may feel 
more relaxed and able to cope.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You don’t have to interrupt your 
labour to go into hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You will not need to leave your 
other children.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You will not have to be separated 
from your partner after  
the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You are more likely to be looked 
after by a midwife who you 
have got to know during your 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The things you should consider 
include the following:
• You may need to transfer 
to a hospital if there are any 
complications.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Epidurals are not available 
at home.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your doctor or midwife may 
recommend that you give  
birth in hospital, for example  
if you are expecting twins or 
if your baby is breech.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your 
midwife or doctor will explain 
why they think hospital is  
safer for you and your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Planning a home birth
Ask your midwife whether or not  
a home birth is suitable for you 
and your baby or available to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it is, your midwife will arrange 
for members of the midwifery 
team to support and help you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Here are some of the questions 
that you might want to ask:
• How long would it take if 
you needed to be transferred  
to hospital?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Which hospital would you be 
transferred to?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Would a midwife be with you 
all the time?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• How do you obtain a 
birthing pool?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More information
www.nhs.uk/pregnancyplanner
www.birthchoiceuk.com
www.drfoster.co.uk/Guides/
BirthGuide/

MIDWIFERY UNITS 
OR BIRTH CENTRES 
Birth centres and midwifery  
units are home-from-home places 
where you can go to have your 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These units can be part of  
a general hospital maternity unit,  
in a smaller community hospital  
or completely separate.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The advantages of giving birth 
at a midwifery unit include the 
following:
• You can give birth in surroundings 
where you may feel more relaxed 
and able to cope with labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You are more likely to be looked 
after by a midwife who you 
have got to know during your 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The things you should consider 
include the following:
• You may need to transfer 
to a hospital if there are any 
complications.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Epidurals are not available in 
a midwifery unit.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your doctor or midwife may 
recommend that it is safer for  
you and your baby to give birth  
in hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Planning a birth in  
a midwifery unit  
or birth centre
Midwifery care is available at  
home, in a midwifery unit and  
in hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your midwife if 
there are any midwifery units  
or birthing centres in your area.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There may be others that you can 
use if you are prepared to travel.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Here are some of the questions that 
you might want to ask:
• How long would it take if you 
needed to be transferred to

text:
BIRTH IN 
HOSPITAL
Most women give birth in an 
NHS hospital maternity unit.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you choose to give birth in 
hospital, you will be looked after 
by a midwife but doctors will be 
available if you need their help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will still have choices about 
the kind of care you want.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife and doctors will 
provide information about what 
your hospital can offer.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The advantages of giving birth  
in hospital include the following:
• You have direct access to 
obstetricians, anaesthetists and 
neonatologists.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You can access other specialist 
services, such as epidurals for 
relief of pain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• There will be a special care baby 
unit if there are any problems.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The things you should consider 
include the following:
• You may go home directly from 
the labour ward or you may be 
moved to a postnatal ward.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• In hospital, you may be looked 
after by a different midwife 
from the one who looked after 
you during pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Planning a hospital birth
Your midwife can help you decide at which hospital you want to have 
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If there is more than one hospital in your locality you can 
choose which one to go to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Find out more about the care provided  
in each so that you can decide which will suit you best.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Here are some of the questions that you might want to ask:
• Are tours of maternity facilities for birth available before the birth?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • When can I discuss my birth plan?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Are TENS machines available (see page 89) or do I need to hire one?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • What equipment is available – e.g.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
mats, a birthing chair or 
beanbags?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Are there birthing pools?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Are partners, close relatives or friends welcome in the delivery room?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Are birthing partners ever asked to leave the room?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Can I move around in labour and ﬁnd my own position for the birth?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • What services are provided for sick babies?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Who will help me breastfeed my baby?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Who will help me if I choose to formula feed?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • How long will I be in hospital?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • What are the visiting hours?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
BIRTH PLANS
A birth plan is a record of what  
you would like to happen during 
your labour and after the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To see an example of a birth plan,  
visit the online pregnancy planner at  
www.nhs.uk/birthplan.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You don’t 
have to create a birth plan, but if 
you want to, your midwife will be 
able to help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you don’t have access to a 
computer, ask your midwife to print 
out a copy of a birth plan from the 
NHS Choices website.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Discussing 
a birth plan with your midwife will 
give you the chance to 
ask questions and 
ﬁnd out more about 
what happens 
when you are in 
labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It also gives 
your midwife the 
chance to get to 
know you better 
and understand 
your feelings and 
priorities.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will probably 
want to think 
about or discuss 
some things 
more fully with the baby’s father 
and friends and relatives.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
And you 
can change your mind at any time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Your birth plan is personal to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It will depend not only on what 
you want, but also on your medical 
history, your own circumstances and 
what is available at your maternity 
service.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
What may be safe and 
practical for one pregnant woman 
may not be a good idea for another.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be given a special form 
for a birth plan, or there may be 
room in your notes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s a good 
idea for you to keep a copy of your 
birth plan with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The maternity 
team who care for you during 
labour will discuss it with you so 
that they know what you want.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But 
remember, you need to be ﬂexible if 
complications arise with you or the 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The maternity team will be 
able to give advice on your particular 
circumstances.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t hesitate to ask 
questions if you need to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Read the chapters on labour and 
birth (page 85) and the ﬁrst days 
with your new baby (page 120) 
before talking to your midwife, 
to see if there is anything you feel 
strongly about and want to include.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A midwife is a healthcare professional who is 
qualiﬁed to care for women during pregnancy, 
labour and after the baby is born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They also 
care for newborn babies until they are 28 days 
old, if necessary.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Midwives provide care for 
all women and involve other members of the 
team, including doctors when necessary.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Midwives help women prepare for birth 
through antenatal education and provide 
advice about common problems.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A nursing 
qualiﬁcation is not necessary to become a 
midwife, although some midwives have one.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: What is a supervisor of midwives?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A supervisor of midwives is an experienced midwife who has had extra 
training and education to assist and support midwives in providing the 
best quality maternity care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Supervisors of midwives aim to make sure 
that you receive the best guidance and information about the right 
type of care for you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They are there to help and support you if you are 
having any problems with your care, or if you feel that your wishes and 
requests are not being considered.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The telephone number for your supervisor of midwives should be in 
your pregnancy information details (or hand-held notes), or you can 
call your hospital’s labour ward/birthing room or your local birth centre.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Discussing issues with the supervisor of midwives will not affect your 
care or inﬂuence how you are further supported in your pregnancy, 
birth and aftercare.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
PALS
The Patient Advice and Liaison 
Service, known as PALS, has been 
introduced to ensure that the NHS 
listens to patients, their relatives, 
carers and friends and answers 
and resolves their concerns as 
quickly as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have any 
suggestions or complaints about 
your care, make contact with the 
PALS service based in hospitals 
in the ﬁrst instance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more 
information visit www.pals.nhs.uk

From the minute you know you are pregnant, your feelings change: feelings about yourself, 
about the baby and about your future.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your relationships change: with your partner, other 
children and also with your parents and friends.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Coping with these changes is not always easy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This chapter is about some of the worries that may come up in pregnancy and suggestions  
on how to handle them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
What is a problem for one person may not be a problem for you,  
and what is helpful advice for some people may not be right for you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
So take from these 
pages what you ﬁnd useful.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
FEELINGS
When you are pregnant it can 
sometimes seem as though you 
have to be happy all of the time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may ﬁnd that people expect 
you to look forward to the baby,  
be excited and to ‘bloom’ all the 
time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You too may think that  
this is the way you ought to feel.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In fact, you are likely to have ups 
and downs, just like any other  
nine months in your life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Hormonal changes  
and tiredness
Hormonal changes taking place in 
your body can make you feel tired, 
nauseous, emotional and upset – 
particularly in the ﬁrst three months.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may ﬁnd that you cry more 
easily, sometimes for no reason, 
and lose your temper more.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Being tired and run down can 
make you feel low.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to look 
after your physical health and  
get plenty of sleep (see Chapter 3  
on your health in pregnancy).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
If you are feeling very anxious 
– for whatever reason – talk to 
your midwife or doctor as soon 
as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Anxiety
It is quite normal to feel anxious 
and worried when you are pregnant 
– especially if this is your ﬁrst 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There are a number of 
things that you may feel anxious 
about.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may ﬁnd antenatal tests 
stressful – because of the possibility 
that something may be wrong.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be worried about practical 
things like money, work or where 
you are going to live.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be 
anxious about whether you will 
cope as a parent, or about whether 
you are ready to be a parent.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some of these anxieties could be 
shared by your partner, friends 
or family.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is a good idea to talk 
through these feelings together.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Dreams
It is normal to have dreams about 
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes your dreams 
may reﬂect your anxieties.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is 
often because you are thinking 
much more about your pregnancy 
and the changes that are happening 
in your body.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your midwife if 
you are worried by this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ways of coping
• Sometimes it helps to share 
anxieties with other pregnant 
women.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Discuss any worries, concerns or 
anxieties you have with someone 
you feel you can talk to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This could 
be your midwife, your partner, 
your friends or family.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
DEPRESSION AND 
MENTAL HEALTH 
PROBLEMS
It’s normal to have some worries 
while you are pregnant and to 
feel a bit down from time to 
time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But it is a cause for concern 
if you are feeling down most of 
the time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Whatever the reason 
for your unhappiness, or even 
if there doesn’t seem to be any 
reason at all, explain how you feel 
to your midwife, doctor or health 
visitor (see page 54 to ﬁnd out 
who is who).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure that they 
understand that you are talking 
about something more than just 
feeling low.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women do get 
depressed during pregnancy and 
you may need treatment to help 
you deal with it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have had a mental health 
problem in the past, then you  
might be at risk of becoming ill 
with a depressive illness during 
pregnancy and childbirth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is 
important that you tell your midwife 
at the start of your pregnancy about 
any previous illness.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your mood 
changes throughout the pregnancy 
then let someone know how you 
are feeling; don’t suffer alone  
– you can be helped.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
discuss
 your
feelings
76
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WORRYING  
ABOUT THE BIRTH
Many women worry about 
whether they can cope with the 
pain they will experience during 
labour and while giving birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is difﬁcult to imagine what a 
contraction is like and no one can 
really tell you – though they may 
try!
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Exploring ways of coping with 
labour may help you to feel more 
conﬁdent and more in control.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can begin by reading the 
chapter on labour and birth  
(page 85) with your partner or 
a friend or relative who will be 
with you for the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your 
midwife or doctor for any further 
information, and look on the 
internet (www.nhs.uk/pregnancy).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Antenatal education will 
also help to prepare you 
for labour and the birth  
and to know what to 
expect (see page 56).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will have an 
opportunity to discuss 
this in more detail with your 
midwife, and to draw up a birth 
plan, during the later months of 
pregnancy (see page 74).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your partner or someone 
close to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may be feeling 
anxious too – particularly if they 
are going to be with you in labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Together, you can then work out 
ways that will help you to cope.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

antenatal

will help
prepare
you

FEELINGS AND RELATIONSHIPS
77
CONCERNS ABOUT DISABILITIES
At some time during pregnancy, most expectant parents worry 
that there may be something wrong with their baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some people 
ﬁnd that talking openly about their fears helps them to cope.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Others prefer not to think about the possibility that something 
could be wrong.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women worry because they are convinced that if something 
does go wrong it will be their fault.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can increase your baby’s 
chances of being born healthy by following the advice outlined 
in Chapter 3.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But there are certain problems which cannot be 
prevented.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is either because the causes are not known or 
because they are beyond your control.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Of all the babies born in the UK, 97% are healthy and 1% of 
babies will be born with abnormalities that can be partly or 
completely corrected, such as extra ﬁngers or toes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
About 2%, 
however, will suffer from some more severe disability.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Regular 
antenatal care and careful observation during labour helps to  
pick up any potential problems and allow appropriate action  
to be taken.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are particularly concerned – perhaps because you or 
someone in your family has a disability – talk to your midwife  
or doctor as soon as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may be able to reassure you or offer you helpful information 
about tests which can be done during pregnancy (see Chapter 4).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have previously had a baby with an abnormality or disability, 
talk to your midwife or doctor and see if you need any additional 
care during this pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
COUPLES
Pregnancy will bring about big 
changes to your relationship, 
especially if this is your ﬁrst baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some people cope with these 
changes easily, others ﬁnd it harder.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Everybody is different.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is quite common for couples to 
ﬁnd themselves having arguments 
every now and then during 
pregnancy, however 
much they 
are looking 
forward to the 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
arguments 
may be 
nothing to 
do with the 
pregnancy, but 
others may be 
because one of 
you is worried about the future 
and how you are going to cope.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s important to realise that during 
pregnancy there are understandable 
reasons for the odd difﬁculty 
between you, and good reasons for 
feeling closer and more loving.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
One practical question you will need 
to discuss is how you will cope with 
labour, and whether your partner 
wants to be there.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many fathers  
do want to be present at their 
baby’s birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The chapter on labour 
and birth (page 85) gives some 
suggestions for ways in which 
fathers can help, and what it can 
mean for them to share  
this experience.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your relationship is particularly 
problematic, or is abusive, do get 
help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For sources of conﬁdential 
support, like Relate or Women’s 
Aid, refer to the list of useful 
organisations featured at the back 
of the book (see page 182).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may be that you do not  
have a partner in this  
pregnancy and you need  
extra support from family  
or friends.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may wish  
to talk to your midwife  
about services that may  
be available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See ‘Single 
parents’ opposite.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
SEX IN PREGNANCY
78
It is perfectly safe to have sex during 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your partner’s penis 
cannot penetrate beyond your 
vagina, and the baby cannot tell 
what is going on!
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, it is 
normal for your sex drive to change 
and you should not worry about this, 
but do talk about it with your partner.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Later in pregnancy, an orgasm 
– or even sex itself – can set off 
contractions (known as Braxton 
Hicks contractions – see page 87).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will feel the muscles of your 
uterus go hard.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is no need for 
alarm, as this is perfectly normal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it feels uncomfortable, try your 
relaxation techniques or just lie 
quietly till the contractions pass.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or doctor will probably 
advise you to avoid sex if you have 
any heavy bleeding in pregnancy, 
since this risks infection in the baby 
– especially if your waters have 
broken (see page 87).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some couples ﬁnd having sex 
very enjoyable during pregnancy, 
while others simply feel that they 
don’t want to have sex.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can 
ﬁnd other ways of being loving 
or of making love.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The most 
important thing is to talk about 
your feelings with each other.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
While sex is safe for most 
couples in pregnancy, it may not 
be all that easy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will probably 
need to ﬁnd different positions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can be a time to explore 
and experiment together.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Even 
early in pregnancy it can become 
uncomfortable to have sex with 
your partner on top.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can 
be because of your bump or 
because your breasts are tender.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can also be uncomfortable if 
your partner penetrates you too 
deeply.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
So it may be better to lie 
on your sides.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
SINGLE PARENTS
If you are pregnant and on your 
own, it is important that there 
are people who can support you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sorting out problems, whether 
personal or medical, is often 
difﬁcult when you are by yourself, 
and it’s better to ﬁnd someone 
to talk to rather than to let things 
get you down.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may ﬁnd 
it encouraging to meet other 
mothers who have also gone 
through pregnancy on their own.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t feel that, just because you 
don’t have a partner, you have to 
go to antenatal visits and cope 
with labour on your own.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You have 
as much right as anyone else to 
take whoever you like – a friend, 
sister, or perhaps your mum.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Involve 
your ‘labour partner’ in antenatal 
classes if you can, and let them 
know what you want from them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your midwife if there are 
antenatal classes in your area that 
are run especially for single women.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Think about the people who can 
help and support you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If there is no 
one who can give you support, it 
might help to discuss your situation 
with a social worker.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife 
can refer you or you can contact 
the social services department of 
your local council directly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

research organisation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

couples to cope with

One Parent Families/Gingerbread (see page 184) is a self-help organisation 
for one-parent families that has a network of local groups which can offer 
you information and advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

They will be able to put you in touch with 
other mothers in a similar situation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

If money is an immediate concern, see the chapter on rights and beneﬁts 
(page 156) for information on what you can claim and your employment 
rights.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Your local Jobcentre Plus or Citizens Advice Bureau (CAB) will be

Ask your local authority at

text:
FAMILY AND 
FRIENDS
Pregnancy is a special time for you 
and your partner, but there may  
be a lot of people around you who  
are interested in your baby, such  
as your parents, sisters, brothers  
and friends.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
People can offer a great deal of help 
in all sorts of ways, and you will 
probably be very glad of their interest 
and support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes it can feel 
as if they are taking over.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If so, it can 
help everyone if you explain gently 
that there are some decisions that 
only you and your partner can take, 
and some things that you would 
prefer to do on your own.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also ﬁnd that being 
pregnant puts you on the receiving 
end of a lot of advice, and perhaps 
a bit of criticism too.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes 
the advice is helpful, sometimes 
not.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes the criticism can 
really hurt.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The important thing is 
to decide what is right for you – it is 
your pregnancy and 
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More information
80
Families Information 
Service
Your local Families Information 
Service (which may be called 
something else in your local 
area) can provide information 
about registered childcare,  
free early education places  
and other services available  
in your area.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can contact them on 
0800 2 346 346.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also 
search www.childcarelink.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
gov.uk for your local Families 
Information Service or look on 
your local authority’s website 
for more details.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WORK 
If you work, and you like the people 
you work with, you may have mixed 
feelings when you go on maternity 
leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to make the most of these 
few weeks to enjoy doing the things 
you want to do at your own pace.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is also a good opportunity to make  
some new friends.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may meet 
other mothers at antenatal classes 
(see page 56) or you may get to 
know more people living close by.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may have decided that you are 
going to spend some time at home 
with your baby, or you may be 
planning to return to work, either 
full or part-time, fairly soon after the 
birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you think that you will be 
going back to work, you need  
to start thinking about who will  
look after your baby in advance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is not always easy to ﬁnd 
satisfactory childcare arrangements, 
and it may take you some time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may have a relative willing 
to look after your child.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If not, 
you should contact your Families 
Information Service for a list 
of registered childminders and 
nurseries.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also want to 
think about organising care in  
your own home, either on your  
own or sharing with other parents.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Care in your own home does not 
need to be registered, but you 
should make sure that your carer 
is experienced and trained to care 
for babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, if you are to 
claim ﬁnancial help with the costs, 
either through tax credits or tax 
relief on help from your employer, 
the carer must be approved 
through the government’s 
Childcare Approval Scheme.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: You can ﬁnd out more at www.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: childcareapprovalscheme.co.uk
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
AFTER THE BIRTH 
Having a baby and becoming a 
parent are major events for both 
you and your partner.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Becoming 
a parent usually brings changes 
to your home life, social life and 
relationships.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Parents of a new baby 
experience a variety of emotions 
after the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will feel happy 
and proud of yourself, or possibly 
relieved that it is all over.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Whether this is your ﬁrst, second or 
third baby, the ﬁrst few weeks of 
parenthood are both physically and 
emotionally tiring.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be difﬁcult 
to ﬁnd time for yourself, your partner 
or your family when you have the  
24-hour demands of a new baby to 
deal with.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Meeting the needs of a 
baby can be rewarding, but in the 
weeks and months following the 
birth of a baby you can feel stressed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is likely that during the ﬁrst few 
weeks and months of parenthood 
you will feel a mixture of emotions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your health visitor will be available 
to talk to you, but it is important 
that you talk honestly to your 
partner, friends or family about  
how you feel.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Being a parent means constantly 
experiencing new events and 
carrying out new tasks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will 
have to learn a new set of skills to 
cope with these situations.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Women 
do not automatically know how 
to be a mother and men do not 
automatically know how to be  
a father.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is something that you 
learn over time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
MOOD CHANGES 
THAT CAN 
DEVELOP AFTER 
THE BIRTH  
OF A BABY
If you experience any of the 
following mood changes, do not feel 
ashamed of how you are feeling.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are not alone: asking for and 
accepting help is the ﬁrst stage of 
recovery – particularly for the more 
serious conditions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you think you 
are in any way depressed, talk to a 
healthcare professional as soon as 
you can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife, health visitor 
and GP are all trained to help you, 
and many voluntary organisations 
offer advice (see the list of useful 
organisations on page 182).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The baby blues 
As many as 8 out of 10 women  
get what is commonly called  
‘the baby blues’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It normally  
begins within a few days of the 
baby’s birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: How does it affect you?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Common reactions are to burst  
into tears for no obvious reason, 
or to feel on top of the world one 
minute and miserable the next.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is 
not unusual to feel anxious or tense, 
lacking in conﬁdence or worried.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember that having a baby  
can turn your world upside down.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the ﬁrst few weeks and months 
you are likely to feel emotionally 
and physically drained.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Becoming  
a parent for the ﬁrst time can  
feel like an overwhelming 
responsibility and it is very easy  
to feel inadequate when other 
parents around you seem to be 
coping well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may expect to  
love your baby immediately, but  
this can take a while and is not 
always instinctive, and does not 
mean that you are not a ‘good’ 
or ‘natural’ mother.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many women 
experience these feelings.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
7
FEELINGS AND RELATIONSHIPS
81
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When you have a baby your life 
changes, so don’t be too hard on 
yourself – you are only human.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
We 
all learn to be a parent when we 
actually have a baby, not before.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Give yourself plenty of time to 
adjust to your new life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Find time 
to rest and eat a good diet, as this 
will help you to become and stay 
physically and emotionally healthy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to someone you can trust 
such as your partner, your mum, a 
friend, or to your midwife or health 
visitor, about how you are feeling.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can help a lot just to conﬁde in 
someone else.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once they know how 
you are feeling, they will be able to 
give you support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you become more unhappy or 
upset, or if your low mood lasts 
more than a week, then you are 
probably experiencing something 
other than the baby blues.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In these 
circumstances, you should talk 
to your midwife, health visitor or 
doctor – especially if you have had 
depression before.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Postnatal depression
Postnatal depression affects 1 in 10 
women following the birth of their 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It usually begins in the ﬁrst six 
months after childbirth, although 
for some women the depression 
begins in pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can occur at 
any time within the ﬁrst year of the 
birth of your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: How does it affect you?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you get postnatal depression, you 
can feel as if you are taken over by a 
feeling of hopelessness.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may feel 
angry, but more often you will feel 
too exhausted to be angry or even  
to cope with the simplest tasks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Postnatal depression is serious, and if 
it is left untreated it can last for longer 
than a year.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, early diagnosis 
and treatment of postnatal depression 
will result in a faster recovery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Quite 
often a partner or close family friend 
will recognise that there is something 
wrong before you do.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you think you are depressed, 
contact your GP, midwife or health 
visitor and explain how you are 
feeling.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your partner or a friend 
could contact them for you if you 
want.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also contact the 
Association for Post-Natal Illness (see 
page 186) for more information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have twins or triplets, you are 
more likely to experience postnatal 
and longer-term depression.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
is mainly because of the additional 
stress of caring for more than one 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Getting out of the house can 
be difﬁcult and this can make you 
feel isolated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tamba (see page 188) 
can help you to make contact with 
other mothers through local twins 
clubs and through their helpline, 
Tamba Twinline (0880 138 0509).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Postnatal post 
traumatic stress 
disorder and  
birth trauma
Post traumatic stress disorder 
symptoms may occur on 
their own or with postnatal 
depression.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The reasons women 
develop this are unclear, but 
women often describe feeling 
‘out of control’ and very afraid 
during the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This condition 
can be caused by:
• a fear of dying or your baby 
dying, or
• life-threatening situations.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: How does it affect you?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The symptoms include ﬂashbacks, 
nightmares, panic attacks, 
numbed emotions, sleeping 
problems, irritable, angry and 
irrational behaviour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you get any of these symptoms, 
you need to talk to someone 
about how you are feeling;  
your midwife, GP or health  
visitor will be able to advise 
where to get help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Puerperal psychosis 
This is a much more rare and serious 
condition, which affects about 1 in 
500 new mothers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Women with a 
family history of mental illness or 
who have suffered from puerperal 
psychosis in previous pregnancies 
are at a higher risk of developing  
this illness.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Symptoms include hallucinations 
(seeing or hearing things that others 
cannot), delusions (incredible beliefs 
such as thinking you must save 
the world) and mania (extremely 
energetic and bizarre activity like 
washing and ironing clothes in the 
middle of the night).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: How does it affect you?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The symptoms of this illness can 
be very severe and sometimes very 
frightening for you, your partner, 
and your family.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In fact, your partner 
may be the ﬁrst to notice that you 
are unwell.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is important that your 
partner or someone close to you 
knows the symptoms to look out 
for.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They will appear suddenly, often 
within the ﬁrst two weeks following 
the birth of the baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Seeking help 
quickly will ensure that you are 
treated as early as possible, to help 
you get well again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Women with this illness are often 
treated in hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Mother and 
baby units are available so that  
you will not be separated from  
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
DOMESTIC ABUSE
One in four women experience 
domestic abuse at some point in 
their lives.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This may be physical, 
sexual, emotional or psychological 
abuse.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Of this, 30% starts in 
pregnancy, and existing abuse may 
get worse during pregnancy or  
after giving birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Domestic abuse 
during pregnancy puts a pregnant 
woman and her unborn child in 
danger.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It increases the risk of 
miscarriage, infection, premature 
birth, low birth rate, fetal injury  
and fetal death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Domestic abuse 
should not be tolerated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are pregnant and being 
abused, there is help available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can speak in conﬁdence to your 
GP, midwife, obstetrician, health 
visitor or social worker.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Or call the 
conﬁdential National Domestic 
Violence Helpline number (see 
right) for information and support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For further sources of conﬁdential 
support, refer to page 184.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
Domestic abuse
If you are in immediate  
danger, call 999.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

For information and support 
call the freephone, 24-hour 
National Domestic Violence 
Helpline, run in partnership 
between Refuge and Women’s 
Aid: 0808 2000 247

BEREAVEMENT
The death of someone you love  
can turn your world upside down, 
and is one of the most difﬁcult 
experiences to deal with.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This may 
be harder to cope with if you are 
pregnant or have just had a baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Family and friends can help you  
by spending time with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A sympathetic arm around the 
shoulders can express love and 
support when words are not enough.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Grief is not just one feeling but a 
whole succession of feelings, which 
take time to get through and which 
cannot be hurried.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you need 
help or advice, contact your GP or 
midwife or any of the organisations 
listed on page 186.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your partner dies
If your partner dies during your 
pregnancy or soon after childbirth, 
you will feel emotionally numb.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may not be something that you 
get over – more something that you 
eventually learn to live with.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t be afraid to lean on your 
family and friends.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your partner 
was going to be with you at the 
birth, you will need to think about 
who will be with you instead.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to choose someone who knows 
you very well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Financially, you may need urgent 
advice and support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can get 
the recommended leaﬂets (see box) 
from your local Jobcentre Plus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As well as speaking to friends, family 
and social services, you may like to 
contact Cruse (see page 186).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

if your partner

England and Wales (DWP1027)

(available from www.dwp.gov.

• If you were not married, you will

you may be able to get some

It is 
always worth talking to your 
undertaker or religious adviser

Going into labour is exciting, but you may also feel apprehensive, so it helps to be 
prepared well in advance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Knowing all about the stages of labour and what to expect 
can help you to feel more in control when the time comes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
GETTING READY 
Whether you are having your 
baby at home, in hospital or at a 
midwifery unit, you should get a 
few things ready at least two weeks 
before your due date.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Packing your bag
If you plan to give birth in hospital 
or a midwifery unit, your midwife will 
probably give you a list of what you 
will need to pack.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may want to 
include the following:
•  Something loose and comfortable 
to wear during labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It should not 
restrict you from moving around or 
make you too hot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may need 
about three changes of clothes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Two or three comfortable 
and supportive bras, including 
nursing bras if you are planning 
to breastfeed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember, your 
breasts will be much larger  
than usual.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  About 24 super-absorbent 
sanitary towels.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Your wash bag with toothbrush, 
hairbrush, ﬂannel, etc.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Things that can help you pass 
the time and relax, e.g.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
books, 
magazines, MP3 player.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  A sponge or water spray to cool 
you down.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Front-opening nightdresses 
if you are going to breastfeed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Dressing gown and slippers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Five or six pairs of pants.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  A loose, comfortable outﬁt to 
wear after you have given birth 
and to come home in.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Clothes (including a hat) and 
nappies for the baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  A shawl or blanket to wrap 
the baby in.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Transport
Work out how you will get to 
hospital or the midwifery unit, as it 
could be at any time of the day or 
night.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are planning to go by 
car, make sure that it’s running well 
and that there is always enough 
petrol in the tank.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If a neighbour has 
said that they will take you, make 
an alternative arrangement just in 
case they are not in.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have not 
got a car, you could call a taxi.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Or 
call your maternity unit, which can 
arrange for an ambulance to pick 
you up.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Try to do so in good time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Home births
If you are planning to give birth at 
home, discuss your plans and what 
you need to prepare with your 
midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are likely to need  
the following:
•�clothes (including a hat) and 
nappies for the baby
• about 24 super-absorbent 
sanitary towels.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Mobile phones
Some hospitals and midwifery units 
will allow you to use your mobile 
phone.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Check with your midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If 
you cannot use your mobile, make 
sure that you have a phone card or 
change for the phone.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Important numbers
Keep a list of important numbers in your handbag  
or near your phone.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is space for you to write 
them down at the back of this book.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You need to include the following:
• Your hospital and midwife’s phone numbers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Your partner and birth partner’s phone numbers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your own hospital reference number (it will be 
on your card or notes).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be asked for  
this when you phone in.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • A local taxi number, just in case you need it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If labour starts early 
Labour can start as early as 
24 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this happens, 
call your midwife or 
hospital immediately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Stocking up 
When you come home you 
will not want to do much 
more than rest and care for 
your baby, so do as much 
planning as you can in 
advance: 
• Stock up on basics, such 
as toilet paper, sanitary 
towels and nappies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Buy tinned and dried food 
like beans, pasta and rice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you have a freezer, cook 
some meals in advance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
THE SIGNS OF 
LABOUR
You are unlikely to mistake the  
signs of labour when the time  
really comes, but if you are in any 
doubt, don’t hesitate to contact 
your midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Regular contractions
During a contraction, your uterus 
gets tight and then relaxes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may 
have had these throughout your 
pregnancy – particularly towards the 
end.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Before labour, these are called 
Braxton Hicks contractions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When 
you are having regular contractions 
that last more than 30 seconds and 
begin to feel stronger, labour may 
have started.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your contractions  
will become longer, stronger and 
more frequent.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Other signs of labour
•  Backache or the aching, heavy 
feeling that some women get 
with their monthly period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The plug of mucus 
in the cervix, which has helped to 
seal the uterus during pregnancy, 
comes away and comes out of 
the vagina.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This small amount of 
sticky pink mucus is called the 
‘show’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It usually comes away 
before or in early labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There 
should only be a little blood mixed 
in with the mucus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are 
losing more blood, it may be a 
sign that something is wrong, so 
phone your hospital or midwife 
straight away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Your waters break.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The bag 
of water surrounding your baby 
may break before labour starts.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To prepare for this, you could keep 
a sanitary towel (not a tampon) 
handy if you are going out, and 
put a plastic sheet on your bed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your waters break before labour 
starts, you will notice either a 
slow trickle from your vagina 
or a sudden gush of water that 
you cannot control.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Phone your 
midwife when this happens.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Nausea or vomiting.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pain relief in labour
Labour is painful, so it is important 
to learn about all the ways you can 
relieve pain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Whoever is going to be 
with you during labour should also 
know about the different options, 
as well as how they can support 
you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your midwife or doctor 
to explain what is available so that 
you can decide what is best for you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Write down what you want in your 
birth plan, but remember that you 
should keep an open mind.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
may ﬁnd that you want more pain 
relief than you had planned, or your 
doctor or midwife may suggest 
more effective pain relief to help  
the delivery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf
