text:
TYPES OF PAIN 
RELIEF
Self-help
The following techniques can help 
you to be more relaxed in labour, 
and this can help you to cope  
with the pain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Learn about labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can 
make you feel more in control  
and less frightened about what  
is going to happen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Read books 
like this one, talk to your  
midwife or doctor and attend 
antenatal classes if they are 
available in your area.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Learn how to relax and stay 
calm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Try breathing deeply.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your position 
can make a difference.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try kneeling, walking around  
or rocking back and forwards.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Have a partner, friend or relative 
to support you during labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you don’t have anyone, don’t 
worry – your midwife will give you 
all the support you need.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Ask your partner to massage you 
(although you may ﬁnd that you 
don’t want to be touched).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Hydrotherapy
Water can help you to relax 
and can make the contractions 
seem less painful.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask if you 
can have a bath or use a 
birth pool.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The water will be 
kept at a temperature that is 
comfortable for you but  
it will not be above 37°C.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your temperature will be 
monitored closely.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
‘Gas and air’ (Entonox)
This is a mixture of oxygen and 
another gas called nitrous oxide.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
‘Gas and air’ will not remove all 
the pain, but it can help to reduce 
it and make it easier to bear.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many 
women like it because it’s easy to 
use and you control it yourself.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How it works
You breathe it in through a mask 
or mouthpiece which you hold 
yourself.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will probably have a 
chance to practise using the mask 
or mouthpiece if you attend an 
antenatal class.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The gas takes 15–20 seconds to 
work, so you breathe it in just as  
a contraction begins.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It works best  
if you take slow, deep breaths.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Side effects
There are no harmful side effects 
for you or the baby, but it can 
make you feel lightheaded.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
women also ﬁnd that it makes 
them feel sick or sleepy or unable to 
concentrate on what is happening.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this happens, you can simply 
stop using it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
staying
calm
will help
88
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
TENS
TENS stands for transcutaneous 
electrical nerve stimulation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
hospitals have TENs machines.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If not, 
you can hire your own machine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
TENS has not been shown to be 
effective during the active phase of 
labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is probably most effective 
during the early stages, when many 
women experience lower-back pain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
TENS may be useful if you plan to 
give birth at home or while you 
are at home in the early stages of 
labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are interested in TENS, 
you should learn how to use it in 
the later months of your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Ask your midwife or physiotherapist.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How it works
Electrodes are taped onto your back 
and connected by wires to a small, 
battery-powered stimulator known 
as an ‘obstetric pulsar’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Holding the 
pulsar, you give yourself small, safe 
amounts of current.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can move 
around while using it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is believed that TENS works by 
stimulating your body to produce 
more endorphins, which are the 
body’s own natural painkillers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It also reduces the number of pain 
signals that are sent to the brain  
by the spinal cord.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Side effects
There are no known side effects  
for either you or the baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Intramuscular 
injections of pain-
relieving drugs
Injections of drugs like pethidine or 
diamorphine can help you to relax, 
and this can lessen the pain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How it works
You are given an intramuscular 
injection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It takes about 20 minutes 
to work and the effects last 
between two and four hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Side effects
• It can make some women feel 
very ‘woozy’, sick and forgetful.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If it has not worn off towards 
the end of labour, it can make it 
difﬁcult to push.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You might prefer 
to ask for half a dose initially, to 
see how it works for you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If pethidine or diamorphine are 
given too close to the time of 
delivery, it may affect the baby’s 
breathing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it does, an antidote 
may be given.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• The drugs can interfere with 
breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Epidural analgesia
An epidural is a special type of 
local anaesthetic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It numbs the 
nerves which carry pain from the 
birth canal to the brain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For most 
women, an epidural gives complete 
pain relief.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be very helpful for 
women who are having a long or 
particularly painful labour, or who 
are becoming very distressed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
An anaesthetist is the only person 
who can give an epidural.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
think you are going to want one, 
check whether anaesthetists are 
always available at your hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How it works
• A drip will run ﬂuid into a vein in 
your arm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• While you lie on your side or 
sit up in a curled position, an 
anaesthetist will clean your back 
with antiseptic and numb a small 
area with some local anaesthetic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• A very small tube will be placed 
into your back near the nerves 
that carry pain from the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Drugs (usually a mixture of local 
anaesthetic and opioid) are then 
administered through this tube.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It takes about 20 minutes to get 
the epidural set up and then 
another 10–15 minutes for it to 
work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Occasionally it doesn’t work 
perfectly at ﬁrst, and needs to  
be adjusted.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• After it has been set up, the 
epidural can be ‘topped up’ by  
an anaesthetist or midwife, or  
you may be given a machine 
which will let you top up the 
epidural yourself.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your contractions and the baby’s 
heart will need to be continuously 
monitored by a machine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
means having a belt round your 
abdomen and possibly a clip 
attached to your baby’s head.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Side effects 
• Epidurals may make your legs 
heavy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It depends on the type  
of epidural that you have.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• An epidural should not make 
you feel drowsy or sick.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Your blood pressure can drop.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is rare, as the drip in your  
arm will help you to maintain 
good blood pressure.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Epidurals can prolong the second 
stage of labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you can no 
longer feel your contractions, 
8
LABOUR AND BIRTH
89
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
the midwife will have to tell you 
when to push.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This may mean 
that instruments are used to help 
you deliver your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, 
when you have an epidural, your 
midwife or doctor will wait longer 
before they use instruments 
as long as your baby is ﬁne.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes, less anaesthetic is 
given towards the end so that the 
effect wears off and you can push 
the baby out naturally.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You may ﬁnd it difﬁcult to pass 
water, and a small tube called a 
catheter may be put into your 
bladder to help you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• About 1 in 100 women gets a 
headache after an epidural.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
develop a headache afterwards,  
it can be treated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your back might be a bit sore for 
a day or two, but epidurals do not 
cause long-term backache.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• About 1 in 2,000 mothers gets 
a feeling of tingling or pins and 
needles down one leg after having 
a baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is more likely to result 
from childbirth itself than from an 
epidural.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be advised on 
when you can get out of bed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Alternative methods  
of pain relief
Some women want to avoid the 
above methods of pain relief and 
choose acupuncture, aromatherapy, 
homeopathy, hypnosis, massage 
and reﬂexology.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most of these 
techniques do not provide very 
effective pain relief.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, if 
you would like to use any of these 
methods it is important to discuss it 
with your midwife or doctor and to 
let the hospital know beforehand.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most hospitals do not offer them 
for the relief of pain during labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you want to try one of these 
alternative techniques, make sure 
that the practitioner you use is 
properly trained and experienced 
and check with your midwife that 
this will be available in the maternity 
unit.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For advice, contact the Institute 
for Complementary and Natural 
Medicine (see page 183).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WHEN TO GO  
TO HOSPITAL  
OR YOUR  
MIDWIFERY UNIT
If it is your ﬁrst pregnancy, you may 
feel unsure about when you should 
go into hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The best thing 
to do is call your hospital or unit 
for advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If your waters have broken, you 
will probably be told to go in to 
be checked.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If it is your ﬁrst baby and you 
are having contractions but your 
waters have not broken, you may 
be told to wait.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will probably 
be told to come in when your 
contractions are regular, strong, 
are about ﬁve minutes apart and 
are lasting about 60 seconds.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you don’t live near to your 
hospital, you may need to go 
in before you get to this stage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Second and later babies often 
arrive more quickly, so you may 
need to contact the hospital, 
midwifery unit or your  
midwife sooner.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t forget to phone the hospital 
or unit before leaving home, and 
remember your notes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Home birth
You and your midwife should have 
agreed what you will do when 
labour starts.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Keep active 
Keep active in labour for as 
long as you feel comfortable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This helps the progress of 
the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t do anything 
strenuous but try and move  
or walk around normally.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ARRIVING AT 
THE HOSPITAL OR 
MIDWIFERY UNIT
Hospitals and midwifery units vary, 
so the following is just a guide 
to what is likely to happen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your 
midwife will be able to give you 
more information about your local 
hospital or unit.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you carry your own notes, take 
them to the hospital admissions 
desk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be taken to the 
labour ward or your room, where 
you can change into a hospital 
gown or a nightdress of your own.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Choose one that is loose and 
preferably made of cotton, because 
you will feel hot during labour and 
will not want something tight.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Examination by  
the midwife
The midwife will ask you about 
what has been happening so far 
and will examine you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are 
having a home birth, then this 
examination will take place at 
home.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The midwife will:
•  take your pulse, temperature 
and blood pressure and check 
your urine
•  feel your  
 
abdomen to  
 check the baby’s  
 position and  
 
record or listen  
 
to your baby’s  
 
heart, and
•  probably do an internal 
examination to ﬁnd out how 
much your cervix has opened.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tell her if a contraction is coming 
so that she can wait until it has 
passed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
She will then be able 
to tell you how far your labour 
has progressed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you would 
prefer not to have an internal 
examination you don’t have  
to have one.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These checks will be repeated at 
intervals throughout your labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you and your partner have  
made a birth plan, show your 
midwife so that she knows what 
kind of labour you want and can 
help you to achieve it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Delivery rooms 
Delivery rooms have become 
more homelike in recent years.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most have easy chairs, beanbags 
and mats so that you can move 
about in labour and change 
position.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some have baths, 
showers or birthing pools.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should feel comfortable  
in the room where you are 
giving birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Bath or shower
Some hospitals may offer you  
a bath or shower.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A warm bath 
can be soothing in the early 
stages of labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women 
like to spend much of their 
labour in the bath as a way  
of easing the pain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Water births
Some hospitals have birthing 
pools (or you can hire one if 
there is not one available), 
so that you can be in water 
during labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many women 
ﬁnd that this helps them to 
relax.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is possible to deliver 
the baby in the pool.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Speak 
to your midwife about the 
advantages and disadvantages 
of a water birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you want 
one, you will need to make 
arrangements in advance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WHAT HAPPENS  
IN LABOUR
There are three stages to labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the ﬁrst stage the cervix gradually 
opens up (dilates).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the second 
stage the baby is pushed down 
the vagina and is born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the third 
stage the placenta comes away 
from the wall of the uterus and  
is also pushed out of the vagina.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The ﬁrst stage of 
labour – dilation
The dilation of the cervix
The cervix needs to open to 
about 10cm for a baby to pass 
through.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This is called ‘fully dilated’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Contractions at the start of labour 
help to soften the cervix so that it 
gradually opens.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes the 
process of softening can take many 
hours before what midwives refer  
to as ‘established labour’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is 
when your cervix has dilated to at 
least 4cm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you go into hospital or your 
midwifery unit before labour is 
established, you may be asked if 
you would prefer to go home again 
for a while, rather than spending 
extra hours in hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you go home, you should make 
sure that you eat and drink, as you 
will need energy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At night, try to  
get comfortable and relaxed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: If you can, try to sleep.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A warm bath 
or shower may help you to relax.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During the day, keep upright and 
gently active.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This helps the baby 
to move down into the pelvis and 
helps the cervix to dilate.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once labour is established, the 
midwife will check you from  
time to time to see how you are 
progressing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In a ﬁrst labour, the 
time from the start of established 
labour to full dilation can be 
between 6 and 12 hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is  
often quicker in subsequent 
pregnancies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife should be with  
you all the time to support you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
She will tell you to try not to push 
until your cervix is fully open and 
the baby’s head can be seen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To help yourself get over the urge 
to push, try blowing out slowly  
and gently or, if the urge is too 
strong, in little puffs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some people 
ﬁnd this easier lying on their side, 
or on their knees and elbows, to 
reduce the pressure of the baby’s 
head on the cervix.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fetal heart monitoring
Your baby’s heart will be monitored 
throughout labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife 
will watch for any marked change  
in your baby’s heart rate, which 
could be a sign that the baby is 
distressed and that something 
needs to be done to speed up the 
delivery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There are different ways  
of monitoring the baby’s heartbeat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you don’t feel comfortable with 
one of these, tell your midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your midwife may listen to your 
baby’s heart intermittently, but 
for at least one minute every 
15 minutes when you are in 
established labour, using a  
hand-held ultrasound monitor 
(often called a Sonicaid).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
method allows you to be free  
to move around.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your baby’s heartbeat and your 
contractions may also be followed 
electronically through a monitor 
linked to a machine called a CTG.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The monitor will be strapped to 
your abdomen on a belt.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Alternatively, a clip can be put 
on your baby’s head to monitor 
the heart rate.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The clip is put on 
during a vaginal examination  
and your waters will be broken 
if they have not already done so.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your midwife or doctor to 
explain why they feel that the  
clip is necessary for your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Speeding up labour
Your labour may be slower than 
expected if your contractions  
are not frequent or strong enough  
or because your baby is in an 
awkward position.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this is the case, your doctor or 
midwife will explain why they  
think labour should be sped up 
and may recommend the following 
techniques to get things moving: 
• Your waters will be broken 
(if this has not already  
happened) during a vaginal 
examination.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is often  
enough to get things moving.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If this doesn’t speed up labour, 
you may be given a drip 
containing a hormone, which  
is fed into a vein into your arm  
to encourage contractions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may want some pain relief 
before the drip is started.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• After the drip is attached, 
your contractions and your  
baby’s heartbeat will be 
continuously monitored.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Coping at the beginning
•  You can be up and moving about 
if you feel like it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  You can drink ﬂuids and may ﬁnd 
isotonic drinks (sports drinks) help  
to keep your energy levels up.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also snack, although  
many women don’t feel  
very hungry and some  
feel nauseated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  As the contractions get stronger and 
more painful, you can try relaxation and  
breathing exercises.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your birthing  
partner can help by doing  
them with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Your birthing partner 
can rub your back to  
relieve the pain  
if that helps.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The second stage  
of labour – the  
baby’s birth
This stage begins when the cervix is 
fully dilated, and lasts until the birth 
of your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife will help 
you to ﬁnd a comfortable position 
and will guide you when you feel 
the urge to push.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Find a position
Find a position that you prefer 
and which will make labour easier 
for you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You might want to remain in bed 
with your back propped up with 
pillows, or you may wish to stand, 
sit, kneel or squat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Squatting  
may be difﬁcult if you are not 
used to it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you are very tired, you might 
be more comfortable lying on 
your side rather than propped up 
with pillows.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is also a better 
position for your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You may ﬁnd kneeling on all fours 
might be helpful if you suffer from 
backache in labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can help if you have tried out 
some of these positions beforehand.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pushing
When your cervix is fully dilated,  
you can start to push when you feel 
you need to during contractions:
• Take two deep breaths as 
the contractions start, and  
push down.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•�Take another breath when you 
need to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Give several pushes until the 
contraction ends.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• After each contraction, rest and 
get up strength for the next one.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This stage is hard work, but your 
midwife will help and encourage 
you all the time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your birth partner 
can also give you lots of support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This stage may take an hour or 
more, so it helps to know how you 
are doing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The birth
During the second stage, the  
baby’s head moves down until  
it can be seen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When the head is visible, the 
midwife will ask you to stop 
pushing, and to pant or puff  
a couple of quick short breaths, 
blowing out through your mouth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is so that your baby’s head 
can be born slowly and gently, 
giving the skin and muscles of the 
perineum (the area between your 
vagina and back passage) time to 
stretch without tearing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The skin of the perineum usually 
stretches well, but it may tear.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes to avoid a tear or to 
speed up the delivery, the midwife 
or doctor will inject local anaesthetic 
and cut an episiotomy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Afterwards, 
the cut or tear is stitched up again 
and heals.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once your baby’s head is born, most 
of the hard work is over.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
With one 
more gentle push the body is born 
quite quickly and easily.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can have your baby lifted straight 
onto you before the cord is cut by 
your midwife or birthing partner.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby may be born covered 
with some of the white, greasy 
vernix, which acts as a protection  
in the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Skin-to-skin contact
Skin-to-skin contact really helps 
bonding, so it is a good idea to  
have your baby lifted onto you 
before the cord is cut so that you 
can feel and be close to each other 
straight away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The cord is clamped and cut, the 
baby is dried to prevent them from 
becoming cold, and you will be able 
to hold and cuddle your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby may be quite messy,  
with some of your blood and 
perhaps some of the vernix on  
their skin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you prefer, you can  
ask the midwife to wipe your baby 
and wrap him or her in a blanket 
before your cuddle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes mucus has to be 
cleared out of a baby’s nose 
and mouth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some babies need 
additional help to establish 
breathing and may be taken to  
the resuscitor in the room to be 
given oxygen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby will not 
be kept away from you any longer 
than necessary.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The third stage of 
labour – the placenta 
After your baby is born, the uterus 
can contract to push out the 
placenta.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife will offer 
you an injection in your thigh just as 
the baby is born, which will speed 
up the delivery of the placenta.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The injection contains a drug  
called Syntocinon, which makes  
the uterus contract and helps to 
prevent the heavy bleeding which 
some women experience.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Let your baby breastfeed as soon 
after birth as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It helps with 
breastfeeding later on and it also 
helps your uterus to contract.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies start sucking immediately, 
although maybe just for a short 
time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may just like to feel  
the nipple in the mouth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After the birth
Skin-to-skin contact with your 
baby is important and helps with 
bonding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby will like  
being close to you just after birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The time alone with your partner  
and your baby is very special.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby will be examined by a 
midwife or paediatrician and then 
weighed (and possibly measured) and 
given a band with your name on it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vitamin K 
You will be offered an injection of 
vitamin K for your baby, which is 
the most effective way of helping 
to prevent a rare bleeding disorder 
(haemorrhagic disease of the 
newborn).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife should 
have discussed this with you 
beforehand.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you prefer that your 
baby doesn’t have an injection, oral 
doses of vitamin K are available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Further doses will be necessary.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Stitches
Small tears and grazes are often  
left to heal without stitches because 
they frequently heal better this 
way.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you need stitches or other 
treatments, it should be possible  
to continue cuddling your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife will help with this as 
much as they can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have had a large tear or an 
episiotomy, you will probably need 
stitches.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have already had an 
epidural, it can be topped up.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If  
you have not, you should be offered 
a local anaesthetic injection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The midwife or maternity support 
worker will help you to wash and 
freshen up, before leaving the 
labour ward to go home or to the 
postnatal area.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
SPECIAL CASES
Labour that starts 
too early (premature 
labour)
About 1 baby in every 13 will 
be born before the 37th week 
of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In most cases 
labour starts by itself, either with 
contractions or with the sudden 
breaking of the waters or a ‘show’ 
(see page 87).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
About one early baby 
in six is induced (see next page) 
and about one early baby in ﬁve is 
delivered by caesarean section  
(see page 98).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby is likely to be born 
early, you will be admitted to a 
hospital with specialist facilities for 
premature babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Not all hospitals 
have these facilities, so it may be 
necessary to transfer you and your 
baby to another unit, either before 
delivery or immediately afterwards.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If contractions start prematurely, the 
doctors may be able to use drugs to 
stop your contractions temporarily.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will probably be given injections 
of steroids that will help to mature 
your baby’s lungs so that they are 
better able to breathe after the 
birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This treatment takes about  
24 hours to work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many multiple birth babies are born 
prematurely.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The normal delivery 
date for twins is 37 weeks and for 
triplets 33 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have any reason to think that 
your labour may be starting early, 
get in touch with your hospital or 
midwife straight away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Overdue pregnancies
Pregnancy normally lasts about  
40 weeks, which is approximately 
280 days from the ﬁrst day of your 
last period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most women will go 
into labour within a week either  
side of this date.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your labour does not start by  
41 weeks, your midwife will 
offer you a ‘membrane sweep’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This involves having a vaginal 
examination, which stimulates the 
neck of your uterus (known as the 
cervix) to produce hormones which 
may trigger natural labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your labour still doesn’t start, your 
midwife or doctor will suggest a 
date to have your labour induced 
(started off).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you don’t want labour 
to be induced and your pregnancy 
continues to 42 weeks or beyond, 
you and your baby will be monitored.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or doctor will check 
that both you and your baby are 
healthy by giving you ultrasound 
scans and checking your baby’s 
movement and heartbeat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your 
baby is showing signs of distress, 
your doctor and midwife will again 
suggest that labour  
is induced.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Induction
Labour can be induced if your  
baby is overdue or there is any  
sort of risk to you or your baby’s 
health – for example, if you have 
high blood pressure or if your 
baby is failing to grow and thrive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Induction is always planned in 
advance, so you will be able to talk 
over the beneﬁts and disadvantages 
with your doctor and midwife and 
ﬁnd out why they recommend  
your labour is induced.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Contractions are usually started 
by inserting a pessary or gel into 
the vagina, and sometimes both 
are used.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Induction of labour may 
take a while, particularly if the neck 
of the uterus (the cervix) needs 
to be softened with pessaries or 
gels.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes a hormone drip 
is needed to speed up the labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once labour starts it should proceed 
normally, but it can sometimes take 
24–48 hours to get you into labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Assisted birth (forceps 
or ventouse delivery)
About one in eight women have an 
assisted birth, where forceps or a 
ventouse are used to help the baby 
out of the vagina.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can be because:
• your baby is distressed
• your baby is in an awkward 
position
• you are too exhausted.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Both ventouse and forceps are 
safe and are used only when 
necessary for you and your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A paediatrician may be present to 
check your baby’s health.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A local 
anaesthetic will usually be given to 
numb the birth canal if you have 
not already had an epidural or spinal 
anaesthetic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your obstetrician  
has any concerns, you may be 
moved to a theatre so that a 
caesarean section can be carried  
out if needed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As the baby is being born, a cut 
(episiotomy) may be needed to 
enlarge the vaginal opening.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Any tear or cut will be repaired  
with stitches.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Depending on the circumstances, 
your baby can be delivered onto your 
abdomen and your birthing partner 
may still be able to cut the cord,  
if they want to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ventouse
A ventouse (vacuum extractor) 
is an instrument that has a 
soft or hard plastic or metal 
cup which is attached to your 
baby’s head by a tube that is 
ﬁtted to a suction device.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The 
cup ﬁts ﬁrmly onto your baby’s 
head and, with a contraction 
and your pushing, the 
obstetrician or midwife gently 
pulls to help deliver your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The suction cup (ventouse) 
can leave a small mark on your 
baby’s head called a chignon 
and it may also cause a bruise 
on your baby’s head called a 
cephalhaematoma.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A ventouse 
is not used if your baby is less 
than 34 weeks old, because 
the head is too soft.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A ventouse is less likely to cause 
vaginal tearing than forceps.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Forceps
Forceps are smooth metal 
instruments that look like large 
spoons or tongs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They are curved  
to ﬁt around the baby’s head.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The forceps are carefully positioned 
around your baby’s head and joined 
together at the handles.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
With a 
contraction and your pushing, an 
obstetrician gently pulls to help 
deliver your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There are many different types 
of forceps.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some forceps are 
speciﬁcally designed to turn the 
baby to the right position to be 
born, for example if your baby  
is ‘back to your back’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Forceps can leave small marks 
on your baby’s face.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These will 
disappear quite quickly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Afterwards
You will sometimes be ﬁtted with a 
catheter (a small tube that ﬁts into 
your bladder) for up to 24 hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are more likely to need this if 
you have had an epidural, as you 
may not have full feeling back.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
8
LABOUR AND BIRTH
97
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Caesarean section
There are situations where the  
safest option for you or your baby  
is to have a caesarean section.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As a caesarean section involves 
major surgery, it will only be 
performed where there is a real 
clinical need for this type of delivery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby is delivered by cutting 
through your abdomen and then 
into your uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The cut is made 
across your abdomen, just below 
your bikini line.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The scar is usually 
hidden in your pubic hair.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are expecting twins, triplets 
or more, it is more likely that you 
will be advised to have a caesarean 
section.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will depend on how 
your pregnancy progresses, the 
position of your babies and whether 
the babies share a placenta.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Whenever a caesarean is suggested, 
your doctor will explain why it 
is advised and any possible side 
effects.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Do not hesitate to  
ask questions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Urgent (emergency) 
caesareans
Urgent (emergency) caesarean 
sections are necessary when 
complications develop and delivery 
needs to be quick.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This may be 
before or during labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your 
midwife and doctor are concerned 
about your or your baby’s safety, 
they will suggest that you have a 
caesarean straight away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes 
your doctor or midwife may suggest 
an emergency caesarean if your 
cervix does not dilate fully during 
labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The operation
In the UK, most caesarean sections 
are performed under epidural or 
spinal anaesthesia, which minimises 
risk and means that you are awake 
for the delivery of your baby (see 
page 89).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A general anaesthetic is 
sometimes used – particularly  
if the baby needs to be delivered 
very quickly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have an epidural or spinal 
anaesthesia, you will not feel pain 
– just some tugging and pulling as 
your baby is delivered.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A screen will 
be put up so that you cannot see 
what is being done.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The doctors will 
talk to you and let you know what 
is happening.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
98
Planned (elective) caesareans
A caesarean is ‘elective’ if it is planned in advance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This usually 
happens because your doctor or midwife thinks that labour will  
be dangerous for you or your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It takes about 5–10 minutes to 
deliver the baby and the whole 
operation takes about 40–50 
minutes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
One advantage of an 
epidural or spinal anaesthetic is  
that you are awake at the moment 
of delivery and can see and hold 
your baby immediately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your birth 
partner can be with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After a caesarean section
After a caesarean section, you 
will be uncomfortable and will be 
offered painkillers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will usually 
be ﬁtted with a catheter (a small 
tube that ﬁts into your bladder) for 
up to 24 hours and you may be 
prescribed daily injections to prevent 
blood clots (thrombosis).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Depending on the help you have at 
home, you should be ready to leave 
hospital within two to four days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be encouraged to become 
mobile as soon as possible, and your 
midwife or hospital physiotherapist 
will give you advice about postnatal 
exercises that will help you in your 
recovery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As soon as you can move 
without pain, you can drive – as 
long as you are able to make an 
emergency stop.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This may be six 
weeks or sooner.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once a caesarean 
always a caesarean?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have your ﬁrst baby by 
caesarean section, this does 
not necessarily mean that any 
future baby will have to be 
delivered in this way.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vaginal 
birth after a previous caesarean 
can and does happen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will 
depend on your own particular 
circumstances (see page 155).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Discuss your hopes and plans 
for any other deliveries with 
your doctor or midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
Contact the Caesarean 
Support Network for 
information and support  
(see page 182).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ﬁrst
moments
8
LABOUR AND BIRTH
99
together
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breech birth
If your baby is breech, it means 
that it is positioned with its bottom 
downwards.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This makes delivery 
more complicated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your obstetrician 
and midwife will talk to you about 
the best and safest way for your 
breech baby to be born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will  
be advised to have your baby  
in hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
External cephalic version
You will usually be offered the 
option of an external cephalic 
version (ECV).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is when pressure 
is put on your abdomen to try  
to turn the baby to a head  
down position.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Caesarean section
If an ECV doesn’t work, you will 
probably be offered a caesarean 
section.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is the safest delivery 
method for breech babies but there 
is a slightly higher risk for you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See the section on caesarean 
sections for more information  
(see pages 98–99).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you choose a caesarean delivery 
and then go into labour before the 
operation, your obstetrician will 
assess whether to proceed with  
an emergency caesarean delivery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the baby is close to being born, 
it may be safer for you to have  
a vaginal breech birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
TWINS, TRIPLETS 
OR MORE
If you are expecting twins, labour 
may start early because of the 
increased size of the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is unusual for multiple pregnancies 
to go beyond 38 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More 
health professionals will usually be 
present at the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For example, 
there may be a midwife, an 
obstetrician and two paediatricians 
(one for each baby).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The process of labour is the same 
but the babies will be closely 
monitored.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To do this, an electronic 
monitor and a scalp clip might be 
ﬁtted on the ﬁrst baby once the 
waters have broken (see page 87).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be given a drip in case it 
is needed later, and an epidural is 
usually recommended.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once the ﬁrst 
baby has been born, the midwife  
or doctor will check the position 
of the second by feeling  
your abdomen and doing  
a vaginal examination.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the second baby is in a good 
position to be born, the waters 
surrounding the baby will be broken, 
and the second baby should be born 
very soon after the ﬁrst because  
the cervix is already fully dilated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If contractions stop after the ﬁrst 
birth, hormones will be added to  
the drip to restart them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Triplets or more are almost  
always delivered by elective 
caesarean section.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
has been born, the midwife
ctor will check the position
e second by feeling 
abdomen and doing 
inal examination.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
100
Contact the Multiple 
Births Foundation (MBF) or 
Twins and Multiple Births 
Association (Tamba) for 
advice and support  
(see pages 183 and 188).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WHAT YOUR BIRTH PARTNER CAN DO
Whoever your birth partner is – your partner, your baby’s father, a close 
friend or a relative – there are quite a few practical things that he or she can 
do to help you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The most important thing will probably be just being with 
you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Beforehand you should talk about what you want, and what you 
don’t want, so that they can support your decisions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is no way  
of knowing what your labour is going to be like or how each of you 
will cope, but there are many ways in which a partner can help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can:
8
LABOUR AND BIRTH
101
•  Keep you company and help 
to pass the time in the  
early stages.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Hold your hand, wipe your 
face, give you 
sips of water,  
massage your 
back and 
shoulders, help 
you move about  
or change 
position, or 
anything else  
that helps.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Comfort you as 
your labour progresses and your 
contractions get stronger.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Remind you how to use 
relaxation and breathing 
techniques, perhaps breathing 
with you if it helps.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Support your decisions, for 
example about pain relief.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Help you to make it clear to 
the midwife or doctor what 
you need – and the other way 
round.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can help you to  
feel much more in control  
of the situation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Tell you what is happening 
as your baby is born if you  
cannot see what is going on  
for yourself.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For many couples, being 
together during labour and 
welcoming their baby together 
is an experience that they 
cannot begin to put into words.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
And many fathers who have 
seen their baby born and who 
have played a part themselves 
say they feel much closer to  
the child from the very start.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
FEEDING 
YOUR BABY
Breastfeeding 
103
Formula feeding 
115
It’s never too early to start thinking about how you are going to feed your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breastfeeding gives your baby the best possible start in life as it has lots of beneﬁts for 
both you and your baby that last a lifetime.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Discuss it with your partner as their help is 
important.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You both might like to watch the Bump to Breastfeeding DVD to see what 
feeding your baby might be like.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have not received a copy of the DVD, ask your 
midwife for one.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your breastmilk is the only food 
designed for your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It contains 
everything your baby needs for 
around the ﬁrst six months of life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After that, giving your baby 
breastmilk alongside solid food 
will help them continue to grow 
and develop.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The World Health 
Organization recommends 
breastfeeding for two years  
or longer.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Breastfeeding protects your 
baby from infections and  
diseases.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It also offers health 
beneﬁts for mums.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Every day 
makes a difference to your baby, 
and the longer you breastfeed,  
the longer the protection lasts.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
And it reduces your chance of 
getting some illnesses later in life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Formula milk cannot give your 
baby the same ingredients or 
provide the same protection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Breastfeeding helps build a strong 
bond between mother and baby, 
both physically and emotionally.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Breastfeeding reduces the risk 
of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
What does breastfeeding 
help protect against?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
102
Your baby:
Ear infections
Asthma 
Eczema
Chest infections
Obesity
Gastro- 
intestinal 
infections
Childhood 
diabetes
Urine 
infections
You:
Breast cancer
Weak bones 
later in life
Ovarian 
cancer
Women who 
breastfeed 
get their 
ﬁgures  
back faster
Help and support
Midwives, health visitors and trained volunteers – or peer supporters 
– can all offer advice and practical help with breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Peer 
supporters are mothers who have breastfed their own babies and have 
had special training to help them support other mothers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your 
midwife or health visitor about the help that is available in your area.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
BREASTFEEDING
Just like any new skill, breastfeeding 
takes time and practice to work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the ﬁrst few days, you and your 
baby will be getting to know each 
other.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Close contact and holding 
your baby against your skin can 
really help with this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The more time you spend with 
your baby, the quicker you will 
learn to understand each other’s 
signs and signals.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The next few 
pages will help you to understand 
how breastfeeding works.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
And 
remember, it’s OK to ask for help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Immediately after  
your baby is born 
Every pregnant woman has milk 
ready for her baby at birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
milk is called colostrum and it is 
sometimes quite yellow in colour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is very concentrated, so your  
baby only needs a small amount  
at each feed, which might be quite 
frequent.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is full of antibodies  
to boost your baby’s ability to  
ﬁght off infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Holding your baby against your skin 
straight after birth will calm them, 
steady their breathing and keep 
them warm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It will also encourage 
them to breastfeed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies are often 
very alert in the ﬁrst hour after birth 
and keen to feed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife can 
help you with this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The ﬁrst few days 
Each time your baby feeds, they are 
letting your body know how much 
milk it needs to produce.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The amount 
of milk you make will increase or 
decrease in line with your baby’s 
needs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Around days two to four, you 
may notice that your breasts become 
fuller and warmer.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is often referred to as your milk 
‘coming in’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To keep yourself as 
comfortable as possible, feed  
your baby as often as they want.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your milk will vary according to  
your baby’s needs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It will look quite 
thin compared with colostrum, but  
gets creamier as the feed goes on.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Let your baby decide when they 
have had enough.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes, breastmilk may leak 
from your breast – try gentle but 
ﬁrm hand pressure on your nipple 
whenever this happens.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This usually helps very quickly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you decide to buy breast pads,  
it is necessary to change them  
at each feed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Plastic-backed ones 
can make you even soggier.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
‘Liquid gold’: the 
perfect food for your 
newborn
Colostrum is sometimes  
called ‘liquid gold’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This  
extra-special breastmilk is full 
of germ-ﬁghting antibodies 
that will help protect your baby 
against infections that you have 
had in the past.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The ﬁrst few 
feeds ‘coat’ your baby’s gut to 
protect them from germs and 
reduce the chances of them 
developing allergies as they  
get older.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Later on, your breastmilk will 
still contain antibodies, and as 
you come across new infections 
you will have new antibodies 
in your milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This means that if 
you get colds or ﬂu while you 
are breastfeeding, your baby 
will automatically get some 
immunity from those illnesses.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
9
FEEDING YOUR BABY
103
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the beginning, it can seem that 
you are doing nothing but feeding, 
but gradually your baby will get 
into a pattern of feeding and the 
amount of milk you produce will 
settle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby will be happier if 
you keep them near you and feed 
them whenever they are hungry.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will quickly help your body to 
produce the amount of milk your 
baby needs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At night, your baby 
will be safest sleeping in a cot in the 
same room as you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will make 
feeding easier and will reduce the 
risk of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to take each 
day as it comes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are very 
uncomfortable or sore, ask for help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
First steps: starting  
to breastfeed 
You can breastfeed in a number  
of different positions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Finding one  
that is comfortable for both of  
you will help your baby feed as  
well as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are lying back in a well 
supported position with your  
baby lying on your tummy, they  
will often move themselves onto 
your breast and begin to feed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember at all times to keep  
your baby safe.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can try feeding lying on your 
side or in a chair, supported in an 
upright position.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will make it 
easier to hold your baby so their 
neck, shoulders and back are 
supported and they can reach your 
breast easily.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Their head and body 
should be in a straight line.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Partners and breastfeeding
As a partner, you can bond with your baby in lots of different  
ways, like bathing, changing nappies and carrying your baby  
in a sling close to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also help by bringing your baby  
to their mother when it’s time for a feed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some parents worry  
that breastfeeding will make it harder for their partner to bond  
with the baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: But this doesn’t have to be the case.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You have an important role to play  
in supporting your partner, for example 
by preparing meals or providing  
extra help so she can get some rest.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can do small, practical things like 
making sure she has a cool drink to 
hand while she is feeding, and later 
you can even give some feeds yourself, 
using expressed milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
1
Hold your baby’s whole body close with 
the nose level with your nipple.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
2
Let your baby’s head tip back a little so 
that their top lip can brush against your 
nipple.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This should help your baby to 
make a wide open mouth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
3
When your baby’s mouth opens wide, the 
chin is able to touch the breast ﬁrst, with 
the head tipped back so that the tongue 
can reach as much breast as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
4
With the chin ﬁrmly touching, and with the 
nose clear, the mouth is wide open, and 
there will be much more of the darker skin 
visible above your baby’s top lip than below 
their bottom lip – and their cheeks will look 
full and rounded as your baby feeds.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby’s sucking causes milk 
stored in your breasts to be 
squeezed down ducts inside your 
breasts towards your nipples.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
is called the ‘let-down’ reﬂex.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
women get a tingling feeling which 
can be quite strong, while others 
feel nothing at all.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will see your 
baby respond and their quick sucks 
change to deep rhythmic swallows 
as the milk begins to ﬂow.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies 
often pause after the initial quick 
sucks while they wait for more 
milk to be ‘delivered’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby 
falls asleep quickly before the deep 
swallowing stage, check that they 
are properly latched on.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It might be 
easier to get someone else to check 
for you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes you will notice 
your milk ﬂowing in response to 
your baby crying or when you have 
a warm bath.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After your baby has ﬁnished 
feeding, you can hold them upright 
on your shoulder to wind them – 
that is, until they burp.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breastfed 
babies don’t usually get as much 
wind as formula-fed babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have any concerns about any 
of these points, talk to your peer 
supporter, midwife, GP or health 
visitor, or contact the National 
Breastfeeding Helpline on  
0300 100 0212.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Note that if your baby seems 
unusually sleepy and/or is slow to 
start feeding, they may be ill, so 
contact your GP as soon as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Helpful tips
Breastfeeding should 
feel comfortable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your 
baby should be relaxed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should hear a soft 
swallowing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it doesn’t 
feel right, start again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Slide one of your ﬁngers 
into your baby’s mouth, 
gently break the suction 
and try again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How do I know that 
my baby is feeding 
well?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Your baby has a large 
mouthful of breast.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Your baby’s chin is ﬁrmly 
touching your breast.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  It doesn’t hurt you to feed 
(although the ﬁrst few sucks 
may feel strong).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If you can see the dark skin 
around your nipple, you 
should see more dark skin 
above your baby’s top lip 
than below their bottom lip.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Your baby’s cheeks stay 
rounded during sucking.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Your baby rhythmically takes 
long sucks and swallows 
(it’s normal for your baby to 
pause from time to time).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Your baby ﬁnishes the feed 
and comes off the breast  
on their own.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tips for breastfeeding 
• Make sure your baby is well 
attached to your breast (see pictures 
on page 104).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will help your 
body make the right amount of 
milk and stop your breasts getting 
sore.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The more you breastfeed 
your baby, the more milk you will 
produce.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When your baby comes 
off the ﬁrst breast, offer the 
second.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It doesn’t matter if they 
are not interested or don’t feed 
for long, or even if they feed for 
longer on the second breast.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
is ﬁne – just start with this breast 
next time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes your baby 
might seem hungrier than usual 
and feed for longer or 
more often.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your body 
responds automatically 
and makes more milk 
to provide the extra 
needed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is why you 
can feed more than one 
baby at the same time 
(see next page).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  There is no need to 
 offer formula milk in  
 addition to breastmilk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby feels  
 hungrier, feed more  
 often, rather than  
 offer formula milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  After a while, you will 
 get to know the signs 
 that mean your baby  
 is ready to feed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most 
 babies will signal that  
 they are hungry by  
 opening and closing  
 their mouths, making 
 sucking noises,  
 opening their eyes or  
 turning their heads to 
 bring their mouths  
 towards you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
By the time a newborn baby starts 
crying, they will normally have 
been hungry for a while.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Try not to give your baby any 
other food or drink before the 
age of about six months.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will 
reduce your milk supply and could 
increase the chance of your baby 
getting ill.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Try not to give your baby a dummy 
until breastfeeding is going  
well, as this can also reduce your 
milk supply.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• When you are out and about, 
wear something that will make it 
easier for you to breastfeed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
don’t forget
to ask
for help
if you need it!
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How do I know my 
baby is getting 
enough milk?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your baby should be healthy 
and gaining weight.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• In the ﬁrst 48 hours, your 
baby is likely to have only two 
or three wet nappies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Wet 
nappies should then start to 
become more frequent, with 
at least six every 24 hours 
from day ﬁve onwards.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Most babies lose weight 
initially.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They should be 
weighed by a health 
professional some time 
around day three to ﬁve.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
From then on, they should 
start to gain weight.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most 
babies regain their birth 
weight in the ﬁrst two weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• At the beginning, your 
baby will pass a black  
tar-like stool (poo) called 
meconium.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
By day three,  
this should be changing  
to a lighter, runnier,  
greenish stool that is  
easier to clean up.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
From day four and for  
the ﬁrst few weeks, 
your baby should pass  
at least two yellow  
stools every day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These 
stools should be at least 
the size of a £2 coin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember, it’s normal  
for breastfed babies to  
pass loose stools.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your breasts and nipples 
should not be sore.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If they 
are, do ask for help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your baby will be 
content and satisﬁed  
after most feeds and  
will come off the breast 
on their own.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are concerned 
about any of these points, 
speak to your midwife or 
health visitor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Dummies
Try not to give your baby a 
dummy until breastfeeding is 
established, usually when your 
baby is a month old.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Using 
dummies has been shown 
to reduce the amount of 
milk that is produced.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your 
baby becomes accustomed 
to using a dummy while 
sleeping, it should not be 
stopped suddenly in the ﬁrst 
six months.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But you should 
stop using a dummy when 
your baby is between six and 
12 months old.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breastfeeding more 
than one baby
Twins, triplets or more can be 
breastfed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Because multiple 
babies are more likely to be born 
prematurely and to have a low 
birth weight, breastmilk is especially 
important for their well-being.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To start with, you may ﬁnd it 
easier to feed each of your babies 
separately, until you feel conﬁdent 
about handling them at the same 
time and feeding is well established.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This may take some time, so it can 
be really helpful to accept any offers 
of help around the house from 
family and friends.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Over time, you will learn what 
works best for you and your babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Triplets can be breastfed either 
two together and then one 
after, or all three rotated at each 
feed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Alternatively, you can use a 
combination of breast and formula, 
depending on the babies and your 
milk supply.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How long should 
I breastfeed?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Exclusive breastfeeding (with 
no other food or drink) is 
recommended for around the ﬁrst 
six months of a baby’s life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After 
this, you can carry on giving your 
baby breastmilk alongside other 
foods for as long as you and your 
baby want.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can be into the 
second year or beyond.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Every day you breastfeed makes  
a difference to you and your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is no need to decide at 
the beginning how long you will 
breastfeed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many mothers continue 
to breastfeed if or when they return 
to work or college.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The practicalities 
will depend on how old your baby 
is and how many feeds they need 
while you are apart, but it’s often 
easier to manage than people 
think.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your peer supporter, midwife, 
health visitor, local support group or 
the National Breastfeeding Helpline 
(0300 100 0212) can explain the 
options and talk them through 
with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you stop breastfeeding, it can 
be difﬁcult to start again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Giving 
formula milk to a breastfed  
baby can reduce your supply  
of breastmilk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

positive

More information
The Equality Bill
The Equality Bill offers mothers 
stronger protection when 
breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The Equality Bill  
will make it clear that it is unlawful 
to force breastfeeding mothers  
and their babies out of places  
like coffee shops, public galleries 
and restaurants.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For further information go to  
www.equalities.gov.uk
