source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Expressing milk
Expressing milk means removing 
milk from your breast.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may 
want to express milk if your breasts 
are feeling uncomfortably full,  
or if your baby is not sucking  
well but you still want to give  
them breastmilk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have to be away from your 
baby – for example, because your 
baby is ill or premature, or because 
you are going back to work – you 
may wish to express milk so that 
somebody else can feed your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can express milk by hand or 
with a breast pump.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Different 
pumps suit different women, so ask 
for information to compare them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A pump needs to be clean and 
sterilised each time it is used.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Expressing by hand 
It is more effective to express milk 
by hand than to use a pump in the 
ﬁrst few days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you want to collect 
the milk, you will need a sterilised 
container.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The following suggestions 
should help:  
1 Before you start, wash your 
hands thoroughly then gently 
massage your breast.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
2 Cup your breast and feel back 
from the end of the nipple to 
where the texture of your breast 
feels different.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STEP 2
3 Using your thumb and the rest of 
your ﬁngers in a C shape, squeeze 
gently about 3 to 6cm behind the 
nipple – this should not hurt.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
4 Release the pressure then repeat, 
building up a rhythm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Avoid 
sliding your ﬁngers over the skin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At ﬁrst, only drops will appear,  
but just keep going as it will  
help build up your supply.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
With practice, and a little time, 
milk will ﬂow freely.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STEP 3
108
STEP 4
5 When no more drops are 
coming, move your ﬁngers round 
to try a different section of your 
breast and repeat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
6 When the ﬂow slows down, 
swap to the other breast.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Keep 
changing breasts until the milk 
is dripping very slowly or stops 
altogether.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
7  If the milk doesn’t ﬂow, try 
moving your ﬁngers slightly 
towards the nipple or further 
away, and try giving your breast  
a gentle massage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Expressing milk if your 
baby is premature or ill 
It is important to start expressing 
your milk as soon as possible 
after your baby is born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To ensure 
that you produce plenty of milk, 
you will need to express at least 
six to eight times in 24 hours, 
including during the night, just as 
your baby might be doing if they 
were able to feed directly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask the 
hospital staff about having skin-
to-skin contact with your baby as 
soon as possible after the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will help with bonding and 
keeping up your milk supply.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Hospitals often have machines 
for expressing milk, and will 
show you how to use one.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Alternatively, you can hire an 
electric breast pump.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Contact 
breastfeeding organisations  
or pump companies directly to 
ﬁnd out about pump hire in  
your area (see page 114 for 
contact details).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are freezing breastmilk 
because your baby is premature 
or ill, ask the staff caring for your 
baby for support and information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Also see opposite for guidance  
on storing breastmilk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife, health visitor or 
peer supporter can give you 
practical help and answer any 
questions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cup feeding
Sometimes, your baby might  
need some extra milk, or ﬁnd it  
hard to feed from your breast.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In this case, your midwife might 
suggest that you give your baby 
some expressed milk in a cup.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Ask her to show you how.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In this 
way, your baby is able to taste  
and begin drinking your milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should not pour milk directly  
into your baby’s mouth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Storing breastmilk 
You can store breastmilk for: 
• up to ﬁve days in the fridge at 
4ºC or lower.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This means putting 
the milk in the coolest part of  
the fridge, usually at the back  
(do not keep it in the door)
• up to two weeks in the freezer 
compartment of a fridge, or
• up to six months in a domestic 
freezer, at minus 18ºC or lower.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breastmilk must always be stored 
in a sterilised container.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you use 
a pump, make sure you wash it 
thoroughly after use and sterilise  
it before use.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Milk should be defrosted  
in the fridge.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once 
it’s defrosted, 
you will need 
to use it 
straight 
away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Milk that has been frozen is still 
good for your baby and better than 
formula milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Milk should not be  
refrozen once thawed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t use  
a microwave oven to warm or 
defrost breastmilk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some common 
breastfeeding 
problems and how  
to solve them 
It can be hard to ask for help,  
but tackling any problems as soon 
as they start will give you more  
time to enjoy these early days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In lots of cases, the solution is as 
simple as changing your baby’s 
position slightly or feeding them  
a bit more often.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Unsettled feeding 
If your baby is unsettled at the 
breast and doesn’t seem satisﬁed  
by feeds, it may be that they are 
sucking on the nipple alone, and  
so are not getting enough milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask for help to get your baby into  
a better feeding position.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sore or cracked nipples
If your nipples hurt, take your  
baby off the breast and start  
again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the pain continues or  
your nipples start to crack or  
bleed, ask for help so you get  
your baby latched on comfortably  
(see page 114 for information on 
how to get help).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can sometimes 
take a little while to sort out how 
to prevent the soreness, but it 
is important to get support  
as soon as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The following suggestions may  
also help:
• Try squeezing out a drop or two 
of your milk at the end of a feed 
and gently rubbing it into your 
skin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Let your nipples dry before 
covering them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you are using breast pads, 
they need to be changed at  
each feed (if possible, use pads 
without a plastic backing).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•�Avoid soap as it dries your 
skin out.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Wear a cotton bra, so air can 
circulate.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Some mothers treat any cracks 
or bleeding with a thin smear of 
white soft parafﬁn or puriﬁed 
lanolin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Put the ointment on the 
crack (rather than the whole 
nipple) to help it heal and prevent 
a scab forming.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tender breasts, blocked  
ducts and mastitis
Milk can build up in the ducts for 
a variety of reasons.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The most 
common are wearing a too-tight 
bra, missing a feed, or a blow to 
the breast.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s important that you 
deal with a blocked duct as soon as 
possible so that it doesn’t lead to 
mastitis (inﬂammation of the breast).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have mastitis, your breasts will 
feel hot and tender.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may see 
a red patch of skin which is painful 
to touch.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can feel quite ill, as if 
you have ﬂu, and you may have a 
temperature.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can happen very 
suddenly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is very important to carry 
on breastfeeding as this will help  
you get better more quickly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you think you might have  
mastitis (or a blocked duct), try  
the following: 
• Take extra care to make sure 
your baby is attached well to  
your breast.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •�Feed your baby more often.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Let your baby feed on the 
tender breast ﬁrst.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
9
FEEDING YOUR BABY
109
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If your breasts still feel full after a 
feed, or your baby cannot feed, 
express your milk (see page 108 
for more information on how to  
do this).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Warmth on your breast before a 
feed can help milk ﬂow and make 
you feel more comfortable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• While your baby is feeding, gently 
stroke the lumpy area with your 
ﬁngertips towards your nipple.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This should help the milk to ﬂow.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Go to bed if 
you can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Take a painkiller such as 
paracetamol or ibuprofen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Ask for help with how you get 
your baby latched on properly  
(see page 114 for information  
on where to get help).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Mastitis may also be a sign of 
infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If there is no improvement 
within 12 to 24 hours, or you start 
to feel worse, contact your GP or 
healthcare professional.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If necessary, 
they can prescribe antibiotics that 
are safe to take while breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Thrush
If you suddenly get sore, bright pink 
nipples after you have been feeding 
without problems for a while, you 
might have an infection known as 
thrush.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask for help to check that 
your baby is latched on properly, and 
make an appointment with your GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You and your baby will both need 
treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can easily give 
thrush to each other, so if your  
baby has it in their mouth you 
will still need some cream for 
your nipples to stop it spreading 
to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may want to ask 
your pharmacist for advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
antifungal creams can be bought 
over the counter from a pharmacy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tongue-tie
Some babies are born with a tight 
piece of skin between the underside 
of their tongue and the ﬂoor of 
their mouth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is known as 
tongue-tie, and it can affect feeding 
by making it hard for your baby to 
attach to your breast.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tongue-tie 
can be treated easily, so if you have 
any concerns talk to your midwife 
or health visitor or contact the  
National Breastfeeding Helpline  
on 0300 100 0212.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Staying healthy 
You don’t need to eat  
anything special while  
you are breastfeeding, just  
make sure you have a  
varied and balanced diet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your milk 
is good  
for your baby 
whatever you eat, but 
there are foods to avoid  
(see next page).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Being a new 
mother is hard work though, so it’s 
important to look after yourself and 
try to eat as varied and balanced a 
diet as you normally would.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Aim to 
eat healthily as a family.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A healthy 
range of food includes:
• at least ﬁve portions of a variety 
of fruit and vegetables a day 
(including fresh, frozen, tinned, 
dried and juiced)
• starchy foods such as wholemeal 
bread, pasta, rice and potatoes 
• plenty of ﬁbre, found in

Peanuts 
Peanuts are one of the most 
common causes of food allergy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Peanut allergy affects about  
1% of people and can cause 
severe reactions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby may 
be at higher risk of developing a 
peanut allergy if you, the baby’s 
father, brothers or sisters have 
a food allergy or other allergic 
condition such as hayfever, 
asthma and/or eczema.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you would like to eat peanuts 
or foods containing peanuts 
(such as peanut butter) while 
breastfeeding, you can choose 
to do so as part of a healthy 
balanced diet, unless you are 
allergic to them or your health 
professional advises you not to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You may have heard that some 
women have, in the past, 
chosen not to eat peanuts while 
they were breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
is because the government 
previously advised women 
that they may wish to avoid 
eating peanuts while they were 
breastfeeding if there was a 
history of allergy in their child’s 
immediate family (such as 
asthma, eczema, hayfever, food 
allergy or other types of allergy), 
in case small amounts of peanut 
in their breastmilk increased the 
chance of the baby developing 
a peanut allergy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But this advice 
has now been changed because 
the latest research has shown 
that there is no clear evidence 
to say that eating or not eating 
peanuts while breastfeeding 
has any effect on your baby’s 
chances of developing a  
peanut allergy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you have a child under 
six months and are not 
breastfeeding (for example 
because you are feeding your 
baby on formula), then there  
is no reason why you should 
avoid consuming peanuts or 
foods containing peanuts.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Alcohol
Generally, adult women should 
not regularly drink more than two 
to three units of alcohol per day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During pregnancy, women are 
advised to avoid drinking.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If they  
do drink, they are advised to drink 
no more than one to two units once 
or twice a week, and are advised 
not to get drunk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
By breastfeeding, you are giving 
your baby the best possible start in 
life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s very unlikely that having an 
occasional drink will harm you or 
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, we do know 
that alcohol passes through to the 
baby in very small amounts in your 
breastmilk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Because of this, if you 
are breastfeeding it is sensible to 
limit your drinking and to keep 
within the limits recommended for 
pregnant women.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
One unit of alcohol is approximately 
equal to a single (25ml) measure  
of spirits, half a pint of beer, or half  
a 175ml glass of wine, although  
it depends on the strength of  
the drink.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The website www.nhs.uk/units 
contains more information on  
units, including the units found  
in typical drinks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you drink alcohol and breastfeed, 
it can affect your baby in a number 
of ways:
• your milk may smell different and 
put your baby off feeding
• the alcohol may make your baby 
too sleepy to feed, or
• your baby may have difﬁculties 
with digestion and problems with 
their sleeping patterns.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Smoking 
Smoking is bad for you, bad for 
your partner and especially bad for 
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
One of the best things 
you can do for your own and your 
baby’s health is to stop smoking.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Each year, more than 17,000 
children under the age of ﬁve are 
admitted to hospital because of 
the effects of secondhand smoke.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Avoid smoking in the home or car, 
and ask your partner, friends and 
family to do the same when they 
are around your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you do smoke and you are 
ﬁnding it difﬁcult to quit, 
breastfeeding will still protect 
your baby from infections and 
give them nutrients they cannot 
get through formula milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Smoking after feeds, rather than 
before, will help reduce your 
baby’s exposure to nicotine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are up to four times more 
likely to stop smoking successfully 
with NHS support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Call the NHS 
Smoking Helpline on 0800 022 
4 332, or the NHS Pregnancy 
Smoking Helpline on 0800 169 9 
169 for information about the wide 
range of free specialist support 
available and for details of your 
local NHS Stop Smoking Service.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also speak to your GP 
or pharmacist about the nicotine 
replacement therapy available to 
help you manage your cravings 
and become smokefree.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

predict when that will be!

breastfeeding
Many illnesses, including depression

Small amounts

The following new advice is based

text:
Choosing a formula
Infant formula milk usually comes 
in powder form and is based on 
processed, skimmed cows’ milk, 
and is treated so babies can digest 
it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vegetable oils, vitamins, minerals 
and fatty acids are added to make 
sure the milk contains the vitamins 
and minerals that young babies 
need.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This information will be 
on the contents list on the pack.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Infant formula powders are not 
sterile, so it is important to follow 
the cleaning and sterilising 
instructions on page 116.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Formula is either ‘whey dominant’ 
or ‘casein dominant’, depending  
on the balance of proteins it 
contains.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may also be referred to 
as stage one or stage two milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Whey-dominant milk is thought 
to be easier to digest than casein-
dominant milk, so should always be 
the ﬁrst formula you give your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is little nutritional difference in 
the two forms of milk, so if whey-
dominant formula milk suits your 
baby, they can stay on it for the ﬁrst 
year or even longer.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
‘Ready-to-feed’ infant formula  
milk in cartons is also available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is generally more expensive 
than powdered milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once opened, 
the carton should be stored in the 
fridge with the cut corner turned 
down.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Do not store it for longer 
than 24 hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can continue giving your baby  
infant formula when they are older 
than six months.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have any worries 
about the infant 
formula milk you are 
giving your baby, 
ask your midwife,  
health visitor or 
GP for advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Helpful tips
There are a number of 
different brands of infant 
formula milk available in the 
shops.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All should meet the 
legal standards for formula 
milk, and it’s up to you to 
decide which one to use.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the past it was thought 
better to stick to one brand, 
but there is no evidence 
to suggest that changing 
brands does any good or  
any harm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vitamin drops
If your baby is formula fed, 
you should give them vitamin 
drops from the age of six 
months or if they are drinking 
less than 500ml of formula 
a day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can buy suitable 
drops at any pharmacy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your midwife or health 
visitor where you can get 
vitamin drops.

text:
Using formula  
milk safely
Powdered infant formula milk  
must be prepared as carefully as 
possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is not a sterile product, 
and even though tins and packets 
of milk powder are sealed, they 
can contain bacteria such as 
Cronobacter sakazakii (formerly 
known as Enterobacter sakazakii) 
and, more rarely, salmonella.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the feed is not prepared safely, 
these bacteria can cause infections.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Infections are very rare, but can 
be life-threatening.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Formula must 
therefore be made up with water 
hot enough to kill the bacteria – at 
least 70ºC.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In practice, this means 
boiling the kettle and leaving it to 
cool for no longer than 30 minutes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Very young babies are at most risk, 
and it is better to use sterile, liquid 
ready-to-feed products for premature 
or low birth weight babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are 
using formula, mix the formula and 
water and cool quickly to feeding 
temperature in cold water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s also essential to make up a  
fresh bottle for each feed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Throw 
away unused formula within two 
hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Bacteria multiply rapidly at 
room temperature and can even 
survive and multiply slowly in some 
fridges, so storing formula milk for 
any length of time increases the risk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sterilising
All the equipment used for feeding 
your baby must be sterilised.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
By 
sterilising your feeding equipment, 
washing your hands and keeping 
the preparation area clean, you will 
reduce the chance of your baby 
getting sickness and diarrhoea.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The following cleaning and 
sterilising instructions apply whether 
you are using expressed breastmilk 
or infant formula milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Clean the 
bottle and teat in hot soapy 
water as soon as possible after a 
feed, using a clean bottle brush.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rinse all equipment in cold, clean 
running water before sterilising.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: 2 Cold water sterilising.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Follow 
the manufacturer’s instructions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Change the sterilising solution 
every 24 hours, and leave 
feeding equipment in the 
solution for at least 30 minutes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure there is no air trapped 
in the bottles or teats when 
putting them in the sterilising 
solution.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Keep all the equipment 
under the solution with a 
ﬂoating cover.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
3 Steam sterilising (electric 
or microwave).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Follow the 
manufacturer’s instructions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure the openings of the 
bottles and teats are facing 
down in the steriliser.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Any 
equipment not used straight 
away should be re-sterilised 
before use.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Preparing a feed 
STEP 1: Before making up a feed, 
clean and disinfect the surface  
you are going to use.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Wash your 
hands carefully.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are using a 
cold water steriliser, shake off any 
excess solution from the bottle and 
the teat or rinse the bottle with 
cooled boiled water from the kettle 
(not the tap).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Stand the bottle on a 
clean surface.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Keep the teat and cap 
on the upturned lid of the steriliser.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Don’t put them on the work surface.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STEP 2
116
STEP 2: Use fresh tap water to ﬁll 
the kettle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After it has boiled, let 
the water cool for no more than 
30 minutes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t use artiﬁcially 
softened water or water that has 
already been boiled.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have  
to use bottled water, you will still  
need to boil it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The water must  
still be hot, otherwise any bacteria 
in the milk powder might not  
be destroyed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For information about using bottled 
water, go to www.eatwell.gov.uk
Always put the partially cooled 
boiled water in the bottle ﬁrst.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Be careful – at 70°C, water is still 
hot enough to scald.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Always check 
that the water level is correct.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Failure to follow the manufacturer’s 
instructions may make your baby ill.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STEP 3
STEP 3: Loosely ﬁll the scoop 
with milk powder and level it  
off using the ﬂat edge of a  
clean, dry knife or the leveller 
provided.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STEP 4
STEP 4: Add the milk powder to the 
water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Repeat, until you have added 
the number of scoops speciﬁed in 
the manufacturer’s instructions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is important to use only the scoop 
that is enclosed with that milk 
powder.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Using too much powder can 
give your baby constipation and lead 
to dehydration; too little could mean 
that your baby is not getting the 
nutrients they need.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t add sugar 
or cereals to the feed in the bottle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STEP 5
STEP 5: Holding the edge of 
the teat, put it on the bottle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Screw the retaining ring onto  
the bottle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cover the teat with  
a cap.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Shake the bottle until  
the powder dissolves.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure you make up a fresh 
bottle each time you feed your  
baby and throw away unused 
feed after two hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Using stored 
formula milk can increase the 
chance of your baby becoming ill.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Feeding your baby
Always cool your baby’s milk down 
before feeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At 70°C, it is still 
hot enough to scald.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To cool it, hold 
the bottle, with the cap covering 
the teat, under cold running water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Test the temperature of the feed by 
dropping a little onto the inside of 
your wrist.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It should just feel warm 
to the touch, not hot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the milk is too cool, and your baby 
doesn’t like it that way, you can 
warm it up a little by putting the  
bottle upright in some hot water, 
keeping the teat out of the water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Never warm milk in a microwave 
oven.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It will continue to heat up for 
a time after you take it out of the 
microwave, even though the outside 
of the bottle may feel cold.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The milk inside may be very hot  
and could scald your baby’s mouth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Get everything you need ready 
before you start feeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Find a 
comfortable position to hold your 
baby while you are feeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
may need to give your baby time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some babies take some milk,  
pause for a nap, and then wake  
up for more.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
So you might have  
to be patient.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember, feeding  
is an opportunity to feel close to 
your baby and get to know them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Even when your baby is a little  
older, they should never be left 
alone to feed with a propped-up 
bottle, as they may choke.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should check regularly that 
teats are not torn or damaged.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When feeding, make sure you keep 
the teat full of milk, otherwise your 
baby will take in air and get wind.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the teat becomes ﬂattened while 
you are feeding, pull gently on the 
corner of your baby’s mouth to 
release the vacuum.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the teat gets 
blocked, replace it with another 
sterile teat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
If you want help or advice on 
formula feeding, talk to your 
midwife or health visitor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See  
the list of useful organisations  
at the back of this book.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
9
FEEDING YOUR BABY
117
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Bottles and teats
You might ﬁnd it useful to have 
about six bottles and teats, so 
you can always have at least one 
or two bottles clean, sterilised 
and ready for use.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your 
midwife or health visitor for 
more information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should always buy new 
teats.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They come in different 
shapes and with different hole 
sizes, and you may have to try 
several before you ﬁnd the one 
that suits your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the hole 
is too small, your baby will not 
get enough milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it’s too big, 
the milk will come too fast.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s best if you can buy new 
bottles too.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Check regularly to 
make sure the bottles are in 
good condition.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If they are badly 
scratched, you will not be able to 
sterilise them properly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If in doubt, 
ask your midwife or health visitor 
for more information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Bottled water
Bottled water is not a healthier 
choice than tap water and 
usually is not sterile.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In fact,  
some natural mineral waters are 
not suitable for babies because 
of the amount of minerals they 
contain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you need to use 
bottled water, remember that 
any bottled water that is labelled 
‘natural mineral water’ might 
contain too much sodium  
for babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are giving bottled water 
to babies under six months,  
you should boil and cool it just 
like tap water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you need to  
use bottled water to make up 
infant formula (for babies of 
any age), you should boil it and 
allow it to cool for no more  
than half an hour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At the end of the feed, sit and  
hold your baby upright and gently 
rub or pat their back for a while  
to bring up any wind.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is no 
need to overdo it – wind is not as 
big a problem as many people think.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Talk to your baby as you rub or pat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will help them feel closer to you 
and get them used to listening to 
your voice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t forget to throw 
away any milk that is not used  
within two hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most babies gradually settle into  
a pattern.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies vary in how  
often they want to feed and how 
much milk they want to take.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Feed your baby when they are 
hungry, just as you would if you 
were breastfeeding, and don’t try 
to force your baby to ﬁnish a bottle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may have had enough for the 
time being or just want a rest.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Feeding away  
from home
The safest way of feeding your 
baby away from home is to carry a 
measured amount of milk powder 
in a small clean and dry container, 
a ﬂask of boiled hot water and an 
empty sterilised feeding bottle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make up a fresh feed whenever  
you need it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The water must still  
be hot when you use it, otherwise 
any bacteria in the milk powder 
might not be destroyed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember 
to cool the bottle under cold 
running water before you use it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Alternatively, you could use  
ready-to-drink infant formula milk 
when you are away from home.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it’s not possible to make up a fresh 
feed, or if you need to transport a 
feed – for example to a nursery or 
childminder – you should prepare  
the feed at home and cool it in the 
back of the fridge for at least one 
hour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Take it out of the 
fridge just before you 
leave, and carry it in 
a cool bag with an  
ice pack and  
use it within  
four hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you reach your destination  
within four hours, take it out of  
the cool bag and store it at the  
back of a fridge for a maximum  
of 24 hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Re-warm for no  
more than 15 minutes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Helpful tips
It is always safer to make up a 
fresh feed whenever possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When this is not possible, feeds 
should never be stored for 
longer than 24 hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
9
FEEDING YOUR BABY
119
Some common 
problems with  
formula feeding
Crying and colic
For information about crying and 
colic, see pages 138–139.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sickness and vomiting
Some babies bring up more milk 
than others during or just after a 
feed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is called ‘possetting’, 
‘regurgitation’ or ‘gastric reﬂux’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is not unusual for babies to  
bring up quite a lot, but it can  
be upsetting when it happens  
and you may be worried that 
something is wrong.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As long as 
your baby 
is gaining 
weight, there 
is usually nothing 
to worry about.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But 
if your baby is violently sick or 
appears to be in pain, or you are 
worried for any other reason, talk  
to your health visitor or GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cover your baby’s front when 
feeding and have a cloth or paper 
towels handy to mop up any mess.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Check too that the hole in your 
baby’s teat is not too big, as giving 
milk too quickly can cause sickness.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sitting your baby upright in a baby 
chair after a feed can also help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The problem usually stops after  
six months when your baby is 
starting on solid foods and drinking 
less milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby brings up a lot of milk, 
remember that they are likely to 
be hungry again quite quickly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t force your baby to take  
on more milk than they want  
during a feed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember, every 
baby is different.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some prefer  
to feed little and often.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Constipation
Always 
stick to the 
recommended 
amount of infant 
formula milk powder.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Using too much can make your 
baby constipated or thirsty.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breastfed babies don’t usually 
get constipated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby is 
under eight weeks old and has not 
passed a stool for a few days, talk 
to your health visitor or GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Water
In very hot weather, babies fed on 
infant formula milk can get thirsty.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this happens, you can give them 
cool boiled tap water if they seem 
unsettled between feeds.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to 
your health visitor or GP if you 
have any concerns.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breastfed babies do not need any 
water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Instead, you may notice that 
they have shorter, more frequent 
feeds if the weather is hotter.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Coping with allergies 
If you think your baby might be 
allergic to formula milk, talk to  
your GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can prescribe formula 
feeds called extensively hydrolysed 
protein feeds.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some formulas are labelled as 
hypoallergenic, but they are not 
suitable for babies with a diagnosed 
cows’ milk allergy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your GP 
before using this milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Always get 
their advice before using soya-based 
infant formulas, too.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies who  
are allergic to cows’ milk may also 
be allergic to soya.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies sometimes grow out of 
allergies, and you may ﬁnd that  
you can introduce cows’ milk into 
your baby’s diet as they get older.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Always ask your GP or health  
visitor for advice before making  
any changes to your baby’s diet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

FIRST DAYS 
WITH YOUR BABY

The ﬁrst few days with your baby can be a very emotional time  
for you and your partner.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: There is a lot to learn and do.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is the excitement of getting to know your baby,  
but you will also be tired and your body will be 
recovering from labour and the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Keep your baby close to you as much as you can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your partner should also spend time holding and 
being close to your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may feel a little left 
out, especially if they have to leave you and the baby 
in hospital and return to an empty home.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may 
need support and encouragement to get involved.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The more you can both hold and cuddle your 
baby, the more conﬁdent you will all feel.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
HOW YOU FEEL
You may feel tired for the ﬁrst few 
days, so make sure you get plenty of 
rest.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Even just walking and moving 
about can seem like hard work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For a lot of mothers, the excitement 
and the pleasure of the new baby 
far outweigh any problems.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But 
you can begin to feel low or rather 
depressed, especially if you are very 
tired or feel you cannot look after 
your baby in the way you would like.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
holding your
close
baby
120
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Giving birth is an emotional 
and tiring experience and your 
hormones change dramatically in 
the ﬁrst few days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women 
get the ‘baby blues’ and feel rather 
weepy around three to ﬁve days 
after giving birth (see page 136).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can be worse if your labour  
was difﬁcult, you are very tired 
or you have other worries.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
women worry because they don’t 
love their baby immediately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is  
not always love at ﬁrst sight.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
may just need to give yourself time 
– you can still care for your baby 
and provide all the warmth and 
security they need.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
POSTNATAL CARE
If you have your baby in hospital, 
you may be able to return home 
with your baby straight from the 
labour ward or you may be moved 
to a transfer lounge or a postnatal 
ward where you will be with other 
mothers and babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should discuss your postnatal 
care with your midwife during 
pregnancy so you know what  
to expect.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are likely to need quite a lot of 
help and advice with your ﬁrst baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Whether you are in hospital or at 
home, the midwives are there to 
guide and support you as well as  
to check that you are recovering 
from the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t hesitate  
to ask for help if you need it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A midwife will be available in your 
community to help you look after 
yourself and your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
10
THE FIRST DAYS WITH YOUR BABY
121
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STITCHES
If you have had stitches, bathe the 
area often in clean warm water 
to help it to heal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Have a bath or 
shower with plain warm water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Afterwards, dry yourself carefully.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the ﬁrst few days, remember  
to sit down gently and lie on your 
side rather than on your back.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pelvic ﬂoor exercises can also help 
you to heal (see page 35).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the stitches are sore and 
uncomfortable, tell your midwife 
as they may be able to recommend 
treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Painkillers will also  
help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are breastfeeding,  
check with your midwife, GP  
or pharmacist before you buy  
over the counter products like 
ibuprofen or paracetamol.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Usually stitches just dissolve by  
the time the cut or tear has healed, 
but sometimes they have to be 
taken out.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Going to the toilet
The thought of passing urine can 
be a bit frightening at ﬁrst if you are 
sore or cannot feel what you are 
doing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Drinking lots of water dilutes 
your urine, but if it is difﬁcult to pass 
urine, tell your midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You probably will not need to open 
your bowels for a few days after the 
birth, but it’s important not to let 
yourself become constipated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eat 
fresh fruit, vegetables, salad and 
wholemeal bread, and drink plenty 
of water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Whatever it may feel like, 
it’s very unlikely that you will break 
the stitches or open up the cut or 
tear again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
BLEEDING
After the birth you will bleed from 
your vagina.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will be quite  
heavy at ﬁrst, which is why you 
will need super-absorbent sanitary 
towels.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Do not use tampons until 
after your postnatal check, as 
they can cause infections.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
While 
breastfeeding you may notice that 
the discharge is redder or heavier.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also feel cramps like period 
pain, known as ‘after pains’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These 
are both because feeding causes the 
uterus to contract.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Gradually, the discharge will 
become a brownish colour and may 
continue for some weeks, getting 
less and less until it stops.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you ﬁnd 
you are losing blood in large clots, 
you should save your sanitary towels 
to show the midwife as you may 
need some treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
SEX AND 
CONTRACEPTION 
Soon after your baby is born, a 
midwife or doctor will talk to you 
about contraception.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this doesn’t 
happen, ask.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can become 
pregnant straight away, even if  
you are breastfeeding or have not 
had a period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure you are using a reliable 
form of contraception before you 
and your partner have sex again, 
unless you want to get pregnant 
(see page 135 for your different 
contraceptive options).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are 
breastfeeding, you may not have 
another period until you stop 
feeding, or even for some weeks 
or months after that.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are 
not breastfeeding, your ﬁrst period 
might start as early as a month after 
the birth, or it might be much later.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
recovery
healing
and
122
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
YOUR BODY
Your body will have gone through 
some major changes over the past 
few days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your breasts
Many women experience changes 
in the size of their breasts during 
pregnancy and breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See Chapter 9 for more information 
about this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you don’t intend to breastfeed 
from the start, you need not do 
anything.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But on the third or fourth 
day, your breasts may be tender 
as the milk is still being produced.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Wearing a ﬁrm, supportive bra  
may help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your breasts will reduce  
in size in a week or so.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Speak to your midwife if you are 
very uncomfortable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your abdomen
Your abdomen will probably be  
quite baggy after delivery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Despite having delivered your  
baby plus the placenta and a lot  
of ﬂuid, you will still be quite a 
lot bigger than you were before 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is partly because 
your muscles have stretched.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you eat a balanced diet and 
exercise, your shape should  
soon return to normal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breastfeeding helps because 
it makes the uterus contract.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes, because this is 
happening, you may feel a quite 
painful twinge in your abdomen  
or period-type pain while you  
are breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your bladder
It’s quite common after having a 
baby to accidentally leak urine if 
you laugh, cough or move suddenly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pelvic ﬂoor exercises (see page 35) 
will help with this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the problem 
persists after three months, see  
your doctor, who may refer you  
to a physiotherapist.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your bowels
Piles (see page 63) are very  
common after delivery but they 
usually disappear within a few  
days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eat plenty of fresh fruit, 
vegetables, salad, brown bread  
and wholegrain cereals, and drink 
plenty of water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This should make 
it easier and less painful when you 
pass a stool.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try not to push or 
strain as this will make the piles 
worse.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Let the midwife know  
if you feel very uncomfortable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They will be able to give you an 
ointment to soothe the piles.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Personal child health 
record (PCHR)
You will be given a PCHR  
for your baby within a few days 
of their birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This book records 
important information about 
your child.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Take it with you 
whenever you see anyone  
about your child’s health  
or development.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is your 
record, so do add information 
yourself.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This could be a note  
of when your child does 
something for the ﬁrst time 
or advice given to you by a 
healthcare professional.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rhesus negative 
mothers
If your blood group is rhesus 
negative and your baby’s father’s 
is rhesus positive, blood samples 
will be taken after the delivery  
to see whether your baby is 
rhesus positive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may need 
an injection to protect your  
next baby from anaemia.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This should be given within  
72 hours of delivery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Helpful tips
Postnatal exercises 
Postnatal exercises 
(see page 133) will 
help to tone up the 
muscles of your pelvic 
ﬂoor and abdomen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They will also get you 
moving and feeling 
generally ﬁtter.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
may be able to attend 
a postnatal exercise 
class at your hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your midwife or 
physiotherapist to help 
you organise this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
10
THE FIRST DAYS WITH YOUR BABY
123
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
YOUR BABY’S 
HEALTH
When your baby is born, they  
will have a quick physical 
examination to check that there are 
no major problems that need urgent 
treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Within 72 hours of  
birth, another more detailed 
examination will be carried out.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can ﬁnd more information  
at www.screening.nhs.uk
Your baby will also have some  
other routine health checks  
and care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cord care  
(belly button)
Shortly after birth, the midwife will 
clamp the umbilical cord close to 
your baby’s navel with a plastic clip.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They then cut the cord, leaving a 
small bit of cord with the clamp 
attached.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The cord will take about a 
week to dry out and drop off.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Keep 
the navel clean and dry until this 
happens.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you notice any bleeding 
or discharge from the navel, tell your 
midwife, health visitor or doctor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vitamin K
We all need vitamin K to make our 
blood clot properly so that we will 
not bleed too easily.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some newborn 
babies have too little vitamin K.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Although this is rare, it can  
cause them to bleed dangerously 
into the brain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To prevent this, 
your baby should be offered 
vitamin K.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be offered  
an injection of vitamin K for  
your baby, as this is the most 
effective way of helping to 
prevent a rare bleeding  
disorder (haemorrhagic  
disease of the newborn).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you prefer that your baby 
doesn’t have an injection,  
oral doses of vitamin K are 
available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Further doses will  
be necessary.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Newborn hearing 
screening 
programme
A small number of babies are 
born with hearing loss.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your 
baby will be given a quick 
and simple test to check their 
hearing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Finding out about 
hearing loss early means that 
babies and parents can get  
the support they need.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This  
can help the development  
of the child’s language  
and social skills.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See  
www.hearing.screening.nhs.uk 
for further information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Newborn blood  
spot screening  
(heel prick test)
When your baby is between 
ﬁve and eight days old, your 
midwife will ask to take a  
sample of blood from their  
heel.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is used to test for  
rare but potentially serious 
illnesses.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All babies are tested  
for phenylketonuria (PKU –  
a metabolic disorder), cystic 
ﬁbrosis, sickle cell disorders  
and congenital hypothyroidism 
(CHT – low thyroid hormone).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some babies are also tested  
for MCADD, an inherited 
problem with the metabolism.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
YOUR BABY’S 
APPEARANCE
You will probably spend the ﬁrst 
few days looking at your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will notice every detail – the 
colour and texture of their hair, 
the shape of their hands and feet, 
and the different expressions on 
their face.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you notice anything 
that worries you, however small, 
ask your midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby 
will be examined by a midwife, 
paediatrician or neonatal nurse 
practitioner to make sure  
everything is all right.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The fontanelle
On the top of your baby’s head, 
near the front, is a diamond-shaped 
patch where the skull bones have 
not yet fused together.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is called 
the fontanelle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It will probably be a 
year or more before the bones close 
over.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may notice the fontanelle 
moving as your baby breathes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t worry about touching it or 
washing the area.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is a tough 
layer of membrane under the skin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More information
124
For more information  
on blood spot screening:  
http://newbornbloodspot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
screening.nhs.uk 
For more information on  
sickle cell screening:  
www.sct.screening.nhs.uk
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Bumps and bruises
It is quite common for a newborn 
baby to have some swelling and 
bruises on its head, and perhaps to 
have bloodshot eyes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is just the 
result of the squeezing and pushing 
that is part of being born and will 
soon disappear.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Birthmarks and spots
Once you begin to look closely at 
your baby, you will probably ﬁnd 
lots of little marks and spots, mainly 
on their head and face.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
babies have larger marks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most of 
them will go away eventually.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask 
the doctor who examines your baby 
if they will disappear completely.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most common are the little pink or 
red marks some people call ‘stork 
marks’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These V-shaped marks on 
the forehead and upper eyelids 
gradually fade, though it may be 
some months before they disappear 
altogether.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Marks on the nape of 
the neck can stay for much longer, 
but they will be covered by hair.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Strawberry marks are also quite 
common.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They are dark red and 
slightly raised.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They sometimes 
appear a few days after birth and 
gradually get bigger.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may take 
a while to go away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Spots and rashes are very common 
in newborn babies and may come 
and go.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should tell your doctor 
or midwife immediately if you also 
notice a change in your baby’s 
behaviour, for example if your baby 
is not feeding properly or is very 
sleepy or very irritable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby’s skin
At birth, the top layer of your 
baby’s skin is very thin and easy 
to damage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Over the ﬁrst month 
(longer in premature babies) your 
baby’s skin matures and develops  
its own natural protective barrier.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vernix (the white sticky substance 
that covers your baby’s skin in the 
uterus) should always be left to 
absorb naturally.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is nature’s 
own moisturiser and gives added 
protection against infection in the 
ﬁrst few days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Premature babies’ skin is even 
more delicate.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Staff in a specialised 
neonatal area will advise you on  
skin care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby is overdue, their skin 
may well be dry and cracked.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
is to be expected, as the protective 
vernix has all been absorbed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t be tempted to use any 
creams or lotions as they 
may do more harm than 
good.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The top layer 
of your baby’s skin 
will peel off over 
the next few days, 
leaving perfect skin 
underneath.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Wash 
your baby with plain 
water only for at least 
the ﬁrst month.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breasts and genitals
A newborn baby’s breasts can be a 
little swollen and ooze some milk, 
whether the baby is a boy or a girl.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Girls also sometimes bleed a bit or 
have a white, cloudy discharge from 
their vagina.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These are a result of 
hormones passing from the mother 
to the baby before birth and are no 
cause for concern.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The genitals of 
male and female newborn babies 
often appear rather swollen, but 
they will look in proportion to their 
bodies in a few weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Jaundice
When they are about three days  
old, many babies develop mild 
jaundice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will make their skin 
and the whites of their eyes look  
a bit yellow.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This usually fades 
within 10 days or so.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But more 
severe jaundice may  
need treatment  
(see page 149).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
getting
to know
each other
10
THE FIRST DAYS WITH YOUR BABY
125
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rubella 
If you were not immune to 
rubella (German measles) 
when tested early in your 
pregnancy, you will usually 
be offered the MMR 
(measles, mumps and rubella) 
immunisation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should get 
this before you leave hospital, 
or shortly afterwards from your 
GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it is not offered, speak 
to your doctor or midwife, as 
it’s a good opportunity to get 
it done.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should not get 
pregnant again for one month 
after the injection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more 
information about rubella, visit 
www.immunisation.nhs.uk
Tests for hepatitis B 
and C 
All babies born to mothers 
who are infected with hepatitis 
B should receive a course of 
immunisation to prevent them 
getting hepatitis B.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby 
will be offered immunisation 
soon after birth and at one, 
two and 12 months old.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby should be tested 
at 12 months to check that 
immunisation has worked.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more information about 
hepatitis B immunisation, refer 
to page 37.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are infected with 
hepatitis C when your baby 
is born, there is a small risk 
that you could pass on the 
infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby will be 
tested at an appropriate time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
126
WHAT YOUR 
NEWBORN BABY 
CAN DO 
There is one important skill that 
your baby will not have to learn.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They are born knowing how to 
suck.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During the ﬁrst few days they 
learn to co-ordinate their sucking 
and their breathing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Newborn babies also automatically 
turn towards a nipple or teat if it is 
brushed against their cheek, and 
they will open their mouths if their 
upper lip is stroked.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can also 
grasp things (like your ﬁnger) with 
either their hands or feet, and they 
will make stepping movements 
if they are held upright on a ﬂat 
surface.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Apart from sucking, these 
automatic responses will go, and 
your baby will begin to make 
controlled movements instead.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Newborn babies can use all of their 
senses.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They will look at people and 
things, especially if they are near, 
and particularly at people’s faces.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They will enjoy gentle touch and the 
sound of a soothing voice, and they 
will react to bright light and noise.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Very soon they will also know their 
mother’s special smell.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WHAT YOU  
NEED 
FOR YOUR BABY
Nappies  
127
Bathing  
128
Sleeping 
129
Out and about 
130
In the car 
130
Feeding 
131
Clothes  
131
It can be easy to get confused about what you really need for your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can always 
ask your midwife or health visitor for advice on what to buy, and you may be given a 
list of essentials at your antenatal classes or by your maternity service.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There are some 
essentials that every new mother needs, as well as extras that you might want to think 
about.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be able to borrow some items, and then pass them on later to another 
mother or keep them for a second child.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
NAPPIES 
Disposable nappies
Disposable nappies are convenient 
to use and are available from 
supermarkets and other retail outlets.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cloth nappies
Washable cloth nappies are cheaper 
than disposable nappies, even when 
you take into account the cost of 
washing them at home or getting 
them washed by a laundry service.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They are more environmentally 
friendly and are easily laundered in 
a 60ºC wash.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can get shaped 
cloth nappies with Velcro or popper 
fastenings and waterproof wraps.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For cloth nappies, you will need:
•  nappy pins for nappies without 
Velcro or fasteners
•  nappy liners – either disposable 
or cloth, which you can wash and 
use again
•  a bucket with a lid and nappy 
sterilising powder or liquid for 
sterilising nappies, and
•  about four pairs of plastic 
pants that are either tie-on or 
elasticated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tie-on ones will ﬁt 
small babies better.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some cloth 
nappies have the waterproof 
wraps attached.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More information
For information about 
choosing and using 
cloth nappies, visit  
www.wen.org.uk, or visit  
www.goreal.org.uk to ﬁnd 
local suppliers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Nappy services 
Nappy laundry services deliver 
freshly laundered nappies to  
your home and take away the  
soiled ones to wash each week.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They supply everything you  
need – wraps, liners and  
storage bins.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Nappy changing
To change nappies, you will need:
•  cotton wool.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Always choose 
white.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rolls are usually cheaper 
than balls
•  a changing mat
• baby lotion or wipes 
• baby barrier cream to help 
prevent nappy rash, and
•  a bag to carry all the nappy-
changing equipment when you  
go out.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A carrier bag will do but 
you can get special bags that 
include a changing mat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
BATHING
It is a personal choice how 
frequently you bathe your baby;  
a wash will often be enough to 
keep your baby clean and ensure 
they are comfortable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A warm bath 
may help your baby to sleep.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will need:
•  a baby bath or any large, 
clean bowl, such as a sink,  
as long as it’s not metal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember to wrap a towel  
round the taps for safety 
•  two towels, the softer the better.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Keep them only for your baby’s 
use.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is no need for special 
baby towels, unless you want them
•  unperfumed soap – although 
washing your baby with just 
water is ﬁne.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See page 144 for how to bathe 
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Safety 
The safest place to change 
a nappy is on a mat on the 
ﬂoor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you use a higher 
surface, keep your hand 
on your baby at all times 
to stop them rolling off.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See page 144 for how to 
change your baby’s nappy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
SLEEPING
For the ﬁrst few months, you will 
need a crib, a carry cot or a Moses 
basket (a light, portable bassinet).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby needs somewhere to 
sleep that is safe and warm and 
not too far away from you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
are borrowing a crib or cot, or if 
you have one that has been used 
by another of your children, you 
will need a new mattress.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See the 
section on reducing cot death on 
the right.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will also need:
•  a ﬁrm mattress that ﬁts the cot 
snugly without leaving spaces 
round the edges so that your 
baby cannot trap their head 
and suffocate
• sheets to cover the mattress.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You need at least four because 
they need to be changed 
often.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fitted sheets make 
life easy but they are quite 
expensive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You could use  
pieces of old sheet
•  light blankets for warmth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pillows and duvets are not 
safe for babies less than a 
year old because of the risk of 
suffocation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Duvets can also 
make the baby too hot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Baby nests and quilted sleeping 
bags are not suitable for your 
baby to sleep in when you are 
not there because of the  
danger of suffocation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cot safety
Your baby will spend many hours 
alone in a cot, so make sure it’s safe.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  The mattress must ﬁt snugly with 
no space for your baby’s head to 
get stuck.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  The bars must be smooth and 
securely ﬁxed, and the distance 
between each bar should be not 
less than 1 inch (25mm) and not 
more than 2 ½ inches (60mm) 
so that your baby’s head cannot 
become trapped.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  The cot should be sturdy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  The moving parts should work 
smoothly so that ﬁngers or 
clothing cannot get trapped.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Cot bumpers are not 
recommended as babies can 
overheat or become entangled  
in the fastenings.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Never leave anything with ties – 
for example, bibs or clothes – in 
the cot in case they get caught 
around your baby’s neck.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If you are buying a new cot, 
look for the British Standard  
mark BS 1753.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The baby on the left is sleeping in the ‘feet to foot’ position (also 
see page 140).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This means that the baby’s feet are right at the end of the 
cot to prevent the baby wriggling under the covers and overheating.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
11
WHAT YOU NEED FOR YOUR BABY
129
Reducing the risk of 
cot death
The Foundation for the Study 
of Infant Deaths (FSiD) has 
developed important key 
messages for parents to help  
to reduce the risk of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Place your baby on their back 
to sleep, in a cot in a room 
with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Do not smoke in pregnancy 
or let anyone smoke in the 
same room as your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•� Do not share a bed with 
your baby if you have been 
drinking alcohol, if you take 
drugs or if you are a smoker.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Never sleep with your baby 
on a sofa or armchair.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Do not let your baby get 
too hot – keep your baby’s 
head uncovered – and place  
your baby in the ‘feet to foot’ 
position.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
OUT AND ABOUT
Spend some time looking at what 
is available for getting around with 
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Think about what will 
suit you best.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You could always 
ask other mothers what they have 
found useful.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Baby carriers (also called slings) 
carry your baby in front of you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most babies like being carried like 
this because they are close to you 
and warm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The back part of the 
carrier must be high enough to 
support your baby’s head.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Check 
that the buckles and straps that 
attach the carrier to you are secure.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Older babies who can hold up their 
heads and whose backs are stronger 
(at about four months) can be 
carried in backpacks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pushchairs are only suitable for 
young babies if they have fully 
reclining seats that let your baby 
lie ﬂat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Wait until your baby can sit 
up before using any other type of 
pushchair.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should also consider 
the weight of the pushchair if you 
use public transport as you might 
have to lift it onto trains or buses.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Prams give your baby a lot of space 
to sit and lie comfortably, although 
they take up a lot of space and are 
hard to use on public transport.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have a car, look for a pram 
that can be dismantled easily.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Buy a pram harness at the same 
time, as you will soon need it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby 
can sleep in the carrycot for the 
ﬁrst few months and the cot can 
be attached to the frame to go out.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can also be taken in a car with 
appropriate restraints.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is a carrycot 
and transporter (set of wheels)  
that can be converted into a 
pushchair when your baby 
outgrows the carrycot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Shopping trays that ﬁt under 
the pushchair or pram can be very 
useful when you are out.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
IN THE CAR
If you have a car, you must have a 
car seat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is also called a safety 
restraint.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby must always go 
in their seat, including when you 
bring them home from the hospital.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s very dangerous – and illegal – 
to carry your baby in your arms.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The best way for your baby to 
travel is in a rear-facing infant 
car seat, on either the front 
or back seat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is held  
in place by the adult  
safety belt.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Checks
Before buying a pushchair or 
pram, check that:
•  the brakes are in good 
working order
•  the handles are at the right 
height for pushing, and
•  the frame is strong 
enough.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:

travel is in a rear-facing infant
car seat, on either the front
or back seat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is held 
in place by the adult
safety belt.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have a car with  
air bags in the front, your  
baby should not travel in  
the front seat, even if they  
are facing backwards,  
because of the danger of 
suffocation if the bag inﬂates.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To keep your baby as safe as 
possible:
• Make sure the car seat is 
ﬁtted correctly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Do not place a rear-facing infant 
car seat in the front passenger 
seat if your car is ﬁtted with an  
air bag.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Don’t buy a second-hand car 
seat as it may have been  
damaged in an accident.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Look for United Nations ECE 
Regulation number R44.03, or  
a later version of this standard,  
when you buy a car seat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This  
is the standard for new seats.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, if you have car seats that 
conform to a British Standard or  
to an earlier version of R44, you 
can continue to use them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
FEEDING
If you are going to breastfeed, you 
will probably want:
• nursing bras that open at the 
front and have adjustable straps.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cotton is best because it allows air 
to circulate.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you try on bras at 
about 36–38 weeks, they should 
ﬁt when you need them
• breast pads.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You put these into 
your bra to prevent milk from 
leaking onto your clothes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are going to formula feed,  
you will need:
•  six bottles with teats and caps
•  sterilising equipment
•  a bottle brush
•  infant formula milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Avoid buying 
this too far in advance, as instant 
formula milk has a ‘use by date’ 
printed on the package.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See Chapter 9 for how to feed  
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
CLOTHES 
Babies grow very quickly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All you 
need for the ﬁrst few weeks are 
enough clothes to make sure that 
your baby will be warm and clean.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will probably need:
•  six stretch suits for both day and 
night or four stretch suits and  
two nighties for the night.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Use socks or bootees with the 
nightie if it’s cold
•  two cardigans.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They should be 
wool or cotton rather than  
nylon, and light rather than  
heavy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Several light layers of 
clothing are best for keeping  
your baby warm
•  four vests
•  a shawl or blanket to wrap 
your baby in
•  a wool or cotton hat, mittens 
and socks or bootees for going 
out if the weather is cold.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s better to choose close-knitted 
patterns for safety
•  a sun hat for going out if the 
weather is hot or the sun  
is bright.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Washing  
baby clothes
If you use a washing 
machine, don’t use washing 
powders with enzymes 
(bio powders) or fabric 
conditioner, as they may 
irritate your baby’s skin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Always rinse clothes  
very thoroughly.

THE EARLY WEEKS: 
YOU

132

133
