Your postnatal check 
136
Your ﬁrst few weeks at home can be an exciting but anxious time for parents as you get 
used to caring for your new baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have been in hospital or a midwifery unit, you may feel apprehensive about  
being on your own without staff on call to help you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The more you handle your baby,  
the more your conﬁdence will increase.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
And your community midwife, health visitor and 
GP are there to support you if you have any worries or problems.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask your midwife  
or health visitor for a copy of the book Birth to Five, which has advice 
on looking after your child up to the age of ﬁve.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
PARTNERS
As the mother’s partner, you 
can get involved in caring  
for your baby from day one.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the ﬁrst weeks, you can:
•  help your baby’s mother to  
 
breastfeed by:
 –   spending time with her 
while the baby is feeding
–   bringing your baby 
to their mother when 
they need feeding in  
the night
–   helping to wind 
your baby
 – getting specialist help and information 
 on breastfeeding if the mother has  
 any concerns
• provide emotional support and 
encouragement
• make nutritious meals and snacks for 
your baby’s mother
• change your baby’s nappies
• bathe and dress 
your baby
• cuddle and play 
with your baby
• clean the house, 
go shopping  
and do other 
household chores.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
132
You may feel quite nervous about handling the baby at ﬁrst  
but you will get more conﬁdent.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t be embarrassed to  
ask for help or encouragement.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
HELP AND 
SUPPORT
You will probably need a lot of 
practical help, as well as emotional 
support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are bound to feel up 
and down and to get tired easily in 
the ﬁrst few weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many women 
want to have their partner around 
so that you get to know the baby 
together and have help with the 
work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Being together at this time 
helps you to start to adjust to the 
changes in your life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are on 
your own, or your partner cannot 
be with you, ask your mother or a 
close friend to be there.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Even with help, you will probably 
feel tired.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Here are some things you 
could try:
•  Cut down on cleaning – a bit of 
dust will not hurt.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Keep meals simple but healthy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You need to eat well but this 
need not involve a great deal of 
preparation and cooking.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Try to space visitors out and say no 
to visitors if you feel too tired or 
need some time with your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Too many visitors in a short time 
can be very tiring.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If visitors do 
come, don’t feel you have to tidy 
up or lay on a meal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Let them do 
things for you, like the washing 
up, making a meal or bringing 
some groceries.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  If you need extra help, ask.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Friends 
or neighbours will probably be 
very willing to help you by doing 
things like shopping.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
LOOKING AFTER 
YOURSELF
Although you may feel like your 
every waking hour is spent caring 
for your baby, it’s important to look 
after yourself as well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rest
While you are feeding your baby at 
night and your body is recovering 
from childbirth, it is essential to 
catch up on rest.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s tempting to use your baby’s 
sleep times to catch up on  
chores, but try to have a sleep  
or a proper rest at least once  
during the day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Exercise
Continue with any postnatal 
exercises you have been shown  
by your midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also do 
this deep stomach exercise when 
you feel well enough.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
1 Lie on your side with your 
knees slightly bent.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
2 Let your tummy relax and 
breathe in gently.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
3 As you breathe out, gently 
draw in the lower part of  
your stomach like a corset, 
narrowing your waistline.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: 4 Squeeze your pelvic ﬂoor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
5 Hold for a count of 10 
then gently release.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should not move your back  
at any time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After six weeks, 
progress to the box position  
(see page 34).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Besides these exercises, try to  
ﬁt in a walk with your baby  
every day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This  
can help you lose 
weight and feel 
better.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
12
THE EARLY WEEKS: YOU
133
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eating properly
It’s very important to eat properly 
(see Chapter 3).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you want to lose 
weight, don’t rush it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A varied diet 
without too many fatty foods will 
help you lose weight gradually.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try 
to make time to sit down, relax and 
enjoy your food so that you digest 
it properly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It doesn’t have to be 
complicated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try food like baked 
potatoes with baked beans and 
cheese, salads, pasta, French bread 
pizza, scrambled eggs or sardines on 
toast, followed by fruit mixed with 
yoghurt or fromage frais.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A healthy diet is especially 
important if you are breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breastfeeding can help mothers to 
lose weight.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some of the fat you 
put on in pregnancy will be used to 
help produce milk, but the rest of 
the nutrients will come from your 
diet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This means that you may be 
hungrier than usual.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you do need 
a snack, try having beans on toast, 
sandwiches, bowls of cereal or fruit 
(see page 29).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sure Start Children’s Centres give 
advice about healthy eating plans 
for mothers, as well as support for 
breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can ﬁnd out 
more about the services offered in 
Children’s Centres in your area by 
visiting www.surestart.gov.uk
YOUR 
RELATIONSHIPS
After you have had a baby, the 
relationships around you can 
change.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many women ﬁnd that 
they turn to their own mother for 
help and support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But your mother 
may not be sure about how much 
to get involved.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may ﬁnd that 
she is trying to take over or that she 
is so anxious not to interfere that 
she doesn’t help at all.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to let her 
and others know what help and 
support you want from them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your relationship with your partner 
will also change.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is very easy in 
those exhausting early weeks just 
to leave things to sort themselves 
out.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may wake up six months 
later to ﬁnd that you have not spent 
an hour alone together and have 
lost the knack of easily talking your 
problems through.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You both need 
time alone, without the baby, to 
recharge your own batteries.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
also need time together, without 
the baby, to keep in touch with 
each other.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your relationship with your baby 
may not be easy either, particularly 
if you are not getting much sleep.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t feel guilty if you sometimes 
feel resentful at the demands your 
baby makes, or if your feelings are 
not what you expected them to be.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to your midwife or health  
visitor if you are upset or worried.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But remember, many mothers ﬁnd 
their babies difﬁcult at ﬁrst and 
come to love them gradually over 
some weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are on your own and  
don’t have family to support you, 
ask a friend to help you in the  
early weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sex and contraception
There are no rules about when to 
start having sex again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t rush 
into it – if it hurts, it will not  
be pleasurable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may want  
to use a lubricating jelly the ﬁrst 
time because hormone changes 
may make your vagina feel drier 
than usual.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
THE EARLY WEEKS: YOU
It might be some time before you 
want to have sex.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Until then, you 
both may feel happier ﬁnding other 
ways of being loving and close.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you or your partner have any 
worries, discuss them with your GP 
or health visitor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is possible to get pregnant even 
if you have not started your periods 
again or if you are breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is therefore important to use 
contraceptives as 
soon as you  
start having  
sex again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your midwife or 
doctor should 
talk to you about contraception 
before you leave hospital and again 
when you go for your six-week 
postnatal check.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Alternatively, you 
could talk to your midwife or health 
visitor when they visit you at home 
or go to your GP or community 
contraceptive clinic (sometimes 
called family planning or CASH 
clinic).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The FPA (Family Planning 
Association – see page 184) 
publishes free leaﬂets about  
all methods of contraception.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Contraceptives
Short-acting  
contraceptive methods
Short-acting contraceptive 
methods rely on you taking them 
every day or when you have sex.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This may be 
the easiest choice for the 
early weeks after childbirth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Condoms offer the best 
protection against sexually 
transmitted infections (STIs) so 
if you think you or your partner 
may have been exposed to an 
STI you should use a condom in 
addition to your other choice  
of contraception.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  The combined pill.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are 
not breastfeeding, you can start 
taking this pill 21 days after you 
give birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you start it later 
than the 21st day, it will not be 
reliable for the ﬁrst seven days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
So for this time you will have to 
use another contraceptive (like a 
condom) as well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t take this 
pill if you are breastfeeding as it 
reduces milk ﬂow.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  The progestogen-only pill.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are breastfeeding, you 
can take a progestogen-only 
pill, which will not affect your 
milk supply.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can also be 
started 21 days after you give 
birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It has to be taken at the 
same time every day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
start it later than the 21st day, 
it will not be reliable for two 
days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
So for this time you will 
have to use some other form of 
contraceptive (like a condom) 
as well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is no evidence 
to suggest that this pill affects 
your baby in any way.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Even so, 
some women prefer not to take 
it while they are breastfeeding 
and use another form of 
contraception instead.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  The cap or diaphragm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These 
can be used six weeks after 
you give birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you had a cap 
before, it probably will not be 
the right size any longer.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
can have a new one ﬁtted at 
your postnatal check-up.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Long-acting  
contraceptive methods
Long-acting contraceptive 
methods last between three 
months and ten years.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They  
may be suitable if you think  
you will forget to take or use  
a short-acting contraceptive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  The IUD (intra-uterine device) 
or IUS (intra-uterine system).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These can be ﬁtted from the 
fourth week after you give 
birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can be ﬁtted at your 
postnatal check-up when your 
uterus is back to its normal size.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • The contraceptive injection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is recommended that you wait 
until six weeks after you give 
birth before you are given this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be given earlier in some 
circumstances.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The contraceptive 
injection will not affect your milk 
supply if you are breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• The contraceptive implant 
(Implanon).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This contains a 
long-lasting progestogen and  
is effective for three years.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be ﬁtted 21 days after 
you give birth or earlier in some 
circumstances.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it’s ﬁtted after 
21 days, you will have to use 
another contraceptive for seven 
days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The contraceptive implant 
will not affect your milk supply  
if you are breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
12
THE EARLY WEEKS: YOU
135
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
THE ‘BABY BLUES’ 
AND POSTNATAL 
DEPRESSION
As many as 8 out of 10 mothers get 
the ‘baby blues’, often about three 
to ﬁve days after the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
might feel upset, mildly depressed, 
or just keep bursting into tears for 
no apparent reason.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It usually only 
lasts for a few days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Around 1 in 10 mothers become 
depressed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is usually mild but 
sometimes can be quite severe.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must get help if you are taken 
over by a feeling of sadness and 
hopelessness, you feel irritable 
and anxious, or you have difﬁculty 
sleeping and coping with even the 
smallest task.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See page 82 for  
more information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
YOUR POSTNATAL 
CHECK
You should have your postnatal 
check about six weeks after your 
baby’s birth to make sure that you 
feel well and are recovering from 
the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be offered an 
appointment to go back to the 
hospital or midwifery unit where 
you gave birth, but otherwise  
you should see your GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s time  
to introduce your baby to your  
GP as the new member of  
your family!
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s a good opportunity to ask 
any questions and sort out any 
problems that are troubling you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may like to make a list of 
questions to take along with you  
so that you don’t forget what  
you want to ask.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
What usually happens
•  You will be weighed and can 
get weight loss advice if you  
need it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Your urine will be tested to 
make sure your kidneys are 
working properly and that  
there is no infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Your blood pressure will be 
checked.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  You may be offered an 
examination to see if:
- your stitches (if you had any) 
have healed
- your uterus is back to its 
normal size, and
- all the muscles used during 
labour and delivery are  
returning to normal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tell the doctor if the examination  
is uncomfortable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your breasts are unlikely to be 
examined unless you have a 
particular concern.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• A cervical smear test may be 
discussed if you have not had one 
in the past three years (see page 
48).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is usually delayed until 
three months after delivery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you are not immune to rubella 
(German measles) and were not 
given an immunisation before you 
left hospital, you will be offered 
one now.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should not become 
pregnant for one month after this 
immunisation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You will be asked if you still have 
any vaginal discharge and whether 
you have had a period yet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Tell your doctor if:
- you are having trouble holding 
in urine or wind, or you are 
soiling yourself
- intercourse is painful
- you are feeling very tired, 
low or depressed, or
- you are worried about anything.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also ask your doctor about 
contraception.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may wish to 
choose a different method to 
the one you had previously used 
(especially if your pregnancy  
was not planned).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The doctor or  
nurse can help you decide which 
method is right for you now.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See the box on page 135 for  
some of the different options.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
If you think you are depressed, 
contact your GP or health 
visitor and explain how you are 
feeling.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your partner or a friend 
could contact them for you if 
you want.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also contact 
the Association for Post-Natal 
Illness (see page 186) for more 
information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have twins or triplets,  
you are more likely to experience 
postnatal and longer-term 
depression.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is mainly because 
of the additional stress of caring 
for more than one baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Just 
getting out of the house can be 
difﬁcult when you have more 
than one baby, and this can make 
you feel isolated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tamba (see page 
188) can help you make contact 
with other mothers of multiples 
via local twins clubs and through 
their helpline – Tamba Twinline on 
0880 138 0509 – where you can 
talk to other mothers of multiples.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also ﬁnd it helpful 
to contact the Multiple Births 
Foundation (see page 183).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby’s check
Your GP’s surgery or health 
clinic will probably arrange 
for your baby’s six-week 
check to be done at your 
postnatal check.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you go 
to the hospital, the baby’s 
check will usually need to  
be arranged separately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

In the ﬁrst few weeks, you will be learning how to look after your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will start to 
understand them and will learn what is normal and what may be a sign that something  
is wrong.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But the most important thing to do in the ﬁrst few weeks is to enjoy your  
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Spending time with them is the best way to help them feel safe and loved.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ENJOYING  
YOUR BABY
Keeping your baby warm, fed and 
safe may seem to take up all of your 
time in the ﬁrst weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But they are 
only a tiny part of what it means to 
be a parent.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Every second that your 
baby is awake, they are learning 
from you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Learning about what it 
feels like to be touched gently, the 
sound of your voice and your very 
special smell.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They are learning about what the 
world is like and, above all, what it 
feels like to love and be loved.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is 
important to talk to your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
to your
listening
voice
Talking to your baby 
It is very important to talk to 
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you or your family 
speak another language, use 
it to speak to your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can 
help your baby to learn other 
languages, and enjoy another 
culture.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can talk to them 
about anything and everything.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talking to young children, even 
very young babies helps them 
become good communicators 
later in life.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It will also help 
your baby build their early 
bond with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
REGISTERING  
THE BIRTH
Your baby’s birth must be registered 
within six weeks from when they 
were born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will take place at 
the register ofﬁce in the district 
where they were born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The contact 
details will be in the telephone 
book under the name of your local 
authority or you can ﬁnd it online  
at www.direct.gov.uk
If you are married, you or the father 
can register the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are not 
married, you may register together 
with your baby’s father and his name 
will appear on the birth certiﬁcate.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In most circumstances, children 
beneﬁt from being acknowledged 
by both parents and by knowing the 
identity of both their mother and 
father.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To register jointly, you must 
either go together to register the 
birth or one of you can go with an 
appropriate document.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Including 
the father’s name in the birth 
register will usually give him parental 
responsibility.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your local register 
ofﬁce will explain this process.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At the moment, if you are not 
married, you can decide whether 
you want the father’s name to 
appear on the birth certiﬁcate.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you do not want his name to 
appear, you can register the birth  
by yourself.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, the 
government plans to change the  
law so that joint registration, by both 
mother and father, becomes the 
normal arrangement for unmarried 
parents.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your local register ofﬁce 
will be able to provide detailed 
information about these changes 
when they come into effect.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you live in a different district from 
the one where your baby was born, 
you can go to your nearest register 
ofﬁce.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The registrar will take details 
from you and then send them to 
the district where your baby was 
born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will then be sent the 
birth certiﬁcate.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You cannot claim 
beneﬁts, such as Child Beneﬁt,  
until you have a birth certiﬁcate.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All babies born in England and 
Wales are now given a unique 
NHS number at birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Midwives 
request and receive a newborn 
baby’s NHS number.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They send 
this NHS number to the 
Registrar of Births,  
Deaths and 
Marriages via 
your local 
child health 
department.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
CRYING
All babies cry.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s their way of 
saying that something is not right.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes you will be able to ﬁnd 
the reason for your baby’s distress 
and deal with it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At other times 
all you can do is try to comfort or 
distract your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it’s not obvious 
why your baby is crying, think of 
possible reasons.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  hot, cold or uncomfortable?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  feeling tired and unable to sleep?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  lonely and wanting company?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  bored and wanting to play?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Do they have:
•  a wet or dirty nappy?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It could be none of these things.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Perhaps your baby simply feels 
overwhelmed and a 
bit frightened by all 
the new sights, 
sounds and 
sensations.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Comforting  
your baby
Holding your baby close and 
talking in a soothing voice or 
singing softly will reassure them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Movement often helps to calm 
down crying.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Gently sway or rock 
your baby or take them for a walk 
or for a ride in a car.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Sucking can also be comforting.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can put your baby to your 
breast or give them a dummy,  
as long as breastfeeding  
is well established  
(see page 
106).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make 
sure the 
dummy is 
sterilised and don’t 
dip it in honey or 
sugar to make your baby suck.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: They will suck anyway.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Using 
sugar will only encourage a 
craving for sweet things, which 
are bad for their teeth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

When crying gets  
too much
Some babies do cry more than 
others and it’s not really clear why.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t blame yourself, your partner 
or your baby if they cry a lot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can 
be very exhausting so try to get 
rest when you can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Share soothing 
your baby with your partner.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
could ask a friend or relative to take 
over for an hour from time to time, 
just to give you a break.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If there 
is no one to turn to and you feel 
your patience is running out, leave 
your baby in the cot and go into 
another room for a few minutes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Put on some music to drown the 
noise, take some deep breaths, 
make yourself a cup of tea or ﬁnd 
some other way to unwind.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will 
cope better if you do.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are very 
angry or upset, telephone someone 
who will make you feel better.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Never shake your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Shaking 
makes a baby’s head move violently.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can cause bleeding and damage 
the brain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Getting help
If you feel you are having difﬁculties 
coping with your baby’s crying, talk 
to your midwife or health visitor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Or 
contact Cry-sis on 08451 228669 – 
they will put you in touch with other 
parents who have been in the same 
situation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have twins or more, 
the crying can seem relentless – 
Twinline, Tamba’s helpline (see page 
188), can offer support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby’s crying sounds 
different or unusual, it may be the 
ﬁrst sign of illness, particularly if 
they are not feeding well or will 
not be comforted.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you think 
your baby is ill, contact your doctor 
immediately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you cannot contact 
your doctor and it’s an emergency, 
take your baby to the nearest 
hospital accident and emergency 
department.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Colic
If your baby has repeated episodes of excessive and inconsolable 
crying but they otherwise appear to be thriving and healthy,  
they may have colic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Although it may appear that your baby is in distress, colic is not 
harmful.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Your baby will continue to feed and gain weight normally.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: There is no evidence that colic has any long-term effects.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Colic can be very upsetting for parents.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may feel like you are letting 
your baby down or that you are doing something wrong.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Although 
colic can be distressing at the time, it is a common phase that should 
last only a few weeks at the most.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may help to remind yourself that 
you are not causing the crying and it is not under your control.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
are concerned, talk to your health visitor or GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
SLEEP 
The amount that babies sleep, even 
when they are very small, varies a 
lot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During the early weeks some 
babies sleep for most of the time 
between feeds.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Others will be 
wide awake.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As they grow older, 
they begin to develop a pattern of 
waking and sleeping.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some babies 
need more sleep than others and at 
different times.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try not to compare 
what your baby does with other 
people’s babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All babies are 
different, and their routines will 
change as they grow.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will gradually begin to 
recognise when your baby is ready 
for sleep and is likely to settle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
babies settle better after a warm 
bath.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Most sleep after a good feed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A baby who wants to sleep is not 
likely to be disturbed by ordinary 
household noises, so there is no 
need to keep your whole home 
quiet while your baby sleeps.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It will 
help you if your baby gets used to 
sleeping through a certain amount of 
noise.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See the column on the right 
for advice on sleeping positions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Twins, triplets or more can have 
speciﬁc sleeping issues and it may 
be difﬁcult for you to get them 
into a routine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The Multiple Births 
Foundation and Tamba (see pages 
183 and 188) have information  
that you may ﬁnd useful.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can 
sleep in the same cot – there is 
information from Tamba on  
how you can do this safely.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Reducing the risk  
 of cot death
Sadly, we don’t know why some 
babies die suddenly and for no 
apparent reason from what is 
called ‘cot death’ or ‘Sudden 
Infant Death Syndrome’ (SIDS).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But we do know that placing 
a baby to sleep on their back 
reduces the risk, and that 
exposing a baby to cigarette 
smoke or overheating a baby 
increases the risk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All the advice that we now 
have for reducing the risk of cot 
death and other dangers, such 
as suffocation, is listed on this 
page and opposite.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember 
that cot death is rare, so don’t 
let worrying about it stop you 
enjoying your baby’s ﬁrst few 
months.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But do follow the advice 
given here to reduce the risks as 
much as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To reduce the risk of cot death:
•  Place your baby on their back 
to sleep, in a cot in a room 
with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Do not smoke in pregnancy or 
let anyone smoke in the same 
room as your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Do not share a bed with your 
baby if you have been drinking 
alcohol, if you take drugs or if 
you are a smoker.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Never sleep with your baby on 
a sofa or armchair.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Do not let your baby get too 
hot – keep your baby’s head 
uncovered.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Place your baby in the ‘feet to 
foot’ position.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The safest place for your  
baby to sleep is on their 
back in a cot in a room  
with you for the ﬁrst  
six months.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
140
Place your baby on their 
back to sleep
Place your baby on their back to 
sleep from the very beginning for 
both day and night sleeps.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will 
reduce the risk of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Side 
sleeping is not as safe as sleeping 
on the back.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Healthy babies placed 
on their backs are not more likely 
to choke.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When your baby is old 
enough to roll over, they should not 
be prevented from doing so.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies may get ﬂattening of 
the part of the head they lie on 
(plagiocephaly).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This will become 
rounder again as they grow, 
particularly if they are encouraged 
to lie on their tummies to play 
when they are awake and being 
supervised.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Experiencing a range of 
different positions and a variety of 
movement while awake is also good 
for a baby’s development.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The risks of bed sharing
The safest place for your baby to 
sleep is in a cot in a room with you 
for the ﬁrst six months.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Do not 
share a bed with your baby if you or 
your partner:
•  are smokers (no matter where or 
when you smoke and even if you 
never smoke in bed)
•  have recently drunk alcohol
•  have taken medication or drugs 
that make you sleep more heavily
•  feel very tired.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The risks of bed sharing are also 
increased if your baby:
•  was premature (born before 
37 weeks), or
•  was of low birth weight 
(less than 2.5kg or 5.5lb).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is also a risk that you might 
roll over in your sleep and suffocate 
your baby, or that your baby could 
get caught between the wall and 
the bed, or could roll out of an adult 
bed and be injured.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Never sleep with a baby on  
a sofa or armchair
It’s lovely to have your baby with 
you for a cuddle or a feed but it’s 
safest to put your baby back in their 
cot before you go to sleep.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cut out smoking during 
pregnancy – partners too!
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Smoking in pregnancy greatly 
increases the risk of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It is best not to smoke at all.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are pregnant and want  
to give up, call the NHS  
Pregnancy Smoking Helpline  
on 0800 169 9 169.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t smoke near  
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t let anyone smoke in 
the same room as your baby
Babies exposed to cigarette smoke 
after birth are also at an increased 
risk of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Nobody should 
smoke in the house, including 
visitors.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Anyone who needs to 
smoke should go outside.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Do not 
take your baby into smoky places.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are a smoker, sharing a bed 
with your baby increases the risk  
of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t let your baby get too 
hot (or too cold)
Overheating can increase the risk 
of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies can overheat 
because of too much bedding or 
clothing, or because the room is too 
hot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember, a folded blanket 
counts as two blankets.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When you 
check your baby, make sure they 
are not too hot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby is 
sweating or their tummy feels hot 
to the touch, take off some of the 
bedding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t worry if your baby’s 
hands or feet feel cool – this  
is normal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• It is easier to adjust the 
temperature with changes  
of lightweight blankets.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember, a folded blanket 
counts as two blankets.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf
Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Keep the room at a 
temperature that is comfortable 
for you at night.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
About 18°C 
(65°F) is comfortable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If it is very warm, your baby may 
not need any bedclothes other 
than a sheet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Even in winter, most babies who 
are unwell or feverish do not  
need extra clothes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Babies should never sleep with 
a hot-water bottle or electric 
blanket, next to a radiator, heater 
or ﬁre, or in direct sunshine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Babies lose excess heat from their 
heads, so make sure their heads 
cannot be covered by bedclothes 
during sleep periods.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t let your baby 
overheat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remove hats and extra 
clothing as soon as you  
come indoors or enter  
a warm car, bus or train,  
even if it means waking  
your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t let your baby’s head 
become covered
Babies whose heads are covered 
with bedding are at an increased 
risk of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To prevent your 
baby wriggling down under the 
covers, place your baby feet to foot 
in the crib, cot or pram.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make the covers up so that they 
reach no higher than the shoulders.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Covers should be securely tucked  
in so they cannot slip over your 
baby’s head.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Use one or more  
layers of lightweight blankets.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sleep your baby on a mattress that 
is ﬁrm, ﬂat, well ﬁtting and clean.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The outside of the mattress should 
be waterproof.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cover the mattress 
with a single sheet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember, do not use duvets, 
quilts, baby nests, wedges,  
bedding rolls or pillows.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Put your baby feet to foot  
in the crib.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
13
THE EARLY WEEKS: YOUR BABY
141
Feeding
Breastfeeding your baby reduces the 
risk of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See Chapter 9 for 
everything you need to know about 
breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is possible that using a dummy at 
the start of any sleep period reduces 
the risk of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Do not begin 
to give a dummy until breastfeeding 
is well established, usually when 
your baby is around one month  
old.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Stop giving the dummy when  
your baby is between six and  
12 months old.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby is unwell, seek 
MEDICAL advice promptly
Babies often have minor illnesses 
that you do not need to worry 
about.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure your baby drinks plenty 
of ﬂuids and is not too hot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If 
your baby sleeps a lot, wake them 
regularly for a drink.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be difﬁcult to judge whether 
an illness is more serious and 
requires prompt medical attention.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See the section on illnesses on 
page 145 for guidance on when 
you should get help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Monitors
Normal healthy babies do not need 
a breathing monitor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some parents 
ﬁnd that using a breathing monitor 
reassures them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, there is 
no evidence that monitors prevent 
cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have any worries 
about your baby, ask your doctor 
about the best steps to take.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Immunisation reduces  
the risk of cot death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more information  
about immunisation, visit 
www.immunisation.nhs.uk
More information
For more information on 
reducing the risk of cot 
death, or to buy a simple 
room thermometer for 
your baby, contact the 
Foundation for the Study 
of Infant Deaths (FSID):
Telephone: 020 7802 3200 
Email: ofﬁce@fsid.org.uk 
Website: www.fsid.org.uk
CHANGING  
YOUR BABY
Babies need their 
nappies changed fairly 
often, otherwise they 
become sore.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Unless 
your baby is sleeping 
peacefully, always 
change a wet or dirty 
nappy and change 
your baby before 
or after each feed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Organise the place where 
you change your baby so that 
everything you need is handy (see 
page 128).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The best place to change  
a nappy is on a changing mat or 
towel on the ﬂoor, particularly if you 
have more than one baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
That way,  
if you take your eye off your baby  
for a moment to look after another 
child, your baby cannot fall and  
hurt themselves.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Try to sit down, so you don’t 
hurt your back.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are using a 
changing table, keep an eye on your 
baby at all times.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See the next page for the different 
kinds of nappies that are available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to change a nappy
You need to clean your baby’s 
bottom carefully each time you 
change a nappy to help prevent 
soreness and nappy rash.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STEP 1
• Take off the nappy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it’s dirty, wipe 
away the mess from your baby’s 
bottom with tissues or cotton wool.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Wash your baby’s bottom and 
genitals with cotton wool and warm 
water and dry thoroughly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For girls, 
wipe the bottom from 
front to back, away 
from the vagina, so that 
germs will not infect 
the vagina or bladder.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For boys, gently clean 
the foreskin of the 
penis (it can be pulled 
back very gently).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Clean under the penis and the 
scrotum.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Water is ﬁne for cleaning 
your baby’s bottom but you may 
want to use wipes or lotion for 
convenience when you are away 
from home.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You may want to use a cream, such 
as zinc and castor oil cream, which 
forms a waterproof coating to help 
protect the skin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Or you can just leave 
the skin clean and dry, especially  
with disposable nappies, since cream 
may prevent them absorbing urine 
so well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t use baby powder  
as it can cause choking.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you are using a cloth nappy, 
place it in a waterproof cover (if 
needed) and put a nappy liner 
inside.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Lay your baby carefully on 
the nappy, bring the centre of the 
nappy between your baby’s legs 
and then fasten the poppers or 
Velcro.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Check that it ﬁts snugly 
around the waist and legs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STEP 2
• If you are using a disposable 
nappy, put the side with the sticky 
tapes under your baby’s bottom.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STEP 3
• Fasten the tapes at the front.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Be very careful not to get cream 
on the tabs or they will not stick.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Nappy hygiene
Disposable nappies
If the nappy is dirty, ﬂush the 
contents down the toilet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Roll up 
the nappy and re-tape it securely.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Put it into a plastic bag.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t put 
anything but nappies in this bag.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fasten the bag and put it outside  
in your bin each day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cloth nappies
•  If the nappy is dirty, ﬂush the 
contents down the toilet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Biodegradable, ﬂushable nappy 
liners are available to make it easy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Have a lidded bucket ready to store 
the dirty nappies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can soak 
them in a nappy cleanser (follow 
the instructions on the packet) or 
just store them here until you have 
a load ready for washing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  Wash nappies every two to three 
days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Follow the care instructions 
on your nappies, but a 60ºC 
wash is usually OK.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you did not 
soak the nappies before, add an 
antibacterial nappy cleanser to your 
normal washing detergent (follow 
the instructions on the packet).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t use enzyme (bio) washing 
powders or fabric conditioner as 
these may irritate your baby’s skin – 
and the conditioner may make the 
nappy less absorbent.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure 
you use the correct amount of 
detergent and rinse thoroughly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Nappy rash
Most babies get a sore bottom 
or have nappy rash at some time, 
but some have extra-sensitive skins.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Nappy rashes are caused by contact 
between sensitive skin and soiled 
nappies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you notice redness or 
spots, clean your baby very carefully 
and change their nappies more 
frequently.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Better still, give your 
baby time without a nappy and 
let the air get to their skin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Keep a 
spare nappy handy to mop up any 
accidents.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will soon see the rash 
start to get better.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby does have a rash, ask 
your midwife or health visitor about 
it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may advise you to use a 
protective cream.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the rash seems 
to be painful and will not go away, 
see your health visitor or GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies’ poo (stools)
Immediately after birth and for the 
ﬁrst few days, your baby is likely 
to pass a sticky, greenish-black 
substance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is called meconium 
and it is the waste that has collected 
in your baby’s bowels while they 
were in your uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As your baby begins to digest milk, 
the stools will change.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They will 
become more yellow or orange 
and can be quite bright in colour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breastfed babies have quite runny 
stools.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Formula-fed 
babies’ stools  
are ﬁrmer and 
smell more.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies vary a lot 
in how often they 
pass stools.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some have a 
bowel movement at or around each 
feed; some can go for several days 
without having a movement.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Either 
can be normal, but most breastfed 
babies produce at least one stool  
a day for the ﬁrst six weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When to get help
Most small babies strain and go 
red in the face, or even cry, when 
passing a stool.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is normal and 
doesn’t mean they are constipated 
as long as the stools are soft.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
are worried that your baby may be 
constipated, mention this to your 
midwife or health visitor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
What you ﬁnd in your baby’s 
nappies will probably vary from day 
to day, and usually there is no need 
to worry.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For example, it is normal 
for some babies to have very runny 
stools.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But ask your doctor, midwife 
or health visitor if you notice any  
big changes, such as stools: 
• becoming very frequent and 
watery
• being very smelly
• changing colour to become 
green, white or creamy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See ‘Babies with jaundice after  
two weeks’ on page 149.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Putting on a disposable nappy

text:
WASHING AND 
BATHING
Washing
You don’t need to bath your baby 
every day, but you should wash 
their face, neck, hands and bottom 
carefully each day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can do this 
on your lap or on a changing mat.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Choose a time when your baby  
is awake and contented, and  
make sure the room is warm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will need a bowl of warm 
water, some cotton wool, a towel 
and a fresh nappy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you want to 
use soap, make sure that it is mild 
and unperfumed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
1 Take off your baby’s clothes 
except for the vest and nappy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Wrap your baby in a towel.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
2 Gently wipe round each eye, 
from the nose side outwards.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Use a fresh piece of cotton  
wool for each eye, so you  
don’t transfer any stickiness  
or infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
3 Using fresh, moist cotton wool, 
wipe out each ear – but don’t 
clean inside their ears.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Never use 
cotton buds inside the ear canal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
4 Wash the rest of your baby’s face 
and neck with moist cotton wool 
and dry gently.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Wash and dry your 
baby’s hands in the same way.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
5 Take off the nappy and wash 
your baby’s bottom (genitals), 
with fresh cotton wool and 
warm water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Dry your baby very 
carefully, including in skin folds, 
and put on a clean nappy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See page 124 on keeping your  
baby’s umbilical cord clean and dry.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Bathing
Bath your baby two or three times 
a week, or more often if they enjoy 
it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Don’t bath them straight after 
a feed or when they are hungry or 
sleepy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure the room is warm 
and that you have everything you 
need ready in advance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
1 Check that the water is not 
too hot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Test it with your wrist 
or elbow.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It should be just 
comfortably warm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
2 Undress your baby except for 
their nappy, and wrap them 
snugly in a towel.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Wash your 
baby’s face with cotton wool and 
water as described above.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There 
is no need to use any soap.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
3 Wash your baby’s hair with baby 
soap or liquid, supporting their 
head over the baby bath or 
basin.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You don’t 
need to use soap every time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
4 If you want to use soap 
occasionally, use a mild, 
unperfumed soap.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Unwrap your 
baby and soap them all over, but 
keep them on your lap so you 
have a ﬁrm grip.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Take the nappy 
off at the last minute.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
5 Put your baby gently into the 
water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Using one hand for 
support, gently swish the water 
to wash your baby without 
splashing their face.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should 
never leave your baby alone 
in the water even for a few 
seconds.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For boys, gently clean 
the top of the foreskin of the 
penis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The foreskin can be pulled 
back very gently to clean.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
6 Lift your baby out and pat them 
dry with the towel.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Dry carefully 
in all the creases.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby’s 
skin is dry, gently massage in 
some baby oil or cream (not 
aqueous cream).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby may 
enjoy this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby seems frightened of 
the bath and cries, it may help to 
try bathing together.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may like 
to do this anyway.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Make sure the 
water is only warm, not hot, and 
don’t add anything to the water.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should also think about how 
you are going to get out of the bath 
with your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You might need 
someone around who you can pass 
them to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ILLNESS
It’s sometimes difﬁcult to tell at ﬁrst 
when a baby is ill, but you may have 
a funny feeling that things are not 
quite right.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are at all worried, 
ask for help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s far better to be on the safe side, 
particularly with a very small baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Trust your own judgement.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
know your baby best.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Very urgent problems
Sometimes there are obvious signs 
that your baby is not well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Contact 
your doctor at once if your baby:
•  turns blue or very pale
•  has quick, difﬁcult or grunting 
breathing, or unusual periods of 
breathing, for example breathing 
with pauses of over 20 seconds 
between breaths
•� is very hard to wake, unusually 
drowsy or doesn’t seem to  
know you
•  develops a rash of red spots 
that do not fade and lose colour 
(blanch) when they are pressed 
(see the ‘glass test’).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This may be 
the rash of meningococcal disease 
and meningitis, which causes 
infection in the blood.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There may 
not be any other symptoms.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby may need treatment 
very quickly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you cannot get 
hold of your GP at once, dial 999 
for an ambulance or take your 
baby to the nearest accident and 
emergency (A&E) department with 
a paediatrician on site.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Problems that could  
be serious
•  If your baby has a hoarse cough 
with noisy breathing, is wheezing, 
or cannot breathe through  
the nose.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If your baby is unusually hot, 
cold or ﬂoppy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If your baby cries in an unusual 
way or for an unusually long time 
or seems to be in pain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If you notice any bleeding from 
the stump of the umbilical cord  
or from the nose, or any bruising.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  If your baby keeps refusing feeds.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If your baby keeps vomiting 
a substantial part of feeds or 
has frequent watery diarrhoea.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vomiting and diarrhoea together 
may mean your baby is losing too 
much ﬂuid, and this may need 
prompt treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If your baby develops jaundice 
(looks yellow) when they are over 
a week old, or has jaundice that 
continues for over two weeks 
after birth (see page 149).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have seen your GP and your 
baby is not getting better or seems 
to be getting worse, tell your GP 
again the same day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you become 
very worried and cannot get hold of 
your GP, dial 999 for an ambulance 
or take your baby to the nearest  
A&E department with a 
paediatrician on site.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are worried 
about your baby
•  Phone your midwife or health 
visitor for advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Keep their 
phone numbers where they 
can be reached easily.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your GP may 
be able to advise you over the 
phone or may suggest that you 
bring your baby along to the 
surgery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most GPs will try to 
ﬁt a young baby in without an 
appointment, although it may 
mean a wait in the surgery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  If you are really worried about 
your baby, you should always 
phone your GP for help 
immediately, whatever the 
time of day or night.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There will 
always be a doctor on duty, 
even if it is not your own GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you cannot contact a 
GP, take your baby to an 
appropriate paediatric 
emergency department.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Not all 
A&E departments have resident 
paediatricians.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You need to 
take them to one that does.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The ‘glass test’ 
13
THE EARLY WEEKS: YOUR BABY
145
The ‘glass test’ can help you 
to tell if a rash is a symptom 
of meningitis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Press the side or 
bottom of a glass ﬁrmly against 
the rash.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be able to see 
if the rash fades and loses colour 
under the pressure (see photo).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it doesn’t change colour,  
contact your GP immediately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Group B 
streptococcal 
infection
Group B streptococcal infection 
is a life-threatening infection in 
babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most babies who are 
infected show symptoms within 
12 hours of birth, but there  
are some who get it later.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The symptoms include:
• being ﬂoppy and unresponsive
• not feeding well
• grunting
• high or low temperature
• fast or slow heart rate
• fast or slow breathing rate
• irritability.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby may need treatment 
very quickly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you cannot get 
hold of your GP at once, dial 
999 for an ambulance or 
take your baby to the 
nearest accident 
and emergency 
department with  
a paediatrician  
on site.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

information, see

GETTING 
SUPPORT
Everyone needs advice or 
reassurance at some time when 
they are caring for a young baby, 
even if it’s just to make sure that 
they are doing the right thing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some problems just need talking 
over with someone.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It’s always 
better to ask for help than to 
worry on your own.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Do talk to 
your midwife or health visitor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As you grow more conﬁdent, 
you will begin to trust your own 
judgement more.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be  
able to decide which advice 
makes most sense for you and 
your baby and which suggestions 
you can safely ignore.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will also want to talk to 
friends, relations or other mothers 
in a similar situation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will 
meet other mothers when you 
start taking your baby to the 
child health clinic or Sure Start 
Children’s Centre.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your health 
visitor will explain where  
these are and when you  
should go.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your nearest Children’s Centre  
can be found by visiting  
www.surestart.gov.uk
Your health visitor can tell you 
about any mother and baby 
groups in the area.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Or your local 
branch of the NCT (see page 
183) or MAMA (Meet A Mum 
Association) (see page 184) may  
be able to put you in touch with 
other mothers nearby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

BABIES WHO NEED

About one in eight of all babies will need extra care in hospital, sometimes on the 
ordinary postnatal ward and sometimes in a specialist neonatal area.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Having a baby  
in neonatal care is naturally worrying for parents and every effort should be made  
to ensure that you receive the information, communication and support you need.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Not all hospitals provide neonatal services, so it may be necessary to transfer your  
baby to another hospital for specialist care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WHY BABIES NEED ADDITIONAL CARE
147
Babies can be admitted to  
neonatal services for any of the 
following reasons:
•  They are born early.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
One in 10 
of all babies are born prematurely.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies born earlier than 34  
weeks may need extra help  
with breathing, feeding and 
keeping warm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  They are very small and have 
a low birth weight.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  They have an infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: •  Their mother is diabetic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  The delivery was very difﬁcult 
and they need to be kept under 
close observation for a time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•  They have very marked jaundice 
(see page 149).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• They are awaiting or recovering 
from complex surgery.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
CONTACT WITH 
YOUR BABY
Your baby will beneﬁt from physical 
contact with you, even though the 
environment of the unit may seem 
strange and confusing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When you 
ﬁrst go into the unit, your baby 
may be in an incubator and on a 
breathing machine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There may also 
be tubes and wires attached to their 
face and body.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ask the nurse to 
explain what everything is for and  
to show you how you can be 
involved with your baby’s care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once your baby is stable, you will  
be able to hold them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The nurses 
will show you how to do this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
FEEDING
To begin with, your baby may be 
too small or sick to feed themselves.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be asked to express some 
of your breastmilk, which can be 
given to your baby through a tube.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A ﬁne tube is passed through 
their nose or mouth into their 
stomach.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This will not hurt them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breastmilk has particular beneﬁts, 
and especially for sick or premature 
babies, as it is specially enriched 
with fats and minerals.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby is unable to have your 
breastmilk to begin with, it can be 
frozen and given to them when 
they are ready.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When you go home, 
you can express milk for the nurses 
to give while you are away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There 
is no need to worry about the 
quantity or quality of your milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some mothers ﬁnd that providing 
breastmilk makes them feel that 
they are doing something positive 
for their baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See Chapter 9 for information on 
expressing and storing milk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
INCUBATORS
Babies who are very small are 
nursed in incubators rather than 
cots to keep them warm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, 
you can still have a lot of contact 
with your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some incubators 
have open tops.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If not, you can put 
your hands through the holes in the 
side of the incubator and touch your 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When your baby is stable, the 
nurses will be able to help you take 
your baby out of the incubator and 
show you how to have skin to skin 
contact.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should carefully wash 
and thoroughly dry your hands 
before touching your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can 
talk to your baby as well – this can 
help both of you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
NEWBORN BABIES 
WITH JAUNDICE
Jaundice in newborn babies is 
common because their livers are 
immature.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Severely jaundiced babies 
may be treated with phototherapy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies are undressed and put under 
a very bright light, usually with 
a soft mask over their eyes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The 
special light helps to break down 
the chemical that causes jaundice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may be possible for your baby to 
have phototherapy by your bed so 
that you don’t have to be separated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This treatment may continue for 
several days, with breaks for feeds, 
before the jaundice clears up.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the 
jaundice gets worse, an exchange 
transfusion of blood may be 
needed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
babies have jaundice because of 
liver disease and need a different 
treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby will be given 
a blood test before phototherapy is 
started to check for this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies with jaundice 
after two weeks
Many babies are jaundiced for up 
to two weeks following birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
can be as long as three weeks in 
premature babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is common 
in breastfed babies and usually it is 
normal and does no harm.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is not 
a reason to stop breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But 
it’s important to see your doctor if 
your baby is still jaundiced after two 
weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should see them within 
a day or two.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is particularly 
important if your baby’s poo (stools) 
is chalky white.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A blood test will 
show whether your baby has  
‘breastmilk’ jaundice, which will go 
away by itself, or jaundice that may 
need urgent treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
BABIES WITH 
DISABILITIES
If your baby is disabled, you will 
be coping with a lot of different 
feelings.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will also need to cope 
with the feelings of others – your 
partner, relations and friends – as 
they come to terms with the fact 
that your baby has a disability.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More 
than anything else at this time, you 
will need to talk to people about 
how you feel as well as about your 
baby’s health and future.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your own GP, a neonatologist or 
paediatrician at your hospital, or 
your health visitor can all help you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can also contact the hospital 
Patient Advice and Liaison Service 
(PALS) or your social services 
department for information about 
local organisations that may  
be able to help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In the useful 
organisations section (page 182) 
you will ﬁnd a list of organisations 
that can offer help and advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many are self-help groups run by 
parents.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talking to other parents 
with similar experiences can often 
be the best help.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Getting information
Hospital staff should explain 
what kind of treatment your 
baby is being given and why.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If they don’t, make sure you 
ask.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is important that you 
understand what is happening 
so that you can work together 
to make sure that your baby 
gets the best possible care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some treatments will need 
your consent and the doctors 
will discuss this with you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is natural to feel anxious if 
your baby requires additional 
care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk over any fears or 
worries with the hospital staff.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Hospitals often have their 
own counselling or support 
services, and a number of 
charities run support and 
advice services.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The consultant neonatologist 
or paediatrician should 
arrange to see you, but 
you can also ask for an 
appointment at any time if 
you wish.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The hospital social 
worker may be able to help 
with practical problems such 
as travel costs or help with 
looking after other children.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
14
BABIES WHO NEED ADDITIONAL CARE
149
Help and support
Bliss, the neonatal charity, 
supplies all neonatal services 
with a free Parent Information 
Guide, which you should be 
given on admission.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more information contact 
Bliss Family Support Helpline 
on freephone 0500 618 140  
or visit the website  
www.bliss.org.uk
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf
