Some women may have to cope with miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy, termination, 
stillbirth or neonatal death (death shortly after birth).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This chapter explains why some  
of these things may happen.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Help and support
If your pregnancy goes 
wrong, you will need both 
information and support.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk to the people close  
to you about how you feel, 
and to your midwife, doctor 
or health visitor about what 
has happened and why.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes it is easier to 
talk to someone who is not 
a family member or friend, 
for example your doctor, 
midwife or health visitor.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There are also a number  
of voluntary organisations  
that offer support and 
information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These are  
often run by bereaved 
parents.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be 
very helpful to talk to 
another parent who has 
been through a similar 
experience.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The following organisations  
may help:
The Ectopic Pregnancy Trust 
(www.ectopic.org.uk) offers 
support and information for 
parents who have had an ectopic 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They have a helpline 
on 020 7733 2653 and can 
put you in touch with other 
people who have had an ectopic 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The Miscarriage Association 
can give you information and put 
you in touch with other parents 
who have experienced  
a miscarriage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See page  
186 for details.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sands can put you in touch 
with other parents who 
have had a late miscarriage, 
stillbirth or neonatal death.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They also have an internet 
forum at www.sandsforum.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
org and a parents’  
telephone helpline on  
020 7436 5881.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: See page 186 for details.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Antenatal Results and Choices 
(ARC) is a voluntary organisation 
that supports parents who 
are making decisions about 
terminating or continuing their 
pregnancies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See page 186 for 
details.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ECTOPIC 
PREGNANCY 
After fertilisation, the egg should 
move down into the uterus to 
develop.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes it gets stuck 
in the fallopian tube and begins to 
grow there.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is called an ectopic 
or tubal pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rarely, the egg 
can become stuck elsewhere,  
such as the ovary or the cervix.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The fertilised egg cannot develop 
properly and your health may be 
at serious risk if the pregnancy 
continues.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The egg has to be 
removed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can be done through 
an operation or with medicines.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ectopic pregnancy can be caused 
by damage in the fallopian tube, 
possibly as a result of an infection.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Previous abdominal surgery and 
previous ectopic pregnancy can also 
increase the risk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The warning signs 
start soon after a missed period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These are:
• severe pain on one side, low 
down in the abdomen
• vaginal bleeding or a brown 
watery discharge
• pain in your shoulders
• feeling dizzy or faint
• pain when you have a bowel 
movement.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have any of these symptoms 
and you might be pregnant – even 
if you have not had a positive 
pregnancy test – you should see 
your doctor immediately.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women have no obvious 
signs or symptoms at all and an 
ectopic pregnancy may sometimes 
be mistaken for irritable bowel 
syndrome, food poisoning or  
even appendicitis.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Afterwards 
You may feel a strong sense of loss 
and it is important to give yourself 
time to grieve.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
An ectopic pregnancy 
involves abdominal surgery or 
treatment with powerful medicines.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may affect your chances of 
becoming pregnant again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may be helpful to talk to  
your doctor to discuss the possible 
causes and whether your  
chances of conceiving a baby  
have been affected.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
MISCARRIAGE
If a pregnancy ends before the 24th 
week, it is known as a miscarriage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Miscarriages are quite common in 
the ﬁrst three months of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At least one in six conﬁrmed 
pregnancies end this way.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many 
early miscarriages (before 14 weeks) 
happen because there is something 
wrong with the development of the 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There can be other causes, 
such as hormone or blood-clotting 
problems.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A later miscarriage may 
be due to an infection, problems 
in the placenta, or the cervix being 
weak and opening too early in  
the pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A miscarriage in the ﬁrst few weeks 
may start like a period, with spotting 
or bleeding and mild cramps or 
backache.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The pain and bleeding 
may get worse and there can be 
heavy bleeding, blood clots and quite 
severe cramping pains.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
With a later 
miscarriage, you may go through an 
early labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you bleed or begin to 
have pains at any stage of pregnancy, 
you should contact your GP or 
midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You could also contact your 
local early pregnancy unit (though 
they may want a referral from your 
GP before they see you).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
are more than six or seven weeks 
pregnant, you may be referred for an 
ultrasound scan to see if your baby 
has a heartbeat and is developing 
normally.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes the bleeding 
stops by itself and your pregnancy 
will carry on quite normally.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women ﬁnd out that their 
baby has died only when they have 
a routine scan.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If they have had no 
pain or bleeding, this can come as 
a terrible shock, especially if the 
scan shows that the baby died days 
or weeks before.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is sometimes 
called a missed or silent miscarriage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Treatment for 
miscarriage
Sometimes it is preferable to wait 
and let the miscarriage happen 
naturally, but there are three ways 
of actively managing a miscarriage: 
•�Medicine.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may be offered 
tablets or pessaries to start the 
process of miscarriage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have been 
pregnant for less than 14 
weeks, your doctor may advise 
an operation called an ERPC 
(evacuation of retained  
products of conception).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This will empty your uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It is done under anaesthetic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
15
THE LOSS OF YOUR BABY
151
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The cervix is gently widened and 
the contents of your uterus are 
removed by suction.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby 
dies after about 14 weeks, you 
may go into labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this doesn’t 
happen, you will be offered 
tablets that start labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Although some women would 
prefer not to go through 
labour, this is safer for you than 
an operation to remove the 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be cared for and 
supported throughout the labour 
and the birth of your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Afterwards 
One early miscarriage is unlikely  
to affect your chances of having  
a baby in the future.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have  
three or more early miscarriages in 
a row, you should be referred to a 
specialist for further investigations.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, sometimes no clear  
cause can be found.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Both women and men ﬁnd it 
difﬁcult to come to terms with a 
miscarriage at any stage.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will 
almost certainly feel a sense of loss.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will need time to grieve over 
the lost baby just as you would over 
the death of anyone close to you, 
especially if the miscarriage has 
happened later in your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may feel shocked, distressed, 
angry, or just numb.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may 
feel guilty, wondering whether 
your miscarriage was caused 
by anything you did or did not 
do.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is important to know that, 
whatever the cause, miscarriage 
is never anyone’s fault.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If a 
miscarriage is going to happen, 
there is very little that anyone  
can do to stop it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some people ﬁnd having 
something to remember their 
baby by helps.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In an early 
loss, this may be a copy of a 
scan picture.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have a late 
miscarriage, you may be able  
to see and hold your baby if you 
wish.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You might also be able  
to take photographs, footprints 
and handprints as a keepsake.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some hospitals offer parents  
a certiﬁcate to commemorate  
their baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is done because 
there is no formal registration  
of a baby who dies before  
24 weeks of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Talk about your feelings with your 
partner and those close to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You might also want to contact 
the Miscarriage Association or 
Sands (see page 150).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
ABNORMAL  
TEST RESULTS
When tests show that the baby 
has a signiﬁcant abnormality, 
some couples wish to continue the 
pregnancy and be prepared for 
the needs of their newborn baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Others decide to terminate the 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If tests show that your 
baby has a serious abnormality, 
ﬁnd out as much as you can from 
your doctor about the particular 
condition and how it might affect 
your baby, so that you can make  
a decision that is right for you  
and your family.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will probably be very shocked 
when you are ﬁrst told the diagnosis 
and may ﬁnd it hard to take in.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may need to go back and talk 
to the doctor with your partner or 
someone close to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Spend time 
talking things through.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also 
ﬁnd it helpful to contact Antenatal 
Results and Choices (see page 150).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
What happens
A termination in the ﬁrst three 
months can be done under a general 
anaesthetic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A later termination 
usually involves going through labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may wish to think beforehand 
about whether you want to see and 
perhaps even hold your baby, and 
whether you want to give your baby 
a name.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you do not want to see 
your baby, you could ask hospital 
staff to take a photograph for you 
in case you want to see it in the 
future.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The photograph can be  
kept in your notes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Afterwards
You may ﬁnd it hard to cope after a 
termination.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can help to talk, but 
sometimes family and friends ﬁnd it 
difﬁcult to understand what you are 
going through.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you would like to 
make contact with people who have 
undergone a similar experience, you 
can contact Antenatal Results and 
Choices (see page 150).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STILLBIRTH AND 
NEONATAL DEATH
In the UK about 4,000 babies are 
stillborn every year.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This means that 
the pregnancy has lasted for 24 
weeks or more and the baby is  
dead when it is born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
About the 
same number of babies die soon 
after birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Often the causes of 
these deaths are not known.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes a baby dies in the uterus 
(an intra-uterine death or IUD) but 
labour does not start spontaneously.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this happens, you will be given 
medicines to induce the labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
is the safest way of delivering the 
baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It also means that you and 
your partner can see and hold the 
baby at birth if you want to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It is shocking to lose a baby like this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You and your partner are likely to 
experience a range of emotions that 
come and go unpredictably.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These 
can include disbelief, anger, guilt 
and grief.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some women think they 
can hear their baby crying, and it is 
not uncommon for mothers to think 
that they can still feel their baby 
kicking inside.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The grief is usually 
most intense in the early months 
after the loss.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some parents ﬁnd 
it helpful to create 
memories of their baby, 
for example they may 
see and hold their baby 
and give their baby a name.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may 
want to have a photograph of your 
baby and to keep some mementos, 
such as a lock of hair, hand and 
footprints or the baby’s shawl.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All 
this can help you and your family to 
remember your baby as a real person 
and may, in time, help you to live 
with your loss.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also ﬁnd it 
helpful to talk to your GP, community 
midwife or health visitor or to other 
parents who have lost a baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sands 
can put you in touch with other 
parents who can offer support and 
information (see page 150).

text:
Post-mortems
One of the ﬁrst questions you 
are likely to ask is why your baby 
died.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sometimes a post-mortem 
examination can help to provide 
some answers, although often no 
clear cause is found.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A post- 
mortem may, however, provide  
other information that could be 
helpful for future pregnancies and 
may rule out certain causes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If it 
is thought that a post-mortem 
could be helpful, a senior doctor or 
midwife will discuss this with you 
and explain the possible beneﬁts.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you decide to have a full or partial 
post-mortem, you will be asked 
to sign a consent form.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When the 
post-mortem report is available,  
you will be offered an appointment 
with a consultant who can  
explain the results to you and  
also what these might mean  
for a future pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Multiple births
The loss of one baby from a  
multiple pregnancy is very difﬁcult 
for any parent.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Grieving for the 
baby who has died while caring  
for and celebrating the life of  
the surviving baby brings very  
mixed and complex emotions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Often the surviving baby is 
premature and in a neonatal  
unit, causing additional concern.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For further information and  
support, contact the Multiple  
Births Foundation or Tamba  
(see pages 183 and 188 for  
contact details).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

15
THE LOSS OF YOUR BABY
153
A funeral or some other way  
of saying goodbye can be a very 
important part of coping  
with your loss, however early  
it happens.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby dies before 24 weeks, 
the hospital may offer to arrange 
for a cremation, possibly together 
with other babies who have died 
in pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you prefer to take 
your baby home or to make your 
own arrangements, you can do 
that.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may need some form 
of certiﬁcation from the hospital 
and they should provide helpful 
information and contacts.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The Miscarriage Association  
and Sands can provide further 
support and information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your baby dies after 24 weeks, 
you will need to register your 
baby’s birth (even if they were 
stillborn) with the Registrar of 
Births, Deaths and Marriages.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The hospital will offer to arrange 
a funeral, burial or cremation free 
of charge, or you may choose to 
organise this yourself.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The hospital 
chaplain will be able to help you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Alternatively, you may prefer 
to contact someone from your 
own religious community, the 
Miscarriage Association or Sands 
about the kind of funeral you 
want.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You do not have to attend 
the funeral if you don’t want to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many hospitals arrange a regular 
service of remembrance for all 
babies who die in pregnancy, at 
birth or in infancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Again, you  
can choose to attend if you wish.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Many parents are surprised at 
how much and how long they 
grieve after losing a baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Friends 
and acquaintances often don’t 
know what to say or how to offer 
support, and they may expect 
you to get back to ‘normal’ long 
before that is possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may 
ﬁnd it helpful to contact Sands  
or the Miscarriage Association  
(see page 150) so that you can  
talk to people who have been 
through similar experiences  
and who can offer you  
support and information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Holding your new baby in your arms, it may be impossible to imagine that you will 
ever have the energy to go through it all again!
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But sooner or later, you may decide 
that you want another child.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you had a low birth weight baby, a baby with a disability or special needs,  
a miscarriage or a stillbirth, you may be particularly anxious to do everything you can 
to create the best possible circumstances for your next pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This chapter explains 
how you and your partner can prepare for your next pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
IT TAKES TWO
You will increase your chances of 
getting pregnant if you are in good 
health – and that applies to men 
too.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A bad diet, smoking, drinking 
and unhealthy working conditions 
can affect the quality of sperm 
and stop you getting pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should both try to make your 
lifestyle as healthy as possible  
before you try to conceive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Chapter 3 has advice about diet, 
smoking, alcohol and exercise, 
which can help you to conceive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
FOLIC ACID
Women should take 400 
micrograms of folic acid from the 
time you start trying to conceive 
right up until you are 12 weeks 
pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can get these tablets 
from a supermarket or pharmacist.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eat foods that contain this 
important vitamin as well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These include green, leafy 
vegetables, and breakfast cereals 
and breads with added folic acid.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will need a bigger dose of folic 
acid if:
• you already have a baby with 
spina biﬁda
• you have coeliac disease
• you have diabetes 
• you take anti-epileptic medicines.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Ask your GP for advice as well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Finding it hard  
to get pregnant?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can take several months  
or more to get pregnant, 
even if it happened really 
quickly the ﬁrst time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Chapter 1 (page 14) explains 
when is the best time of the 
month to have sex if you 
want to get pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are still not pregnant 
after a few months, talk 
to your doctor or family 
planning clinic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
THINGS TO 
CONSIDER
Rubella (German 
measles)
Rubella in early pregnancy can 
damage your developing baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you were not immune during your 
last pregnancy, you should have 
been offered a measles, mumps 
and rubella (MMR) immunisation 
immediately after your baby was 
born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Before trying for another 
baby, it is important to check that 
you are immune by having a blood 
test.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The blood test will measure 
if you have enough protection 
(antibodies) against rubella.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Women 
with low or uncertain levels of 
antibodies can be immunised again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your weight
Maintaining a healthy weight can 
improve your chances of getting 
pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may have put on 
weight during your last pregnancy 
and want to go back to your normal 
size.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is particularly important 
if you weigh more than 100kg.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The best way to lose weight is by 
following a balanced low-fat diet 
and doing exercise.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It might help to 
join a slimming class with a friend 
or your partner to encourage and 
support you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Speak to your doctor  
if you need help or advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Medicines and drugs
Some medicines can harm a baby  
in pregnancy but others are safe.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If either you or your partner has a 
long-term illness or disability and has 
to take long-term medication, talk 
to your doctor about any possible 
effects on fertility or pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Check with your doctor, midwife  
or pharmacist before you take  
any over the counter drugs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Illegal drugs will affect your ability 
to conceive and can damage 
your baby’s health.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See page 183 
for contact details for Narcotics 
Anonymous or talk to FRANK,  
the drugs information line,  
on 0800 77 66 00.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Diabetes and epilepsy
If you have diabetes or epilepsy,  
talk to your doctor before you try  
to get pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Postnatal depression 
and puerperal 
psychosis
If you have previously experienced 
postnatal depression or puerperal 
psychosis, talk to your doctor before 
you try to get pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sexually transmitted 
infections (STIs)
STIs can affect your health and your 
ability to conceive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If there is any 
chance that either of you has an STI, 
it’s important to get it diagnosed  
and treated before you get pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
STIs, including HIV, hepatitis B 
and hepatitis C, can be passed on 
through sex with an infected person, 
especially if you don’t use a condom.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some STIs can be transmitted 
during sex without penetration.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
HIV, 
hepatitis B and hepatitis C can also 
be passed on by sharing equipment 
for injecting drugs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are HIV positive, you can 
pass the virus on to your baby 
during pregnancy, at birth or when 
breastfeeding (see box on page 47).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
WORK-RELATED 
RISKS
Your employer is required to take 
into account any work-related risks 
to new and expectant mothers.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once you have told your employer 
that you are pregnant, they should 
make sure that your job does not 
pose a risk to you or your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some risks can be avoided, for 
example by changing your working 
conditions or hours of work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If a risk cannot be avoided, your 
employer should offer you suitable 
alternative work with similar terms 
and conditions to your present job.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this is not possible, you should  
be suspended on full pay.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
means that you will be given paid 
leave for as long as necessary.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you want advice on these issues, 
speak to Citizens Advice or your 
union if you have one.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vaginal birth after  
a caesarean section
Most women who have 
had a caesarean section 
can have a vaginal delivery 
for their next baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
depends on why you had 
a caesarean section the 
ﬁrst time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Women thought 
to have a small pelvis, for 
example, may be advised to 
have a ‘planned’ (elective) 
caesarean section next time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your GP, or midwife, will 
be able to advise you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most 
women who are advised to 
try for a vaginal delivery in 
subsequent pregnancies do 
have normal deliveries.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Free prescriptions and  
NHS dental treatment
What are they?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Prescriptions and NHS dental 
treatment are free while you are 
pregnant and for 12 months after 
you have given birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your child  
also gets free prescriptions until  
they are 16.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To claim for free prescriptions, ask 
your doctor or midwife for form 
FW8 and send it to your health 
authority.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be sent an 
exemption certiﬁcate that lasts until 
a year after your due date.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To claim after your baby is born  
(if you did not claim while you were 
pregnant) ﬁll in form A in leaﬂet  
P11, NHS Prescriptions, which 
you can get from your doctor or 
Jobcentre Plus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To claim for dental treatment, tick 
a box on a form provided by the 
dentist or show your exemption 
certiﬁcate (see above).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Child Trust Fund
What is it?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A long-term savings and investment 
account for children.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All children born on or after  
1 September 2002, provided they 
are eligible for Child Beneﬁt, live 
in the UK, and are not subject to 
immigration control.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will get a voucher for £250  
from the government to start an 
account for your child.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you get the full amount of Child 
Tax Credit (CTC) because your 
household income is at or below  
the Child Tax Credit income limit 
(£16,040 in 2009/10), your child will 
get a further £250 paid directly into 
their account.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
At seven, children will get another 
payment of £250 (with children 
from lower income families again 
receiving a further £250).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You, your family, your friends and, 
in time, your child can contribute 
up to a total of £1,200 a year to the 
account tax free.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The money can 
only be withdrawn by your child, 
and they cannot take it out until  
they are 18.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
All you have to do is claim

You will automatically be sent an

Income-based Jobseeker’s

Maternity Allowance
What is it?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Maternity Allowance (MA) is a 
weekly allowance paid through 
Jobcentre Plus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Women who cannot get Statutory 
Maternity Pay (see page 165) get 
MA.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These are:
• women who have changed jobs 
during pregnancy
• women who have had periods of 
low earnings or unemployment 
during pregnancy 
• women who are self-employed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can claim MA if you have been 
employed and/or self-employed in 
at least 26 of the 66 weeks before 
your expected week of childbirth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 66-week period is known as 
the test period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must also have 
gross average weekly earnings of at 
least £30.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The average is taken over 
any 13 weeks in the test period.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should choose the 13 weeks 
in which you earned the most.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In your chosen weeks, you can 
add together earnings from more 
than one job, including any self-
employed work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be treated 
as earning a certain amount if you 
are self-employed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
MA is paid for 39 weeks at a standard 
rate of £123.06 per week, or 90% of 
your gross average weekly earnings if 
this is less than £123.06.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The earliest that MA can start is 
11 weeks before the week your 
baby is due and the latest is the day 
following the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are unemployed, your MA 
will start 11 weeks before the week 
your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are employed or self-employed 
at the start of the 11th week before 
the week your baby is due, you can 
choose when to start your MA.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
can even work right up until the date 
the baby is due, unless:
• you are absent from work because 
of a pregnancy-related reason 
during the four weeks before the 
week your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In this case 
your MA will start automatically 
on the day following the ﬁrst day 
of your absence from work, or
• your baby is born before your MA 
is due to start.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In this case your MA 
will start on the day following the 
birth and will last for 39 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can make a claim for MA from 
the 14th week before the week 
your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Fill in form MA1, available from 
Jobcentre Plus or your antenatal 
clinic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
•�Download an MA claim pack in 
PDF format from  
www.dwp.gov.uk/advisers/
claimforms/ma1.pdf 
• Contact Jobcentre Plus on 
0800 055 6688.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must also send your maternity 
certiﬁcate (form MAT B1).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is 
issued by your GP or midwife from 
20 weeks before the week your 
baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Working during the 
Maternity Allowance pay 
period
You are allowed to work as an 
employed or self-employed person 
for up to 10 days during your MA 
pay period without losing any MA.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These 10 days are called Keeping 
in Touch (KIT) days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once you have 
used up your 10 KIT days, if you 
do any further work you will lose a 
day’s MA for any day on which you 
work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must tell Jobcentre Plus 
about any work you do.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The amount you get paid for the 
days you work in your MA pay 
period will not affect your MA.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Employment and 
Support Allowance 
What is it?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is a weekly allowance that is 
normally paid to people whose 
ability to work is limited because of 
an illness or disability.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may also be 
paid to women who don’t qualify 
for Statutory Maternity Pay or 
Maternity Allowance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Women who have paid enough 
National Insurance contributions 
during the last three tax years or 
women who are on a low income.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Jobcentre Plus will check this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you 
are not sure whether or not you 
qualify, phone Jobcentre Plus for 
more information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• £64.30 per week if you are aged 
25 or over.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • £50.95 if you are aged under 25.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may get more than this in some 
circumstances, for example if you 
have a partner who is not working 
and is not claiming beneﬁts for 
themselves.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

Statutory  
Maternity Pay
What is it?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Statutory Maternity Pay (SMP) 
is money paid by your employer 
to help you take time off at and 
around the birth of your baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is 
paid up to a maximum of 39 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your employer can claim back 
some or all of it from Her Majesty’s 
Revenue and Customs (HMRC).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
SMP counts as earnings and your 
employer will deduct tax and 
National Insurance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can get it even if you don’t plan 
to go back to work or you leave your 
employment after you qualify for 
SMP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will not have to pay SMP 
back if you don’t return to work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may qualify for SMP from  
more than one employer.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You get SMP if:
• you have been continuously 
employed for at least 26 weeks 
by the same employer up to 
the qualifying week.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is the 
15th week before the week your 
baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This means you 
must have been employed 
by that employer before you 
were pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Part weeks 
count as full weeks and one day’s 
employment in the qualifying 
week counts as a full week, and
• you earn an average of £95 a 
week before tax.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This amount is 
called the Lower Earnings Limit for 
National Insurance contributions 
and is the amount you have to 
earn to qualify for beneﬁts.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You 
have to earn more than this 
amount before you actually start 
paying National Insurance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your earnings are averaged over an 
eight-week period, running up to 
and including the 15th week before 
the week your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
period may vary slightly depending 
on whether you are paid weekly, 
monthly, or at other intervals.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To ﬁnd out which is your qualifying 
week, look on a calendar for the 
Sunday before your baby is due  
(or the due date if that is a Sunday).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Count back 15 Sundays from there.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should use the due date on 
the MAT B1 certiﬁcate, which your 
midwife or GP will give you when 
you are 20 weeks pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are not sure if you are entitled 
to SMP, ask your employer anyway.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your employer will work out whether 
or not you should get it, and if  
you don’t qualify they will give  
you form SMP1 to explain why.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your employer is not sure how  
to work out your SMP or how to  
claim it back, they can ring the 
HMRC Employer Helpline on  
08457 143 143 for advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
SMP is paid for a maximum of  
39 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• For the ﬁrst six weeks you get 
90% of your average gross weekly 
earnings, with no upper limit.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• For the remaining 33 weeks, you 
get a standard rate of £123.06, 
or 90% of your average gross 
weekly earnings if 90% is less 
than £123.06.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
SMP is usually paid in the same 
way and at the same time as your 
normal wages, but your employer 
may decide to pay differently, for 
example in a lump sum.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The earliest you can start your SMP 
is 11 weeks before the week your 
baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The latest is the day 
following the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To work out the earliest date, 
use the due date on your MAT 
B1 certiﬁcate, which your 
midwife or GP will  
give you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Find the Sunday before your baby 
is due (or the due date if it is a 
Sunday) and count back 11  
Sundays from there.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is up to you to decide when you 
want to stop work, unless your job 
ﬁnishes before your SMP starts or 
you are off work for pregnancy-
related reasons in the four weeks 
before your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your job ﬁnishes before the 11th 
week before the week your baby is 
due, your SMP must start 11 weeks 
before the week your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your job ﬁnishes after the 11th 
week but before your SMP is due to 
start, your SMP must start the day 
after you left your job.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are still 
employed you can choose to work 
right up until the date the baby is 
due, unless:
• you are absent from work because 
of pregnancy-related reasons 
during the four weeks before the 
week that your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In 
that case your SMP should start 
automatically the day following 
the ﬁrst day of absence from 
work, or 
• your baby is born before the start 
of your SMP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In that case your 
SMP will start the day following 
the birth and will be paid for  
39 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can work for up to 10 days for 
the employer who pays you SMP 
and still keep the SMP for the weeks 
in which you do that work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These 
days are called Keeping in Touch 
(KIT) days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After that, if you do any further 
work you cannot get SMP for any 
week in which you work for the 
employer who pays you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you return to work early, your 
SMP will stop.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your SMP cannot 
start again once you have stopped 
your maternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If after the birth you start work  
for a new employer who did not 
employ you in the 15th week before 
the week your baby was due, you 
must tell the employer paying your 
SMP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They will then stop paying 
your SMP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must give your employer at 
least 28 days’ notice of the date you 
want to start your pay.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They may 
need this in writing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must also 
send your maternity certiﬁcate (MAT 
B1 form), which is issued by your GP 
or midwife from 20 weeks before 
the week your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can give notice for leave and 
pay together in the 15th week 
before the week your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can change your mind about 
the dates you have given for the 
start of your SMP but you must give 
your employer 28 days’ notice of 
this change and conﬁrm the new 
date in writing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

IF YOU ARE 
UNEMPLOYED
Contribution-based 
Jobseeker’s Allowance
What is it?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Contribution-based Jobseeker’s 
Allowance (JSA) is an allowance that 
lasts for up to 26 weeks for people 
who are unemployed or working 
less than 16 hours a week.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You get it if:
• you have paid enough National 
Insurance contributions during 
the last two tax years before the 
current calendar year.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tax years 
run from April to March.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• you are available for work for 
as many hours as your caring 
responsibilities permit (this must 
be at least 16 hours a week), and 
• you are actively seeking work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • £50.95 a week if you are under 25.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• £64.30 a week if you are 25 
or over.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your partner’s earnings are not 
taken into account, but, if you are  
in part-time work, your earnings 
are and will reduce how much 
beneﬁt you get.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The beneﬁt is paid directly into  
your bank account, normally every 
two weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Go to your local Jobcentre Plus, 
or claim by post if you live too far 
away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will have to go to your 
Jobcentre Plus every fortnight to 
‘sign on’ to show that you are 
available for work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More information
If your family has no other income, 
you will probably be entitled to 
income-based JSA and other 
beneﬁts for families on low  
incomes (see page 159).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you resign from  
your job
If you resign from your job and 
don’t go back to work after 
maternity leave, you may be able to 
claim contribution-based Jobseeker’s 
Allowance (JSA) for up to six 
months.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, you will have to 
show that you had ‘just cause’ for 
voluntarily leaving your job.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will 
also have to be available for work 
for as many hours a week as your 
caring responsibilities permit.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
must be at least 16 hours a week.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have not paid enough National 
Insurance contributions, you may 
be able to claim income-based JSA 
instead (see page 159), depending 
on your personal circumstances.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Apply in person at your local 
Jobcentre Plus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are a single parent, you may 
be able to claim Income Support 
(see page 159) once your baby  
is born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Remember that you may still be 
able to claim tax credits if you are 
unemployed (Child Tax Credit for 
your children; Working Tax Credit if 
your partner works enough hours).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Apply to Jobcentre Plus for Income 
Support or to Her Majesty’s Revenue 
and Customs for tax credits.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

MATERNITY LEAVE
All employed women are entitled to 52 weeks’ maternity leave, no matter 
how long they have worked for their employer, or the hours they worked.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is made up of 26 weeks of Ordinary Maternity Leave (OML) and 26 weeks  
of Additional Maternity Leave (AML).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are usually considered to be an employee if:
•  your employer deducts tax and National Insurance from your pay
•  your employer controls the work you do, when and how you do it, and
•  your employer provides all the equipment for your work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you work for an agency or do casual work, you are probably  
not an employee.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, you can still get maternity pay if you  
meet the normal conditions (see ‘Maternity Allowance’ on page 163 
and ‘Statutory Maternity Pay’ on page 165).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

RIGHTS AND BENEFITS
167
Ordinary Maternity 
Leave
All employed women:
• can take 26 weeks’ leave, and
• have the right to return to the 
same job.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Additional Maternity 
Leave
All employed women:
• can take 26 weeks’ leave from the 
end of their Ordinary Maternity 
Leave, and
• have the right to return to the 
same job.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If that is not reasonably 
practicable, then you have the 
right to a suitable job on very 
similar terms and conditions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When does maternity  
leave start?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The earliest you can start your 
statutory maternity leave is  
11 weeks before the expected 
week of childbirth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is when  
you are about 29 weeks pregnant, 
so count back from the due date on 
your MAT B1 certiﬁcate, which your 
midwife or GP will give you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Find 
the Sunday before your baby is due 
(or the due date if it is a Sunday) 
and count back 11 Sundays  
from there.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can decide when you want 
to stop work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can even work 
right up until the date your baby is 
born, unless:
• you have a pregnancy-related 
illness/absence in the last four 
weeks of your pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In this case your employer can 
start your maternity leave even 
if you are off sick for only one 
day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, if you are ill for 
only a short time, your employer 
may agree to let you start your 
maternity leave when you had 
planned, or
• your baby is born before the day 
you were planning to start your 
leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
In this case leave will start 
on the day after you give birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should tell your employer  
as soon as you can that you  
have given birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How to give notice
Telling your employer  
that you are pregnant
The latest time you can tell your 
employer that you are pregnant  
is the 15th week before your baby 
is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, it is best to tell 
your employer as soon as possible 
to make sure that you have health 
and safety protection during your 
pregnancy and the right to paid 
time off for antenatal care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The law 
protects you from being dismissed 
or discriminated against because 
you are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you cannot give notice by the 
15th week before you are due  
(for example, because you have  
to go into hospital unexpectedly), 
you must give notice as soon as  
you reasonably can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Giving notice for statutory 
maternity leave
To give notice that you will be 
taking maternity leave, you must tell 
your employer the following in or 
before the 15th week before your 
baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is probably best to 
put this in writing:
• that you are pregnant
• the expected week of childbirth, 
and
• the date on which you intend 
to start your maternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you want to change the date 
on which you start your maternity 
leave, you must give your employer 
notice of the new date at least 28 
days before either the new date or 
the old date – whichever is earliest.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If there is a good reason why that is 
not possible, tell your employer as 
soon as you reasonably can.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can choose when to start 
maternity leave, but the earliest you 
can start getting Statutory Maternity 
Pay is in the 11th week before the 
week your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Once you have given notice, your 
employer must write to you within 
28 days and state the date you  
are expected to return from 
maternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Working out the 15th week 
before your baby is due
Find the Sunday before your baby 
is due (or the due date if it is a 
Sunday) and count back 15 Sundays 
from there.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
That is the start of the 
15th week before the expected 
week when your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should use the due date on 
the MAT B1 certiﬁcate that your 
midwife or GP will give you when 
you are about 20 weeks pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
RIGHTS DURING 
MATERNITY LEAVE
Since 5 October 2008, your 
contractual rights (that is, any 
special rights that apply to your 
particular workplace, such as a 
company car) continue throughout 
your maternity leave (Ordinary 
Maternity Leave (OML) and 
Additional Maternity Leave (AML)) 
as if you were still at work.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
includes your legal right to 5.6 
weeks’ paid annual leave (normally 
28 days for full-time employees and 
the pro-rata equivalent for part-
time workers) whether you are on 
maternity leave or not.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This does 
not include your normal pay.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During the ﬁrst 39 weeks of your 
leave you will probably be entitled 
to either Statutory Maternity Pay 
or Maternity Allowance (see pages 
165 and 163).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After that your leave 
will be unpaid.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some employers 
also offer extra maternity pay: check 
your contract, or ask the human 
resources department or your union 
representative.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are made redundant while  
on maternity leave, your employer 
must offer you any suitable 
alternative work that is available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If there is none, they must give  
you any notice and redundancy  
pay that you are entitled to, 
although they could offset any 
maternity pay you get from the 
notice pay.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Also, your employer 
must not discriminate against 
you by failing to consider you for 
opportunities such as promotion.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more information visit  
www.direct.gov.uk/workandfamilies 
Pay
During OML and the ﬁrst 13 weeks 
of AML, you may be entitled to 
Maternity Allowance or Statutory 
Maternity Pay (see pages 163 and 
165).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
After that your leave will 
usually be unpaid.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some employers 
offer extra (or contractual) maternity 
pay, so check your contract or ask 
the human resources department  
or your union representative.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

This guide shows you when you should claim for a range of beneﬁts.

You must have notiﬁed your employer of your

This is also your ‘qualifying’ week for

You should apply for Maternity

If you qualify for a Sure Start Maternity Grant

your maternity leave and Maternity 
Allowance or Statutory Maternity Pay.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The date your  
baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

17
RIGHTS AND BENEFITS
169
Discrimination
Your employer must not 
discriminate against you while you 
are on maternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This means 
that they have to consider you for 
opportunities such as promotion.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are made redundant while on 
maternity leave, your employer must 
offer you any suitable alternative 
work that is available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If there is 
none, they must pay you any notice 
and redundancy pay that you are 
entitled to.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
RETURNING  
TO WORK
Giving notice about 
returning to work
Your employer should assume 
that you will be taking your full 
entitlement of 52 weeks unless you 
tell them otherwise.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will be due 
back to work on the day after the 
52-week period of maternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you want to take all of your 
leave, you simply go back to work 
on that day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you decide not to take some or 
all of your maternity leave, whether 
Ordinary Maternity Leave (OML) or 
Additional Maternity Leave (AML), 
you should give eight weeks’ notice 
to return to work early.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Even if you 
only wish to take OML, or you just 
want to be off work while you still 
get maternity pay, you must give 
eight weeks’ notice of your return 
as you will in fact be returning early.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you don’t give this notice and just 
turn up at work before the end of 
your maternity leave, your employer 
can refuse to allow you to work for 
up to eight weeks or until the end 
of your leave, whichever is earlier.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you change your mind and wish 
to continue taking your maternity 
leave, you must give your employer 
eight weeks’ notice before the 
earlier date of return.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The law does not allow you to 
work for two weeks (four weeks 
if you work in a factory) after 
childbirth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This period is known as 
Compulsory Maternity Leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will not be allowed to return to 
work during this time.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your job when you go back
When you go back to work after 
AML, you have the right to return to 
the same job.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
But if your employer 
can show that this is not reasonably 
practicable, you have the right to 
be offered a suitable alternative 
job on at least the same terms and 
conditions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If the job no longer 
exists, this could be a redundancy 
situation and you should get advice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should also be offered any 
suitable alternative vacancies if  
your post is made redundant  
while you are on maternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you need more time 
off work
If you stay off work after your 
maternity leave has ended, you will 
lose your right to return to the same 
job.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you need more time off you 
could do one of the following:
• Ask your employer if you can take 
annual leave immediately after 
your maternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your paid 
holiday continues to accrue during 
maternity leave so you may have 
some holiday owing to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Take some parental leave at the 
end of your maternity leave (see 
page 172).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must give 21 days’ 
notice to take parental leave, and 
it is usually unpaid, unless your 
employer offers paid parental leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If you cannot return because you 
are ill, you can take sick leave as 
long as you follow your  
employer’s sickness procedures.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are not able to take annual 
leave and don’t have enough 
notice to ask for parental leave, you 
can still ask your employer if they 
will agree to a further period off 
work (this will usually be unpaid).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should ask your employer to 
conﬁrm this agreement in writing 
and to conﬁrm that you will have 
the right to return to the same job.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should also check whether your 
employer is counting this as part of 
your parental leave entitlement.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you don’t go back  
to work
You should resign in the normal 
way, giving at least the notice 
required by your contract or the 
notice period that is normally given 
in your workplace.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you don’t  
have a contract, you should give  
at least a week’s notice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you say you are going to return to 
work and then change your mind, 
you can resign from your job in the 
normal way.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your notice period 
can run at the same time as your 
maternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you don’t go back to work, 
you don’t have to repay any  
of the Statutory Maternity 
Pay you received during your 
maternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Work during  
maternity leave
During maternity leave it is often 
helpful to keep in touch with your 
employer.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your employer is entitled 
to make reasonable contact with 
you during maternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This 
might be to discuss things like 
arrangements for your return to 
work, or to update you on any 
signiﬁcant changes in the workplace 
while you have been away.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are entitled to do up to 10 
days’ work during your maternity 
leave without losing maternity pay 
or bringing your leave to an end.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These Keeping in Touch (KIT) days 
may only be worked if both you 
and your employer agree.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Although 
particularly useful for things such as 
training or team events, they may 
be used for any form of work and 
should make it easier to return to 
work after your leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You will need 
to agree with your employer what 
work is to be done on KIT days and 
how much pay you will receive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are  
pregnant again
Maternity leave does not break 
your continuity of employment, 
so if you are pregnant again, your 
right to maternity leave will be 
based on your total service with 
your employer.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also 
qualify for Statutory Maternity 
Pay (SMP), as long as you meet 
the normal conditions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, 
this will mean you will have to be 
receiving an average of at least 
£95 per week from your  
employer, worked out over 
approximately weeks 18–25 
of your pregnancy when SMP 
entitlement is calculated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you have already taken Ordinary 
Maternity Leave (OML) and 
Additional Maternity Leave (AML)
(a year off) you will be entitled to a 
second period of OML and AML.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If 
you go straight into another period 
of OML without physically returning 
to work and decide to return to 
work after the second period of 
OML, you will not have the right 
to return to exactly the same job 
as you normally would at the end 
of OML.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
However, you will have 
the same right as you would have 
had at the end of AML.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is the 
right to return to the same job or, 
if that is not reasonably practicable, 
a suitable alternative job on similar 
terms and conditions.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you return to work after the end 
of your ﬁrst period of AML and 
before the start of your second 
period of OML, your rights to 
maternity leave are not affected.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This means that you have the 
right to return to exactly the 
same job after your second 
period of OML.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This applies 
even if you only returned to  
work for one day.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
OTHER 
EMPLOYMENT 
RIGHTS
These rights apply no matter  
how long you have been 
employed or how many hours  
you work per week.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Paid time off for 
antenatal care
If you are an employee, you 
have the right to take reasonable 
time off for your antenatal 
appointments, including time 
needed to travel to your clinic or 
GP, without loss of pay.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should let your employer 
know when you need time off.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For appointments after the ﬁrst 
one, your employer can ask to  
see your appointment card and  
a certiﬁcate stating that you  
are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Antenatal care can include 
antenatal education and relaxation 
classes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may need a letter from 
your GP or midwife to show your 
employer, saying that these classes 
are part of your antenatal care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Health and safety 
rights 
If you are pregnant, have recently 
given birth or are breastfeeding, 
your employer must make sure 
that the kind of work you do and 
your working conditions will not 
put your health or your baby’s 
health at risk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To get the full 
beneﬁt of this legal protection, 
you must notify your employer 
in writing that you are pregnant, 
have recently given birth or  
are breastfeeding.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Your employer must carry 
out a risk assessment at your 
workplace and do everything 
reasonable to remove or reduce 
the risks found.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If there are still risks, your 
employer must change your 
working conditions or hours of 
work to remove the risk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If this is not possible or would 
not remove the risk, your 
employer must offer you a 
suitable alternative job.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• If this is not possible, your 
employer must suspend you on 
full pay for as long as is necessary 
to avoid the risk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you do night 
work and your doctor advises 
that you should stop for health 
and safety reasons, you have 
the right to transfer to day work 
or, if that is not possible, to be 
suspended on full pay.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must 
provide a medical certiﬁcate.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Dismissal or  
unfair treatment
It is sex discrimination for your 
employer to treat you unfairly, 
dismiss you or select you for 
redundancy for any reason 
connected with pregnancy, 
childbirth or maternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are dismissed while you are 
pregnant or during your maternity 
leave, your employer must give 
you a written statement of the 
reasons.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You may also have a 
claim for compensation for sex 
discrimination.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are making 
a claim against your employer, 
you must put your claim into the 
Employment Tribunal within three 
months of the problem arising – 
get advice as soon as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
OTHER TYPES  
OF LEAVE
Paternity leave
Paternity leave is one or two weeks’ 
leave to care for a child or support 
their mother.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your baby’s biological father, your 
husband or your partner, including 
a same-sex partner, will be able to 
take paternity leave providing they: 
• expect to have responsibility for 
bringing up the child, and
• have worked for the same employer 
for at least 26 weeks by the 15th 
week before your baby is due.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your partner is not the biological 
father and is not married to you or 
in a civil partnership with you, they 
must live with you and your baby  
to get paternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can start: 
• from the date of your baby’s birth
• from a chosen number of days 
or weeks after the date of your 
baby’s birth (whether this is earlier 
or later than expected), or 
• from a chosen date.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Paternity leave must be taken within 
56 days of your baby’s birth or, if 
your baby is born early, within the 
period from the actual date of birth 
up to 56 days after the expected 
week of birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your partner will be able to return  
to the same job after paternity leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Statutory Paternity  
Pay 
Statutory Paternity Pay (SPP) is paid 
by employers for up to two weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your partner can get SPP if they:
• are the baby’s father or your 
husband/partner and are 
responsible for the baby’s 
upbringing (your partner must  
live with you and your baby if they 
are not the biological father and 
are not married to you or in a civil 
partnership with you)
• have worked for an employer 
for 26 weeks by the 15th week 
before the baby is due 
• are still employed by the same 
employer when the baby is born
• earn at least £95 per week on 
average (before tax) in the eight 
weeks immediately before the 
week your baby is born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
£123.06 per week or 90% of your 
partner’s average weekly earnings, 
whichever is less.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your partner must give their 
employer at least 28 days’ notice of 
the date when they want their SPP 
to start – or notify them as soon  
as is reasonably practicable.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
17
RIGHTS AND BENEFITS
171
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Parental leave
Parental leave is designed to give 
parents more time with their young 
children.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It entitles you to take  
13 weeks’ leave per parent per child, 
usually unpaid, up to your child’s ﬁfth 
birthday.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Parents of disabled children 
are entitled to 18 weeks’ leave, to 
be taken before the child is 18.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For 
parental leave, a disabled child is 
a child who gets Disability Living 
Allowance (DLA).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is also available 
for adoptive parents, in which case 
you can take it either within ﬁve 
years of the placement for adoption 
or before your child’s 18th birthday, 
whichever is earlier.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Employees who have been employed 
for a year by the time they wish to 
take leave to care for a child.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You cannot usually take all your  
13 weeks in one go.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your employer 
may limit the amount of leave you 
can take to four weeks per child in 
any one year.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must give your employer  
21 days’ notice of the dates 
when you want to take your 
leave.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your employer can 
postpone the leave, but only 
if their business would be 
disrupted unduly.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fathers wanting to take 
time off at or around 
the birth of their baby 
can take parental leave, 
providing they give 
their employers 21 days’ 
notice of the expected 
week of childbirth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
An employer 
cannot postpone 
leave in these 
circumstances.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More information
Visit www.direct.gov.uk/
workandfamilies 
Time off for 
dependants
Every employee is also entitled to 
emergency unpaid leave to make 
arrangements for the care of a 
child who falls ill, gives birth or is 
injured.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This leave can be used if 
there is a sudden problem with 
care arrangements for your  
child – for example, if your 
childminder falls ill.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Flexible working 
arrangements
Parents have the right to  
ask for ﬂexible working 
arrangements.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you need to 
change your working hours 
because of childcare, you also 
have the right to have your 
request considered seriously 
under sex discrimination law.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Follow the procedure outlined 
on page 173.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your request is 
refused, you should get advice 
about whether you have a claim 
for compensation under the  
new right and under sex 
discrimination law.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your rights
You have the right to request 
ﬂexible working arrangements 
if you have or expect to have 
parental responsibility for:
• a child under 17 
(from April 2009), or 
• a disabled child under 18 who 
is entitled to Disability Living 
Allowance (DLA).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Parental responsibility means  
that you are a:
• mother
• father
• adopter
• guardian
Flexible working 
Flexible working covers a wide 
variety of working practices.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be any working pattern 
other than the normal working 
pattern in an organisation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Most people are familiar with 
working part time for pro-rata 
pay or working different shift 
patterns.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Other ways of ﬂexible 
working include the following:
• Flexitime.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Employees may be 
required to work within core 
hours, but outside these times 
they get ﬂexibility in how they 
work their hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Typically, 
two employees share the 
work normally done by one 
employee.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
New technology makes work 
possible by telephone, fax and 
email from home, or other 
remote locations.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
An 
employee on a permanent 
contract takes paid or unpaid 
leave during school holidays.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Employees 
in the same workplace have 
different start, ﬁnish and 
break times – often as a way of 
covering longer opening hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Compressed working hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Employees work their total 
agreed hours over fewer 
working days – for example, 
a ﬁve-day working week is 
compressed into four days.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is a clear procedure that 
you and your employer must 
follow.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your employer must 
seriously consider your request 
and can only refuse for one of 
the business reasons set out in 
the legislation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Any reduction in 
the number of hours worked will 
result in pay being reduced.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

• foster parent

The change that you ask for can 
relate to the hours that you

source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Who does it apply to?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can ask for ﬂexible working if: 
• you are an employee
• you have worked for your 
employer for 26 continuous 
weeks prior to your request 
(continuous employment generally 
means working for the same 
employer without a break,  
but this is not always the case.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Further information is available  
at www.direct.gov.uk
• you have parental responsibility 
for a child under 17 (from April 
2009) or a disabled child under 18 
who is entitled to DLA (or you are 
married to, or the partner or civil 
partner of, that person).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You cannot ask for ﬂexible  
working if:
• you have made a request in the 
last 12 months 
• you are an agency worker
• you are a member of the 
armed forces.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How do I ask to change  
my hours?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your request/application must: 
• be in writing (whether on paper 
or by email).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Find out if your 
employer has a standard form 
for making an application.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If not, 
sample letters can be downloaded 
from www.direct.gov.uk 
• state that the application is being 
made under the statutory right to 
request a ﬂexible working pattern
• conﬁrm that you are applying as 
someone who has or expects to 
have parental responsibility for the 
upbringing of a child under 17 or 
a disabled child under 18 who is 
entitled to DLA and that you are 
the parent, adopter, guardian or 
foster parent of the child (or that 
you are married to, or the partner  
or civil partner of, that person) 
• state the ﬂexible working pattern 
you are asking for and the date 
you want it to start.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The proposed 
date should allow time for the 
application to be considered and 
implemented.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
There is no set time, 
but the process can take up to  
14 weeks or longer where  
issues arise
• explain how you think your new 
working pattern may affect your 
employer and how you think this 
could be dealt with
• state whether you have made 
 an application to your employer 
before, and if so when
•  be signed and dated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your application should be  
as clear as possible.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should also keep  
a copy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
When your employer  
receives the application
Your employer must: 
• hold a meeting with you within 
28 days of your application.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You are allowed to bring a 
companion but your employer 
does not have to let you bring 
someone who is not employed  
by them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This meeting should 
discuss your application.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your 
employer does not think that  
the proposed working pattern  
can be accommodated within  
the needs of the business,  
they should discuss any possible 
compromise arrangements
• give you notice of their decision 
within 14 days of the meeting  
and tell you about your right  
of appeal
• give a reason for refusing, which 
must be one of those allowed 
by the regulations, with an 
explanation of why that reason 
applies in your case.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Refusing your request
Your employer can only refuse your 
request for one of the following 
business reasons: 
• the burden of additional costs
• the detrimental effect on the 
ability to meet customer demand
• an inability to reorganise the 
work among existing staff
• an inability to recruit 
additional staff
• the detrimental effect on quality
• the detrimental effect on 
performance
• not enough work during the 
periods when the employee  
wants to work
• planned structural changes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your employer must also explain 
why that reason applies in your 
circumstances.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf
