text:
Appeal
You have the right to appeal within 
14 days of receiving notiﬁcation of 
your employer’s refusal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
To appeal, 
you must write to your employer 
stating your reasons for appealing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: You must sign and date your letter.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your employer must hold the appeal 
meeting within 14 days of receiving 
your notice of appeal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You have 
the right to be accompanied during 
the meeting if you wish, usually 
by another worker employed by 
the same employer, although your 
employer may agree to let someone 
else attend.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your employer must: 
• allow your companion time off 
to accompany you without it 
affecting their pay
• hold the meeting at a convenient 
time and place for both parties, and
• notify you of their decision in 
writing within 14 days of the 
appeal meeting, giving reasons  
for their decision.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Tribunals
You can make a claim in a tribunal  
if your employer does not follow the 
procedure or refuses for a reason 
not stated in the rules or without  
an explanation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must complete the appeal 
procedure and wait for the  
decision before you can make  
a tribunal application.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
An employment tribunal or an Acas 
binding arbitration that ﬁnds in your 
favour can order your employer to:
• reconsider your application by 
following the procedure correctly
• pay you an award (up to a 
maximum of eight weeks’ pay 
(up to the statutory maximum of 
£350 per week) in compensation).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Legal help
The legal help scheme allows 
people on a low income to get free 
legal advice and assistance when 
preparing for a tribunal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Funding for 
general legal advice (not advocacy) 
is available, to those who qualify 
ﬁnancially, under the legal help 
scheme.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Full representation is 
available under legal aid (to those 
who qualify ﬁnancially) for cases 
brought in the Employment  
Appeal Tribunal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More information is available at 
www.adviceguide.org.uk
YOUR RIGHTS 
UNDER SEX 
DISCRIMINATION 
LAW
It may be indirect sex discrimination 
if an employer refuses a woman’s 
request to change her working 
pattern.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It may be direct sex 
discrimination if an employer refuses 
a man’s request when they allow a 
woman to work differently.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Your employer will only know 
if they have a good reason for 
refusing your request if they give it 
a lot of thought.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Refusing even to 
consider your request or having a 
policy of refusing part-time work 
could be seen as sex discrimination 
by an employment tribunal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
An 
employer must consider each 
individual request in order to avoid 
discriminating against a woman or  
a man with childcare responsibilities.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
People often assume that a job has 
to be done full time or at certain 
ﬁxed times of day, but if you and 
your employer look carefully at 
your job you may be able to work 
out a more child-friendly option – 
perhaps one that neither of you had 
considered before.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Who does the law apply to?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sex discrimination law applies to all 
employers and all employed parents 
with childcare responsibilities.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It only applies if you would be 
disadvantaged by not being allowed 
to work the child-friendly hours you 
need.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must have a good reason 
for asking to work differently – just 
as an employer must have a good 
reason for refusing.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A good reason 
might be: 
• you cannot ﬁnd or afford full-time 
childcare 
• you cannot ﬁnd or afford childcare 
outside 9am–5pm, Monday–Friday
• you have to be there when your 
child or children come home  
from school
• your parents or relatives cannot 
look after your child full time
• you are suffering from severe 
stress from working long hours
• you are distressed or 
disadvantaged by having to work 
your old hours.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The difference between 
rights under sex 
discrimination law and the 
right to request ﬂexible 
working
The new statutory right to request 
ﬂexible working only applies to 
employees who are parents of 
children under 17 (or under 18  
if disabled), who have not made  
an application within the last  
12 months, and who have worked 
for their employer for 26 weeks at 
the time of making the application.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Sex discrimination law may help you 
if you need to change your working 
pattern in order to care for your 
child but cannot use the statutory 
procedure.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This may be because 
you have made a request under the 
procedure within the last 12 months 
or have worked for your employer 
for less than 26 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The procedure 
There is no speciﬁc application 
procedure under sex discrimination 
law.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you can, initially make your 
request under the new right to ask 
for ﬂexible working (see page 172).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If your employer refuses  
your request
If your new working pattern 
will cause major problems, then 
your employer may be justiﬁed 
in refusing your request.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can 
get further advice from your trade 
union representative or local Citizens 
Advice Bureau or the Equality and 
Human Rights Commission (EHRC).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you want advice on whether 
you might have a good case for a 
tribunal, you should see a specialist 
employment lawyer.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If this doesn’t work, you can make  
a claim in an employment tribunal  
if your employer refuses your 
request without a good business 
reason.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The tribunal will look at your 
employer’s reasons and will question 
them carefully about whether 
they were justiﬁed in refusing 
your request.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can also award 
unlimited compensation for loss of 
pay (if you had to leave your job) 
and for injury to feelings.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You must make a tribunal claim 
within three months of the refusal 
under the new right and under sex 
discrimination law.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

THE NHS  
CONSTITUTION
The NHS belongs to us all.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It touches our lives at times of basic human need,  
when care and compassion are what matter most.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Pregnancy is one of these times.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
So it is important that you know what you and your baby can expect from the 
NHS, and what is expected from you in return.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
176
The NHS Constitution was launched on 21 January 
2009.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It brings together for the ﬁrst time in one place 
what staff, patients and the public can expect from 
the NHS.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It explains that by working together we 
can make the very best of ﬁnite resources to improve 
our health and well-being, to keep our minds and 
bodies well, to get better when we are ill, and when 
we cannot recover to stay as well as we can to the end of our lives.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The 
Constitution reafﬁrms that everyone has a role to play in the success of  
the NHS.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
As well as capturing what is important to the NHS (the principles and 
values that determine how the NHS should act and make decisions), the 
Constitution brings together a number of rights, pledges and responsibilities 
for staff and patients alike.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These rights, pledges and responsibilities are the result of extensive 
discussion and research with staff, patients and the public and they reﬂect 
what matters to them most.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rights
The NHS Constitution sets out the legal rights of the public, patients  
and staff.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some of the rights that may be of interest to you are listed below:
• You have the right to receive NHS services free of charge, unless 
Parliament has sanctioned charges.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • You have the right to be treated with dignity and respect.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • You have the right to be treated with a professional standard of care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • You have the right to be given information about your care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • You have the right to privacy and conﬁdentiality.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You have the right to be involved in discussions and decisions 
about your care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• You have the right to have any complaints you make properly 
investigated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pledges
The NHS Constitution sets out a number of pledges for the public, patients 
and staff.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: These are things that the NHS is committed to achieving.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Some 
of the pledges that may be of interest to you are listed below:
• The NHS commits to make sure that it is easy to access health services.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• The NHS commits to inform you about the services that are available 
to you.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• The NHS commits to offer you information that helps you to take part 
in making decisions about your care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• The NHS commits to work in partnership with you, your family, carers 
and representatives.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• The NHS commits to treat you with courtesy and to be supportive 
 when you make a complaint.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Responsibilities
There are a number of things we can all do to help the NHS deliver  
quality services.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: These are set out as responsibilities in the NHS Constitution.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Responsibilities are the things we can all do to help the NHS work 
effectively.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You should always think about your responsibilities when you 
are receiving NHS services.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You have nine responsibilities to keep in mind:
• Do what you can yourself to stay healthy and feel well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Register with a GP.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Treat NHS staff and patients with respect.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Give accurate information about yourself.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Keep appointments, or let the NHS know when you cannot keep them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
• Follow the course of your treatment, or speak to someone if you feel 
you cannot.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Take part in important public health immunisation programmes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Make sure people close to you know about your wishes for organ donation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: • Give feedback on your treatment and care.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The NHS Constitution sets out all of these rights and pledges, together with 
the principles and values, in more detail.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The NHS Constitution Handbook 
contains further information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The NHS Constitution 
Handbook gives further 
information about the NHS 
Constitution and further 
advice on what to do if  
you are not happy with  
the service you receive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The Statement of 
NHS Accountability 
summarises how the NHS 
is structured and what  
the responsibilities of 
individual parts of the  
NHS are.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
How do I get a copy of 
the NHS Constitution?
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
You can get copies of the 
NHS Constitution from 
libraries, doctors, dentists 
and town halls.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

GLOSSARY OF USEFUL TERMS 
TERM
MEANING
Albumin
A protein that can appear in your urine when you are pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be a sign of an infection 
or pre-eclampsia.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Your midwife will test your urine for albumin at your antenatal check-ups.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Amniocentesis
A test in which a thin needle is inserted into the uterus through the abdominal wall to take a 
sample of the ﬂuid surrounding the baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The ﬂuid is then tested for certain chromosomal and 
genetic disorders.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
An amniocentesis is usually carried out between 15 and 18 weeks into your 
pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It may be used later in pregnancy to ﬁnd out if your baby’s lungs are mature.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Amniotic sac
The bag of ﬂuid that surrounds and cushions your baby in the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Before or during labour 
the sac breaks and the ﬂuid drains out.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This is called the ‘waters breaking’.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Anaesthetics
Medicines that reduce or take away pain.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Antenatal 
This literally means ‘before birth’ and refers to the whole of pregnancy, from conception to birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Baby blues
Feeling sad or mildly depressed a few days after your baby is born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The baby blues are very 
common – eight out of 10 new mothers feel like this.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They can be caused by hormone 
changes, tiredness or discomfort and usually only last a week.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
More severe depression  
or anxiety that lasts longer than a week could be postnatal depression (see page 181).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Balanced diet
A diet that provides a good balance of nutrients.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Bereavement
The loss of a person.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Coping with a bereavement can be particularly difﬁcult if you are 
pregnant or have just had a baby, and even harder if it is your baby who has died.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Birth plan 
A written record of what you would like to happen during pregnancy, labour and childbirth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Breech birth
When a baby is born bottom rather than head ﬁrst.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Caesarean section
An operation to deliver a baby by cutting through the mother’s abdomen and then into her 
uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: If you have a caesarean, you will be given an epidural or general anaesthetic.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Catheter
A thin, ﬂexible, hollow plastic tube that can be used to perform various diagnostic and/or 
therapeutic procedures.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Catheters may be used for the injection of ﬂuids or medications into 
an area of the body or for drainage, such as from a surgical site.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
They are also frequently used 
to allow physicians to access the body with surgical instruments.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cervix
The neck of the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is normally almost closed, with just a small opening through which 
blood passes during monthly periods.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During labour, your cervix will dilate (open up) to let your 
baby move from your uterus into your vagina.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Chorionic villus 
sampling
A test to detect genetic disorders, particularly chromosomal disorders such as Down’s 
syndrome.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It is usually carried out at around 11 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Colostrum
The milk that your breasts produce during the ﬁrst few days after your baby is born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is very 
concentrated and full of antibodies to protect your baby against infections.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Colostrum has  
a rich, creamy appearance and is sometimes quite yellow in colour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Conception
The start of a pregnancy, when an egg (ovum) is fertilised and then moves down the fallopian 
tube to the uterus, where it attaches itself to the uterus lining.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Contraception
(also known as  
birth control)
Contraception prevents or reduces your chances of getting pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
See page 135 for the 
different types of contraception that are available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Cot death 
(also known as Sudden 
Infant Death Syndrome) 
The sudden and unexpected death of an apparently healthy infant during their sleep.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: For information on what you can do to avoid cot death, go to pages 129 and 140.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
TERM
MEANING
GLOSSARY OF USEFUL TERMS
179
Down’s syndrome
A lifelong condition caused by an abnormal number of chromosomes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
People with Down’s 
syndrome have some degree of learning disability and an increased risk of some health problems.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It also affects their physical growth and facial appearance.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
For more information about screening 
or tests for Down’s syndrome, see page 50.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ectopic pregnancy 
An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilised egg begins to grow in the fallopian tube, cervix, 
ovaries or abdomen, not in the lining of the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The fertilised egg cannot develop properly 
and has to be removed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Embryo
The term used for the developing baby in the very early weeks up until eight weeks  
of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Entonox 
(also known as  
‘gas and air’)
A form of pain relief offered during labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is a mixture of oxygen and another gas called nitrous 
oxide, which is breathed in through a mask or mouthpiece.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Epidural
An anaesthetic that numbs the lower half of the body.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can be very helpful for women  
who are having a long or particularly painful labour, or who are becoming very distressed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A thin catheter is placed between the vertebrae so that medicine can be delivered to the  
nerves in the spinal cord.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Episiotomy
A surgical incision made in the area between the vagina and anus (perineum).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This is done 
during the last stages of labour and delivery to expand the opening of the vagina to prevent 
tearing during the birth of the baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fallopian tubes
Branch-like tubes that lead from the ovaries to the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Eggs are released from the ovaries 
into the fallopian tubes each month.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Fertilisation takes place in one of the fallopian tubes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fertilisation
Fertilisation takes place if a man’s sperm joins with a woman’s egg and fertilises it in the 
fallopian tube.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fetal alcohol 
syndrome (FAS)
A syndrome that can cause children to have restricted growth, heart defects and facial 
abnormalities as well as learning and behavioural disorders.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is caused if your baby is exposed 
to too much alcohol (via the placenta) when they are in the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fetus
The term used for the developing baby from week eight of pregnancy onwards.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Folic acid
One of the B group of vitamins, which is found naturally in foods, including green leafy 
vegetables, fortiﬁed breakfast cereals and brown rice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Folic acid is important for pregnancy as  
it can help prevent birth defects known as neural tube defects.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If you are pregnant or trying  
to get pregnant, you should take a 400 microgram folic acid tablet every day until you are  
12 weeks pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fontanelle
A diamond-shaped patch on the front and top of a baby’s head where the skull bones have 
not yet fused together.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
During birth, the fontanelle allows the bony plates of the skull to ﬂex, 
so that the baby’s head can pass through the birth canal.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The bones usually fuse together and 
close over by a child’s second birthday.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Formula milk
Cows’ milk that has been processed and treated so that babies can digest it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It comes in 
powder or liquid form.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Fundus
The top of the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Haemoglobin (Hb)
Haemoglobin is found in red blood cells and carries oxygen from the lungs to all parts of the 
body.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Pregnant women need to produce more haemoglobin because they produce more blood.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: If you don’t produce enough, you can become anaemic, which will make you feel very tired.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Your haemoglobin levels are tested during antenatal check-ups.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Home birth
Giving birth at home, with care provided by a midwife.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This is usually planned!
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
TERM
MEANING
180
Induction
A method of artiﬁcially or prematurely stimulating labour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
A baby can be induced if they are 
getting too big, if the pregnancy has gone past the 42-week mark or if there are health risks  
to either the baby or the mother if the pregnancy continues.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Jaundice
The development of a yellow colour on a baby’s skin and a yellowness in the whites of their 
eyes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It is caused by an excess of the pigment bilirubin in the blood.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Jaundice is common in 
newborn babies and usually occurs approximately three days after birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It can last for up to two 
weeks after birth or up to three weeks in premature babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Severe jaundice can be treated by 
phototherapy, where a baby is placed under a very bright light.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies who are jaundiced for 
longer than two weeks should be seen by a doctor as they may need urgent treatment.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: See page 149 for more information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Lanugo
Very ﬁne, soft hair that covers your baby at approximately 22 weeks.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The lanugo disappears 
before birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Mastitis
An infection in the breasts caused by blocked milk ducts.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Symptoms include hot and tender 
breasts and ﬂu-like symptoms.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: See page 109 for how to treat it.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Maternity team 
care 
A team of midwives, obstetricians, anaesthetists, neonatologists and other specialists who 
provide care to women who have complex pregnancies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Meconium
The ﬁrst stools that your baby passes.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Meconium is made up of what a baby has ingested during 
their time in the uterus, including mucus and bile.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It is sticky like tar and has no odour.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Midwifery care 
Care for pregnant women where the midwife is the lead professional.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Midwifery care is suitable 
for women who have an uncomplicated pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Morning  
sickness/nausea
Morning sickness affects more than half of all pregnant women.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Symptoms include nausea  
or feeling sick, as well as actually being sick.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Morning sickness can occur at any time of the day, 
though it occurs most often in the morning because blood sugar levels are low after a night 
without food.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The symptoms usually start after the ﬁrst month of the pregnancy, peaking in 
weeks ﬁve to seven, and continuing until weeks 14 to 16.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Neonatal care
The care given to sick or premature babies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It takes place in a neonatal unit, which is specially 
designed and equipped to care for them.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Nuchal 
translucency scan
An ultrasound scan to help identify whether you are at risk of having a baby with Down’s syndrome.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The scan is carried out at 11 to 13 weeks of your pregnancy and measures the amount of the 
nuchal translucency, which is ﬂuid behind the neck of the baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Babies at risk of Down’s syndrome 
tend to have a higher amount of ﬂuid around their neck.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The scan may also help conﬁrm both the 
accuracy of the pregnancy dates and whether the baby has any other health problems.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Obstetric 
cholestasis
A potentially dangerous liver disorder.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Symptoms include severe generalised itching without  
a rash, particularly in the last four months of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Obstetrician
A doctor specialising in the care of women during pregnancy and labour and after the birth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Oedema
Another word for swelling, most often of the feet and hands.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It is usually nothing to worry about, 
but if it gets worse suddenly it can be a sign of pre-eclampsia.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ovulation
Ovulation occurs when an egg (ovum) is released from one of a woman’s ovaries during  
her monthly menstrual cycle.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: If the egg is fertilised during this time, she will get pregnant.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This is the time of the month when you are most likely to conceive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Paediatrician
A doctor specialising in the care of babies and children.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Perinatal 
The time shortly before and after the birth of a baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
TERM
MEANING
GLOSSARY OF USEFUL TERMS
181
Perinatal mental 
health
Mental health problems that develop during pregnancy and that can last for up to one  
year after childbirth.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Placenta
The organ attached to the lining of the uterus, which separates your baby’s circulation from  
your circulation.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Oxygen and food from your bloodstream are passed to your baby’s bloodstream 
through the placenta and along the umbilical cord.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Waste is also removed this way.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Postnatal
The period beginning immediately after the birth of a baby until they are about six  
weeks old.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Postnatal care
The professional care provided to you and your baby, from the birth until your baby is  
about six to eight weeks old.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It usually involves home visits by midwives to check that both 
mother and baby are well.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Classes may also be available.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Postnatal 
depression
Feelings of depression and hopelessness after the birth of a baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
These feelings are more 
severe than the ‘baby blues’ (see page 178).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Postnatal depression affects one in 10 women and 
can be serious if left untreated.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: See page 82 for more information.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Pre-eclampsia
A condition that only occurs during pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Symptoms include high blood pressure,  
protein in urine, bad headaches, vision problems and the sudden swelling of the face,  
hands and feet.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It usually develops after the 20th week of pregnancy but can occur earlier.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Although most cases are mild and cause no trouble, it can be serious for both mother  
and baby.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: For more information, see page 67.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Premature birth
The birth of a baby before the standard period of pregnancy (37 weeks) is completed.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Premature labour
When labour starts before 37 weeks of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rhesus disease
A woman who is rhesus negative (see below) can carry a baby who is rhesus positive if the 
baby’s father is rhesus positive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: This can cause problems in second or later pregnancies.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
If she 
gets pregnant with another rhesus positive baby, the immune response will be quicker and 
much greater.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
The antibodies produced by the mother can cross the placenta and attach to the 
D antigen on her baby’s red blood cells.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can be harmful to the baby as it may result in a 
condition called haemolytic disease of the newborn, which can lead to anaemia and jaundice.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rhesus negative
People with a certain blood type are known as rhesus negative.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It means that they do not 
have a substance known as D antigen on the surface of their red blood cells.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This can cause 
problems in second or later pregnancies (see above).
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rhesus positive
People with a certain blood type are known as rhesus positive.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This means that they have  
a substance known as D antigen on the surface of their red blood cells.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Rubella (German 
measles)
A virus that can seriously affect unborn babies if the mother gets it during the early weeks  
of pregnancy.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: Most women have been immunised against rubella, so they are not at risk.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Ultrasound/scans
An imaging technique that uses high-frequency sound waves to create an image of your baby 
in the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text: It shows your baby’s body and organs as well as the surrounding tissues.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Also 
called sonography, this test is widely used to estimate delivery dates and check that  
your developing baby is healthy and growing normally.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Umbilical cord
The cord that attaches the baby to the placenta, linking the baby and mother.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Blood circulates 
through the cord, carrying oxygen and food to the baby and carrying waste away again.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vernix
A sticky white coating that covers a baby when it is in the uterus.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
It mostly disappears  
before birth but there may be some left on your baby when they are born.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Vertebrae
Your spine is made up of 33 irregularly shaped bones called vertebrae.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
Each vertebra has  
a hole in the middle through which the spinal cord runs.
source: Pregnancy_Book_comp.pdf

text:
This handbook has been written primarily for those who live far from medical 
centers, in places where there is no doctor.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But even where there are doctors, people 
can and should take the lead in their own health care.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So this book is for everyone who 
cares.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It has been written in the belief that:
1.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Health care is not only everyone’s right, but everyone’s responsibility.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Informed self-care should be the main goal of any health program  
or activity.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Ordinary people provided with clear, simple information can prevent and 
treat most common health problems in their own homes—earlier, cheaper, 
and often better than can doctors.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Medical knowledge should not be the guarded secret of a select few, but 
should be freely shared by everyone.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
People with little formal education can be trusted as much as those with a 
lot.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: And they are just as smart.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Basic health care should not be delivered, but encouraged.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Clearly, a part of informed self-care is knowing one’s own limits.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Therefore 
guidelines are included not only for what to do, but for when to seek help.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The book 
points out those cases when it is important to see or get advice from a health worker 
or doctor.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But because doctors or health workers are not always nearby, the book also 
suggests what to do in the meantime—even for very serious problems.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This book has been written in fairly basic English, so that persons without much 
formal education (or whose first language is not English) can understand it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
language used is simple but, I hope, not childish.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A few more difficult words have 
been used where they are appropriate or fit well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Usually they are used in ways that 
their meanings can be easily guessed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This way, those who read this book have a 
chance to increase their language skills as well as their medical skills.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Important words the reader may not understand are explained in a word list or 
vocabulary at the end of the book.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The first time a word listed in the vocabulary is 
mentioned in a chapter it is usually written in italics.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor was first written in Spanish for farm people in the 
mountains of Mexico where, years ago, the author helped form a health care network 
now run by the villagers themselves.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor has been translated 
into more than 80 languages and is used by village health workers in over 100 
countries.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Introduction
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The first English edition was the result of many requests to adapt it for use in Africa 
and Asia.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
I received help and suggestions from persons with experience in many 
parts of the world.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But the English edition seems to have lost much of the flavor and 
usefulness of the original Spanish edition, which was written for a specific area, and 
for people who have for years been my neighbors and friends.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In rewriting the book to 
serve people in many parts of the world, it has in some ways become too general.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To be fully useful, this book should be adapted by persons familiar with the 
health needs, customs, special ways of healing, and local language of specific 
areas.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Persons or programs who wish to use this book, or portions of it, in preparing their 
own manuals for villagers or health workers are encouraged to do so.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Permission 
from the author or publisher is not needed—provided the parts reproduced are 
distributed free or at cost—not for profit.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It would be appreciated if you would 
(1) include a note of credit and (2) send a copy of your production to Hesperian,  
1919 Addison St., #304, Berkeley, California 94704, U.S.A.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For local or regional health programs that do not have the resources for revising this 
book or preparing their own manuals, it is strongly suggested that if the present edition 
is used, leaflets or inserts be supplied with the book to provide additional information 
as needed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In the Green Pages (the Uses, Dosage, and Precautions for Medicines) blank 
spaces have been left to write in common brand names and prices of medicines.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Once again, local programs or organizations distributing the book would do well to 
make up a list of generic or low-cost brand names and prices, to be included with 
each copy of the book.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This book was written for anyone who wants to do something about his or her own 
and other people’s health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
However, it has been widely used as a training and work 
manual for community health workers.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For this reason, an introductory section has 
been added for the health worker, making clear that the health worker’s first job is to 
share her knowledge and help educate people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Today in over-developed as well as under-developed countries, existing health care 
systems are in a state of crisis.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Often, human needs are not being well met.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
There is 
too little fairness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Too much is in the hands of too few.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Let us hope that through a more generous sharing of knowledge, and through 
learning to use what is best in both traditional and modern ways of healing, people 
everywhere will develop a kinder, more sensible approach to caring—for their own 
health, and for each other.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Words to the Village Health Worker
Who is the village health worker?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A village health worker is a person who helps lead family and neighbors toward 
better health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Often he or she has been selected by the other villagers as someone 
who is especially able and kind.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some village health workers receive training and help from an organized 
program, perhaps the Ministry of Health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Others have no official position, but are 
simply members of the community whom people respect as healers or leaders in 
matters of health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Often they learn by watching, helping, and studying on their own.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In the larger sense, a village health worker is anyone who takes part in 
making his or her village a healthier place to live.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Where There Is No Doctor 2011
Dear Village Health Worker,
This book is mostly about people’s health needs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But to help your village be 
a healthy place to live, you must also be in touch with their human needs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Your 
understanding and concern for people are just as important as your knowledge of 
medicine and sanitation.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Here are some suggestions that may 
help you serve your people’s human 
needs as well as health needs:
1.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A friendly word, a smile, a 
hand on the shoulder, or some other sign 
of caring often means more than anything 
else you can do.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treat others as your 
equals.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Even when you are hurried or 
worried, try to remember the feelings 
and needs of others.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Often it helps to ask 
yourself, “What would I do if this were a 
member of my own family?”
Treat the sick as people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Be 
especially kind to those who are very sick  
or dying.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: And be kind to their families.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Let them see that you care.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: SHARE YOUR KNOWLEDGE.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: As a health worker, your first job is to teach.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This 
means helping people learn more about how to keep from getting sick.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It also means 
helping people learn how to recognize and manage their illnesses—including the 
sensible use of home 
remedies and common 
medicines.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
There is nothing 
you have learned that, 
if carefully explained, 
should be of danger to 
anyone.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some doctors 
talk about self-care as if it 
were dangerous, perhaps 
because they like people 
to depend on their costly 
services.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But in truth, most 
common health problems 
could be handled earlier 
and better by people in 
their own homes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: LOOK FOR WAYS TO SHARE YOUR KNOWLEDGE.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Kindness often helps more than medicine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Never be afraid to show you care.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
3.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: RESPECT YOUR PEOPLE’S TRADITIONS AND IDEAS.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Because you learn something about modern medicine does not mean you 
should no longer appreciate the customs and ways of healing of your people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Too 
often the human touch in the art of healing is lost when medical science moves in.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: This is too bad, because.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: In this way, you will be adding to your people’s culture, not taking away.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Of course, if you see that some of the home cures or customs are harmful  
(for example, putting excrement on the freshly cut cord of a newborn baby), you 
will want to do something to change this.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But do so carefully, with respect for those 
who believe in such things.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Never just tell people they are wrong.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Try to help them 
understand WHY they should do something differently.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: People are slow to change their attitudes and traditions, and with good reason.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: They are true to what they feel is right.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: And this we must respect.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Modern medicine does not have all the answers either.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It has helped solve 
some problems, yet has led to other, sometimes even bigger ones.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
People quickly 
come to depend too much on modern medicine and its experts, to overuse 
medicines, and to forget how to care for themselves and each other.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So go slow—and always keep a deep respect for your people, their traditions, 
and their human dignity.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Help them build on the knowledge and skills they  
already have.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you can use what is best in modern medicine,  
together with what is best in traditional healing, the combination may be 
better than either one alone.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

WORK WITH TRADITIONAL 
HEALERS AND MIDWIVES— 
NOT AGAINST THEM.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Learn from them 
and encourage them  
to learn from you.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

4.

text: KNOW YOUR OWN LIMITS.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
No matter how great or small your 
knowledge and skills, you can do a good 
job as long as you know and work within 
your limits.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This means: Do what you 
know how to do.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Do not try things you 
have not learned about or have not had 
enough experience doing, if they might 
harm or endanger someone.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But use your judgment.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Often, what you decide to do or not 
do will depend on how far you have to go 
to get more expert help.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, a mother has just given 
birth and is bleeding more than you think 
is normal.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you are only half an hour 
away from a medical center, it may be 
wise to take her there right away.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But 
if the mother is bleeding very heavily 
and you are a long way from the health 
center, you may decide to massage her womb (see p.

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But when the danger is clearly greater if you 
do nothing, do not be afraid to try something you feel reasonably sure will help.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Always do your best to protect the 
sick person rather than yourself.

Study whatever books or information you 
can lay your hands on that will help you be a 
better worker, teacher, or person.

Always be ready to ask questions of 
doctors, sanitation officers, agriculture

Never pass up the chance to take refresher 
courses or get additional training.

Your first job is to teach, and unless you

text: PRACTICE WHAT YOU TEACH.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
People are more likely to pay 
attention to what you do than what you 
say.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As a health worker, you want to take 
special care in your personal life and 
habits, so as to set a good example for 
your neighbors.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Before you ask people to make 
latrines, be sure your own family

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

group—for example, to dig a common

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you want other people to take part in improving their village and caring for 
their health, you must enjoy such activity yourself.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If not, who will want to follow 
your example?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Try to make community work projects fun.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, fencing off the public 
water hole to keep animals away from where people take water can be hard work.

text:
But if the whole village helps do it as a ‘work festival’—perhaps with refreshments 
and music—the job 
will be done quickly 
and can be fun.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Children will work 
hard and enjoy it, if 
they can turn work 
into play.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You may or may not 
be paid for your work.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But 
never refuse to care, or 
care less, for someone who 
is poor or cannot pay.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This way you will win your 
people’s love and respect.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These are worth far 
more than money.

text: LOOK AHEAD—AND HELP OTHERS TO LOOK AHEAD.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: A responsible health worker does not wait for people to get sick.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
She tries to stop 
sickness before it starts.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
She encourages people to take action now to protect their 
health and well-being in the future.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Many sicknesses can be prevented.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Your job, then, is to help your people 
understand the causes of their health problems and do something about them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Most health problems have many causes, one leading to another.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To correct the 
problem in a lasting way, you must look for and deal with the underlying causes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You 
must get to the root of the problem.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, in many villages diarrhea is the most common cause of death in 
small children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The spread of diarrhea is caused in part by lack of cleanliness (poor 
sanitation and hygiene).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You can do something to correct this by digging latrines and 
teaching basic guidelines of cleanliness (p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But the children who suffer and die most often from diarrhea are those who 
are poorly nourished.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Their bodies do not have strength to fight the infections.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So to 
prevent death from diarrhea we must also prevent poor nutrition.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: And why do so many children suffer from poor nutrition?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

TAKE A GOOD LOOK AT YOUR COMMUNITY
Because you have grown up in your community and know your people well, you 
are already familiar with many of their health problems.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: You have an inside view.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But in 
order to see the whole picture, you will need to look carefully at your community from 
many points of view.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As a village health worker, your concern is for the well-being of all the people—not 
just those you know well or who come to you.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Visit their homes, 
fields, gathering places, and schools.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Understand their joys and concerns.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Examine 
with them their habits, the things in their daily lives that bring about good health, and 
those that may lead to sickness or injury.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Before you and your community attempt any project or activity, carefully think about 
what it will require and how likely it is to work.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

following:

health problems and their biggest concerns.

a list of questions.

USING LOCAL RESOURCES TO MEET NEEDS
How you deal with a problem will depend upon what resources are available.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some activities require outside resources (materials, money, or people from 
somewhere else).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, a vaccination program is possible only if vaccines are 
brought in—often from another country.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Other activities can be carried out completely with local resources.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A family or a 
group of neighbors can fence off a water hole or build simple latrines using materials 
close at hand.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

make a big difference in people’s health.

TRYING A NEW IDEA
Not all the suggestions on the last pages are 
likely to work in your area.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Perhaps some will 
work if changed for your particular situation and 
resources at hand.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Often you can only know 
whether something will work or not by trying it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: That is, by experiment.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When you try out a new idea, always start 
small.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you start small and the experiment fails, 
or something has to be done differently, you will 
not lose much.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If it works, people will see that it 
works and can begin to apply it in a bigger way.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Do not be discouraged if an experiment does not work.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Perhaps you can try 
again with certain changes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You can learn as much from your failures as your 
successes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Here is an example of experimenting with a new idea.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You learn that a certain kind of bean, such as soya, is an excellent body‑building 
food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But will it grow in your area?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: And if it grows, will people eat it?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Start by planting a small patch—or 2 or 3 small patches in different conditions of soil 
or water.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the beans do well, try preparing them in different ways, and see if people 
will eat them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If so, try planting more beans in the conditions where you found they grew 
best.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But try out still other conditions in more small patches to see if you can get an 
even better crop.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: There may be several conditions you want to try changing.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, type 
of soil, addition of fertilizer, amount of water, or different varieties of seed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To best 
understand what helps and what does not, be sure to change only one condition 
at a time and keep all the rest the same.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, to find out if animal fertilizer (manure) helps the beans grow, and how 
much to use, plant several small bean patches side by side, under the same conditions 
of water and sunlight, and using the same seed.

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
WORKING TOWARD A BALANCE BETWEEN  
PEOPLE AND LAND
Health depends on many things, but above all it depends on whether people have 
enough to eat.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Most food comes from the land.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Land that is used well can produce more food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A 
health worker needs to know ways to help the land better feed the people—now and 
in the future.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But even the best used piece of land can only feed a certain number 
of people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
And today, many of the people who farm do not have enough land to 
meet their needs or to stay healthy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: In many parts of the world, the situation is getting worse, not better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Parents often 
have many children, so year by year there are more mouths to feed on the limited 
land that the poor are permitted to use.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Many health programs try to work toward a balance between people and land 
through ‘family planning,’ or helping people have only the number of children they 
want.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Smaller families, they reason, will mean more land and food to go around.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But 
family planning by itself has little effect.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As long as people are very poor, they often 
want many children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Children help with work without having to be paid, and as they 
get bigger may even bring home a little money.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When the parents grow old, some of 
their children—or grandchildren—will perhaps be able to help care for them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: For a poor country to have many children may be an economic disaster.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But for a 
poor family to have many children is often an economic necessity—especially when 
many die young.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In the world today, for most people, having many children is the 
surest form of social security they can hope for.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Some groups and programs take a different approach.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They recognize that hunger 
exists not because there is too little land to feed everyone, but because most of 
the land is in the hands of a few selfish persons.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The balance they seek is a fairer 
distribution of land and wealth.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They work to help people gain greater control over 
their health, land, and lives.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It has been shown that, where land and wealth are shared more fairly and people 
gain greater economic security, they usually choose to have smaller families.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Family 
planning helps when it is truly the people’s choice.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A balance between people and 
land can more likely be gained through helping people work toward fairer distribution 
and social justice than through family planning alone.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: It has been said that the social meaning of love is justice.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The health worker who 
loves her people should help them work toward a balance based on a more just 
distribution of land and wealth.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
WORKING TOWARD A 
BALANCE BETWEEN
A balance between treatment and prevention often comes down to a balance 
between immediate needs and long-term needs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As a health worker you must go to your people, work with them on their terms, 
and help them find answers to the needs they feel most.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
People’s first concern is 
often to find relief for the sick and suffering.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Therefore, one of your first concerns 
must be to help with healing.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
While caring for people’s immediate felt needs, also help 
them look to the future.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Help them realize that much sickness and suffering can be 
prevented and that they themselves can take preventive actions.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Sometimes health planners and workers go too far.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In their 
eagerness to prevent future ills, they may show too little concern for the sickness 
and suffering that already exist.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
By failing to respond to people’s present needs, 
they may fail to gain their cooperation.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
And so they fail in much of their preventive 
work as well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Treatment and prevention go hand in hand.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Early treatment often prevents 
mild illness from becoming serious.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you help people to recognize many of 
their common health problems and to treat them early, in their own homes, much 
needless suffering can be prevented.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: If you want their cooperation, start where your people are.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Work toward a 
balance between prevention and treatment that is acceptable to them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Such a 
balance will be largely determined by people’s present attitudes toward sickness, 
healing, and health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As you help them look farther ahead, as their attitudes 
change, and as more diseases are controlled, you may find that the balance shifts 
naturally in favor of prevention.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You cannot tell the mother whose child is ill that prevention is more important 
than cure.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Not if you want her to listen.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But you can tell her, while you help her care 
for her child, that prevention is equally important.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Use treatment as a doorway to prevention.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
One of the best times to talk to 
people about prevention is when they come for treatment.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, if a mother 
brings a child with worms, carefully explain to her how to treat him.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But also take 
time to explain to both the mother and child how the worms are spread and the 
different things they can do to prevent this from happening (see Chapter 12).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Visit 
their home from time to time, not to find fault, but to help the family toward more 
effective self-care.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
w17
Early treatment is a form of preventive medicine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Work toward prevention—do not force it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Use treatment as a chance to teach prevention.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The body itself can usually fight off sickness with rest, good food, drinking 
lots of liquid, and perhaps some simple home remedies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: People may come to you asking for medicine when they do not need any.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You 
may be tempted to give them some medicine just to please.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But if you do, when 
they get well, they will think that you and the medicine cured them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Really their 
bodies cured themselves.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Instead of teaching people to depend on medicines they do not need, take 
time to explain why they should not be used.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also tell people what they can do 
themselves to get well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This way you are helping people to rely on local resources (themselves), rather 
than on an outside resource (medicine).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, you are protecting their health, for 
there is no medicine that does not have some risk in its use.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Three common health problems for which people too often request medicines 
they do not need are (1) the common cold, (2) minor cough, and (3) diarrhea.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The common cold is best treated by resting, drinking lots of liquids, and at the 
most taking aspirin.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Penicillin, tetracycline, and other antibiotics do not help at all 
(see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For minor coughs, or even more severe coughs with thick mucus or phlegm, 
drinking a lot of water will loosen mucus and ease the cough faster and better 
than cough syrup.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Breathing warm water vapor brings even greater relief  
(see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Do not make people dependent on cough syrup or other medicines 
they do not need.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: For most diarrhea of children, medicines do not make them get well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Many 
commonly used medicines (neomycin, streptomycin, kaolin-pectin, Lomotil, 
chloramphenicol) may even be harmful.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
What is most important is that the child 
get lots of liquids and enough food (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The key to the child’s 
recovery is the mother, not the medicine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you can help mothers understand this 
and learn what to do, many children’s lives can be saved.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
Medicines are often used too much, both by doctors and by ordinary people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is unfortunate for many reasons:
•	 It is wasteful.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Most money spent on medicine would be better spent on 
food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 It makes people depend on something they do not need (and often cannot 
afford).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Every medicine has some risk in its use.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
There is always a chance that an 
unneeded medicine may actually do the person harm.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 What is more, when some medicines are used too often for minor problems, 
they lose their power to fight dangerous sicknesses.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: An example of a medicine losing its power is chloramphenicol.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The extreme 
overuse of this important but risky antibiotic for minor infections has meant that in 
some parts of the world chloramphenicol no longer works against typhoid fever, 
a very dangerous infection.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Frequent overuse of chloramphenicol has allowed 
typhoid to become resistant to it (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: For all the above reasons the use of medicines should be limited.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Neither rigid rules and restrictions nor permitting only highly trained 
persons to decide about the use of medicines has prevented overuse.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Only when 
the people themselves are better informed will the limited and careful use of 
medicines be common.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To educate people about sensible and limited use of 
medicines is one of the important jobs of the health worker.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is especially true in areas where modern medicines are already in  
great use.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: WHEN MEDICINES ARE NOT NEEDED, TAKE TIME TO EXPLAIN WHY.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For more information about the use and misuse of medicines, see Chapter 6, 
page 49.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: For the use and misuse of injections, see Chapter 9, page 65.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For 
sensible use of home remedies, see Chapter 1.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
FINDING OUT WHAT PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE 
(EVALUATION)
From time to time in your health work, it helps to take a careful look at what and 
how much you and your people have succeeded in doing.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
What changes, if any, have 
been made to improve health and well-being in your community?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You may want to record each month or year the health activities that can be 
measured.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example:
•	How many families have put in latrines?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	How many farmers take part in activities to improve their land and crops?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	How many mothers and children take part in an Under-Fives Program (regular 
check-ups and learning)?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: This kind of question will help you measure action taken.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But to find out 
the result or impact of these activities on health, you will need to answer other 
questions such as:
•	How many children had diarrhea or signs of worms in the past month or year—as 
compared to before there were latrines?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	How much was harvested this season (corn, beans, or other crops)—as 
compared to before improved methods were used?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	How many children show normal weight and weight-gain on their Child Health 
Charts (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
297)—as compared to when the Under-Fives Program was 
started?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	Do fewer children die now than before?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To be able to judge the success of any activity you need to collect certain 
information both before and after.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, if you want to teach mothers how 
important it is to breastfeed their babies, first take a count of how many mothers are 
doing so.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Then begin the teaching program and each year take another count.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This 
way you can get a good idea as to how much effect your teaching has had.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: You may want to set goals.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, you and the health committee may hope 
that 80% of the families have latrines by the end of one year.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Every month you take 
a count.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If, by the end of six months, only one-third of the families have latrines, you 
know you will have to work harder to meet the goal you set for yourselves.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To evaluate the results of your health activities it helps to count and measure certain 
things before, during, and after.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But remember: The most important part of your health work cannot be 
measured.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It has to do with the way you and other people relate to each other; with 
people learning and working together; with the growth of kindness, responsibility, 
sharing, and hope.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It depends on the growing strength and unity of the people to stand 
up for their basic rights.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: You cannot measure these things.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But weigh them well when 
you consider what changes have been made.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Setting goals often helps people work harder and get more done.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
TEACHING AND LEARNING TOGETHER— 
THE HEALTH WORKER AS AN EDUCATOR
As you come to realize how many things affect health, you may think the health 
worker has an impossibly large job.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
And true, you will never get much done if you 
try to deliver health care by yourself.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Your community’s well-being depends on the involvement not of one person,  
but of nearly everyone.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For this to happen, responsibility and knowledge must  
be shared.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is why your first job as a health worker is to teach—to teach children, 
parents, farmers, schoolteachers, other health workers—everyone you can.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: The art of teaching is the most important skill a person can learn.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To teach is to 
help others grow, and to grow with them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A good teacher is not someone who 
puts ideas into other people’s heads; he or she is someone who helps others 
build on their own ideas, to make new discoveries for themselves.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Teaching and learning should not be limited to the schoolhouse or health post.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: They should take place in the home and in the fields and on the road.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As a health 
worker one of your best chances to teach will probably be when you treat the sick.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But you should look for every opportunity to exchange ideas, to share, to show, 
and to help your people think and work together.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: On the next few pages are some ideas that may help you do this.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They are only 
suggestions.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: You will have many other ideas yourself.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Only when the people themselves become actively responsible for their own 
and their community’s health, can important changes take place.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf
