text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
Tools for Teaching
Flannelboards are good for talking with groups 
because you can keep making new pictures.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Cover 
a square board or piece of cardboard with a flannel 
cloth.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You can place different cutout drawings or 
photos on it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Strips of sandpaper or flannel glued to the 
backs of cutouts help them stick to the flannelboard.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Posters and displays.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
“A picture is worth a 
thousand words.” Simple drawings, with or without a 
few words of information, can be hung in the health 
post or anywhere that people will look at them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You 
can copy some of the pictures from this book.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you have trouble getting sizes and shapes right, 
draw light, even squares in pencil over the picture 
you want to copy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Now draw the same number of squares lightly, 
but larger, on the poster paper or cardboard.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Then 
copy the drawing, square for square.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If possible, ask village artists to draw or paint 
posters.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Or have children make posters on different 
subjects.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Models and demonstrations help get ideas across.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, if you want to talk with mothers and midwives 
about care in cutting the cord of a newborn child, you 
can make a doll for the baby.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Pin a cloth cord to its belly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Experienced midwives can demonstrate to others.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Color slides and filmstrips are available on different 
health subjects for many parts of the world.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some come in 
sets that tell a story.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Simple viewers and battery-operated 
projectors are also available.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A list of addresses where you can send for teaching 
materials to use for health education in your village can be  
found on pages 429 to 432.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
Other Ways to Get Ideas Across
Story telling.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When you have a hard time explaining something, a story, 
especially a true one, will help make your point.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, if I tell you that sometimes a village worker can make a better 
diagnosis than a doctor, you may not believe me.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But if I tell you about a village 
health worker called Irene, who runs a small nutrition center in Central America, 
you may understand.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: One day a small sickly child arrived at the nutrition center.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
He had been sent by the 
doctor at a nearby health center because he was badly malnourished.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The child also 
had a cough, and the doctor had prescribed a cough medicine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Irene was worried about 
the child.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
She knew he came from a very poor family and that an older brother had died 
a few weeks before.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
She went to visit the family and learned that the older brother had 
been very sick for a long time and had coughed blood.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Irene went to the health center 
and told the doctor she was afraid the child had tuberculosis.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Tests were made, and 
it turned out that Irene was right.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So you see, the health worker spotted the real 
problem before the doctor—because she knew her people and visited their homes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Stories also make learning more interesting.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It helps if health workers are good 
story tellers.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Stories that make important points can reach people with even 
more force if they are acted out.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Perhaps you, the schoolteacher, or someone on 
the health committee can plan short plays or ‘skits’ with the schoolchildren.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, to make the 
point that food should be 
protected from flies to prevent 
the spread of disease, several 
small children could dress up 
as flies and buzz around food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The flies dirty the food that 
has not been covered.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Then 
children eat this food and get 
sick.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But the flies cannot get 
at food in a box with a wire 
screen front.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So the children 
who eat this food stay well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

w23
The more ways you can find to share ideas,
 the more people will understand and remember.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
Working and Learning Together for the Common Good
There are many ways to interest and involve people in working together to meet 
their common needs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Here are a few ideas:
1.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: A village health committee.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A group of able, interested persons can be 
chosen by the village to help plan and lead activities relating to the well-being of the 
community—for example, digging garbage pits or latrines.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The health worker can and 
should share much of his responsibility with other persons.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Mothers, fathers, schoolchildren, young people, folk healers, 
or other groups can discuss needs and problems that affect health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Their chief 
purpose can be to help people share ideas and build on what they already know.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Community 
projects such as putting in a water 
system or cleaning up the village go 
quickly and can be fun if everybody 
helps.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Games, races, refreshments, 
and simple prizes help turn work into 
play.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
People can help 
keep prices down by sharing tools, 
storage, and perhaps land.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Group 
cooperation can have a big influence 
on people’s well-being.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Work with the village schoolteacher to encourage health-
related activities, through demonstrations and play acting.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also invite small groups 
of students to come to the health center.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Children not only learn quickly, but they can 
help out in many ways.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you give children a chance, they gladly become a valuable 
resource.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Mother and child health meetings.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is especially important that pregnant 
women and mothers of small children (under five years old) be well informed 
about their own and their babies’ health needs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Regular visits to the health post are 
opportunities for both check-ups and learning.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Have mothers keep their children’s 
health records and bring them each month to have their children’s growth recorded 
(see the Child Health Chart, p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Mothers who understand the chart often take 
pride in making sure their children are eating and growing well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They can learn 
to understand these charts even if they cannot read.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Perhaps you can help train 
interested mothers to organize and lead these activities.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Make friendly visits to people’s homes, especially homes of families 
who have special problems, who do not come often to the health post, or who do 
not take part in group activities.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But respect people’s privacy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If your visit cannot be 
friendly, do not make it—unless children or defenseless persons are in danger.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
Ways to Share and Exchange Ideas in a Group
As a health worker you will find that the success you have in improving your 
people’s health will depend far more on your skills as a teacher than on your 
medical or technical knowledge.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For only when the whole community is involved 
and works together can big problems be overcome.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: People do not learn much from what they are told.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They learn from what they 
think, feel, discuss, see, and do together.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: So the good teacher does not sit behind a desk and talk at people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
He talks 
and works with them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
He helps his people to think clearly about their needs and to 
find suitable ways to meet them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
He looks for every opportunity to share ideas in 
an open and friendly way.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Perhaps the most important thing you can do as a health worker is to awaken 
your people to their own possibilities.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
to help them gain confidence in 
themselves.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Sometimes villagers do not change things they do not like because 
they do not try.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Too often they may think of themselves as ignorant and powerless.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Most villagers, including those who cannot read or write, have 
remarkable knowledge and skills.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They already make great changes in their 
surroundings with the tools they use, the land they farm, and the things they build.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: They can do many important things that people with a lot of schooling cannot.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you can help people realize how much they already know and have done 
to change their surroundings, they may also realize that they can learn and do 
even more.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
By working together it is within their power to bring about even bigger 
changes for their health and well-being.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Then how do you tell people these things?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But you can help them find out some of these things for 
themselves—by bringing them together for discussions.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Say little yourself, but start 
the discussion by asking certain questions.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Simple pictures like the drawing on 
the next page of a farm family in Central America may help.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You will want to draw 
your own picture, with buildings, people, animals, and crops that look as much as 
possible like those in your area.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
USE PICTURES TO GET PEOPLE TALKING AND THINKING TOGETHER
Show a group of people a picture similar to this and ask them to discuss it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Ask 
questions that get people talking about what they know and can do.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Here are some 
sample questions:
•	Who are the people in the picture and how do they live?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	What was this land like before the people came?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	In what ways have they changed their surroundings?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	How do these changes affect their health and well-being?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	What other changes could these people make?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
What else could they learn to 
do?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: What is stopping them?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: How could they learn more?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	How did they learn to farm?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	If a doctor or a lawyer moved onto this land with no more money or tools than 
these people, could he farm it as well?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	In what ways are these people like ourselves?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
This kind of group discussion helps build people’s confidence in themselves 
and in their ability to change things.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It can also make them feel more involved in 
their community.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: At first you may find that people are slow to speak out and say what they think.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But after a while they will usually begin to talk more freely and ask important 
questions themselves.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Encourage everyone to say what he or she feels and to 
speak up without fear.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Ask those who talk most to give a chance to those who are 
slower to speak up.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You can think of many other drawings and questions to start discussions 
that can help people look more clearly at problems, their causes, and possible 
solutions.

text:
This can be done in 
several ways.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A health worker or anyone who gives out the book should make sure that people 
understand how to use the list of Contents, the Index, the Green Pages, and the 
Vocabulary.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Take special care to give examples of how to look things up.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Urge 
each person to carefully read the sections of the book that will help her understand 
what may be helpful to do, what could be harmful or dangerous, and when it is 
important to get help (see especially Chapters 1, 2, 6, and 8, and also the SIGNS 
OF DANGEROUS ILLNESS, p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Point out how important it is to prevent sickness 
before it starts.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Encourage people to pay special attention to Chapters 11 and 12, 
which deal with eating right (nutrition) and keeping clean (hygiene and sanitation).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also show and mark the pages that tell about the most common problems in 
your area.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, you can mark the pages on diarrhea and be sure mothers 
with small children understand about ‘special drink’ (oral rehydration, p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Many 
problems and needs can be explained briefly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But the more time you spend with 
people discussing how to use the book or reading and using it together, the more 
everyone will get out of it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You as a health worker might encourage people to get together in small groups to 
read through the book, discussing one chapter at a time.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Look at the biggest problems 
in your area—what to do about health problems that already exist and how to prevent 
similar problems in the future.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Try to get people looking ahead.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Perhaps interested persons can get together for a short class using this book (or 
others) as a text.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Members of the group could discuss how to recognize, treat, and 
prevent different problems.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They could take turns teaching and explaining things to 
each other.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: To help learning be fun in these classes you can act out situations.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, 
someone can act as if he has a particular sickness and can explain what he feels.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Others then ask questions and examine him (Chapter 3).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Use the book to try to find 
out what his problem is and what can be done about it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The group should remember 
to involve the ‘sick’ person in learning more about his own sickness—and should end 
up by discussing with him ways of preventing the sickness in the future.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
All this can be 
acted out in class.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Exciting and effective ways to teach about health care are in the book Helping 
Health Workers Learn, also available from Hesperian.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As a health worker, one of the best ways you can help people use this book 
correctly is this: When persons come to you for treatment, have them look up their own 
or their child’s problem in the book and find out how to treat it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This takes more time, 
but helps much more than doing it for them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Only when someone makes a mistake or 
misses something important do you need to step in and help him learn how to do it 
better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: In this way, even sickness gives a chance to help people learn.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Dear village health worker—whoever and wherever you are, whether you have a 
title or official position, or are simply someone, like myself, with an interest in the

text:
But remember, the most important part of health care you will not find in this 
book or any other.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The key to good health lies within you and your people, in the 
care, the concern, and appreciation you have for each other.

your community be healthy, build on these.

Everywhere on earth people use home remedies.

In some places, the

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Home remedies, like modern medicines, must be used 
with caution.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is often safer to treat very serious illnesses with modern
medicine—following the advice of a health worker if possible.

know exactly how to use them.

or even better.

in some cases they are safer.

people use for home treatment of coughs 
and colds do more good and cause fewer 
problems than cough syrups and strong 
medicines some doctors prescribe.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, the ‘rice water’, teas, or sweetened 
drinks that many mothers give to babies with 
diarrhea are often safer and do more good 
than any modern medicine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The Limitations
of Home Remedies
Some diseases are helped by home remedies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Others can be treated better 
with modern medicine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: This is true for most serious infections.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Sicknesses like 
pneumonia, tetanus, typhoid, tuberculosis, appendicitis, diseases caused by sexual 
contact, and fever after childbirth should be treated with modern medicines as soon 
as possible.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For these diseases, do not lose time trying to treat them first with home 
remedies only.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is sometimes hard to be sure which home remedies work well and which do 
not.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: More careful studies are needed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

For this reason:

2
Old Ways and New
Some modern ways of meeting health needs work better than old ones.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But at times 
the older, traditional ways are best.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, traditional ways of caring for children 
or old people are often kinder and work better than some newer, less personal ways.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Not many years ago everyone thought that mother’s milk was the best food for a 
young baby.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Then the big companies that make canned and artificial 
milk began to tell mothers that bottle feeding was better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is not true, but many 
mothers believed them and started to bottle feed their babies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As a result, thousands 
of babies have suffered and died needlessly from infection or hunger.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For the reasons 
breast is best, see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Respect your people’s traditions and build on them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For more ideas for building on local traditions, see Helping Health Workers 
Learn, Chapter 7.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
BELIEFS THAT CAN MAKE PEOPLE WELL
Some home remedies have a direct effect on the body.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Others seem to work only 
because people believe in them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: The healing power of belief can be very strong.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, I once saw a man who 
suffered from a very bad headache.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To 
cure him, a woman gave him a small 
piece of yam, or sweet potato.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
She 
told him it was a strong painkiller.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
He 
believed her—and the pain went away 
quickly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It was his faith in her treatment, and 
not the yam itself, that made him feel 
better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Many home remedies work in this 
way.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They help largely because people 
have faith in them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For this reason, they 
are especially useful to cure illnesses that are partly in people’s minds, or 
those caused in part by a person’s beliefs, worry, or fears.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Included in this group of sicknesses are: bewitchment or hexing, unreasonable 
or hysterical fear, uncertain ‘aches and pains’ (especially in persons going through 
stressful times, such as teenage girls or older women), and anxiety or nervous worry.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also included are some cases of asthma, hiccups, indigestion, stomach ulcers, 
migraine headaches, and even warts.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For all of these problems, the manner or ‘touch’ of the healer can be very 
important.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
What it often comes down to is showing you care, helping the sick person 
believe he will get well, or simply helping him relax.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Where There Is No Doctor 2011
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

In other lands people have their own snakebite remedies—often many different

text:
As far as we know, none of these home remedies has any direct effect 
against snake poison.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The person who says that a home remedy kept a snake’s 
poison from harming him at all was probably bitten by a non-poisonous snake!
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Yet any of these home remedies may do some good if a person believes in it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If it makes him less afraid, his pulse will slow down, he will move and tremble less, 
and as a result, the poison will spread through his body more slowly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So there is 
less danger!
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But the benefit of these home remedies for snakebite is limited.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In spite of their 
common use, many people still become very ill or die.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As far as we know:
For snakebite it is usually better to use modern treatment.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Be prepared: obtain 
‘antivenoms’ or ‘serums’ for poisonous bites before you need them (see p.

text: Do not wait until it is too late.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
No home cure for poisonous bites (whether from snakes, 
scorpions, spiders, or other poisonous animals) has much 
effect beyond that of the healing power of belief.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
4
BELIEFS THAT CAN MAKE PEOPLE SICK
The power of belief can help heal people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But it can also harm them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If a person 
believes strongly enough that something will hurt him, his own fear can make him sick.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example:
Once I was called to see a woman 
who had just had a miscarriage and 
was still bleeding a little.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
There was 
an orange tree near her house.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So I 
suggested she drink a glass of orange 
juice.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
(Oranges have vitamin C which 
helps strengthen blood vessels.) She 
drank it—even though she was afraid 
it would harm her.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Her fear was so great that soon she 
became very ill.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
I examined her, but 
could find nothing physically wrong.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
I tried to comfort her, telling her she 
was not in danger.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But she said she 
was going to die.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
At last I gave her an 
injection of distilled (completely pure) 
water.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Distilled water has no medical 
effect.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But since she had great faith in 
injections, she quickly got better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Actually, the juice did not harm her.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
What harmed her was her belief that it would 
make her sick.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: And what made her well was her faith in injections!
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In this same way, many persons go on believing false ideas about witchcraft, 
injections, diet, and many other things.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Much needless suffering is the result.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Perhaps, in a way, I had helped this woman.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But the more I thought about it, the more 
I realized I had also wronged her; I had led her to believe things that were not true.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: I wanted to set this right.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So a few days later, when she was completely well, I went 
to her home and apologized for what I had done.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
I tried to help her understand that not 
the orange juice, but her fear had made her so sick.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
And that not the injection of water, 
but her freedom from fear had helped her get well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
By understanding the truth about the orange, the injection, and the tricks of her own 
mind, perhaps this woman and her family will become freer from fear and better able 
to care for their health in the future.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For health is closely related to understanding and 
freedom from fear.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

HEALING WITH WATER
Most of us could live without medicines.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But no one can live without water.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In fact, 
over half (57%) of the human body is water.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If everyone living in farms and villages 
made the best use of water, the amount of sickness and death—especially of children—
could be reduced.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, correct use of water is basic both in the prevention and treatment of 
diarrhea.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In many areas diarrhea is the most common cause of sickness and death in 
small children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Contaminated (unclean) water is often part of the cause.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
An important part of the prevention of diarrhea and many other illnesses is to make 
sure that drinking water is safe.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Protect wells and springs from dirt and animals by 
putting fences or walls around them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Use cement or rock to provide good drainage 
around the well or spring, so that rain or spilled water runs away from it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where water may be contaminated, an 
important part of the prevention of diarrhea 
is to boil or filter the water used for drinking 
or for preparing foods.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is especially 
important for babies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Babies’ bottles and 
eating utensils should also be boiled.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If 
regular boiling of bottles is not possible, it is 
safer to use a cup and water spoon.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Washing 
hands with soap and water after a bowel 
movement (shitting) and before eating or 
handling foods is also important.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

diarrhea is severe dehydration, or loss of 
too much water from the body (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
By giving a child with diarrhea plenty of 
water (best with sugar or cereal and salt), 
dehydration can often be prevented or 
corrected (see Rehydration Drink, p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Giving lots of liquids to a child with diarrhea is more important than any 
medicine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In fact, if enough liquid is given, no medicine is usually needed in the 
treatment of diarrhea.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

IMPORTANCE OF LIMITED USE OF ANTIBIOTICS
The use of all medicines should be limited.

Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Poisoning and reactions.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Antibiotics not only kill bacteria, they can also harm 
the body, either by poisoning it or by causing allergic reactions.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Many people die each 
year because they take antibiotics they do not need.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Upsetting the natural balance.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Not all bacteria in the body are harmful.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some 
are necessary for the body to function normally.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Antibiotics often kill the good bacteria 
along with the harmful ones.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Babies who are given antibiotics sometimes develop 
fungus or yeast infections of the mouth (thrush, p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: 232) or skin (moniliasis, p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This 
is because the antibiotics kill the bacteria that help keep fungus under control.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For similar reasons, persons who take ampicillin and other broad-spectrum 
antibiotics for several days may develop diarrhea.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Antibiotics may kill some kinds of 
bacteria necessary for digestion, upsetting the natural balance of bacteria in the gut.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Resistance to treatment.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In the long run, the most important reason the use 
of antibiotics should be limited, is that WHEN ANTIBIOTICS ARE USED TOO MUCH, 
THEY BECOME LESS EFFECTIVE.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When attacked many times by the same antibiotic, bacteria become stronger and 
are no longer killed by it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: They become resistant to the antibiotic.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For this reason, 
certain dangerous diseases like typhoid are becoming more difficult to treat than they 
were a few years ago.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In some places typhoid has become resistant to chloramphenicol, normally the 
best medicine for treating it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

infections, infections for which other antibiotics would be safer and work as well, or for 
which no antibiotic at all is needed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Throughout the world important diseases are becoming resistant to antibiotics—
largely because antibiotics are used too much for minor infections.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If antibiotics 
are to continue to save lives, their use must be much more limited than it is at 
present.

themselves.

WHAT TO DO WHEN BREATHING STOPS:
MOUTH-TO-MOUTH BREATHING
Common causes for breathing to stop are:
• something stuck in the throat
• the tongue or thick mucus blocking the throat of an unconscious person
• drowning, choking on smoke, or poisoning
• a strong blow to the head or chest
• a heart attack
A person can die within 4 minutes if he does not breathe.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

Step 1: Quickly use a finger to remove anything stuck in 
the mouth or throat.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

begin mouth-to-mouth breathing IMMEDIATELY.

text:

from it, than are children who are well nourished.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •   Measles is especially dangerous where many children are malnourished.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•   Tuberculosis is more common, and gets worse more rapidly, in those who are 
malnourished.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•   Cirrhosis of the liver, which comes in part from drinking too much alcohol, is more 
common and worse in persons who are poorly nourished.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•   Even minor problems like the common cold are usually worse, last longer, or lead 
to pneumonia more often in persons who are poorly nourished.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
EATING WELL AND 
KEEPING CLEAN 
ARE THE BEST 
GUARANTEES     
OF GOOD HEALTH.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Eating right helps the body resist sickness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Eating right helps the sick get well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Not only does good food help prevent disease, it helps the sick body fight disease 
and become well again.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So when a person is sick, eating enough nutritious food is 
especially important.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Unfortunately, some mothers stop feeding a child or stop giving certain nutritious 
foods when he is sick or has diarrhea—so the child becomes weaker, cannot fight 
off the illness, and may die.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Sick children need food!
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If a sick child will not eat, 
encourage him to do so.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Feed him as much as he will eat and drink.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A sick child often does 
not want to eat much.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: So feed him something many times during the day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, try to 
make sure that he drinks a lot of liquid so that he pees (passes urine) several times a 
day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: If the child will not take solid foods, mash them and give them as a mush or gruel.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Often the signs of poor nutrition first appear when a person has some other 
sickness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, a child who has had diarrhea for several days may develop 
swollen hands and feet, a swollen face, dark spots, or peeling sores on his legs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These 
are signs of severe malnutrition.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: The child needs more good food!
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Feed him many times during the day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: During and after any sickness, it is very important to eat well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
109
WHY IT IS IMPORTANT TO EAT RIGHT
People who do not eat right develop malnutrition.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This can happen from not 
eating enough food of any kind (general malnutrition or ‘undernutrition’), from not 
eating the right kinds of foods (specific types of malnutrition), or from eating too 
much of certain foods (getting too fat, see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf
Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: A malnourished child does not grow well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
She generally is thinner and shorter 
than other children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, she is more likely to be irritable, to cry a lot, to move 
and play less than other children, and to get sick more often.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the child also gets 
diarrhea or other infections, she will lose weight.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A good way to check if a child is 
poorly nourished is to measure the distance around her upper arm.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Checking Children for Malnutrition: The Sign of the Upper Arm
After 1 year of age, any child whose middle 
upper arm measures less than 11 ½ cm.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
around is 
malnourished — no matter how ‘fat’ his feet, hands, 
and face may look.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the arm measures between 11 ½ 
and 12 ½ cm., he is at risk of becoming malnourished.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Another good way to tell if a child is well nourished 
or poorly nourished is to weigh him regularly: once a 
month in the first year, then once every 3 months.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A 
healthy, well nourished child gains weight regularly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
weighing of children and the use of the Child Health 
Chart are discussed fully in Chapter 21.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
PREVENTING MALNUTRITION
To stay healthy, our bodies need plenty of good food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The food we eat has to fill 
many needs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: First, it should provide enough energy to keep us active and strong.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Also, it must help build, repair, and protect the different parts of our bodies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To do 
all this we need to eat a combination of foods every day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
110
MAIN FOODS AND HELPER FOODS
In much of the world, most people eat one main low-cost food with almost every 
meal.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Depending on the region, this may be rice, maize, millet, wheat, cassava, potato, 
breadfruit, or banana.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This main food usually provides most of the body’s daily 
food needs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: However, the main food alone is not enough to keep a person healthy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Certain 
helper foods are needed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is especially true for growing children, women who are 
pregnant or breastfeeding, and older people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Even if a child regularly gets enough of the main food to fill her, she may become 
thin and weak.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is because the main food often has so much water and fiber in it, 
that the child’s belly fills up before she gets enough energy to help her grow.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
112
HOW TO RECOGNIZE MALNUTRITION
Among poor people, malnutrition is often most severe in children, who need 
lots of nutritious food to grow well and stay healthy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
There are different forms of 
malnutrition:
MILD MALNUTRITION
This is the most common form, but it is not always obvious.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The child simply does not grow or gain weight as fast as a well-
nourished child.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Although he may appear rather small and thin, 
he usually does not look sick.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
However, because he is poorly 
nourished, he may lack strength (resistance) to fight infections.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So he becomes more seriously ill and takes longer to get well 
than a well nourished child.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Children with this form of malnutrition suffer more from 
diarrhea and colds.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Their colds usually last longer and are more 
likely to turn into pneumonia.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Measles, tuberculosis, and many 
other infectious diseases are far more dangerous for these 
malnourished children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is important that children like these get special care and enough food before they 
become seriously ill.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is why regular weighing or measuring around the middle 
upper arm of young children is so important.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It helps us to recognize mild malnutrition 
early and correct it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Follow the guidelines for preventing malnutrition.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
SEVERE MALNUTRITION
This occurs most often in babies who stopped breastfeeding early or suddenly, 
and who are not given sufficient high energy foods often enough.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Severe malnutrition 
often starts when a child has diarrhea or another infection.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
We can usually recognize 
children who are severely malnourished without taking any measurements.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 2 main 
examples are:
DRY MALNUTRITION—OR MARASMUS
This child does not get enough of 
any kind of food.

He is said to have dry 
malnutrition or marasmus.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In other words, 
he is starved.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
His body is small, very thin 
and wasted.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
He is little more than skin  
and bones.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This child needs more food—especially 
energy foods.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

113
WET MALNUTRITION—OR KWASHIORKOR

This

text:
115
WAYS OF EATING BETTER WHEN YOU
DO NOT HAVE MUCH MONEY OR LAND
There are many reasons for hunger and poor nutrition.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
One main reason is 
poverty.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In many parts of the world a few people own most of the wealth and the 
land.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They may grow crops like coffee or tobacco, which they sell to make money, 
but which have no food value.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Or the poor may farm small plots of borrowed land, 
while the owners take a big share of the harvest.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The problem of hunger and poor 
nutrition will never be completely solved until people learn to share with each 
other fairly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But there are many things people can do to eat better at low cost—and by eating 
well gain strength to stand up for their rights.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
On pages w13 and w14 of “Words to 
the Village Health Worker” are several suggestions for increasing food production.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These include improved use of land through rotating crops, contour ditches, and 
irrigation; also ideas for breeding fish, beekeeping, grain storage, and family 
gardens.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the whole village or a group of families works together on some of these 
things, a lot can be done to improve nutrition.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When considering the question of food and land, it is important to remember that 
a given amount of land can feed only a certain number of persons.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For this reason, 
some people argue that ‘the small family lives better’.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
However, for many poor 
families, to have many children is an economic necessity.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
By the time they are 10 or 
12 years old, children of poor families often produce more than they cost.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Having a 
lot of children increases the chance that parents will receive the help and care they 
need in old age.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In short, lack of social and economic security creates the need for parents 
to have many children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Therefore, the answer to gaining a balance between 
people and land does not lie in telling poor people to have small families.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It lies 
in redistributing the land more fairly, paying fair wages, and taking other steps to 
overcome poverty.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Only then can people afford small families and hope to achieve 
a lasting balance between people and land.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
(For a discussion of health, food, and 
social problems, see Helping Health Workers Learn.)
When money is limited, it is important to use it wisely.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This means cooperation 
and looking ahead.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Too often the father of a poor family will spend the little bit of 
money he has on alcohol and tobacco rather than on buying nutritious food, a hen to 
lay eggs, or something to improve the family’s health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Men who drink together would 
do well to get together sometime when they are sober, to discuss these problems 
and look for a healthy solution.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, some parents buy sweets or soft drinks (fizzy drinks) for their children when 
they could spend the same money buying eggs, milk, nuts or other nutritious foods.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: This way their children could become more healthy for the same amount of money.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Discuss this with the families and look for solutions.

Special Diets for Specific Health Problems
Anemia
A person with anemia has thin blood.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This happens when blood is lost or destroyed 
faster than the body can replace it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Blood loss from large wounds, bleeding ulcers, 
or dysentery can cause anemia.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: So can malaria, which destroys red blood cells.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Not 
eating enough foods rich in iron can cause anemia or make it worse.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Women can become anemic from blood loss during monthly bleeding (menstrual 
periods) or childbirth if they do not eat the foods their bodies need.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Pregnant women 
are at risk of becoming severely anemic, because they need to make extra blood for 
their growing babies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: In children anemia can come from not eating foods rich in iron.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It can also come 
from not starting to give some foods in addition to breast milk, after the baby is 6 
months old.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Common causes of severe anemia in children are hookworm infection (see 
p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: 142), chronic diarrhea, and dysentery.

text:
The signs of anemia are:
•  pale or transparent skin
•  pale insides of eyelids
•  white fingernails
•  pale gums
•  weakness and fatigue
•  If the anemia is very severe, face 
and feet may be swollen, the 
heartbeat rapid, and the person 
may have shortness of breath.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•  Children and women who like to 
eat dirt are usually anemic.

text:

especially high.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

have some iron.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: It also helps to cook in iron pots (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

absorb more iron, eat raw vegetables and fruit with meals, and avoid drinking 
coffee and tea with food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦  If the anemia is moderate or severe, the person should take iron (ferrous sulfate 
pills, p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: This is especially important for pregnant women who are anemic.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

extract or vitamin B12.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

injected, because iron injections can be dangerous and are no better than pills.

text:
♦  If the anemia is caused by dysentery (diarrhea with blood), hookworm, malaria, 
or another disease, this should also be treated.

text: ♦  If the anemia is severe or does not get better, seek medical help.

text:
This is 
especially important for a pregnant woman.

High Blood Pressure (Hypertension) 
High blood pressure can cause many problems, such as heart disease, kidney 
disease, and stroke.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Fat people are especially likely to have high blood pressure.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Signs of dangerously high blood pressure:
•  frequent headaches
•  pounding of the heart and shortness of 
breath with mild exercise
•  weakness and dizziness
•  occasional pain in the left shoulder and chest
All these problems may also be caused by 
other diseases.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Therefore, if a person suspects he 
has high blood pressure, he should see a health 
worker and have his blood pressure measured.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
WARNING: High blood pressure at first causes no signs, 
and it should be lowered before danger signs develop.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
People who are 
overweight or suspect they might have high blood pressure should have their 
blood pressure checked regularly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For instructions on measuring blood pressure, 
see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
What to do to prevent or care for high blood pressure:
♦	
If overweight, lose weight (see next page).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦	
Avoid fatty foods, especially pig fat, and foods with a lot of sugar or starch.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Always use vegetable oil instead of pig fat.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦	
Prepare and eat food with little or no salt.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Do not drink much alcohol.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦	
When the blood pressure is very high, the health worker may give medicines 
to lower it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Many people can lower their blood pressure by losing weight if 
they are fat (next page), and by learning to relax.

126
People who are too Heavy
To be very fat is not healthy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Very heavy people are 
more likely to get high blood pressure, stroke, gallstones, 
some kinds of diabetes, arthritis in legs and feet, and other 
problems.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Sometimes being too heavy brings on illness, 
and sometimes illness may cause you to become too heavy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As our diets change and traditional foods are replaced 
by processed foods, especially “junk foods” high in calories 
but low in nutrition, people tend to gain weight in ways that 
are not healthy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Losing weight may help with the illnesses mentioned 
above.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Losing weight is also important if you are having 
difficulty doing your daily activities.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You can lose weight by:
♦  eating less greasy, fatty, or oily foods.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦  eating less sugar or sweet foods.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦  getting more exercise.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦  stop eating processed foods and eat 
fresh fruits and vegetables instead.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Constipation
A person who has hard stools and has not had a bowel movement for 3 or more 
days is said to be constipated.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Constipation is often caused by a poor diet (especially 
not eating enough fruits, green vegetables, or foods with natural fiber like whole grain 
bread) or by lack of exercise.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Drinking more water and eating more fruits, vegetables, and foods with natural 
fiber like whole grain bread, cassava, wheat bran, rye, carrots, turnips, raisins, nuts, 
pumpkin or sunflower seeds, is better than using laxatives.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It also helps to add a little 
vegetable oil to food each day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Older people especially may need to walk or exercise 
more in order to have regular bowel movements.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A person who has not had a bowel movement for 4 or more days, if he does not 
have a sharp pain in his stomach, can take a mild salt laxative like milk of magnesia.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But do not take laxatives often.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Do not give laxatives to babies or young children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If a baby is severely constipated, 
put a little cooking oil up the rectum (asshole).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Or, if necessary, gently break up and 
remove the hard shit with a greased finger.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Never use strong laxatives or purgatives—
especially if there is stomach pain.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
127
Diabetes
Persons with diabetes have too much sugar in their blood.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This can start when 
a person is young (juvenile diabetes) or older (adult diabetes).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is usually more 
serious in young people, and they need special medicine (insulin) to control it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But it 
is most common in people over age 40 who eat too much and get fat.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Early signs of diabetes:	 	
      	
Later, more serious signs:
•  always thirsty	
•  itchy skin
•  urinates (pees) often and a lot	
•  periods of blurry eyesight
•  always tired	
•  some loss of feeling in hands or feet
•  always hungry	
•  frequent vaginal infections
•  weight loss	
•  sores on the feet that do not heal
	
•  loss of consciousness (in extreme	 	
	
    cases)
All these signs may be caused by other diseases.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In order to find out whether a 
person has diabetes, test her urine to see if there is sugar in it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
One way to test the 
urine is to taste it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: If it tastes sweet to you, have 2 other persons taste it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Have them 
also taste the urine of 3 other people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If everyone agrees that the same person’s 
urine is sweeter, she is probably diabetic.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Another way of testing urine is to use special paper strips (for example, Uristix).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If 
these change color when dipped in the urine, it has sugar in it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the person is a child or young adult, he should be seen by an experienced 
health worker or doctor.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When a person gets diabetes after he is 40 years old, it can often be best 
controlled without medicines, by eating correctly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The diabetic person’s diet is 
very important and must be followed carefully for life.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The diabetic diet: Fat people with diabetes should lose weight until their weight is 
normal.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Diabetics must not eat any sugar or sweets, or foods that taste sweet.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It 
is important for them to eat lots of high fiber foods, such as whole grain breads.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But 
diabetics should also eat some other starchy foods, like beans, rice, and potatoes, 
and also foods high in protein.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Diabetes in adults can sometimes be helped by drinking the sap of the prickly 
pear cactus (nopal, Opuntia).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To prepare, cut the cactus into small pieces and crush 
them to squeeze out the liquid.

text:
Drink 1 ½ cups of the liquid 3 times each day before 
meals.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To prevent infection and injury to the skin, clean the teeth after eating, keep 
the skin clean, and always wear shoes to prevent foot injuries.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

For poor circulation 
in the feet (dark color, numbness), rest often with the feet up.

128
Acid Indigestion, Heartburn, and Stomach Ulcers
Acid indigestion and ‘heartburn’ often come from eating too much heavy or greasy 
food or from drinking too much alcohol or coffee.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These make the stomach produce 
extra acid, which causes discomfort or a ‘burning’ feeling in the stomach or mid chest.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some people mistake the chest pain, called ‘heartburn’, for a heart problem rather than 
indigestion.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: If the pain gets worse when lying down, it is probably heartburn.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Frequent or lasting acid indigestion is a warning sign of an ulcer.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
An ulcer is a chronic sore in the digestive 
system, usually caused by bacteria.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Too much 
acid in the stomach prevents it from healing.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It may cause a chronic, dull (sometimes sharp) 
pain in the pit of the stomach.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As with acid 
indigestion, often the pain lessens when the 
person eats food or drinks a lot of water.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
pain usually gets worse an hour or more after 
eating, if the person misses a meal, or after 
he drinks alcohol or eats fatty or spicy foods.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Pain is often worse at night.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Without a special 
examination (endoscopy) it is often hard to know 
whether a person with frequent stomach pain 
has an ulcer or not.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the ulcer is severe, it can cause vomiting, sometimes with fresh blood, or with 
digested blood that looks like coffee grounds.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Stools with blood from an ulcer are 
usually black, like tar.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
WARNING: Some ulcers are painless or ‘silent’, and the first sign is blood in vomit, or 
black, sticky stools.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: This is a medical emergency.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The person can quickly bleed to 
death.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: GET MEDICAL HELP FAST.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Prevention and Treatment:
Whether stomach or chest pain is caused by heartburn, acid indigestion, or an ulcer, 
a few basic recommendations will probably help calm the pain and prevent it from 
coming back.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦  Do not eat too much.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Eat small meals and eat frequent snacks between meals.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦  Notice what foods or drinks make the pain worse and avoid them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These usually include alcoholic drinks, coffee, 
spices, pepper, carbonated drinks (soda, pop, 
colas), and fatty or greasy foods.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦  If the heartburn is worse at night when 
lying flat, try sleeping with the upper body 
somewhat raised.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

130
Goiter (a Swelling or Lump on the Throat)
A goiter is a swelling or big lump on the throat that results from abnormal growth of a 
gland called the thyroid.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Most goiters are caused by a lack of iodine in the diet.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, a lack of iodine in a 
pregnant woman’s diet sometimes causes babies to die or to be born mentally slow 
and/or deaf (cretinism, p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This can happen even though the mother does not have 
a goiter.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Goiter and cretinism are most common in mountain areas where there is little 
natural iodine in the soil, water, or food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In these areas, eating a lot of certain foods like 
cassava makes it more likely for a person to get a goiter.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
How to prevent or cure a goiter and prevent cretinism:
Everyone living in areas where people get goiters should use iodized salt.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Use of 
iodized salt prevents the common kind of goiter and will help many goiters go away.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
(Old, hard goiters can only be removed by surgery, but this is usually not necessary.)
If it is not possible to get iodized salt, it may be possible to get iodine oil to take by 
mouth or injection.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Or, mix 1 drop of povidone iodine in 1 liter of water and drink a glass 
of the mixture every week.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Most home cures for goiter do not do any good.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
However, eating crab and other 
seafood can do some good because they contain iodine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Mixing a little seaweed with 
food also adds iodine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But the easiest way is to use iodized salt.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
HOW TO KEEP FROM GETTING A GOITER
   NEVER use regular salt.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ALWAYS use iodized salt.

is much better.

text:
CLEANLINESS—AND PROBLEMS
THAT COME FROM LACK OF CLEANLINESS
Cleanliness is of great importance in the prevention of many kinds of infections—
infections of the gut, the skin, the eyes, the lungs, and the whole body.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Personal 
cleanliness (or hygiene) and public cleanliness (or sanitation) are both important.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Many common infections of the gut are spread from one person to another 
because of poor hygiene and poor sanitation.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Germs and worms (or their eggs) 
are passed by the thousands in the stools or feces (shit) of infected persons.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These 
are carried from the feces of one person to the mouth of another by dirty fingers or 
contaminated food or water.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Diseases that are spread or transmitted from feces-to-
mouth in this way, include:
•	 diarrhea and dysentery (caused by amebas and bacteria)
•	 intestinal worms (several types)
•	 hepatitis, typhoid fever, and cholera
•	 certain other diseases, like polio, are sometimes spread this same way
The way these infections are 
transmitted can be very direct.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example: A child who has worms 
and who forgot to wash his hands after 
his last bowel movement, offers his friend 
a cracker.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
His fingers, still dirty with his 
own stool, are covered with hundreds of 
tiny worm eggs (so small they cannot be 
seen).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some of these worm eggs stick 
to the cracker.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When his friend eats the 
cracker, he swallows the worm eggs, too.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Soon the friend will also have worms.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
His mother may say this is because he ate 
sweets.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But no, it is because he ate shit!
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

quickly and is most dangerous in small children.

Hepatitis is an inflammation of the liver usually caused by a virus, but also by 
bacteria, alcohol, or chemical poisoning.

pregnant women.

VARICOSE VEINS
Varicose veins are veins that are swollen, twisted, and often painful.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They are 
often seen on the legs of older people and of women who are pregnant or who have 
had many children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treatment:
There is no medicine for varicose veins.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But the 
following will help:
♦	 Do not spend much time standing or sitting with your 
feet down.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you have no choice but to sit or stand for 
long periods, try to lie down with your feet up (above 
the level of the heart) for a few minutes every half hour.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: When standing, try to walk in place.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

your heels off the ground and put them back down.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Also, sleep with your feet up (on pillows).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

to help hold in the veins.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Be sure to take them off at night.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Epilepsy causes seizures (fits) in people who otherwise seem fairly healthy.

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: The eyes often roll back.

text:
In mild types of 
epilepsy the person may suddenly ‘blank out’ a moment, make strange movements, or 
behave oddly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

from brain damage at birth, high fever in infancy, or tapeworm cysts in the brain  
(p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is often a life-long 
problem.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: However, babies sometimes get over it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

Note: These do not ‘cure’ epilepsy; they help prevent seizures.

TUBERCULOSIS (TB, CONSUMPTION)
Tuberculosis of the lungs is a chronic (long-lasting), contagious (easily spread) 
disease that anyone can get.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But it often strikes persons between 15 and 35 years 
of age—especially those who are weak, poorly nourished, have HIV, or live with 
someone who has TB.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Because so many people with HIV (p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
399) get very sick with 
TB, all people with HIV should get a TB test.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
People with HIV can take isoniazid (see 
p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: 360) to prevent TB from developing.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Encourage people with TB to also be tested 
for HIV and find help with a treatment program if they are positive.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Tuberculosis is curable.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Yet thousands die needlessly from this disease every 
year.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Both for prevention and cure, it is very important to treat tuberculosis early.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Be on the lookout for the signs of tuberculosis.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A person may have one or many 
of them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Most frequent signs of TB:
•	 A cough that lasts longer than 3 weeks, often worse just after 
waking up.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Slight fever in the evening and sweating at night.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 There may be pain in the chest or upper back.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Chronic loss of weight and increasing weakness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In serious or advanced cases:
•	 Coughing up blood (usually a little, but in some cases a lot).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The skin of a dark skinned person tends to 
get lighter, especially the face.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Voice grows hoarse (very serious).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: In young children: The cough may come late.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Instead, look for:
•	 Steady weight loss.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Lighter skin color.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Swellings in the neck (lymph nodes), or the belly (p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: TB is usually only in the lungs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But it can affect any part of the body.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

In young 
children it may cause meningitis (see p.

if you have TB or not.

health center.
