in different countries, but usually the treatment has 2 parts.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You will take 4 medicines 
for 2 months and then test your sputum.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you are getting better, you will take 2 or 3 
medicines for another 4 months.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Then you will be tested again to make sure you are 
cured.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Do not stop taking the medicines, even if you feel better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This can lead to the 
illness coming back and infecting you and other people, with a form of TB that is much 
harder to cure, multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To cure TB completely 
can take from 6 months to more than a year.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Eat as well as possible: plenty of energy foods and also foods rich in proteins and 
vitamins (p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If possible, stop working and take it easy 
until you begin to get better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
From then on, try not to work so hard that you become tired 
or breathe with difficulty.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Try to always get enough rest and sleep.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Tuberculosis in any other part of the body is treated 
the same as TB of the lungs, but the treatment may be 
longer.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This includes TB in the glands of the neck, TB of the 
abdomen (see picture on p.

212),

text:
A child with severe TB of the 
backbone may also need surgery to prevent paralysis (see 
Disabled Village Children, Chapter 21).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Tuberculosis is very contagious.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It spreads when 
someone with TB coughs germs into the air.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Anyone, 
especially a child, who lives with someone who has TB  
runs a great risk of catching the disease.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If someone in the house has TB:
♦	 If possible, see that the whole family is tested for TB (Tuberculin test).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦	 Have the children vaccinated against TB with B.C.G.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦	 Everyone, especially the children, should eat plenty of nutritious food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦	 The person with TB should eat and sleep separately from the children, if possible 
in a different room, as long as he has any cough at all.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦	 Ask the person with TB to cover his mouth when coughing and not spit on the floor.

RABIES
Rabies comes from the bite of

rabid dog, cat, fox, wolf, skunk,

In the animal:
•	 Acts strangely—sometimes

text: •	 Foaming at the mouth, cannot eat or drink.

nearby.

text: •	 The animal dies within 5 to 7 days.

•	 Pain and tingling in the area of the bite.

text: •	 Irregular breathing, as if the person has just been crying.

text: •	 Pain and difficulty swallowing, and fear of liquids.

text: A lot of thick, sticky saliva.

text: •	 The person is alert, but very nervous or excitable.

text: Fits of anger can occur.

text: •	 As death nears, seizures (convulsions) and paralysis.

wound; leave it open.

caught), take the bitten person at once to a health center where he can be 
given a series of anti-rabies injections.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

(usually within 3 to 7 weeks).

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

♦ 	 Kill and bury (or cage for one week) any animal suspected of having rabies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦ 	 Cooperate with programs to vaccinate dogs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦ 	 Keep children far away from any animal that seems sick or acts strangely.

text: Take great care in handling any animal that seems sick or acts strangely.

LEPROSY (HANSEN’S DISEASE)
This mildly infectious disease develops slowly, often over many years.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It can only 
spread from persons who have untreated leprosy, to persons who have low resistance 
to the disease.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In areas where leprosy is common, children should be checked every 
6 to 12 months—especially children living with persons who have leprosy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Signs: Leprosy can cause a variety of skin problems, loss of feeling, and paralysis of 
the hands and feet.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The first sign of leprosy is 
often a slowly growing patch 
on the skin that does not 
itch or hurt.

normal.

If you have an open sore, keep the part with the sore very clean and at rest until it

If you

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Prevention of damage to hands, feet, and eyes: The large open sores often seen on 
the hands and feet of persons with leprosy are not caused by the disease itself and 
can be prevented.

text:
They result because, when feeling has been lost, a person no 
longer protects himself against injury.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

it hurts, so he stops walking or limps.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

blister, or burn them:
Do not go barefoot, especially not where there are sharp 
stones or thorns.

text: Wear shoes or sandals.

text:
Put soft padding 
inside shoes and under straps that may rub.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: When working or cooking meals, wear gloves.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Never pick up an object that might be hot without 
first protecting your hand with a thick glove or 
folded cloth.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If possible, avoid work that involves 
handling sharp or hot objects.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

But when a person with 
leprosy gets a blister, it 
does not hurt.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Still without pain, the 
infection gets deeper 
and attacks the bone.

and more deformed.

Some skin problems are caused by diseases or irritations that affect the skin 
only—such as ringworm, diaper rash, or warts.

signs of serious diseases—like tuberculosis, syphilis, leprosy, or HIV infection.

they are hard to tell apart—yet their causes and the specific treatments they require

Scabies is especially common in children.

Scabies is caused by little animals—similar to tiny ticks or chiggers—which make

bedding.

swollen lymph nodes or fever.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

♦	 If one person has scabies, everyone in his family should be treated.

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦	 Cut fingernails very short to reduce spreading and infection.

to dry.

LICE
There are 3 kinds: head lice, body lice, and pubic lice (or 
‘crabs’) that live in the hairy parts of the body.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Lice cause 
itching, and sometimes skin infections and swollen lymph 
nodes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: To avoid lice, take great care with personal cleanliness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Wash clothing and bedding often and hang them in the sun.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Bathe and wash hair often.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Check children’s hair.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If they have lice, treat them all at once, otherwise they will pass 
them back and forth to each other.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Do not let a child with lice sleep with others.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treatment:
For head and pubic lice: You can usually get rid of lice without medicines by scrubbing 
the hair well with regular soap or shampoo for 10 minutes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Rinse well, and comb 
thoroughly with a fine-tooth comb, being sure to remove all the lice and their eggs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Repeat every day for 2 weeks.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Do not use shampoos that include lindane.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

not work, medicated shampoos that include 
pyrethrins (RID) or permethrin (Nix) may work, 
but follow the directions carefully.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

of your eyes, watch for allergic reactions, and 
avoid them if you are pregnant or the person with 
lice is younger than 2 years old.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

of nits (lice eggs).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

be back.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

HOW TO PREVENT SPREADING SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED infections
1.

text:
Be careful with whom you have sex: Someone who has sex with many 
different persons is more likely to catch these infections.

likely to be infected.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: To avoid infection, have sex with only one faithful partner.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you 
or your partner have sex with anyone else, always use a condom.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Get treatment right away: It is very important that all persons infected with 
a sexually transmitted infection get treatment at once so that they do not infect 
other people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Having one STI also makes it easier to become infected with HIV or 
other STIs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Do not have sex with anyone until 3 days after treatment is finished.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: (Unfortunately there is still no cure for HIV.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Tell other people if they need treatment: When a person finds out that he or 
she has a sexually transmitted infection, he should tell everyone with whom he has 
had sex, so that they can get treatment, too.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is especially important that a man tell 
a woman, because without knowing she has the disease she can pass it on to other 
people, her babies may become infected or blind, and in time she may become 
sterile or very ill herself.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Help others: Insist that friends who may have a sexually transmitted infection 
get treatment at once, and that they avoid all sexual contact until they are cured.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Sometimes a man and woman try to have children but the woman does not become

THE MENOPAUSE
(WHEN WOMEN STOP HAVING PERIODS)
The menopause or climacteric is the time in a woman’s life 
when the menstrual periods stop coming.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
After menopause, 
she can no longer bear children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In general, this ‘change of life’ 
happens between the ages of 40 and 50.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The periods often 
become irregular for several months before they stop completely.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
There is no reason to stop having sex during or after the 
menopause.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But a woman can still become pregnant during this 
time.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If she does not want to have more children, she should 
continue to use birth control for 12 months after her periods stop.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: When menopause begins, a woman may think she is pregnant.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
And when she bleeds again after 3 or 4 months, she may think 
she is having a miscarriage.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If a woman of 40 or 50 starts bleeding again after some 
months without, explain to her that it may be menopause.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

flashes’ (suddenly feeling uncomfortably hot), pains that travel all over the body, 
sadness, etc.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: After menopause is over, most women feel better again.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

who begin to bleed again after the bleeding has stopped for months or years, should 
seek medical help.

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Birth is a natural event.

may be in danger.

If there is any reason to think that a birth may be difficult or 
dangerous, a skilled midwife or experienced doctor should be present.

skin at the time of the birth, it would be better for someone else to deliver the baby.

THE STAGES OF LABOR
Labor has 3 parts or stages:
•	 The first stage lasts from the beginning of the strong contractions until the 
womb opens and the baby starts to move through the birth canal.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 The second stage lasts from when the baby enters the birth canal until it is born.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 The third stage lasts from the birth of the baby until the placenta (afterbirth) 
comes out.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

mother’s first birth, and from 7 to 10 hours in later births.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Taking good care of the breasts is important for the health of both the mother

BOTH THESE FAMILIES LIVE IN POOR COMMUNITIES:
Some mothers and fathers want a lot of children—especially in countries where 
poor people are denied a fair share of land, resources, and social benefits.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is 
because children help with work and provide care for their parents in old age.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In 
such areas, having just a few children may be a privilege only wealthier people can 
afford.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The situation is different in poor countries where resources and benefits are fairly 
distributed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where employment, housing, and health care are guaranteed and where 
women have equal opportunities for education and jobs, people usually choose to 
have smaller families.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is in part because they do not need to depend on their 
children for economic security.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In any society, parents have a right to make their own decision about how many 
children to have, and when to have them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Different parents have different reasons for wanting to limit the size of their 
family.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some young parents may decide to delay having any children until they 
have worked and saved enough so that they can afford to care for them well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some 
parents may decide that a small number of children is enough, and they never want 
more.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

the children and their mother will be healthier.

have more children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

FAMILY PLANNING
Having the number of children you want, when you 
want them, is called family planning.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you decide to 
wait to have children, you can choose one of several 
methods to prevent pregnancy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These methods are called 
family planning methods, child spacing methods, or 
contraception.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Every year, half a million women die of problems 
from pregnancy, childbirth, and unsafe abortion.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Most 
of these deaths could be prevented by family planning.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

pregnancies that are:
•	 in young women.

because their bodies are not fully grown.

text:
Their babies have a greater chance of 
dying in the first year.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Older women face more danger in child bearing, especially if 
they have other health problems or have had many children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: A woman’s body needs time to recover between pregnancies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

A woman with more than 4 children has a greater risk of death after 
childbirth from bleeding and other causes.

Birth control pills are made of chemicals (hormones) that normally occur in a

text:
How to take the pills—packet of 21:
Take the first pill on the first day of your period, counting the first day of the period as 
day 1.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Then take 1 pill every day until the packet is finished (21 days).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Take your pills 
at the same time each day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: After finishing the packet, wait 7 days before taking any more pills.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Then begin 
another packet, 1 pill each day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This way, you will take the pills for 3 weeks out of each month, then go 1 week 
without taking any.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Normally, the menstrual period will come during the week when the 
pill is not taken.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Even if the period does not come, start the new packet 7 days after 
finishing the last one.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you do not want to get pregnant, it is important to take the pills as 
directed—1 every day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you forget to take the pill one day, take it as soon as you 
realize this, or take 2 the next day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Condoms from old or torn packages are 
more likely to break.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
THE CONDOM FOR WOMEN is a thin, plastic sheath that fits inside the 
vagina.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: A flexible ring at the closed end of the condom holds it in place.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
other ring at the open end hangs out, covering the outer lips of the vagina.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This condom can be put in up to 6 hours before sex and should be taken out 
immediately after sex.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It should be used only once, because it may break if it 
is washed and reused.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But washing out and reusing a female condom up to 
5 times is better than no condom.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The female condom is the most effective 
method controlled by women for protecting against both pregnancy and 
STIs, including HIV.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The female condom should not be used with a male 
condom.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
THE DIAPHRAGM is a shallow cup made of soft rubber that a woman 
wears in her vagina.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It can be put in anytime and should be left in for 
at least 6 hours after having sex.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Diaphragms come in different sizes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: A trained health worker can recommend the right size for each woman.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
After each use, the woman should wash the diaphragm with soap and 
water, and dry it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Keep it in a clean dry place.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A diaphragm usually lasts 
about 2 years.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Check it regularly for holes by holding it up to the light.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: If there is even a tiny hole, get a new one.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A diaphragm may give 
some protection against STIs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
SPERMICIDES are foam, tablets, cream, or jelly that are put into 
the vagina before having sex.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Spermicide kills the man’s sperm 
before it can get into the womb.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It does not protect against STIs or 
HIV.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Tablets should be put in the vagina 10 to 15 minutes before 
having sex.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Foam, jelly, or cream work best if they are put in the 
vagina just before having sex.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Add spermicide each time you have 
sex.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: After sex, do not douche or wash the spermicide out for at least 6 hours.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some 
spermicides can cause itching or irritation inside the vagina.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
THE INTRAUTERINE DEVICE (IUD) is a small object that is inserted 
in the womb by a specially trained health worker or midwife.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
IUD prevents the man’s sperm from fertilizing the woman’s egg.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
IUD can be inserted any time a woman and her health worker are 
reasonably sure the woman is not pregnant and does not have any 
signs of a vaginal infection or an STI.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A woman can ask a trained 
health care worker or midwife to remove the IUD any time she 
wants to change methods or get pregnant.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The IUD does not 
protect against STIs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
291
THE COUNTING DAYS METHOD
This method is not very sure to prevent pregnancy, but it has the advantage of 
not costing anything.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is more likely to work for a woman whose periods come 
very regularly, more or less once every 28 days.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, the husband and wife must 
be willing to pass 11 days out of each month without having sex the regular way.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Usually a woman has a chance of becoming pregnant only during 11 days of her 
monthly cycle—her ‘fertile days’.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These 11 days come midway between her periods, 
beginning 8 days after the first day of menstrual bleeding.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To avoid getting pregnant, 
a woman should not have sex with her man during these 11 days.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
During the rest of 
the month, she is not likely to get pregnant.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To avoid confusion the woman should mark on a calendar the 11 days she is not 
to have sex.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example: Suppose your period 
begins on the 5th day of May.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Count 
that as day number 1.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Mark it like this:
Then count 8 days.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Starting 
with the 8th day, put a line  
under the next 11 days like this:
During these 11 ‘fertile days’, 
do not have sexual relations.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Now suppose your next period 
begins on the first of June.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Mark it 
the same way, like this:
Once again count off 8 days 
and underline the following 11 days 
in which you will not have sexual 
contact.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the woman and her husband carefully avoid having sex together during these 
11 days of each month, it is possible that they will go years without having another 
child.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: However, few couples are successful for very long.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is not a very sure 
method, unless used in combination with another method such as a diaphragm or 
condoms, especially during the days from the end of the menstrual period until the 
fertile days are over.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Where There Is No Doctor 2011
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
292
THE MUCUS METHOD
This is a variation of the counting days method.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A woman finds out when she could 
become pregnant by checking the mucus in her vagina every day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It works fairly well 
for some couples but not for others.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In general it cannot be considered a very sure 
way of preventing pregnancy, but it costs nothing and has no risks other than those 
that come with pregnancy itself.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
However, it is more difficult to do if the woman has a 
vaginal infection with a lot of discharge, if her periods are not regular, or if she douches 
or washes out her vagina.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Every day, except during her period, the woman should examine the mucus from 
her vagina.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Take a little mucus out of your vagina with a clean finger and try to make it 
stretch between your thumb and forefinger, like this:
As long as the mucus is sticky like 
paste—not slippery or slimy—you 
probably cannot become pregnant, 
and can continue to have sexual 
relations.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When the mucus begins to get slippery or 
slimy, like raw egg, or if it stretches between 
your fingers, you may become pregnant 
if you have sexual relations.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So, do not 
have sex when the mucus is slippery 
or stretches, or until 2 days after it has 
stopped being slippery or stretchy and 
has become sticky again.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The mucus will usually become slippery during a few days midway between your 
periods.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These are the same days you would not have sex with your man if you were 
using the counting days method.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: To be more sure, use the mucus and counting days methods together.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To be still 
more sure, see below.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The mucus and counting days methods do not protect against 
STIs, including HIV.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Combined Methods
If you want to be more certain not to become pregnant, it often helps to use 
2 methods at the same time.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The counting days or mucus method combined with 
the use of a condom, diaphragm, spermicide, or sponge is surer than any of these 
methods alone.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Likewise, if a man uses condoms and the woman a diaphragm, the 
chance of pregnancy is very low.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Where There Is No Doctor 2011
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In this family planning method, a 
woman is given injections of hormones every 1 to 3 
months, usually at a health center or family planning 
clinic, by someone who knows how.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The first injection 
can be given any time a woman and her health worker 
are reasonably sure the woman is not pregnant.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
injection protects against pregnancy immediately if it is 
given within 5 days after monthly bleeding begins.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the 
injection is given 6 or more days after the beginning of 
monthly bleeding, the woman and her partner should use 
condoms or not have sex for the next 7 days.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For more 
information see page 396.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
IMPLANTS are small, soft tubes that are placed under 
the skin on the inside of a woman’s arm.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These tubes 
contain the hormone progestin and prevent pregnancy 
from 6 months to 5 years, depending on the type of implant.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The tubes must be 
inserted and removed by a trained health worker, usually at a clinic or family planning 
center.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They can be inserted any time a woman and her health worker are reasonably 
sure the woman is not pregnant.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If a woman is breastfeeding, implants can be 
inserted 6 weeks after the baby was born.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: For more information see page 397.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
METHODS FOR THOSE WHO NEVER WANT TO HAVE 
MORE CHILDREN
STERILIZATION.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For those who never want to have more children, there are 
fairly safe, simple operations for both men and women.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In many countries these 
operations are free.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Ask at the health center.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Sterilization does not protect against 
STIs, including HIV.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 For men, the operation is called a vasectomy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It can be 
done simply and quickly in a doctor’s office or a health 
center, usually without putting the man to sleep.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Small 
cuts are made here so that the tubes from the man’s 
testicles can be cut and tied.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The testicles are not 
removed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The operation has no effect on the man’s sexual 
ability or pleasure.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
His fluid comes just the same, but 
has no sperm in it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 For women, the operation is called a tubal ligation, 
which means to tie the tubes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
One method is to 
make a small cut in the lower belly so that the tubes 
coming from the ovaries, or egg-makers, can be cut 
and tied.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It can usually be done in a doctor’s office 
or health center without putting the woman to sleep.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Although usually successful, there is a higher risk of 
infection in the operation for women than for men.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This operation has no effect on the woman’s menstrual 
periods or sexual ability, and may make having sex more 
pleasant because she does not have to worry about pregnancy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
294
HOME METHODS FOR PREVENTING PREGNANCY
Every community has traditional methods to prevent or stop pregnancy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some of 
these can help limit the number of children a couple has, but they are usually not as 
effective as modern methods.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some traditional methods can be harmful, and some 
do not work at all.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, washing out the vagina or urinating after sex will not 
prevent pregnancy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: WITHDRAWAL OR PULLING OUT (coitus interruptus).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The man pulls his penis out of 
the woman and away from her genitals before the sperm comes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This method is better 
than no method, but it does not always work.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Sometimes a man is not able to pull 
out before he ejaculates (comes).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Even if the man pulls out in time, some liquid that 
contains sperm can leak out of his penis before ejaculation and cause pregnancy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
295
WHAT TO DO TO PROTECT CHILDREN’S HEALTH
Chapters 11 and 12 tell more about the importance of nutritious food, cleanliness, 
and vaccination.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Parents should read these chapters carefully and use them to help 
care for—and teach—their children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: The main points are briefly repeated here.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Nutritious Food
It is important that children eat the most nutritious foods they can get, so that they 
grow well and do not get sick.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The best foods for children at different ages are:
♦	 in the first 6 months: breast milk and nothing more.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦	 from 6 months to 1 year: breast milk and also other nutritious foods—
such as boiled cereals, mashed-up beans, eggs, meat, cooked fruits and 
vegetables.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦	 from 1 year on: the child should eat the same foods as adults—but more 
often.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To the main food (rice, maize, wheat, potatoes, or cassava) add ‘helper 
foods’ as discussed in Chapter 11.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦	 Above all, children should get enough to eat—several times a day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦	 All parents should watch for signs of malnutrition in their children and should 
give them the best food they can.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

KEEP CHILDREN HEALTHY AND PROTECT THEM AGAINST MANY SICKNESSES.

296
Cleanliness
Children are more likely to be healthy if their village, their homes, and they 
themselves are kept clean.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Follow the Guidelines of Cleanliness explained in 
Chapter 12.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Teach children to follow them—and to understand their importance.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Here 
the most important guidelines are repeated:
•	 Bathe children and change their clothes often.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 Teach children always to wash their hands when they get up in the morning, after 
they have a bowel movement, and before they eat or handle food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Make latrines or ‘outhouses’—and teach children to use them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Where hookworm exists, do not let children go barefoot; use sandals or shoes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 Teach children to brush their teeth; and do not give them a lot of candies, sweets, 
or carbonated drinks.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Cut fingernails very short.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 Do not let children who are sick or have sores, scabies, lice, or ringworm sleep 
with other children or use the same clothing or towels.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 Treat children quickly for scabies, ringworm, intestinal worms, and other 
infections that spread easily from child to child.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 Do not let children put dirty things in their mouths or let dogs or cats lick their 
faces.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Keep pigs, dogs, and chickens out of the house.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Use only pure, boiled, or filtered water for drinking.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is especially important 
for babies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 Do not feed babies from ‘baby bottles’, because these are hard to keep clean 
and can cause illness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Feed babies with a cup and spoon.

text:
Vaccinations
Vaccinations protect children against many 
of the most dangerous diseases of childhood—
whooping cough, diphtheria, tetanus, polio, 
measles, tuberculosis, hepatitis, and rotavirus.

Children should be given the different 
vaccinations at different ages, as shown on

Polio vaccines should be first given if 
possible at birth, but no later than  
2 months of age, because the risk of developing 
infantile paralysis (polio) is highest in babies 
under 1 year old.

NOT DISCUSSED IN OTHER chapters
Earache and Ear Infections
Ear infections are common in small children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The infection 
often begins after a few days with a cold or a stuffy nose.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
fever may rise, and the child often cries or rubs the side of his 
head.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Sometimes pus can be seen in the ear.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In small children 
an ear infection sometimes causes vomiting or diarrhea.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So 
when a child has diarrhea and fever be sure to check his ears.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treatment:
♦	 It is important to treat ear infections early.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Give an antibiotic like penicillin 
(p.

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

(p.

text: 352) often works better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

a stick, leaves, or anything else in the ear.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

swim or dive for at least 2 weeks after they are well.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Sore throat and the danger of rheumatic fever:
For the sore throat that often comes with the common cold or flu, antibiotics 
should usually not be used and will do no good.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treat with gargles and 
acetaminophen.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
However, one kind of sore throat—called strep throat—should be treated with 
penicillin.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: It is most common in children and young adults.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It usually begins suddenly 
with severe sore throat and high fever, often without signs of a cold or cough.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
back of the mouth and tonsils become very red, and the lymph nodes under the jaw or 
in the neck may become swollen and tender.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If penicillin is given early and continued for 
10 days, there is less danger of getting rheumatic fever.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

INFECTIOUS DISEASES OF CHILDHOOD
Chickenpox
This mild virus infection begins 2 to 3 weeks after a child is 
exposed to another child who has the disease.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Signs:
First many small, red, itchy spots appear.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These turn into little pimples or blisters 
that pop and finally form scabs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Usually they begin on the body, and later on the 
face, arms, and legs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: There may be spots, blisters, and scabs, all at the same time.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Fever is usually mild.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treatment:
The infection usually goes away in a week.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Bathe the child daily with soap and 
warm water.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To calm itching, apply cool cloths soaked in water from boiled and 
strained oatmeal.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Cut fingernails very short.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the scabs get infected, keep them 
clean.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Apply hot, wet compresses, and put an antibiotic ointment on them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Try to 
keep the child from scratching.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Measles
This severe virus infection is especially dangerous 
in children who are poorly nourished or have 
tuberculosis.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Ten days after being near a person with 
measles, it begins with signs of a cold—fever, runny 
nose, red sore eyes, and cough.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: The child becomes increasingly ill.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The mouth may 
become very sore and he may develop diarrhea.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: After 2 or 3 days a few tiny white spots like salt grains appear in the mouth.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A day 
or 2 later the rash appears—first behind the ears and on the neck, then on the face 
and body, and last on the arms and legs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
After the rash appears, the child usually 
begins to get better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: The rash lasts about 5 days.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Sometimes there are scattered 
black spots caused by bleeding into the skin (‘black measles’).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

This means the 
attack is very severe.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

312
German Measles
German measles are not as severe as regular measles.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: They last 3 or 4 days.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Often the lymph nodes on the back of the head and neck become 
swollen and tender.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: There is often a low fever.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: The child should stay in bed and take acetaminophen or ibuprofen if necessary.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Women who get German measles in the first 3 months of pregnancy may give birth 
to a child with a disability.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For this reason, pregnant women who have not yet had 
German measles—or are not sure—should keep far away from children who have 
this kind of measles.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Girls or women who are not pregnant can try to catch German 
measles before they get pregnant.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A vaccine exists for German measles, but is not 
often available.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Mumps
The first symptoms begin 2 or 3 weeks after being exposed 
to someone with mumps.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Mumps begin with fever and pain on opening the mouth 
or eating.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In 2 days, a soft swelling appears below the ears at 
the angle of the jaw.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Often it comes first on one side, and later 
on the other side.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treatment:
The swelling goes away by itself in about 10 days, without need for medicine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Acetaminophen or ibuprofen can be taken for pain and fever.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Feed the child soft, 
nourishing foods and keep his mouth clean.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Complications:
In adults and children over 11 years of age, after the first 
week there may be pain in the belly or a painful swelling of the 
testicles in men.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Persons with such swelling should stay quiet 
and put ice packs or cold wet cloths on the swollen parts to 
help reduce the pain and swelling.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If signs of meningitis or hearing problems appear, get 
medical help (p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Prevention of measles:
Children with measles should keep far away from other children, even from brothers 
and sisters.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Especially try to protect children who are poorly nourished or who have 
tuberculosis or other chronic illnesses.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Children from other families should not go into 
a house where there is measles.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If children in a family where there is measles have not 
yet had measles themselves, they should not go to school or into stores or other public 
places for 10 days.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To prevent measles from killing children, make sure all
children are well-nourished.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
And have your children 
vaccinated against measles.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Whooping Cough
Whooping cough begins a week or two after 
being exposed to a child who has it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It starts like a 
cold with fever, a runny nose, and cough.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Two weeks later, the whoop begins.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The child 
coughs rapidly many times without taking a 
breath, until she coughs up a plug of sticky 
mucus, and the air rushes back into her lungs 
with a loud whoop.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
While she is coughing, her 
lips and nails may turn blue for lack of air.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
After 
the whoop, she may vomit.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Between coughing 
spells the child seems fairly healthy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Whooping cough often lasts 3 months or more.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Whooping cough is especially dangerous in babies under 1 year of age, so 
vaccinate children early.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Small babies do not develop the typical whoop so it is hard 
to be sure if they have whooping cough or not.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If a baby gets fits of coughing and 
swollen or puffy eyes when there are cases of whooping cough in your area, treat 
her for whooping cough at once.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treatment:
♦  Antibiotics are helpful only in the early stage of whooping cough, before the 
whoop begins.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is especially important to treat babies under 6 months at 
the first sign.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you do not have erythromycin, try 
cotrimoxazole (p.

A bright red hemorrhage (bleeding) inside the white of the eyes may be caused

If seizures or signs of

See that

Diphtheria
This begins like a cold with fever, sore throat, and hoarse 
voice.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A yellow-gray coating or membrane may form in the back 
of the throat, and sometimes in the nose and on the lips.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
child’s neck may become swollen.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

If you suspect that a child has diphtheria:
♦ Put him to bed in a room separate from other persons.

text: ♦  Get medical help quickly.

text: There is special antitoxin for diphtheria.

text:
Infantile Paralysis (Polio, Poliomyelitis)
Polio is most common in children under 2.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is caused by 
a virus infection similar to a cold, often with fever, vomiting, 
diarrhea, and sore muscles.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Usually the child gets 
completely well in a few days.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But sometimes a part of 
the body becomes weak or paralyzed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Most often this 
happens to one or both legs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In time, the weak limb 
becomes thin and does not grow as fast as the other one.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treatment:
Once the disease has begun, no medicine will 
correct the paralysis.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
(However, sometimes part or 
all of the lost strength slowly returns.) Antibiotics 
do not help.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For early treatment, calm the pain with 
acetaminophen or ibuprofen and put hot soaks on 
painful muscles.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Position the child to be comfortable 
and avoid contractures.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Gently straighten his arms 
and legs so that the child lies as straight as possible.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Put cushions under his knees, if necessary to reduce 
pain, but try to keep his knees straight.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Prevention:
♦	 Vaccination against polio is the best protection (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦	 Do not give injections of any medicine to a child if you think his signs of a cold 
or fever, might be caused by the polio virus.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Although it happens only rarely, the 
irritation caused by an injection could turn a mild case of polio without paralysis 
into a severe case, with paralysis.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Never inject children with any medicine 
unless it is absolutely necessary.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦	 Breastfeed your baby as long as possible.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Breast milk protects your baby against 
infections, including polio.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Vaccinate all children against polio.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Where There Is No Doctor 2011
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

A child who has been paralyzed by polio 
should eat nutritious food and do exercises to 
strengthen remaining muscles.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Leg braces (calipers), 
crutches, and other aids may help the child to

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

see Disabled Village Children, also published by Hesperian.

text:
318
MENTALLY SLOW, DEAF, OR DEFORMED CHILDREN
Sometimes parents will have a child who is born deaf, mentally slow (retarded), or 
with birth defects (something wrong with part of his body).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Often no reason can be 
found.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: No one should be blamed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Often it just seems to happen by chance.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: However, certain things greatly increase the chance of birth defects.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A baby is less 
likely to have something wrong if parents take certain precautions.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Lack of nutritious food during pregnancy can cause mental slowness or birth 
defects in babies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To have healthy babies, pregnant women must eat enough nutritious food 
(see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Lack of iodine in a pregnant woman’s diet can cause 
hypothyroidism (cretinism) in her baby.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The baby’s face is puffy, and 
he looks dull.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
His skin and eyes may remain yellow (jaundiced) for a 
long time after he is born.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
His tongue hangs out, and his forehead may 
be hairy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: He is weak, feeds poorly, cries little, and sleeps a lot.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
He is 
mentally slow, may be deaf, and usually has an umbilical hernia.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
He will 
begin to walk and talk later than normal babies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To help prevent hypothyroidism, pregnant women should use 
iodized salt instead of ordinary salt (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you suspect your baby may have hypothyroidism, take him to a 
health worker or doctor at once.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The sooner he gets special medicine 
(thyroid) the more normal he will be.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Smoking or drinking of alcoholic drinks during pregnancy 
causes babies to be born small or to have other problems (see  
p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Do not drink or smoke—especially during pregnancy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: After age 35, there is more chance that a mother will have a child with defects.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Mongolism or Down disease, which looks somewhat like hypothyroidism, is more likely 
to occur in babies of older mothers.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is wise to plan your family so as to have no more children after age 35 
(see Chapter 20).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Many medicines can harm the baby developing inside a pregnant mother.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Use 
as little medicine as possible during pregnancy—and only those known to be safe.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When parents are blood relatives (cousins, for instance), there is a higher 
chance that their children will have birth defects or mental slowness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Cross-eyes, extra 
fingers or toes, club feet, hare lip, and cleft palate are common defects.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: To lower the chance of these and other problems, do not marry a close relative.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
And 
if you have more than one child with a birth defect, consider not having more children 
(see Family Planning, Chapter 20).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Some children of African origin (or less often from India) are born with a

•	 fever and crying
•	 occasional swelling of the feet and fingers 
which lasts for 1 or 2 weeks
•	 big belly that feels hard at the top
•	 anemia, and sometimes yellow color in the eyes (jaundice)
•	 child frequently sick (cough, malaria, diarrhea)
•	 child grows slowly
•	 by age 2, bony bumps may appear on the head (‘bossing’)
Malaria or other infections can bring on a ‘sickle cell crisis’ with high fever and 
severe pain in the arms, legs, or belly.

HELPING CHILDREN LEARN
As a child grows, she learns partly from what she is taught.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Knowledge and 
skills she learns in school may help her to understand and do more later.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
School 
can be important.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But a child does much of her learning at home or in the forest or fields.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
She 
learns by watching, listening, and trying for herself what she sees others do.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
She 
learns not so much from what people tell her, as from how she sees them act.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some of the most important things a child can learn—such as kindness, 
responsibility, and sharing—can be taught only by setting a good example.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: A child learns through adventure.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
She needs to learn how to do things for 
herself, even though she makes mistakes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When she is very young, protect a 
child from danger.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But as she grows, help her learn to care for herself.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Give her 
some responsibility.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Respect her judgment, even if it differs from your own.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: When a child is young, she thinks mostly of filling only her own needs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Later, 
she discovers the deeper pleasure of helping and doing things for others.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Welcome the help of children and let them know how much it means.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Children who are not afraid ask many questions.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If parents, teachers, and 
others take the time to answer their questions clearly and honestly—and to say 
they do not know when they do not—a child will keep asking questions, and as 
she grows may look for ways to make her surroundings or her village a better 
place to live.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some of the best ideas for helping children learn and become involved 
in community health care have been developed through the Child-to-Child 
program.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Stroke (Apoplexy, Cerebro-Vascular Accident, CVA)
In older people stroke or cerebro-vascular accident (CVA) commonly results from 
a blood clot or from bleeding inside the brain.

text:
The word stroke is used because 
this condition often strikes without warning.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The person may suddenly fall down, 
unconscious.

text:
Her face is often reddish, her breathing hoarse 
and noisy, her pulse strong and slow.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
She may remain in a coma 
(unconscious) for hours or days.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If she lives, she may have trouble speaking, seeing, or 
thinking, or one side of her face and body may be paralyzed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In minor strokes, some of these same problems may result 
without loss of consciousness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The difficulties caused by

text:

Put the person in bed with her head a little higher than her feet.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

unconscious, roll her head back and to one side so her saliva (or vomit) runs out 
of her mouth, rather than into her lungs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

drink, or medicines by mouth (see the Unconscious Person, p.

medical help.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

cane and to use her good hand to care for herself.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

and anger.

text:
DEAFNESS WITH RINGING OF THE EARS AND DIZZINESS
If an older person loses hearing in one or both ears—occasionally with severe 
dizziness—and hears a loud ‘ringing’ or buzzing, he probably has Ménière’s 
disease.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: He may also feel nauseous, or vomit, and may sweat a lot.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
He should take 
an antihistamine, such as dimenhydrinate (Dramamine, p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
386) and go to bed until 
the signs go away.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: He should have no salt in his food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If he does not get better soon, 
or if the problem returns, he should seek medical advice.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
328
Loss of Sleep (Insomnia)
It is normal for older people to need less sleep than younger people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
And they 
wake up more often at night.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
During long winter nights, older people may spend hours 
without being able to sleep.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Certain medicines may help bring sleep, but it is better not to use them if they are 
not absolutely necessary.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Here are some suggestions for sleeping:
♦  Get plenty of exercise during the day.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦  Do not drink coffee or black tea, especially in the afternoon or evening.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦  Drink a glass of warm milk or milk with honey before going to bed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦  Take a warm bath before going to bed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦  In bed, try to relax each part of your body—then your whole body and mind.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦  If you still cannot sleep, try taking an antihistamine like promethazine (Phenergan, 
p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: 385) or dimenhydrinate (Dramamine, p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: 386) half an hour before going to bed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: These are less habit-forming than stronger drugs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
DISEASES FOUND MORe OFTEN
IN PEOPLE OVER 40 YEARS OLD
Cirrhosis of the Liver
Cirrhosis usually occurs in men over 40 who for years have been 
drinking a lot of liquor (alcohol) and eating poorly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Signs:
•	 Cirrhosis starts like hepatitis, with weakness, loss of  
appetite, upset stomach, and pain on the person’s right 
side below the ribs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 As the illness gets worse, the person gets thinner and thinner.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In serious cases the feet swell, and  
the belly swells with liquid until it looks like a drum.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
eyes and skin may turn yellowish (jaundice).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treatment:
When cirrhosis is severe, it is hard to cure.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: There are no medicines that help much.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Most people with severe cirrhosis die from it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you want to stay alive, at the first sign 
of cirrhosis do the following:
♦	 Never drink alcohol again!
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Alcohol poisons the liver.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦	 Eat as well as possible: vegetables, fruit, and some protein (p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But do not eat a lot of protein (meat, eggs, fish, etc.) because this makes the 
damaged liver work too hard.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦	 If a person with cirrhosis has swelling, he should not use any salt in his food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Prevention of this disease is easy: DO NOT DRINK SO MUCH alcohol.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011 329
Gallbladder Problems
The gallbladder is a small sac attached to the liver.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It collects 
a bitter, green juice called bile, which helps digest fatty foods.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Gallbladder disease occurs most commonly in women over 40, 
people who are overweight, and people with diabetes.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Signs:
•	 Sharp pain in the stomach at the edge of the right rib cage: 
This pain sometimes reaches up to the right side of the 
upper back.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 The pain may come an hour or more after eating rich or 
fatty foods.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Severe pain may cause vomiting.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Belching or burping with a bad taste.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 In severe cases, there may be fever.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Occasionally the eyes may become yellow (jaundice).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treatment:
♦	 Do not eat greasy food.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Overweight (fat) people should eat small meals and 
lose weight.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦	 Take ibuprofen to calm the pain (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Stronger painkillers are often 
needed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
(Aspirin will probably not help.)
♦	 If the person has a fever, she should take ampicillin (p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: ♦	 In severe or chronic cases, seek medical help.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Sometimes surgery is needed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Prevention:
Women (and men) who are overweight should try to lose weight (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Avoid rich, sweet, and greasy food, do not eat too much, and get some exercise.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
BILIOUSNESS
In many countries and in different languages, bad-tempered persons are said 
to be ‘bilious’.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some people believe that fits of anger come when a person has too 
much bile.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In truth, most-bad tempered persons have nothing wrong with their gallbladders 
or bile.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
However, persons who do suffer from gallbladder disease often live in 
fear of a return of this severe pain and perhaps for this reason are sometimes 
short‑tempered or continually worried about their health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
(In fact, the term 
‘hypochondria’, which means to worry continually about one’s own health, comes 
from ‘hypo’, meaning under, and ‘chondrium’, meaning rib—referring to the position 
of the gallbladder!)
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
330
ACCEPTING DEATH
Old people are often more ready to accept their own approaching death than are 
those who love them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Persons who have lived fully are not usually afraid to die.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Death 
is, after all, the natural end of life.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
We often make the mistake of trying to keep a dying person alive as long as 
possible, no matter what the cost.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Sometimes this adds to the suffering and strain for 
both the person and his family.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
There are many occasions when the kindest thing to do 
is not to hunt for ‘better medicine’ or a ‘better doctor’ but to be close to and supporting 
of the person who is dying.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Let him know that you are glad for all the time, the joy and 
the sorrow you have shared, and that you, too, are able to accept his death.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In the last 
hours, love and acceptance will do far more good than medicines.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Old or chronically ill persons would often prefer to be at home, in familiar 
surroundings with those they love, than to be in a hospital.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
At times this may mean that 
the person will die earlier.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: But this is not necessarily bad.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
We must be sensitive to the 
person’s feelings and needs, and to our own.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Sometimes a person who is dying suffers 
more knowing that the cost of keeping him barely alive causes his family to go into debt 
or children to go hungry.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
He may ask simply to be allowed to die and—and there are 
times when this may be the wise decision.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Yet some people fear death.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Even if they are suffering, the known world may be hard 
to leave behind.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Every culture has a system of beliefs about death and ideas about life 
after death.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: These ideas, beliefs, and traditions may offer some comfort in facing death.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Death may come upon a person suddenly and unexpectedly or may be 
long‑awaited.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
How to help someone we love accept and prepare for his approaching 
death is not an easy matter.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Often the most we can do is offer support, kindness, and 
understanding.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: The death of a younger person or child is never easy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Both kindness and honesty 
are important.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A child—or anyone—who is dying often knows it, partly by what her own 
body tells her and partly by the fear or despair she sees in those who love her.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Whether 
young or old, if a person who is dying asks for the truth, tell her, but tell her gently, and 
leave some room for hope.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Weep if you must, but let her know that even as you love 
her, and because you love her, you have the strength to let her leave you.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This will give 
her the strength and courage to accept leaving you.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To let her know these things you 
need not say them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: You need to feel and show them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Perhaps the most important job of the healer is to help people 
accept death when it can or should no longer be avoided, and to help ease the 
suffering of those who still live.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
331
Every family and every village should have certain medical supplies ready in 
case of emergency:
•	 The family should have a HOME MEDICINE KIT (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
334) with the 
necessary medicines for first aid, simple infections, and the most common 
health problems.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 The village should have a more complete medical kit (see VILLAGE MEDICINE 
KIT, p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
336) with supplies necessary to care for day-to-day problems as well 
as to meet a serious illness or an emergency.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A responsible person should 
be in charge of it—a health worker, teacher, parent, storekeeper, or anyone 
who can be trusted by the community.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If possible, all members of the village 
should take part in setting up and paying for the medical kit.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Those who can 
afford more should contribute more.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But everyone should understand that 
the medicine kit is for the benefit of all—those who can pay and those who 
cannot.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
On the following pages you will find suggestions for what the medicine kits might 
contain.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You will want to change these lists to best meet the needs and resources 
in your area.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Although the list includes mostly modern medicines, important home 
remedies known to be safe and to work well can also be included.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: How much of each medicine should you have?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The amounts of medicines recommended for the medicine kits are the smallest 
amounts that should be kept on hand.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In some cases there will be just enough to 
begin treatment.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It may be necessary to take the sick person to a hospital or go for 
more medicine at once.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The amount of medicine you keep in your kit will depend on how many people it 
is intended to serve and how far you have to go to get more when some are used 
up.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: It will also depend on cost and how much the family or village can afford.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some 
of the medicines for your kit will be expensive, but it is wise to have enough of the 
important medicines on hand to meet emergencies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Note: Supplies for birth kits—the things midwives and pregnant mothers need to 
have ready for a birth—are listed on pages 254 to 255.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf
