text:
332
HOW TO CARE FOR YOUR MEDICINE KIT
1.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: CAUTION: Keep all medicines out of the reach of children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Any medicine taken 
in large doses can be poisonous.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Be sure that all medicine is well labeled and that directions for use are kept 
with each medicine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Keep a copy of this book with the medicine kit.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Keep all medicines and medical supplies together in a clean, dry, cool place 
free from cockroaches and rats.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Protect instruments, gauze, and cotton by wrapping 
them in sealed plastic bags.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Keep an emergency supply of important medicines on hand at all times.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Each 
time one is used, replace it as soon as possible.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Notice the DATE OF EXPIRATION on each medicine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the date has passed or 
the medicine looks spoiled, destroy it and get new medicine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Note: Some medicines, especially tetracyclines, may be very dangerous if they have 
passed their expiration date.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
However, penicillins in dry form (tablets or powder for 
syrup or injection) can be used for as long as a year after the expiration date if they 
have been stored in a clean, dry, and fairly cool place.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Old penicillin may lose some 
of its strength so you may want to increase the dose.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
(CAUTION: While this is safe 
with penicillin, with other medicines it is often too dangerous to give more than the 
recommended dose.)
Keep medicines out of reach of children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
333
BUYING SUPPLIES FOR THE MEDICINE KIT
Most of the medicines recommended in this book can be bought in the 
pharmacies of larger towns.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If several families or the village got together to buy 
what they need at once, often the pharmacist may sell them supplies at lower 
cost.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Or if medicines and supplies can be bought from a wholesaler, prices will be 
cheaper still.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the pharmacy does not supply a brand of medicine you want, buy another 
brand, but be sure that it is the same medicine and check the dosage.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: When buying medicines, compare prices.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some brands are much more 
expensive than others even though the medicine is the same.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
More expensive 
medicines are usually no better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When possible, buy generic medicines rather 
than brand-name products, as the generic ones are often much cheaper.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Sometimes you can save money by buying larger quantities.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, a 
600,000-Unit vial of penicillin often costs only a little more than a 300,000-Unit vial—
so buy the large vial and use it for two doses.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
338
WORDS TO THE VILLAGE STOREKEEPER  
OR PHARMACIST
If you sell medicines in your store, people 
probably ask you about which medicines to 
buy and when or how to use them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You are in a 
position to have an important effect on people’s 
knowledge and health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This book can help you to give correct 
advice and to see that your customers buy only 
those medicines they really need.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As you know, people too often spend the 
little money they have for medicines that do not 
help them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But you can help them understand 
their health needs more clearly and spend their 
money more wisely.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example:
•	 If people come asking for cough syrups, 
for a diarrhea thickener like Kaopectate, 
for vitamin B12 or liver extract to treat simple anemia, for penicillin to treat a sprain 
or ache, or for tetracycline when they have a cold, explain to them that these 
medicines are not needed and may do more harm than good.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Discuss with them 
what to do instead.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 If someone wants to buy a vitamin tonic, encourage him to buy eggs, fruit, or 
vegetables instead.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Help him understand that these have more vitamins and 
nutritional value for the money.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 If people ask for an injection when medicine by mouth would work as well and be 
safer—which is usually the case—tell them so.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 If someone wants to buy ‘cold tablets’ or some other expensive combination 
of medicines for a cold, encourage him to save money by buying plain aspirin, 
acetaminophen, or ibuprofen tablets and taking them with lots of liquids.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
You may find it easier to tell people these things if you look up the information in this 
book, and read it together with them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Above all, sell only useful medicines.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Stock your store with the medicines and 
supplies listed for the Home and Village Medicine Kits, as well as other medicines and 
supplies that are important for common illnesses in your area.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Try to stock low cost 
generic products or the least expensive brands.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
And never sell medicines that are 
expired, damaged, or useless.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Your store can become a place where people learn about caring for their own 
health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you can help people use medicines intelligently, making sure that anyone 
who purchases a medicine is well informed as to its correct use and dosage, as 
well as the risks and precautions, you will provide an outstanding service to your 
community.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

INJECTABLE PENICILLIN
Injectable penicillin should be used for certain 
severe infections, including:
tetanus
severe pneumonia
badly infected wounds
gangrene
syphilis
Injectable penicillin comes in many different 
preparations.

text:
Choosing the right kind of penicillin 
for injection:
Some kinds of penicillin do their job quickly but 
do not last long.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Others work more slowly but last 
longer.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
There are times when it is better to use one 
kind than another.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Short-acting penicillin: These are known 
by many names, including crystalline penicillin, 
benzylpenicillin, aqueous penicillin, soluble 
penicillin, sodium penicillin, potassium penicillin, 
and penicillin G injections.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These penicillins act 
quickly but only stay in the body a short time, so 
that they must be injected every 6 hours (4 times a 
day).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A short-acting penicillin is the best choice for 
very severe infections when high doses of penicillin 
are needed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For example, for gas gangrene or 
when a broken bone pokes through the skin, or 
meningitis.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Intermediate-acting penicillin: Procaine 
penicillin or procaine penicillin aluminum 
monostearate (PAM).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These work more slowly 
and last about a day in the body, so injections 
should be given once daily.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Procaine penicillin, 
or a combination of procaine and a short-acting 
penicillin, is the best choice for most infections 
when injectable penicillin is needed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Long-acting penicillin: Benzathine penicillin.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This penicillin goes into the blood slowly and lasts 
up to a month.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Its main use is in the treatment of 
strep throat and syphilis, and for prevention of 
rheumatic fever.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is useful when a person lives 
far away from someone who injects or cannot 
be counted upon to take penicillin by mouth.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For 
mild infections a single injection may be enough.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Benzathine penicillin often comes combined with 
faster-acting penicillins.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

MEDICINES FOR TUBERCULOSIS
In treating tuberculosis (TB), it is very important 
to always use 4 anti-tuberculosis medicines at 
the same time.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If only 1 medicine is used, the 
TB bacteria become resistant to it and make the 
disease harder to treat.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Tuberculosis must be treated for a long time, 
usually 6 months or longer.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The length of treatment 
depends on what combination of medicines is 
used.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The full, long-term treatment for TB is 
extremely important to keep tuberculosis from 
coming back again, infecting other people, and 
developing drug resistance.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Drug resistance means that the best and 
least expensive TB drugs no longer work against 
the disease.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
MDR (Multi-Drug Resistant) TB is 
expensive to treat, and XDR (eXtremely Drug 
Resistant) TB is almost impossible to cure.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Medicines for tuberculosis are available through 
government programs that test for TB and give 
medicine free or at low cost.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Experienced local advice is important, because 
treatments change, bacteria become resistant, and 
new medicines may become available.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, some 
programs give medicines only 3 times a week, in 
higher doses.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Isoniazid (INH) and rifampicin should 
always be used together in the treatment of TB.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Ethambutol and streptomycin are also often used 
to treat TB.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Taking pyrazinamide with INH and 
rifampicin can shorten the time of treatment.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If medicines cause itching, yellow skin and eyes 
(jaundice), or stomach pains, see a health worker 
about changing the dosage or medicines.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If blisters 
occur, stop taking medicines until you see a health 
worker.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Avoid alcohol when taking TB medicines, 
especially isoniazid.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Isoniazid can also be used to prevent TB from 
developing in family members of people sick with 
TB, or people with HIV.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Because it is common for 
people to have both HIV and TB, it is a good idea 
for everyone with one disease to be tested for the 
other.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

MEDICINES FOR LEPROSY
When treating leprosy, it is important to know 
which of the two main types of leprosy the person 
has.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If there are light-colored skin patches with 
loss of sensation but no lumps or thickened skin, 
then the person probably has paucibacillary–PB 
(tuberculoid) leprosy and only 2 medicines are 
required.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If there are lumps, then the person 
probably has multibacillary–MB (lepromatous) 
leprosy and 3 medicines must be used.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If possible, 
medicines for leprosy should be taken with the 
guidance of an experienced health worker or 
doctor, according to the national plan.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Treatment of leprosy must usually continue 
for at least 6 months and sometimes for life.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To 
prevent the bacteria (bacilli) that cause leprosy from 
becoming resistant, it is important to keep taking the 
medicines regularly, without interruption.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Be sure to 
get more medicine before your supply runs out.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Recommended treatment:
For PB leprosy take both of these for at least 6 
months:
Dapsone daily
Rifampicin each month
For MB leprosy take all of these for 1 year (12 
months):
Dapsone daily
Clofazimine daily and a larger dose each 
month
Rifampicin each month
Occasionally, a person may develop a serious 
problem called ‘lepra reaction’ while taking leprosy 
medicines.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
There may be lumpy and inflamed 
spots, fever, and swollen, tender nerves.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It may 
also cause joint pains, tender lymph nodes and 
testicles, swelling of the hands and feet, or red and 
painful eyes which may lead to loss of vision.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In case of a severe ‘lepra reaction’ (pain 
along the nerves, numbness or weakness, eye 
irritation, or painful testicles), it is usually best to 
keep taking the leprosy treatment, but to also take 
an anti-inflammatory medicine (cortico-steroid).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Seek experienced medical advice about this 
because the cortico-steroid can also cause serious 
problems.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

MEDICINES FOR MALARIA
There are many medicines that fight malaria.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Unfortunately, in many parts of the world, malaria 
parasites have become resistant to the best malaria 
medicines.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is especially true for the most 
serious type of malaria (falciparum malaria).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It is 
important to learn from health workers, local 
health centers, or the Health Department what 
medicines work best in your area.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
IMPORTANT: Malaria can quickly kill persons 
who have not developed immunity.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Children, and 
people who visit areas with malaria, must be treated 
immediately.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Medicines for malaria can be used in two ways:
1.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

that may be in the blood from doing harm.

common, especially to protect children who are 
weak or sick for other reasons.

mosquito bites.

FOR AMEBAS AND GIARDIA
In diarrhea or dysentery caused by amebas 
there are usually frequent stools with much mucus 
and sometimes blood.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Often there are gut cramps, 
but little or no fever.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

treated with metronidazole, if possible followed by 
diloxanide furoate.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In cases of amebic abscess, 
it is important to take both metronidazole and 
diloxanide furoate.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In order to kill all the amebas in the gut, very 
long (2 to 3 weeks) and expensive treatment is 
necessary.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It often makes more sense to stop giving 
medicines when the person has no more symptoms 
and then let the body defend itself against the few 
amebas that are left.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is especially true in areas 
where the chance of getting a new infection is high.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In diarrhea caused by giardia the stools are 
often yellow and frothy, but without blood or mucus.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

cheaper.

Cough is the body’s method for cleaning the 
air tubes that go to the lungs and preventing 
germs and mucus in these tubes from getting into 
the lungs.

text:
Because cough is part of the body’s 
defense, medicines that stop or calm cough 
sometimes do more harm than good.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

cough-calmers (or cough suppressants) should 
be used only for irritating, dry coughs that do not 
let a person sleep.

supposed to make it easier to cough up the mucus.

Antihistamines are medicines that affect the 
body in several ways:
1.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They help calm or prevent allergic reactions, 
such as itchy rashes or lumps on the skin, hives, 
‘hay fever’, and allergic shock.

text:
They help prevent or control motion sickness or 
vomiting.

text: They often cause sleepiness (sedation).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Avoid 
doing dangerous work, operating machines, or 
drinking alcohol when taking antihistamines.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Promethazine (Phenergan) and diphenhydramine 
(Benadryl) are strong antihistamines that cause a 
lot of sleepiness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Dimenhydrinate (Dramamine) is 
similar to diphenhydramine and is most used for 
motion sickness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
However, for vomiting due to other 
causes, promethazine often works better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Chlorpheniramine is a less expensive 
antihistamine and causes less sleepiness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For this 
reason, it is sometimes best to use chlorpheniramine 
to calm itching in the daytime.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Promethazine is 
useful at night because it encourages sleep at the 
same time that it calms the itching.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
There is no proof that the antihistamines do any 
good for the common cold.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They are often used more 
than they need to be.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: They should not be used much.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Antihistamines should not be used for asthma, 
because they make the mucus thicker and can 
make breathing more difficult.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
One antihistamine is all that is usually needed 
in a medical kit.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Promethazine is a good choice.

Because it is not always available, doses for other

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As a general rule, antihistamines are best 
given by mouth.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Injections should be used only

folic acid as well as iron.

leafy foods, meat, and liver, or by taking folic acid 
tablets.

FAMILY PLANNING METHODS
Oral contraceptives (birth control pills)
Information about the use, risks, and precautions 
for birth control pills can be found on pages 286 to 
289.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The following information is about choosing 
the right pill for individual women.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
(In January 2002, 
we changed the groups of birth control pills in this 
section.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If someone you are working with has an 
older version of the book, be careful not to confuse 
the different kinds of pills!)
Most birth control pills contain 2 hormones 
similar to those produced in a woman’s body to 
control her monthly bleeding.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These hormones 
are called estrogen and progesterone (progestin).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The pills come under many different brand names 
with different strengths and combinations for the 2 
hormones.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A few of the brand names are listed in 
the groups below.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Usually, brands that contain a smaller amount 
of both hormones are the safest and work best for 
most women.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These “low-dose” pills are found in 
Groups 1, 2, and 3.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Group 1 - Triphasic pills
These contain low amounts of both estrogen 
and progestin in a mix that changes throughout the 
month.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Since the amounts change, it is important to 
take the pills in order.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Common brand names:
	
Logynon	
Tricyclen	
Trinovum
	
Synophase	
Trinordiol	
Triquilar
	
Triphasil
Group 2 - Low dose pills
These contain low amounts of estrogen 
(35 micrograms of the estrogen “ethinyl estradiol” 
or 50 micrograms of the estrogen “mestranol”) and 
progestin in a mix that stays the same throughout 
the month.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Common brand names:
	
Brevicon 1+35	
Ovysmen 1/35
	
Noriday 1+50	
Neocon
	
Norinyl 1+35, 1+50	
Norimin
	
Ortho-Novum 1/35, 1/50	
Perle
Group 3 - Low dose pills
These pills are high in progestin and low in 
estrogen (30 or 35 micrograms of the estrogen 
“ethinyl estradiol”).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Common brand names:
	
Lo-Femenal
	
Lo-Ovral
	
Microgynon 30
	
Microvlar
	
Nordette
To assure effectiveness and minimize spotting 
(small amounts of bleeding at other times than your 
normal monthly bleeding), take the pill at the same 
time each day, especially with pills that have low 
amounts of hormones.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If spotting continues after 
3 or 4 months, try one of the brands in Group 3.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If there is still spotting after 3 months, try a brand 
from Group 4.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As a rule, women who take birth control pills 
have less heavy monthly bleeding.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This may be a 
good thing, especially for women who are anemic.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But if a woman misses her monthly bleeding for 
months or is disturbed by the very light monthly 
bleeding, she can change to a brand with more 
estrogen from Group 4.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For a woman who has very heavy monthly 
bleeding or whose breasts become painful before 
her monthly bleeding begins, a brand low in 
estrogen but high in progestin may be better.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These 
pills are found in Group 3.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Women who continue to have spotting or miss 
their monthly bleeding when using a brand from 
Group 3, or who became pregnant before while 
using another type of pill, can change to a pill that 
has a little more estrogen.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These “high dose” pills 
are found in Group 4.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Group 4 - High dose pills
These pills are higher in estrogen (50 micrograms 
of the estrogen “ethinyl estradiol”) and most are also 
higher in progestin.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Eugynon

Neogynon

text:
But these are very strong in estrogen and so 
are rarely recommended.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They are sometimes useful 
for women with severe acne.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Women who are disturbed by morning sickness 
or other side effects after 2 or 3 months of taking 
birth control pills, and women who have a higher 
risk for blood clots, should try a Triphasic birth 
control pill, low in both estrogen and progestin, from 
Group 1.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Women who are breastfeeding, or who should 
not use regular pills because of headaches or mild 
high blood pressure, may want to use a pill with only 
progestin.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These pills in Group 5 are also called 
“mini-pills.”
Group 5 - Progestin only pills
These pills, also known as “mini-pills,” contain 
only progestin.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These pills should be taken at the same time 
every day, even during the monthly bleeding.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Menstrual bleeding is often irregular.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
There is also 
an increased chance of pregnancy if even a single 
pill is forgotten.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Emergency family planning  
(emergency pills)
Emergency pills are special doses of certain birth 
control pills for a woman who has had unprotected 
sex and wants to avoid pregnancy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Using birth 
control pills this way is safe, even for many women 
who should not use pills all the time.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Dosage: Emergency pills must be taken within 5 days 
of unprotected sex.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The sooner you take the pills 
after unprotected sex, the more likely you will not get 
pregnant.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For emergency family planning, carefully 
follow these instructions:
Take 2 “high dose” birth control pills from GROUP 4 
within 5 days of unprotected sex, followed by 2 more 
GROUP 4 pills 12 hours later.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
OR
Take 4 “low dose” birth control pills from GROUP 2 or 
GROUP 3 within 5 days of unprotected sex, followed 
by 4 more GROUP 2 or GROUP 3 pills 12 hours later.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Take 25 progestin-only pills or “mini-pills” from 
the brand names marked in GROUP 5, that have 
0.03 mg.

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Some brand names 
include: Norlevo, Plan B, Postinor-2, Schering-PC-4 
and Tetragynon.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

With Postinor-2, for example, which 
contains only progestin, you take 1 pill within 5 days 
of unprotected sex, followed by 1 more pill 12 hours 
later.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Less than half of all women who use emergency

Intrauterine device (IUD)
Name:__________________ price:__________________
fee for putting it in:______________________________
An IUD must be inserted and removed by a 
trained health worker.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The most common side 
effect is heavier, longer and more painful monthly 
bleeding, but this usually stops after the first 3 
months.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Occasionally an IUD will slip out of place.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If this happens, it will not be effective in preventing 
pregnancy, so it is important for a woman with 
an IUD to learn to check it to make sure it is still 
in place.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Most IUDs have 2 thread-like strings 
attached which hang down into the vagina.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The 
woman should check the strings after each monthly 
bleeding to make sure the IUD is in place.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
To check 
the strings, she should wash her hands well and 
then reach as far as she can into the vagina with 
two fingers and feel for the IUD strings.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Do not pull 
on the strings.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If she cannot feel the strings, or if 
she can feel the hard part of the IUD, she needs to 
use a condom or another method of family planning 
until she can have the IUD checked by a trained 
health worker.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For information on IUDs, see  
page 290.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Pelvic inflammatory disease is the most serious 
problem that can result from having an IUD.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Most 
infections happen in the first 3 months, usually 
because the woman already had an infection when 
the IUD was put in.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Or it may happen because the 
health worker did not put in the IUD under clean 
conditions.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If a woman with an IUD has any signs 
of infection she should see a trained health worker 
right away.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

A woman using these injections may have

She will probably stop having monthly bleeding by

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Combined injections, such as Lunelle or 
Cyclofem, contain both estrogen and progestin.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These injections are good for women who want 
to have regular monthly bleeding.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Women who 
are breastfeeding or who have any of the health 
problems described on page 288 should not use 
combined injections.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Combined injections are given 
every month, are more expensive than progestin-
only injections, and are harder to find.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Women using either progestin-only or combined 
injections sometimes gain weight and get 
headaches, but these effects usually go away after 
the first few injections.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A woman can stop having 
family planning injections any time she wants.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But after she stops, it can take a year or more to 
become pregnant and  for her monthly bleeding to 
return to normal.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If she stops having injections and 
does not want to become pregnant right away, she 
must use another method of family planning.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Contraceptive implants
(Common brands: Jadelle, Implanon, Norplant)
Implants work by preventing the woman’s ovaries 
from releasing an egg.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The hormone also makes 
the mucus at the opening of the womb very thick, 
which helps stop the sperm from getting inside the 
womb.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Implants can be used by women who are 
breastfeeding, but should not be used by women 
who have any of the health problems described 
on page 288.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Jadelle has 2 tubes and prevents 
pregnancy for 5 years.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Implanon has 1 tube and 
prevents pregnancy for 3 years.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Norplant has 6 
tubes and prevents pregnancy for 5 to 7 years.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
During the first year, implants may cause irregular 
bleeding or more days of monthly bleeding.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A 
woman may stop having monthly bleeding, but 
this does not mean that she is pregnant or that 
something is wrong.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A woman may also gain weight 
or have headaches, but these changes usually go 
away as her body becomes accustomed to the 
hormone.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A woman can choose to have the implants 
removed at any time, but she must find a health 
worker who knows how to remove them safely.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
After 
removal, the woman can get pregnant right away, so 
she will need to use another family planning method 
if she does not want to become pregnant.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Taken daily 
as a combination of at least 3 medicines, this is 
called Antiretroviral Therapy, or ART.

HIV care and ART programs
As soon as you have a positive HIV test, try to 
find an HIV care program where health workers can 
see you regularly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They can help you start ART and 
manage any possible side effects.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Getting drugs 
from an ART program is more reliable and less 
costly than buying them from a private source.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
People who test positive for HIV and show signs 
that they are becoming unable to fight illnesses well 
(see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: 400) probably need ART.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A blood test called 
a CD4 cell count measures how well the body is 
able to fight illnesses.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If your CD4 count is below 
350, even if you feel healthy, talk to your health 
worker about starting ART.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Before starting ART, discuss with your health 
worker:
Have you ever taken any ART before?
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

medicine every day, at the same times of day.

hours.

drugs will no longer work for you or for others in 
your community.

that is part of an ART combination without finding 
out if your medicines should be stopped separately 
or all at once.

Side effects of ART
ART can have side effects.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some side effects 
decrease and go away completely with time.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Others appear only after you have taken a medicine 
for a long time.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some common side effects are 
bothersome but are not serious, such as diarrhea, 
tiredness, headaches, and stomach problems.

Talk 
to your health worker about how to handle these 
problems.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But keep taking all your medicines until 
your health worker tells you to change or stop.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Other side effects can be life-threatening, such 
as severe liver problems, severe tiredness with 
shortness of breath, skin allergies and rashes, 
tingling or burning in the hands and feet, and 
anemia.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If you have serious side effects, see a 
health worker right away.

ART for pregnant women with HIV
All pregnant women with a CD4 count of 350 
or less, or who are sick with AIDS, should start 
ART to improve their health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The mother’s ART will 
also help prevent HIV from spreading to her baby.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Pregnant women can take the same ART as other 
adults, except they cannot take EFV (efavirenz) in 
the first 3 months of pregnancy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Once a pregnant 
woman starts ART, she should continue for the rest 
of her life.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A woman who is already on ART when she 
becomes pregnant should continue taking it 
throughout her pregnancy, during the birth, while 
breastfeeding, and after.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If the mother is already on 
ART, her baby will still need to be treated at birth.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Preventing HIV in babies
ART medicines can be given to a pregnant 
woman with HIV and then to the baby after birth, 
even if the woman does not yet need ART for her 
own health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These medicines can prevent HIV 
from spreading to the baby during pregnancy and 
breastfeeding.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They are given for a limited period of 
time, not life-long like ART.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Giving medicines in this 
way is sometimes called prevention of mother-to-
child (or parent-to-child) transmission (PMTCT or 
PPTCT).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Medicines are only one part of preventing 
HIV in a baby.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Safer sex during pregnancy, safe 
birth practices, careful feeding of the baby, and 
treatment of illnesses in both mother and child are 
also important.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
See Where Women Have No Doctor 
for more information.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

HIV and AIDS
HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a very small germ, called a virus, that you 
cannot see without a microscope.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
AIDS (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) is 
an illness that develops later, after a person has been infected with HIV for some time.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: HIV is now found all around the world.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: HIV reduces the body’s ability to fight disease.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A person with HIV can get sick very 
easily—from illnesses such as diarrhea, pneumonia, tuberculosis (TB), and certain 
types of cancer.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Most people with AIDS die from diseases their bodies are no longer 
strong enough to fight.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
HIV spreads when an HIV-infected person’s blood, semen (sperm), breast milk, or 
fluid from the vagina enters the body of a person without HIV.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It can spread through:
Using an 
unsterilized 
needle or syringe 
(or any instrument 
that pierces or  
cuts the skin).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Pregnancy, birth or 
breastfeeding, which 
can pass HIV to a 
baby if the mother is 
infected.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

HIV is not spread through everyday contact such as shaking hands, hugging, 
kissing, or living, playing, sleeping, or eating together.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, it is not spread by food, 
water, insects, toilet seats, or communion cups.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Caring for someone with HIV or 
AIDS is safe if you follow the advice on p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
IMPORTANT: Someone who looks and feels completely healthy can have, and 
spread, HIV.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
It may take years after the virus enters the body for the first signs of 
illness to appear.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The only way to know for sure whether or not you have HIV is to 
get an HIV test.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: These tests are available at many health centers at low or no cost.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

if the blood has not

Signs of AIDS: 
A person has AIDS when the part of the body that fights disease, the immune 
system, gets so weak that it can no longer fight off infections.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The signs of AIDS are 
different in different people.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Often they are the typical signs of other common illnesses, 
but are more severe and last longer.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If a combination of these 3 signs appears and the person 
gets sick more and more often, he or she may have HIV (but 
you cannot be sure without an HIV test):
•	 Gradual weight loss.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Diarrhea for more than 1 month.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 A fever for more than 1 month, sometimes with chills or 
soaking night sweats.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

text: •	 Rashes or painless dark patches on the skin.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
•	 Warts or sores that keep growing and do not go away, 
especially around the genital area and buttocks.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: •	 Feels tired all the time.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Treatment:
There is still no medicine to cure HIV or AIDS.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But medicines called “antiretrovirals” 
can help people with HIV stay healthy and live longer.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Taken in combination, they are 
called Antiretroviral Therapy, or ART.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
ART is becoming less costly and more available in 
many countries.

In the long run, HIV can best be prevented by fighting 
for fairer social and economic conditions, so that people have stronger bodies from 
better nutrition, so that families do not need to separate to find work, and so that 
people need not sell their bodies for sex.

text:
Caring for someone with HIV or AIDS:
People with HIV or AIDS need comfort, kindness, 
and emotional support.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They may also need help 
getting enough to eat, or taking their medicines.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
If they have a lot of fever, diarrhea, or pain, they 
will need extra help staying clean.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This can usually 
be done without risk.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

remember:
♦ 	 Blood, open sores, bloody diarrhea, or bloody 
vomit can spread the virus.

touching these, wear rubber latex or plastic 
gloves, or plastic bags on your hands.

Wash 
your hands often.

should be handled with care.

hot soapy water, or add chlorine bleach.

Keep  
separate from other household laundry.

At some point, there is nothing more that can be done to treat a person with 
AIDS.

with AIDS.

This disease is found in Africa, India, and the Middle East, and in southern Mexico,

text:
POISONING FROM PESTICIDES
Pesticides are chemical poisons used to kill certain plants (herbicides), fungus 
(fungicides), insects (insecticides) or other animals (for example, rat poison).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In 
recent years, the increasing misuse of pesticides has become a big problem in many 
developing countries.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: These dangerous chemicals can cause severe health problems.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They can also damage the ‘balance of nature’, which in time can lead to smaller 
harvests.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Many pesticides are extremely dangerous.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Villagers often use 
them without knowing their risks, or how to protect themselves while 
using them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As a result, many persons become very ill, blind, sterile, 
paralyzed, or their children may have birth defects.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, working with 
these chemicals, or eating foods sprayed with them, 
sometimes causes cancer.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Chemicals used to kill insects and weeds at first allow 
farmers who can afford them to produce more crops.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But today, 
pesticide-treated crops often produce smaller harvests than 
crops produced without pesticides.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This happens because 
pesticides also kill the ‘good’ birds and insects that provide a 
natural control of pests and are beneficial to the soil.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, as 
the insects and weeds become resistant, greater quantities 
and more poisonous kinds of pesticides are needed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
So, once 
farmers begin to use these chemical poisons, they become 
dependent on them.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As farmers’ dependency on chemical pesticides and fertilizers goes up, so does 
the cost.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When the smaller, poorer farmers can no longer afford them, they are forced 
off the land.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As the land becomes owned by a few ‘giant’ farmers, and more and more 
people become landless, the number of malnourished and hungry people increases.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The risk of pesticide poisoning is high for these landless, poorly paid farm workers 
and their families.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Many live in open shacks at the edge of fields that are sprayed 
with pesticides.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: The poison can easily get into their homes or water supply.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This is 
especially dangerous for small children, who can be seriously harmed by even small 
amounts of these poisons.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Farmers who use backpack sprayers, which often leak, are 
also at high risk.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
See A Community Guide to Environmental Health, Chapter 14, for 
more information.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

the beneficial
animals—such as

source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Landless farm workers and 
their families, who live in

pesticide poisoning.

COMPLICATIONS FROM ABORTION
When a woman takes action to end a pregnancy before a baby is fully enough 
formed to survive, this is called an abortion.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
(In this book we use the word ‘abortion’ 
only when the action is planned.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The unplanned, natural loss of an unborn child we 
call a ‘miscarriage’.)
Deciding whether or not to have an abortion can be difficult.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In making a decision, 
most women will benefit from warm, respectful advice and friendly support.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When 
abortions are done under sterile conditions in a hospital or clinic by a trained medical 
worker, they are usually safe for the woman.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Abortions are safest when done in early 
pregnancy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But when abortions are done at home, by untrained persons, or in unclean 
conditions, they can be extremely dangerous.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In places where abortions are illegal 
or difficult to get, these ‘home’ abortions are often a major cause of death for women 
between the ages of 12 and 50.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Methods for ending a pregnancy such as putting sticks or other hard objects into 
the vagina or womb, squeezing the womb, or using modern drugs or plant medicines 
can cause severe bleeding, infection, and death.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

Danger signs following an abortion:
• fever
• pain in the belly
• heavy bleeding from the vagina
If you see these signs in a woman who may have been pregnant, they could be the

text:
DRUG ABUSE AND ADDICTION
The use of harmful, habit-forming drugs is a growing problem in the world today.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Although alcohol and tobacco are legal in most countries, both are habit-forming 
or ‘addictive’ drugs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
They contribute to the poor health and death of many millions of 
people each year.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Alcohol abuse causes enormous health, family, and social problems 
throughout the world.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Cigarette smoking has for many years been a major cause of 
death in rich countries.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
and is now becoming an even bigger cause of death in poor 
countries.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
As more people in the rich countries stop smoking, the tobacco companies 
have turned to the ‘Third World’ as their new and easiest market.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Health problems related to use of alcohol and tobacco are discussed on pages  
148 to 149.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In addition to alcohol and tobacco, many people in different parts of the world are 
using drugs that may be illegal.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
These vary from place to place, and include marijuana 
(weed, pot, grass, sin semilla, mota, hashish, ganja), opium (heroin, morphine, smack), 
methamphetamine (speed) and 
cocaine (crack, snow, rock).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
An increasing problem among 
poor children in cities is the sniffing 
of chemicals, especially glue, but 
sometimes paint thinner, shoe polish, 
gasoline, and cleaning fluid.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, some 
people misuse medicines—especially 
certain strong painkillers, stimulants, and 
‘appetite control’ drugs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Drugs can be swallowed, injected, 
smoked, chewed, or sniffed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Different 
drugs create different effects on the body and mind.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Cocaine or kolanuts may make 
a person feel energetic and happy, but some time later he will feel tired, irritable, and 
depressed.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some drugs, like alcohol, opium, morphine, and heroin, may at first make a 
person feel calm and relaxed, but later they may cause him to lose his inhibitions, self-
control, or even consciousness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Other drugs, such as marijuana, PCP, LSD, and peyote 
make a person imagine things that do not exist, or create dream-like fantasies.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
WARNING: Use of cigarettes, alcohol, or other drugs by pregnant 
women can harm their unborn child.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Also, injecting drugs using the 
same needle for more than one person spreads dangerous diseases.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: 172) and HIV and AIDS (p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
416
Where There Is No Doctor 2011
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
People usually start taking drugs 
to escape the hardships, forget the 
hunger, or calm the pain in their daily 
lives.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But once they start, they often 
become ‘hooked’ or addicted.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf
Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In order to get more 
drugs, they will often commit crimes, 
go hungry, or neglect their families.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Thus drug use becomes a problem for 
whole families and communities.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Some drugs such as cocaine and 
heroin are very addictive; a person 
may try the drug only once and feel 
that he needs to keep taking it.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Other 
drugs become addictive after longer 
periods of time.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Addiction is a dangerous trap that can lead to health problems 
or even death.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
But with determination, effort, and support, addictions can be 
overcome.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
When a person first gives up a drug he is addicted to, he will usually feel 
miserable and act strangely.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: This is called ‘withdrawal’.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The person may be extremely 
nervous, depressed, or angry.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: He may feel that he cannot live without the drug.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
With some drugs, such as heroin or cocaine, withdrawal may be so severe that 
the person can become violent and injure himself or others.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
He or she may need 
the help of a special clinic.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
For other kinds of drugs, such as alcohol, marijuana, 
tobacco, and chemical sniffing, medical care is usually not necessary, but the care 
and support of family and friends is very important.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Here are a few suggestions to help solve the problem of drug use and addiction:
♦ 	 Be as helpful and supportive as possible to someone trying to overcome drug 
use.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Remember that their difficult moods are because of their addiction, not 
because of you.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦ 	 Members of the community who have been addicted to drugs but have 
overcome the habit can form a ‘support group’ to help others trying to give up 
alcohol or drugs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Alcoholics Anonymous is one such organization (see p.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This group of recovering alcoholics has successfully helped people all over 
the world to deal with problems of addiction.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦ 	 Families, schools, and health workers can tell children about the dangers 
of cigarettes, alcohol, and drugs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Help children learn that there are other, 
healthier ways to ‘feel good’, to act ‘grown up’, or to rebel.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
♦ 	 Work to correct some of the problems in your community that may lead 
people to use drugs: hunger, exploitative working conditions, and lack of 
opportunities to lead a better life.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Help disadvantaged persons organize and 
stand up for their rights.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Actions that are supportive and kind work better
than those that are punishing and cruel.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Drug dependence can cause:
Self-neglect,
family problems,
aggression,
and violence.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Sugars   Sweet foods like honey, sugar, or fruit that 
give energy.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Suppository   A bullet-shaped tablet of medicine to 
put up the anus or vagina.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
*Suppressant  A medicine that helps to check, hold 
back, or stop something, such as a medicine to stop 
coughing (cough suppressant).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Suspension   A powder mixed in a liquid.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Suture   A stitch made with needle and thread to sew 
up an opening or wound.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Symptoms   The feelings or conditions a person 
reports about his sickness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
In this book symptoms 
are included with signs.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
T
Tablespoon   A measuring spoon that holds 
3 teaspoons or 15 ml.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Taboo   Something that is avoided, banned, or not 
allowed because of a cultural belief.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Teaspoon   A measuring spoon that holds 5 ml.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Three teaspoons equal 1 tablespoon.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Temperature   The degree of heat of a person’s 
body.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Tendons   Tough cords that join muscles to bones 
(distinct from ligaments, which join bones with bones 
at joints).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
*Thalassemia   A form of hereditary anemia seen 
only in certain countries.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A child may become very 
anemic by age 2, with a large liver and spleen.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Thermometer   An instrument used to measure a 
person’s body temperature.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Where There Is No Doctor 2011
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
428
Tick   A crawling insect-like animal that buries its 
head under the skin and sucks blood.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: *Topical   For the skin.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A topical medicine is to be put 
on the skin.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: *Toxemia   See Pre-eclampsia.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Tract   A system of body organs and parts that work 
together to do a special job; for example, the urinary 
tract cleans the blood and gets rid of urine.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Traditions   Practices, beliefs, or customs handed 
down from one generation to another by example or 
word of mouth.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Transmit   To pass on, transfer, or spread from one 
person to another.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Tropical   Having to do with the tropics or hot regions 
of the world.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Tumor   An abnormal mass of tissue without 
inflammation.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Some tumors are due to cancer.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
U
Ulcer   A break in the skin or mucus membrane; a 
chronic open sore of the skin, the surface of the eye, 
the stomach, or gut.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Umbilical cord   The cord that connects a baby from 
its navel to the placenta on the inside of its mother’s 
womb.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Umbilical hernia   A large, outward bulge of the 
navel caused by a loop of intestine that has pushed 
through the sac holding the guts.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Umbilicus   See Navel.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Unconsciousness   See Loss of consciousness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Under-Fives Program   A plan that helps mothers 
learn about their children’s health needs, make 
regular visits to a clinic for check-ups, and keep a 
record (Child Health Chart) of the growth of their 
children under five years old.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Urethra   Urinary tube or canal.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The tube that runs 
from the bladder to the hole a person urinates from.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Urinary tract   The system of organs that form and 
get rid of urine—such as kidneys, bladder, and 
urinary tube (urethra).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Urine   Liquid waste from the body; piss; pee.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
V
Vaccinations   See Immunization.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Vagina   The tube or canal that goes from the 
opening of the woman’s sex organs to the entrance of 
her womb.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Vaginal   Of or relating to the vagina.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Varicose veins   Abnormally swollen veins, often 
lumpy and winding, usually on the legs of older 
people, pregnant women, and women who have had 
a lot of children.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text: Vaseline   See Petroleum Jelly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Venereal disease   A disease spread by sexual 
contact.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Now called ‘sexually transmitted infection’ 
or ‘STI’.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Blood vessels are the veins and 
arteries that carry the blood through the body.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Virus   Germs smaller than bacteria, which cause 
some infectious (easily spread) diseases.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Vitamins   Protective foods that our bodies need to 
work properly.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Vomiting   Throwing up the contents out ot the 
stomach through the mouth.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
W
Welts   Lumps or ridges raised on the body, usually 
caused by a blow or an allergy (hives).
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Womb   The organ inside a woman’s belly where a 
baby is made.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
X
Xerophthalmia   Abnormal dryness of the eye due to 
lack of vitamin A.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
August Burns, Ronnie

medical information with an understanding of the ways poverty, 
discrimination, and cultural beliefs limit women’s health and access 
to care.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Clearly written and with over 1,000 drawings, this book is 
an essential resource for any woman who wants to improve her 
health, and for health workers who want more information about the 
problems that affect only women, or that affect women differently 
from men.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A Book for Midwives, by Susan Klein, Suellen Miller, and Fiona 
Thomson, completely revised in 2005, is for midwives, community 
health workers, and anyone concerned about the health of women 
and babies in pregnancy, birth and beyond.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
An invaluable tool for 
training as well as a practical reference, it covers helping pregnant 
women stay healthy, care during and after birth, handling obstetric 
complications, breastfeeding, and includes expanded information 
for women’s reproductive health care.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Other Books from Hesperian
Helping Health Workers Learn, by David Werner and Bill Bower, is an 
indispensable resource for anyone involved in teaching about health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This heavily illustrated book shows how to make health education fun 
and effective.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Includes activities for mothers and children; pointers for 
using theater, flannel-boards, and other techniques; and many ideas 
for producing low-cost teaching aids.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
Emphasizing a people-centered 
approach to health care, it presents strategies for effective community 
involvement through participatory education.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
A Health Handbook for Women with Disabilities, by Jane Maxwell, 
Julia Watts Belser, and Darlena David.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The social stigma of disability 
and inadequate care are often greater barriers to health than 
disabilities themselves.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
This groundbreaking handbook, full of useful 
advice and suggestions from women with disabilities worldwide, 
will help women with disabilities improve their general health, self-
esteem, and abilities to care for themselves and participate in their 
communities.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

for the teeth and gums, and prevent tooth and gum problems through 
hygiene, nutrition, and education.

information on using dental equipment, placing fillings, taking out 
teeth, and more.

children from birth through age 5 develop all their capabilities.

Disabled Village Children, by David Werner, contains a wealth of 
information about most common disabilities of children, including 
polio, cerebral palsy, juvenile arthritis, blindness, and deafness.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:
The author gives suggestions for simplified rehabilitation at the village 
level and explains how to make a variety of appropriate low-cost aids.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf

text:

text:
This beautifully illustrated book contains a wealth 
of information, motivational stories, simple how-to projects, and 
group activities to help people take charge of their community’s 
future and transform the crisis in environmental health.
source: Where there is no Doctor - David Werner.pdf
